webTitle: Leader: Holiday? Give us a break

fields.headline: Claus for concern
fields.standfirst: Holiday? Give us a break
fields.trailText: Holiday? Give us a break
fields.body:
Christmas? Frankly, we could do with the break to catch up on work, after a busy month of lunching and schmoozing.

We will not be alone. More and more people are working over the holiday and not just romantic emergency services and Samaritans fielding 500 desperate calls an hour, The Observer has learnt. According to one e-finance specialist, one in four 25- to 34-year-olds will arrange their lunch on Christmas Day to fit in with work they have taken home with them.

There is, after all, so much to do: reading essential emails ('Do you know Claire Swire?'); transferring Auntie Vi's £10 gift into a non-tax ISA via an internet banking service; faxing cousin Jim to ask him to stop off at Sainsbury's or Budgens (both have branches open) to pick up some plastic cups and a roll of tin foil; phoning one of Vodafone's 500 helpline workers on duty to find out how to send a 'url 84 xms din' text message; receiving the reply '): m str&ed in trfc!!' By the end of all this frantic e-activity, we'll be ready - GNER ('We have to control the number of people travelling') permitting - to get back to some real work - networking lunches and schmoozing New Year parties.

fields.headline: A step forward
fields.trailText: Why the assumption that non-parents must be hostile to the Government's parental leave proposals (Leader, last week)?
fields.body:
Why the assumption that non-parents must be hostile to the Government's parental leave proposals (Leader, last week)? Apart from the obvious benefits for children and parents, and the establishment of a principle on which non-parents might begin to negotiate equivalent benefits, the knee-jerk hostility of some dinosaurs at the CBI and IoD should be enough to persuade anyone that these are sound proposals indeed.
Root Cartwright
Chairman, British Organisation of Non-Parents
London WC1

fields.headline: The cost of Nice
fields.trailText: Blair returned from Nice having outwitted those wily continentals (News, last week). Now the euphoria has subsided, can we count the cost?
fields.body:
Blair returned from Nice having outwitted those wily continentals (News, last week). Now the euphoria has subsided, can we count the cost? Britain is still bottom of the league table for the minimum wage; still has the lowest social security benefits; still offers its elderly the meanest state pensions; still has the weakest employment rights. The widening gap between the rich and the poor to which Blair drew attention before the 1997 general election has widened further. Whose side is he on?
Leslie Moody
London SE3

fields.headline: The right note
fields.trailText: Nigella Lawson's confession that she can't sing (Comment, last week), has made me want to elevate her even beyond her current Goddess status. I couldn't agree more that 'singing is one of the few ordinary activities that can confer confidence and even happiness' but that 'today_ we are obsessed with expertise and professionalism'.
fields.body:
Nigella Lawson's confession that she can't sing (Comment, last week), has made me want to elevate her even beyond her current Goddess status. I couldn't agree more that 'singing is one of the few ordinary activities that can confer confidence and even happiness' but that 'today_ we are obsessed with expertise and professionalism'. Desperate to overcome the stigma of being made to mime in the primary school choir (aged 7), and wanting to realise if not my childhood fantasy of being a famous pop star, then at least a voice capable of holding a tune, I took singing lessons. My teacher on day one announced that 'anyone can learn to sing'. By the sixth lesson he wasn't so sure! Refusing to be daunted, I prefer to see that episode as my tutor's inability to teach rather than my inability to learn. Reading Nigella fuelled me with a determination to try again. My New Year's resolution will be to sing as if no one is listening, and be damned.
Mary McKeone
Manchester

fields.headline: Harassment lives
fields.trailText: If there was ever a case of life imitating art it is the harassment of Delroy Lindon. Martin Bright's article (News, last week) shows that we have not come far since the 1980s
fields.body:
If there was ever a case of life imitating art it is the harassment of Delroy Lindon. Martin Bright's article (News, last week) shows that we have not come far since the 1980s, when a Not the Nine O'Clock News sketch then had a dig at police racism by showing an inspector (Mel Smith) criticising a PC (Gryff Rees-Jones) for habitually arresting the same black suspect for such alleged crimes as 'walking on the cracks in the pavement', 'being in possession of an offensive wife' and 'wearing a loud shirt'. Will we still see articles like this in 2015?
Peter Bressington
Whitstable
Kent

fields.headline: Be a good citizen
fields.trailText: Teaching children citizenship is a 'good thing' - and not the same as teaching them the 'values' [of New Labour]
fields.body:
Teaching children citizenship is a 'good thing' - and not the same as teaching them the 'values' [of New Labour] - (News, last week). We should all know how and why taxes are raised and what they can pay for, and how and why the 200 richest people own more than 41 per cent of the world's population; and that there are alternatives which, as citizens, we can put forward to make our society fairer and healthier.
John Nicholson
Chief Executive, UK Public Health Association
Manchester

fields.headline: Net errors
fields.trailText: John Naughton reported that by 2005 the web will have 100 billion pages (Busi ness, 3 December). And, he says the concept of knowledge and erudition will simply mean 'knowing where to find the stuff'.
fields.body:
John Naughton reported that by 2005 the web will have 100 billion pages (Busi ness, 3 December). And, he says the concept of knowledge and erudition will simply mean 'knowing where to find the stuff'. Dr Johnson 225 years ago said knowledge is of two kinds: 'We know a subject ourselves or we know where we can find information upon it.'

Surely there is a more fundamental problem of knowing what is true and what is false? It is reported that 60 per cent of information on the internet is 'blatantly wrong'.
Ellis Thorpe
Inverurie
Aberdeenshire

fields.headline: Brock follies?
fields.trailText: Your article (News, last week) on the killing of badgers oversimplified a complex animal health problem. The badger culling trial is designed to find answers to vital scientific questions on the contribution that badgers make in spreading cattle TB and whether culling reduces it. It is not a badger eradication campaign.
fields.body:
Your article (News, last week) on the killing of badgers oversimplified a complex animal health problem. The badger culling trial is designed to find answers to vital scientific questions on the contribution that badgers make in spreading cattle TB and whether culling reduces it. It is not a badger eradication campaign. The Government has halted culling elsewhere in the country while the trial is in progress. As there is no reliable test for bovine TB in live badgers they need to be examined at post mortem. The trial will not affect the badger population, which exceeds 300,000, of which 50,000 die on our roads every year. An independent audit found the trial meets high welfare standards.
Baroness Hayman,
Minister of State, Maff
London SW1

The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food has been asked, several times, to publish post mortem results on badgers. I wrote to Maff after the first 187 got the chop last year, but Maff refuses to give the information. There is no doubt that if Maff had found bovine TB in even one badger there would have been a press release to justify the cost of the 'experiment', which continues the futility of 25 years of badger pogroms.
Syd Hambly
Manorbier
Pembrokeshire

fields.headline: No superstate
fields.trailText: Sometimes it is rather a relief when a newspaper states the obvious. In today's climate of myth-making and Europhobia, you were quite right to devote some column inches to explaining just why 'Europe will never be a superstate' (Focus, last week).
fields.body:
Sometimes it is rather a relief when a newspaper states the obvious. In today's climate of myth-making and Europhobia, you were quite right to devote some column inches to explaining just why 'Europe will never be a superstate' (Focus, last week). The Observer 's review of the Nice summit and the hysteria surrounding it was a breath of fresh air. As all sensible observers understand, there is no 'superstate' around the corner or anywhere else. Giuliano Amato, the Italian Prime Minister, said when speaking at Ditchly Park some years ago: 'We are not contemplating a European mega-sovereignty.' He went on to explain that we are creating 'a joint venture with a common voice, not a new-born federal state'. This is far removed from some of the headlines we have seen in recent weeks. I congratulate The Observer on a fair and factual analysis of the European reality.
Geoffrey Howe
House of Lords
London SW1

webTitle: Britain's endangered species run wild again

fields.headline: Britain's endangered species run wild again
fields.standfirst: Thanks to conservationists, they're back - the red kite, dormouse, natterjack toad, even the stinking hawk's beard
fields.trailText: Thanks to conservationists, they're back - the red kite, dormouse, natterjack toad, even the stinking hawk's beard
fields.body:
They were supposed to be lost for ever - a whole range of species wiped out by centuries of environmental destruction. But now many of the animals that were once part of our natural heritage are enjoying a remarkable new lease of life.

Dozens of mammals, birds, reptiles, insects and plants which were on the brink of extinction have made a dramatic comeback in the last few years. The cod and other fish in our seas may be threatened, but our woodlands, hedgerows, meadows and heathland are thriving.

The animals include many familiar species such as the natterjack toad, the otter, the dormouse, the red kite, the stag beetle, the pine marten, and the wild boar. The decline of these creatures has been halted, and they are either growing in number or spreading back to parts of the country where they had previously become extinct. More exotic species coming back from the brink include the stinking hawk's-beard, the depressed river mussel and the adder's-tongue spearwort.

Flushed with these successes, conservationists are planning to reintroduce many larger - and more controversial - animals that have been extinct in the UK for centuries, including the beaver, the lynx and even the wolf.

English Nature will publish figures in the new year showing that its 'species recovery programme', which now covers 315 near-extinct animals and plants, has been successful in halting the decline of 59 species for three years in a row. Other species, such as the wild boar, are doing rather well without any official help.

One of the most dramatic comebacks is the tiny dormouse, a star of Alice in Wonderland . Over the last hundred years, a loss of habitat and food supplies has meant it became extinct across half its former range. Conservationists started a captive breeding programme, and released them in selected locations in the wild in Cambridgeshire, Nottinghamshire, Warwickshire, Bedfordshire, Cheshire and, this year, Suffolk.

Dr Paul Bright, of Royal Holloway, University of London, who has been behind much of the programme, said: 'There's been considerable success. They have spread a lot further and faster than I would have thought. From the first introduction site near Huntingdon, the dormice have spread throughout a large wood, and are probably spreading out to surrounding woods.'

Comebacks include:

 The red kite, a bird of prey which was hunted to extinction in England by gamekeepers by 1900, has been reintroduced from Spain, to five sites. There are now 429 breeding pairs in the UK, with the biggest population in the Chilterns.

 The greater horseshoe bat, which measures more than a foot across, had declined to only about 4,000 animals. Farmers have been persuaded to adopt 'bat-friendly policies' and the population has been stabilised.

 The water vole - famous as Ratty from The Wind in the Willows - suffered a 90 per cent collapse in its population and was threatened with extinction. Better management of waterway vegetation has stemmed the decline in many areas, and some are now seeing a recovery.

 The pine marten - driven to the edge of extinction by gamekeepers at the end of the 19th century - has just been reintroduced in Galloway in Scotland, and there are plans to reintroduce it to five other sites in the south of England.

 The lady's slipper orchid was once reduced to a single flowering plant. Seedlings were grown at the Royal Botanical Gardens at Kew, and 200 plants have now been grown in the wild, and one of those flowered for the first time this year. Twelve former sites will be repopulated with the orchid by 2004.

 The stone curlew was once numerous in many areas of Britain, but by 1990 there were only 100 breeding pairs of the bird left. There are now 254 breeding pairs.

 The starfruit, a weird flowering plant dubbed a 'native triffid', was reduced to one pond in Surrey. An accidental discovery on how to propa gate it led to its dispersal to 70 sites.

 The 'large blue' butterfly became extinct in Britain in 1979, but it has now been reintroduced from Sweden to nine sites. A further 115 sites are planned.

 The natterjack toad, a victim of golf courses and housing, has been introduced to 10 new sites, and its population is growing.

 After escaping from captivity, there are thriving herds of wild boar in Kent, Dorset, Wiltshire and the Forest of Dean. They are now thought to number more than 1,000, and farmers - who accuse them of passing on diseases to domestic pigs - want to cull them.

As well as the captive breeding programmes, the animals are recovering because gamekeepers, who drove many of them to extinction, are themselves virtually extinct. Also, after hundreds of years of being raped and pillaged, Britain's natural habitats are finally growing again.

The area of woodland in Britain has doubled in the last 100 years from 5 per cent to 10 per cent, and is at its highest for about two centuries. Nor is all the new forest lifeless conifer plantations (about 20,000 hectares of new forest are created every year in the UK, most of it broad-leaf woodland). The amount of land protected as sites of special scientific interest has risen from about 4 million hectares in 1988, to 6 million now. Between 1990 and 1998, the loss of hedgerows has been halted, with as many being planted as uprooted, and the number of lowland ponds increased by 6 per cent. David Arnold-Forster, the chief executive of English Nature, which is behind much of the conservation work, told The Observer triumphantly: 'The success stories of species recovery give us all hope that those animals and plants driven to the edge of extinction can be brought back from the brink. We can secure the future of fine species like the red kite, lady's slipper orchid and dormouse so that future generations can enjoy them'.

Patrick Wilson, of the People's Trust for Endangered Species, said: 'The habitat conditions are improving and farmers and landowners are more sympathetic to conservation. Species reintroduction has been gathering momentum, fuelled by not-able successes such as the red kites. We're fairly positive about what's been happening so far.'

Next year the People's Trust is holding the first UK conference, not on how ani mals are becoming extinct, but how they can be reintroduced. Scottish Natural Heritage is planning to reintroduce the European Beaver, extinct from the UK for 400 years, to a location in Argyll within two years. The European beaver, larger than the North American one, has already been reintroduced to other European countries.

There are plans to help the relic population of 6,000 wild cats in Scotland, of which only about 1,000 are thought to be pure, and to reintroduce the lynx, extinct in the UK for centuries.

Some conservationists are advocating the reintroduction of wolves to Scotland, which now has more woodland than when they became extinct in the 18th century.

webTitle: Now men are officially the underdogs

fields.headline: Now men are officially the underdogs
fields.trailText: Downtrodden males are set to get a new champion. Plans are being drawn up to scrap Whitehall's Women's Unit and replace it with a new organisation that represents both males and females who are discriminated against because of their sex.
fields.body:
Downtrodden males are set to get a new champion. Plans are being drawn up to scrap Whitehall's Women's Unit and replace it with a new organisation that represents both males and females who are discriminated against because of their sex.

Among names being considered for the new body are the Citizens' Unit or the Equal Opportunities Unit.

The change of role for the Government's flagship of feminism follows a growing debate about how males are being left behind in certain areas.

But the plans to change direction, being drawn up by key Ministers and Number 10, have angered some women's groups who fear the policymaking unit's radicalism could be watered down after the election.

However, the two Women's Ministers, Baroness Jay and Tessa Jowell, argue that the 'new feminism' should be worried about inequalities affecting either sex.

The unit of civil servants has been the driving force behind policies on issues from child care and equal pay to domestic violence and teenage anorexia. It gives Whitehall back-up to Jay and Jowell: changing it would raise questions over whether their roles would survive.

Under the proposals for Labour's second term, the unit would still work on injustices against females, but would also examine why boys underperform in exams and are more likely to be expelled from school, or how to reduce persistent unemployment of men over the age of 50.

'The debate has moved on,' said a senior government source. 'Surely it is as important that boys are underachieving at school as it is that more teenage girls are taking up smoking, for example?'

The move - following the example of the Equal Opportunities Commission, which handles as many sex discrimination complaints from men as from women - provoked sharp criticism from some women's groups.

'The Women's Unit has done a really, really crucial job and the sad thing is it hasn't got the credit,' said Mary Ann Stephenson of the women's think tank the Fawcett Society.

'The reason we need a Women's Unit is because most policy is based around assumptions that are based on men's lives, from working patterns to relationships.

'I know people look at the Women's Unit and say "it's not fair, what about a Men's Unit", but the point is that without it we would have policy that didn't necessarily take account of women -women are poorer than men, they have less political power.'

Men's groups have long called for action to tackle the growing crisis of masculinity. Young men are twice as likely as the average person to be victims of violent crime - and teenage boys are three times as likely as any other group to commit it.

British men work the longest hours in Europe, and male life expectancy is five years less than women's.

The militant men's movement argues, however, that only an all-male unit could solve men's problems. 'This would be like putting the courts in the hands of the thieves,' said Robert Whiston of pressure group Mankind. 'I have never seen a woman in charge of a government department that has ever taken a balanced view of men.'

But Jack O'Sullivan of campaign group Fathers Direct said it could be a positive move. 'I don't think of men and boys as victims and this is not part of some kind of sex war. But when you look at how girls are doing much better now than boys in education, that demonstrates a gendered approach can be very successful for girls. It would probably pay off to take a similar approach to boys' education. There are also a lot of men who don't feel they get a fair deal from family courts. That must be addressed in a rational way.'

Jay has told the all-party equality group that Ministers must recognise discrimination in all forms. But one source close to her said she had not necessarily decided on the unit's future.

Plans are being drawn up to scrap Whitehall's Women's Unit and replace it with a new organisation that represents both males and females who are discriminated against because of their sex. fields.headline: In brief
fields.standfirst: Last three suspects in Damilola murder case released on bail
fields.trailText: Last three suspects in Damilola murder case released on bail
fields.body:
Three 15-year-olds who have been questioned in connection with the death of Damilola Taylor have been released on police bail, Scotland Yard said.

Magistrates had granted detectives extra time to hold the youths, who were among 11 children initially arrested on Thursday. The boys, aged 12 to 16, were arrested in dawn raids involving more than 200 police officers.

Six of the boys were released on bail to return to various London police stations in January. Another 14-year-old boy was also released, with no further action to be taken. A 13-year-old boy was also freed later.

All of the youths initially arrested are known to be associates who congregate together in Peckham, south London, where 10-year-old Damilola died on 27 November.

Sophie profits from publicity

RJH Public Relations, part-owned by Sophie Rhys-Jones, Countess of Wessex, reported a 50 per cent rise in pre-tax profit to almost £150,000 on turnover of £660,000.

Mouse trapped 20,000 times

The world's longest-running play, The Mousetrap by Agatha Christie, had its 20,000th performance at St Martin's Theatre, London. It opened in November 1952.

Bridge plunge witness plea

Police have appealed for people to help officers identify a man, seriously injured when he fell 80ft from North Bridge on to the roof of Waverley Station, Edinburgh.

Tributes to crash students

Floral tributes were left at the spot where two Nottingham Trent University students, a man and a woman, both 20, were killed by a car believed to have been travelling the wrong way up a one-way street.

Fellow students gathered at their union building nearby to express their shock. Ambulance crews were said to have been traumatised by what police called 'an extremely nasty accident'.

A man has been arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving.

Glasgow braced for shoplifting spree

Police are warning that shoplifting in Glasgow could double in the run-up to Christmas because of an on-going strike at the city's district court where than more than half the cases have been abandoned because of industrial action over pay.

Check-up for hunger-strike Moors murderer

Moors murderer Ian Brady, 62, was back in Ashworth Hospital, Merseyside, following 'routine medical tests' after he had been on hunger strike for more than a year.

Bridegroom mown down

Neil Harvey, 31, was critically ill after being run over as he was lying unconscious in the road following a fall as he walked home with his fiancée on the eve of their wedding near Honiton , Devon. They were returning from a pub when he slipped and was knocked unconscious before a car ran him over. The driver was questioned by police.

Star buy

Dr Who's bright yellow car, based on a 1956 Ford Anglia and used in the TV series in the Sixties, is expected to fetch £7,000 at auction at Sandown Park racecourse in Surrey this week.

Comedy Awards winners

James Nesbitt, above, of Cold Feet (ITV), was named best television comedy actor in the British Comedy Awards and Sue Johnston of The Royle Family (BBC1) the best actress.

Graham Norton (C4) was best entertainment personality, Rob Brydon ( Marion & Geoff , BBC) best newcomer, Sean Lock best stand-up and That Peter Kay Thing best new comedy.

Barrister picked for Mowlam seat

Vera Baird, 48, a criminal and civil liberties barrister, has been chosen as Labour candidate for Mo Mowlam's seat of Redcar at the next election.

Search for army student

Christopher Garrett, 16, who disappeared from the Army Foundation College in Harrogate, may be on his way home to the Isle of Man, say soldiers and police searching for him.

fields.headline: Wanted: Women's eggs for research
fields.standfirst: MPs will vote this week on embryo experiments which may lead to cures for Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease
fields.trailText: MPs will vote this week on embryo experiments which may lead to cures for Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease
fields.body:
Women will be asked to donate their eggs for 'humanitarian' medical research when Parliament gives the go-ahead for experiments on embryos this week.

Ministers foresee a surge of women volunteering to help those with incurable diseases, by providing the raw material to grow cells which may hold the key to cures.

The embryos created would initially be used for research. But eventually they could provide a human 'spare parts' kit, supplying stem cells, which are the building blocks for all specialised body cells. These could, theoretically, be grown into skin tissue for grafts, brain cells to replace those damaged by Alzheimer's or even organs for transplant. It could also provide treatments for Parkinson's disease, heart disease and leukaemia.

An alternative to a mass egg donation programme would be to grow eggs from follicles from the ovaries of aborted foetuses. However, it is expected that so many women will come forward this would not be necessary.

Professor Liam Donaldson, the Chief Medical Officer, said: 'Women are already being asked to donate eggs for infertile couples - but that's not the same as asking someone to donate an egg for someone dying of cancer. There would be a surge of humanitarian interest and many women would give eggs.'

MPs are expected to give the go-ahead to stem cell research in a vote in the Commons next Tuesday, despite impassioned objections from the Roman Catholic Church and pro-life groups.

Under present law, research on embryos is only allowed for developing fert-ility treatments. But Donald-son wants a partial lifting of the ban to enable research on serious diseases. Cloning to reproduce humans would remain banned.

However, Donaldson conceded that research could lead to pressure to allow cloning of human embryos for use in treatments.

Pro-life groups expect to lose the Commons vote and are now pinning their hopes on either the House of Lords, or taking the Government to judicial review.

Jack Scarisbrick, of the charity Life, said: 'We should tremble before creating human beings without parents. The implications are mindblowing. I am in favour of stem cell research and finding a cure for leukaemia - the question is where the stem cells come from.'

The advantage of harvesting stem cells from tiny clones of the sufferer is that they would be an exact biological match for the patient.

The procedure involves fusing a cell from the patient with a donated egg, and using an electrical stimulus to trick the egg into thinking it has been fertilised and growing.

The stem cells would be harvested at a week old and the embryo destroyed within 14 days. Eventually Donaldson hopes medicine will advance to harvest stem cells from adults, avoiding the need for embryos.

Until then, the key brake on progress will be the availability of egg donors, currently used in test-tube baby treatment to help infertile women. But research last year suggested a shortage of donors with around 9,000 women waiting.

Women donors need daily hormone injections for a month to stimulate their ovaries: the extraction of eggs is performed under general anaesthetic and is uncomfortable although not painful.

Some doctors want egg donors to be paid, as they are in the US, to encourage them. But fears of creating a trade in unborn babies has so far put off regulators. Donors get only a token amount for expenses.

webTitle: Revealed: why evil lurks in us all

fields.headline: Revealed: why evil lurks in us all
fields.standfirst: Study shows that crude loyalty to our social group and blind obedience make tyranny possible anywhere
fields.trailText: Study shows that crude loyalty to our social group and blind obedience make tyranny possible anywhere
fields.body:
Psychologists have struggled for decades to explain why ordinary people participate in atrocities such as the Nazi Holocaust or the Stalinist purges.

Now experiments carried out in Britain reveal that most people obey authority unquestioningly and would also walk past an injured stranger who did not come from their own ethnic or social group.

The findings will shake the long-held British belief that this country is immune from the kinds of tyranny found in other parts of the world.

Research carried out at Lancaster University on football supporters found that they failed consistently to come to the aid of an injured supporter from a rival team. Secret cameras filmed individual Manchester United fans as they ignored a Liverpool fan played by an actor while he writhed in pain on the floor. When the actor wore a Manchester United shirt, the supporters helped him in 80 per cent of cases. When he switched to a Liverpool shirt, all but a handful walked straight past. The results of the research will be revealed in a BBC programme, Five Steps to Tyranny , on the nature of evil to be presented by Sheena McDonald this week.

A separate experiment - again filmed with secret cameras - shows the majority of people on a train complying with a stranger's order to give up their seat. When the stranger is accompanied by a man in a uniform, not a single person chooses to disobey.

McDonald said she was shocked by what the experiments showed: 'The majority of people have a psychological tendency to obey and conform. All of us involved in the programme found ourselves looking at our own lives and examining whether we were beginning on the first step to tyranny.'

Dr Mark Levine, the psychologist who developed the football fan experiment, said: 'These are ordinary people. If you ask people whether they would help a stranger in distress, they say they would. But in reality they just don't do it. When we asked people afterwards why they didn't intervene, they said they didn't consider the pain as serious when they saw the person was wearing a Liverpool shirt.'

Colonel Bob Stewart, former commander of UN forces in Bosnia, said his experiences in the Balkans left him in no doubt that, given the right circumstances, similar human rights atrocities could be committed in Britain. 'What makes a man go for a drink with his neighbour one moment and shoot him the next? We still don't understand what causes normally good people to go over the edge. Until we do, there is the possibility that it will happen here.' The controversial programme argues that everyday prejudice can quickly develop into full-blown oppression and even genocide. The first step to tyranny, it suggests, is the creation of 'in' and 'out' groups based on irrational prejudice. The tabloid attacks on asylum-seekers are given as evidence that we are not immune to such blind hatred.

The new research draws on experiments such as the one in an Iowa school two decades ago when teacher Jane Elliott split her primary-school class into blue-eyed children, told they were superior, and brown-eyed children, told they were stupid and unattractive. Within hours the blue-eyed 'in group' were bullying their classmates.

The researchers demonstrated that little had changed since 1961, when Stanley Milgram, a young psychologist at Yale, discovered how easily ordinary citizens could become perpetrators of evil. Volunteers were taking part in an experiment to test people's ability to learn. They were then told to administer electric shocks to a stranger behind a screen when they failed to perform a simple task of memory, and gradually increase the severity if they continued to make mistakes. To Milgram's horror, two-thirds of the volunteers were ready to administer potentially lethal doses of electricity when encouraged to do so by a researcher in a white coat.

Professor Philip Zimbardo of Stanford University tells the programme that more crimes are committed in the name of obedience than disobedience: 'It is those who follow any authority blindly who are the real danger.' Zimbardo carried out a famous experiment in 1971 at Stanford University when volunteer students were split into guards and inmates in a makeshift underground jail. The experiment had to be abandoned after the guards began violently assaulting the inmates and several of the prisoners had breakdowns.

'It demonstrated the ease and speed with which things can get out of control. Within days the guards were behaving sadistically and the prisoners were acting pathologically.' But Zimbardo said there were some positive aspects: the research was used in Congressional inquiries into prison riots.

webTitle: Cricketing legend sets his sights on £800,000

fields.headline: Cricketing legend sets his sights on £800,000
fields.standfirst: John Paul Getty and Mick Jagger expected to make record bids for Trueman memorabilia
fields.trailText: John Paul Getty and Mick Jagger expected to make record bids for Trueman memorabilia
fields.body:
Frederick Sewards Trueman OBE is fond of a landmark. The first cricketer to take 250 Test wickets. The first to break the seemingly impossible 300-wicket barrier. And now, as his seventieth birthday looms, he is planning the richest auction of cricketing memorabilia ever.

The Trueman collection is to be auctioned during his birthday dinner at London's Grosvenor House Hotel on 6 February - both on the floor of the dining room and over the internet - and threatens to reach as much as £800,000.

The existing record stands at £296,000, raised in 1995 when Hal Cohen's cricket collection went under the hammer of Phillips auctioneers. Trueman, a national institution both as a player and for more than 20 years as a member of the BBC Test Match Special team, has decided his huge collection represents a security dilemma.

His secluded home close to Skipton, North Yorkshire, has been burgled once and the vast majority of his collection is now in a bank. He would rather see it distributed to collectors, apart from some keepsakes for his children and grandchildren.

'I've been told my complete collection could be worth up to £800,000. Most of it is going, although I am hanging on to some pieces,' he said. 'I never see most of the collection - we live in troubled times. I don't want my wife, Veronica, endangered when I'm not at home, and so most of it is already kept away from the house. What's the point of keeping it under lock and key? I've decided to let it go.'

Most interest is likely to be focused on the ball with which Trueman took his historic 300th Test wicket in 1964 against the Australians: Neil Hawke was the victim when Colin Cowdrey, who died earlier this month, took the catch at first slip.

Trueman, a former cricket columnist for the Sunday People who now contributes to The Observer , said: 'My old Sunday People editor said "Can you do it on Saturday? I want the 300th wicket", and luckily we batted first and so I managed to do it on the Saturday! The editor said he would buy me a case of champagne. A memorable game and this is the very ball that claimed that landmark wicket.'

There are also the balls with which he overtook Brian Statham as the world's leading Test wicket taker - with his 243rd wicket in the 1963 Christchurch Test against New Zealand - and took his 250th Test wicket in the same series.

There are numerous historic bats featuring the signatures of cricketing greats such as Sir Donald Bradman, Sir Leonard Hutton, Ray Lindwall, Neil Harvey, Brian Statham, Ian Botham, Sir Garfield Sobers, Trevor Bailey, Colin Cowdrey, Ted Dexter, Brian Close, Sir Richard Hadlee, Denis Compton, Geoffrey Boycott, the Bedser twins and many others.

Books, paintings, cricketing clothing and silverware are also included. So too are the boots Trueman was wearing at The Oval when he trapped Hawke to take that 300th wicket. Naturally, they are now signed by him.

This celebrated footwear was painted by the well-known Yorkshire artist John Blakey and 300 prints will be on offer, as will an original Blakey portrait of the cricketer depicting him some years after he finished playing the game.

Cricket attracts greater interest in memorabilia among collectors than almost any other sport. Trueman's close friend Sir John Paul Getty junior is a keen collector, although the reclusive philanthropist is in poor health . Perhaps he will be tempted by online bidding.

'He could be interested,' said Trueman. 'I will ensure Sir Paul and Lady Getty are invited. He is a lovely man and a good friend, but I don't know if he will be well enough to show any interest. As for Mick Jagger, we know he loves the game, but who knows? He will be invited to the dinner, I'm sure of that.'

Many of Trueman's old cricket chums will be there too, and invitations are likely to land on the doormats of cricket buff Sir Tim Rice, present and past Prime Ministers Tony Blair and John Major; former Labour sport spokesman Tom Pendry MP and other cricketing dignitaries.

Trueman has in the past campaigned for action to help old cricketers who hit hard times and ironically helped organise a fund-raising dinner at the same London hotel 12 years ago for his friend and England bowling partner Brian Statham, who died ear lier this year.

'The proceeds from the auction will be invested wisely for myself and my family,' he said. 'I have three grandsons and two granddaughters and another grandchild on the way. I remember the dinner we had for Brian and I am so so sad that neither he nor Colin Cowdrey will be with me for my night in February.'

The limited run of Blakey's '300-wicket boots' prints was due to be launched last week with Lord Cowdrey counter-signing them. Cowdrey, of course, was the man Trueman had to thank for catching out Hawke. Sadly, Cowdrey's death meant such matters were postponed.

'That was terribly sad,' said Trueman. 'But now Colin's son Chris has stepped in to carry out the auction in February at the Grosvenor House. It's very, very good of him.'

What am I bid?

LOT 1

The ball with which Trueman took his historic 300th Test wicket in 1964 against the Australians.

LOT 2

Historic bats featuring the signatures of cricketing greats including Sir Donald Bradman, Sir Leonard Hutton, Ian Botham and Ted Dexter.

LOT 3

The set of balls Trueman bowled when he overtook Brian Stratham as the world's leading Test wicket taker with his 243rd wicket in 1963.

LOT 4

Limited edition prints of the 'wicket boots' Trueman wore in one of his best matches.

LOT 5

Various books, paintings, items of clothing and silverware.

Most of it is going, although I am hanging on to some pieces,' he said. 'I never see most of the collection - we live in troubled times. I don't want my wife, Veronica, endangered when I'm not at home, and so most of it is already kept away from the house. What's the point of keeping it under lock and key? I've decided to let it go.' Most interest is likely to be focused on the ball with which Trueman took his historic 300th Test wicket in 1964 against the Australians: Neil Hawke was the victim when Colin Cowdrey, who died earlier this month, took the catch at first slip. Trueman, a former cricket columnist for the Sunday People who now contributes to The Observer , said: 'My old Sunday People editor said "Can you do it on Saturday? I want the 300th wicket", and luckily we batted first and so I managed to do it on the Saturday! The editor said he would buy me a case of champagne. A memorable game and this is the very ball that claimed that landmark wicket.' There are also the balls with which he overtook Brian Statham as the world's leading Test wicket taker - with his 243rd wicket in the 1963 Christchurch Test against New Zealand - and took his 250th Test wicket in the same series. There are numerous historic bats featuring the signatures of cricketing greats such as Sir Donald Bradman, Sir Leonard Hutton, Ray Lindwall, Neil Harvey, Brian Statham, Ian Botham, Sir Garfield Sobers, Trevor Bailey, Colin Cowdrey, Ted Dexter, Brian Close, Sir Richard Hadlee, Denis Compton, Geoffrey Boycott, the Bedser twins and many others. Books, paintings, cricketing clothing and silverware are also included. So too are the boots Trueman was wearing at The Oval when he trapped Hawke to take that 300th wicket. Naturally, they are now signed by him. This celebrated footwear was painted by the well-known Yorkshire artist John Blakey and 300 prints will be on offer, as will an original Blakey portrait of the cricketer depicting him some years after he finished playing the game. Cricket attracts greater interest in memorabilia among collectors than almost any other sport. Trueman's close friend Sir John Paul Getty junior is a keen collector, although the reclusive philanthropist is in poor health . Perhaps he will be tempted by online bidding. 'He could be interested,' said Trueman. 'I will ensure Sir Paul and Lady Getty are invited. He is a lovely man and a good friend, but I don't know if he will be well enough to show any interest. As for Mick Jagger, we know he loves the game, but who knows? He will be invited to the dinner, I'm sure of that.' Many of Trueman's old cricket chums will be there too, and invitations are likely to land on the doormats of cricket buff Sir Tim Rice, present and past Prime Ministers Tony Blair and John Major; former Labour sport spokesman Tom Pendry MP and other cricketing dignitaries. Trueman has in the past campaigned for action to help old cricketers who hit hard times and ironically helped organise a fund-raising dinner at the same London hotel 12 years ago for his friend and England bowling partner Brian Statham, who died ear lier this year. 'The proceeds from the auction will be invested wisely for myself and my family,' he said. 'I have three grandsons and two granddaughters and another grandchild on the way. I remember the dinner we had for Brian and I am so so sad that neither he nor Colin Cowdrey will be with me for my night in February.' The limited run of Blakey's '300-wicket boots' prints was due to be launched last week with Lord Cowdrey counter-signing them. Cowdrey, of course, was the man Trueman had to thank for catching out Hawke. Sadly, Cowdrey's death meant such matters were postponed. 'That was terribly sad,' said Trueman. 'But now Colin's son Chris has stepped in to carry out the auction in February at the Grosvenor House. It's very, very good of him.' What am I bid? LOT 1 The ball with which Trueman took his historic 300th Test wicket in 1964 against the Australians. LOT 2 Historic bats featuring the signatures of cricketing greats including Sir Donald Bradman, Sir Leonard Hutton, Ian Botham and Ted Dexter. LOT 3 The set of balls Trueman bowled when he overtook Brian Stratham as the world's leading Test wicket taker with his 243rd wicket in 1963. LOT 4 Limited edition prints of the 'wicket boots' Trueman wore in one of his best matches. LOT 5 Various books, paintings, items of clothing and silverware. bill.bradshaw@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Where lost kids find they have a future

fields.headline: Where lost kids find they have a future
fields.standfirst: Observer Christmas Appeal :  In the third week of our appeal,  Paul Harris looks at Kids Co, which helps deprived children in south London
fields.trailText: Suzanne knows exactly what Keeping Kids Company has meant to her young life.
fields.body:
Suzanne knows exactly what Keeping Kids Company has meant to her young life.

'This place makes me free. Without it I think I would be dead,' the quiet 15-year-old said as she picked at the chipped silver varnish on her fingernails.

She is not exaggerating. Suzanne's life has been an unrelenting litany of suffering as she grew up on one of Peckham's toughest estates amid the drugs and the violence that blight so many lives in this deprived area of south London.

Both her parents are heroin addicts, and by the age of 12 Suzanne had already dropped out of school to look after her three siblings, sometimes being forced to scavenge for food in bins. Her father is in jail and her mother is still on drugs. Suzanne lives in a care home but now knows what it means to have a future.

Kids Co provided her with education courses, people to talk to and a job. She works as a classroom assistant in a local primary school and wants to become a teacher. 'I love it here. I come every day,' she said. At first glance the row of converted railway arches tucked under a busy commuter line seem an unlikely beacon of hope. Though the murder of Damilola Taylor just a mile away threw a media spotlight on the area's problems, Kids Co had already been here for years, battling with the conditions that bred such an awful crime.

Employing 25 full-time staff, the centre, known locally as 'The Arches', sends teams into schools to provide support to troubled teenagers. It reaches 4,000 children, including 200 who visit. The centre provides hot meals, education, blankets or a listening ear for children and teenagers on the nearby estates.

Almost 90 per cent of those who come to The Arches have been involved in crime: robbery, drug dealing, rape. Instead of condemning, Kids Co workers look into the children's backgrounds for reasons for their behaviour. Many of those coming to the centre have suppressed their emotions. At first they come across as cold, ruthless and uncaring. But through projects run at The Arches, including seemingly trivial activities such as art classes, they begin to express themselves.

Kids Co was formed as a schools project in 1995 by psychotherapist Camila Batmanghelidjh. A year later she used her mortgage repayments to buy The Arches and convert it. Within days a group of about 100 youths, many carrying knives, began to destroy the place and abuse the staff. For Batmanghelidjh it was a pivotal moment.

'We were faced with these kids doing all these terrible things and I was horrified. But then I thought I can either give up or I can try and work with them,' she said.

She decided to stick it out. Enduring the barrage of insults and violence, Batmanghelidjh and her staff persevered and bit by bit Kids Co won the youths' respect.

'Eventually some of them would come up to us and ask us "Why don't you hit us back? Yesterday I called you all those names and you still talk to me today." They began to be impressed,' Batmanghelidjh said.

Once the children begin to discuss their experiences, Kids Co advises them away from the drug gangs and criminal activities on whose fringes they exist. And it works. Scores of children have abandoned crime after visiting The Arches. For Batmanghelidjh, it was fulfilment of a life's dream. A Belgian-Iranian refugee, she had always wanted to work with children.

Most of the stories that emerge from the slums and dilapidated tower blocks are horrific. Sex abuse is common, many of the girls are involved in prostitution while the boys get sucked into dealing drugs.

So popular is the charity that the children are now fiercely loyal. Only a few weeks ago a gunman, not connected to the charity, tried to enter the centre. His target was local youths there, but other children and staff disarmed him and he fled.

The police were called, but as officers questioned staff a note was handed into the centre. It was from local criminal youths and stated simply that the man had been caught and would be dealt with for threatening the charity. In short, he would be killed.

Batmanghelidjh wrote a frantic note back begging them not to hurt him and instead turn him over to the police - something unthinkable in London gang culture. But later that night the miraculous happened. The man was left at a police station. He was unharmed.

Kids Co gets no government support, relying instead on trusts and individuals for the £600,000 it needs a year to stay afloat.

But making it all worthwhile are the success stories.

Louise is 17 and dropped out of school three years ago. She got sucked into a world of violence but was introduced to Kids Co and has not looked back. Last year she sat five GCSEs, getting Bs and Cs, and is now training to be a legal secretary. Hers is a life rescued from the brink, saved by bottomless wells of patience for British children who the rest of the country had abandoned.

'Here you can ask the same question 28 times and they will give you 28 answers,' Louise said 'They always listen. They have time for me.'

Some names have been changed to protect identities

Our Other Appeals
Merlin

The Democratic Republic of Congo, site of what was dubbed 'Africa's First World War', is home to British charity Merlin and its fight against infant mortality. In a part of the world where four in 10 children die from complications at birth and poor diet, Merlin's health programme performs a valuable service. It is the sole operator in the war-torn eastern region, supplying 25 hospitals with medicines.

Changing Faces

Founded eight years ago, helps people like Michael Boateng, 12, left, who suffer from facial disfigurations. The charity, founded by the inspirational Dr James Partridge, organises counselling sessions for burns victims and those suffering from cleft lips and palates, helping them to adjust to daily life. The 13-strong charity helps more than 1,200 new cases a year - and its new website has provoked inquiries from across Europe.

Cheques can be sent to Merlin, Freepost LON 15423, London, SE1 1BT or you can make a credit card donation by calling 020 7378 4845 or by emailing fundraising@merlin.org.uk : Donations can be sent to Changing Faces, 1-2 Junction Mews London W2 1PN or by calling 020 7706 4232 www.changingfaces.co.uk

webTitle: I don't want to give you that

fields.headline: I don't want to give you that
fields.trailText:
Sports Personality of the Year BBC1
Trust Me C4
Mel B - The Players Club BBC2
Silent Witness BBC1
Cutting Edge C4
Friends C4
fields.body:
Sports Personality of the Year BBC1
Trust Me C4
Mel B - The Players Club BBC2
Silent Witness BBC1
Cutting Edge C4
Friends C4

Outside in the bush, the sun had set streakily over New South Wales's Monaro region, glittery Venus had risen, a flock of galahs had colonised the garden's biggest gum tree for the night and the dogs were having a post-prandial tussle on the veranda. Inside, as the jet-lag kicked in, I uncorked a nice South Australian Sauvignon and sat down, numb and fuggy, with my mother to watch the last edition in the first series of Australia's Who Wants To Be a Millionaire?

It's not as if there aren't better things to do on a balmy, early summer even-ing in the Aussie bush - a bracing 20-minute drive along dirt roads to the nearest pub, a blood-chilling confrontation with an arachnid as big as your hand (that came later in the evening, as it happens. And the next evening. And, indeed, the evening after that) or reciting the collected works of Banjo Patterson, for example - but my mother, like most other Australians, had recently been gripped by Millionaire fever so we stayed in and watched a nice young man called Miles from Canberra attempt to pay off his student debts by answering the Aus$16,000-question: what is the date of the Queen's real, as opposed to 'official', birthday?

This was, I thought, a pretty difficult question for a 22-year-old trying to win 16,000 bucks (and given the exchange rate, barely worth getting out of bed for over here) - and its inclusion probably proof that Australia isn't quite as close to becoming a republic as one might have hoped. Extraordinarily, however, Miles got it right. Later, he said he wanted to send his mum on a cruise, but he couldn't have travelled abroad recently or he would have known that he might just be able to afford to send her off with a packet of crisps and can of Coca-Cola for an afternoon on a Sydney Explorer ferry.

It's not - pout, stamp! - fair. You watch mind-altering amounts of TV for 46 weeks of the year before getting on a plane to the other side of the earth and then, at roughly the moment Miles decides the Queen's real birthday probably falls four days before Anzac Day ('and I think she'd moved it, so it wouldn't conflict', which sweetly parochial logic made me snort with laughter before it turned out to be correct), Britain was waking up to the news that it finally had a Millionaire winner. I found out a week later and felt cheated in much the same way I had after spending all day on a plane in May 1997 and arriving home to a different government (though, admittedly, I'd had a bit of warning).

There are now so few collective TV moments to be savoured that if you miss one of the really big ones - Diana's funeral, say, or an election or live action featuring Judy Finnegan's breasts - you feel slightly disenfranchised. But if you watch TV for a living, you feel like a complete fraud.

So this week, numb and fuggy with jet-lag again, I determined to miss as little as possible. Steve Redgrave winning Sports Personality of the Year ? Nasty Nick Bateman's debut as a quiz host (Trust Me)? Scary Spice throwing open the very many doors of her lovely manor house (Mel B - The Players Club)? Please prise open my eyelids and insert matchsticks: if Steve was going to blub, Nick turned out to be the new Anne Robinson and Scary revealed to be an authority on European monetary union - even if it meant looking like The Grinch , I was going to be there to witness it. But of course there were no surprises: Steve didn't cry, and (deplorably) also failed to thank the missus, Scary sounded uncannily like Fay Ripley's Jenny from Cold Feet and Nasty Nick was only slightly nastyish. And even the 'news' footage of William of Staines cleaning the loo and saying 'Big-Up!' just looked like the sensible first step in a career that, when the Guardian has got its way, will probably culminate in him hosting his own campy, late-night C4 chat show while Dad busies himself ruling Australia.

Under strictly monitored conditions - a living-room laboratory briefly sealed off from access to caffeine and cigarettes - I conducted a rigorous medical test: for how long could the jet-lagged viewer focus on Amanda Burton moving very, very slowly around a brace of very old, very dead bodies without succumbing to the come-hither wink of the Sandman? The result: 17 minutes. Having decided that this probably wasn't fair to Amanda, who was, after all, only doing her job, albeit so slowly that she appeared likely to catch rigor mortis, the following day I tried to watch Silent Witness again.

Nothing wrong with the plot - Andrew Sachs as a Holocaust survivor taking revenge on the Auschwitz doctor who had tortured him and killed his twin brother - but Burton's Professor Ryan is so devoid of character and emotions that her own autopsy would reveal only a small, slightly corroded tin heart attached to an Intel Pentium processor. She laughed and cried in this episode, but these moments were like the scenes in Toy Story when Buzz Lightyear tragically assumes he's a real astronaut. 'I think you'd better go,' said Professor Replicant, when one of her students turned up on her doorstep, inveigled his way in and - my word! - asked her out on a date, a question which plainly did not compute. I had visions of Ryan tossing and turning and short-circuiting herself to sleep that night: 'Go. Better. You'd. Think. I...'; 'I. You'd. Go. Better Think...'

The evil Nazi doctor was finally murdered by Andrew Sachs's nice Dr Horowitz in a pleasantly appointed riverside room at the Savoy ('He's lucky,' said Sachs, explaining his actions to Dr Ryan. 'Look at the view. That's the last thing he saw. My brother's view was not so beautiful...', jarring if only because the view in question was of Denys Lasdun's brutalist South Bank complex, not yet considered 'beautiful' even by architectural revisionists). Case solved, Professor Ryan reprogrammed herself as a human being and invited the stalking student out for a drink, though I fear he'd need to be very careful in the event of an exchange of bodily fluids.

Cutting Edge's Easy Money - a documentary about greedy netpreneurs and their dotcom start-ups - provided easy laughs. The Essex lads, for example, trying to set up a website as a virtual car showroom. Two of them were former money traders but, despite careers flogging other people's money, apparently hadn't learned that investing all of your own in the internet goldrush might just be tantamount to business suicide. Or very posh James and Ian, in Edinburgh, who definitely had the right idea with their online offie, having persuaded Dad and Dad's mates and their mates' dads to invest in a company which sometimes saw as many as 37 orders in a whole day.

But it was Julie from Manchester who, as opportunity knocked, chose to slam the door in its face while shouting 'ner-ner ner-ner-ner!' through the letterbox. During a meeting with hot net investors, Oxygen, whose backers include Matthew Freud, Julie outlined her idea for a portal aimed at secretaries and called, with a quite startling lack of vision, secretaryworld.com. Freud, one of Oxygen's backers, had suggested, via twentysomething multi-millionairess and Oxygen MD Emma, that Julie might like to change the name to money-penny.com but Julie looked deeply affronted. 'I'd be insulted,' she said. Bye Julie! Still, the others appear to be in business, after a fashion, despite the fact that it is, as yet, no great hardship to buy a car from a showroom, booze from a shop or, of course, that no British dotcom has yet managed to turn a profit.

Chandler, he of the double-chin, finally got around to proposing to Monica, the increasingly skeletal chef, during Friday's double dose of Friends. I am very fond of Friends, but even a mere three weeks away from them reveals they are turning into a bit of a freak show. All those flattering candles during the proposal scene? I think it's fair to say there is a subtext: hurry and set the date soon, Kidz! Preferably some time before Rachel and Phoebe are bitter, alcoholic liver-spotted and chugging HRT like café latte; before Ross gives up on ever meeting an adult woman larger than a size four and embarks on a sordid affair with a fat intern at the museum and definitely well before Joey is caught smearing Vaseline on the bathroom mirror and singing 'I Am What I Am' while steeling himself to leap out of the closet. Really, it's only a matter of time.

Still, the others appear to be in business, after a fashion, despite the fact that it is, as yet, no great hardship to buy a car from a showroom, booze from a shop or, of course, that no British dotcom has yet managed to turn a profit. Chandler, he of the double-chin, finally got around to proposing to Monica, the increasingly skeletal chef, during Friday's double dose of Friends. I am very fond of Friends, but even a mere three weeks away from them reveals they are turning into a bit of a freak show. All those flattering candles during the proposal scene? I think it's fair to say there is a subtext: hurry and set the date soon, Kidz! Preferably some time before Rachel and Phoebe are bitter, alcoholic liver-spotted and chugging HRT like café latte; before Ross gives up on ever meeting an adult woman larger than a size four and embarks on a sordid affair with a fat intern at the museum and definitely well before Joey is caught smearing Vaseline on the bathroom mirror and singing 'I Am What I Am' while steeling himself to leap out of the closet. Really, it's only a matter of time.

fields.headline: Blood, blood, glorious blood
fields.trailText:
Marc Quinn: Still Life White Cube2, London N1 until 6 January
Rodney Graham Lisson Gallery, London NW1 until 27 January
fields.body:
Marc Quinn: Still Life White Cube2, London N1 until 6 January
Rodney Graham Lisson Gallery, London NW1 until 27 January

The biggest thing in Marc Quinn 's new show is the least spectacular: a test tube containing a few inches of transparent fluid sealed with a rubber plug. The contents look like nothing. But they could hardly be more crucial. For this is a specimen of human DNA suspended in purest alcohol. The essence of being, so complex, so secret, so forceful, is here displayed as some invisible spirit in a tiny glass case: the genie in the bottle.

Self-Conscious is the title of this piece and the DNA was extracted from Quinn, who is, incidentally, a recovering alcoholic. But this is not a self-portrait, any more than his most famous work, Self, nine pints of the artist's own blood frozen into a cast of his head. The blood head was a tremendous thing to behold - a premature death mask made of the exact quantity of the substance needed to keep us alive. Made in 1993, it has changed as the years pass by, mutable as any mortal. Like the DNA in its fragile phial, it was both metaphor and raw material.

At 36, Quinn is the youngest and most intellectual of the Britart generation, a poet with whitecoat tendencies. He has used his own body many times as the basis for contemporary memento mori . These always depend on science for their strange half-life: liquid silicone to preserve his blood, 90-degree alcohol for the DNA, electricity to freeze an ice cast of his entire body - still gradually dissolving to this day. I have no idea how he made last year's poignant lead man, crushed to a shadow of his former self on the floor, but this imploded wraith was titled after Max Planck, founder of quantum theory.

At White Cube2, Quinn is showing casts of a fellow artist, Alison Lapper, who was born with no arms and attenuated legs. In one work, she is eight months' pregnant and smiling beatifically. In another, she sits upright with her baby son, Parys, nestling in her lap. I guess Quinn is just tempting you to be glad that he has all his toes and fingers.

But you will not be thinking any such thing, because mother and child are both equally perfect. These casts have been sent to Italy, where a team of stonemasons has reproduced them in flawless white marble. Alison is clearly elegant and beautiful in her own right. Translated into hard-won marble, she becomes a classical nude, a statue to make the armless Venus de Milo look incomplete. What is questioned here is not human beauty but the idealised values of art.

Quinn's purpose is abidingly moral and serious. But he gives the work a typically contemporary twist. These figures are too pristine, too artificial and uninflected to look precisely like antique sculptures. These are not nuanced portraits of Lapper and her son so much as facsimiles of their outer casing.

Around the sculptures are a great number of paintings that look exactly like photographs printed in high-saturation colours. These are souvenirs of Quinn's grandest enterprise so far: thousands of flowers planted in a tank of liquid silicone, a Garden of Eden for the Prada Foundation in Milan. This is not just any garden. Rhubarb, artichokes and asparagus spears grow in biblical profusion among the peonies and buttercups. The London gallery has a kind of offshoot, too; a single hybrid orchid rising from a fragile red vase. The vase is made from Quinn's blood and it looks as weird as the blossom itself - a costly genetic mutation that would normally have a dragonfly's life.

Life-in-death, these varieties cannot wither or age as long as the silicone remains at freezing point. I imagine the Milan installation is wondrous, its mirrored glass creating an infinite effect. But the pictures in this show are a warning against endless youth and beauty. You look, you admire the eternal spring in this artificial paradise. Very soon, your appetite sickens and wanes.

The Canadian artist Rodney Graham had a popular hit at the 1997 Venice Biennale with a video called Vexation Island . In this nine-minute loop, the artist appeared as a pirate shipwrecked on a desert island with only a parrot for company. The pirate would wake at the foot of a palm tree, gaze at the horizon and then return to unconsciousness as a falling coconut brained him.

In Graham's new video, character replaces coconut as destiny. City Self/Country Self is set in a medieval town. A bumpkin is wandering awestruck along cobbled streets. He will soon cross paths with the city dandy, who is having his boots shined. One of the boots will end up kicking the bumpkin in slow-mo, at which point, the loop resumes.

Needless to say, this costume drama is not what it seems, being a meditation on Freud, Sisyphus, Hollywood and, if Graham's notes are anything to go by, probably Deleuze and Roussel. You can decode it as a dense accretion of allusions to the intellectual history of the twentieth century. Or you can enjoy it as a breezy teaser, a few minutes of vaudeville from overseas.

fields.headline: Big top, small beer
fields.standfirst: Cirque du Soleil may pull them in, but its show lacks drama
fields.trailText: Quidam Cirque du Soleil, Battersea Power Station, London SW11
fields.body:
Quidam Cirque du Soleil, Battersea Power Station, London SW11

Montreal's Cirque du Soleil may have started out in 1984 as people's circus, drawing on the skills of street entertainers, but it's now a class act - with prices to match. For the past four years, the company has appeared in the Royal Albert Hall; this time, performances are in its own Big Top, le Grand Chapiteau. But instead of sawdust and soda pop, champagne is on offer at £45 a bottle (or £2 for a soft drink).

A tented village has pitched up until mid-February outside derelict Battersea Power Station. Cirque du Soleil has brought its own offices, canteen, physio suite and school room (the Chinese girl acrobats are only just in their teens). The long-term plan is that the power station could become a permanent base for the circus when the site is redeveloped. Given the sorry history of previous schemes for the site, nobody is predicting when that might be: guesstimates range from four to 10 years' time.

Cirque du Soleil has already spawned a number of offshoots. As well as its base in Montreal, it has permanent shows in Las Vegas and at Walt Disney World, Orlando. Battersea would become its first purpose-built home outside North America, with its own specially created show. Quidam, the production currently touring Europe, was launched four years ago and has since been seen by over 3.5 million people.

All the more surprising, therefore, that it seems a rather creaky show, with some acts going on for too long. The setting itself is spectacular, with an overarching bridge of girders spanning 120 feet. Aluminium rails convey acrobatic equipment and performers from a backstage platform to positions above the heads of the audience. A team of helpers in white boiler suits, looking like Woody Allen in his sperm outfit, removes spent performers and burst balloons.

Two narrative threads are supposed to hold the show together. One is the Latin title, Quidam ('whoever'), taken to mean a nameless passer-by, lost in the crowd. The troupe wear street-people outfits for their group numbers, with some costumed as eccentric outsiders. They stare blankly rather than beguilingly at us anonymous spectators. The second thread is that of a suburban family, with the little girl who dreams the whole thing, like Lewis Carroll's Alice.

She is seated with her parents in their 'petit salon' when she spots a curious Magritte man going by. He has an umbrella, a bowler hat and no face. He hands her the hat and the show proper begins. Her conventional parents are transported out of sight, reappearing occasionally to dress the set. The directors, Franco Dragone and Serge Roy, feel a superfluous need to animate the space with characters who have nothing to do with the breathtaking acts.

At first, these seem linked by a theme of childhood games. Four tiny Chinese acrobats do incredible tricks with diabolos; three French Canadians spin themselves through and around aerial hoops; most of the cast get involved in mass skipping routines, led by René Bibaud, who has the fastest feet beneath a rope since Muhammad Ali. But then come the speciality acts that have nothing to do with playground activities.

Isabelle Chassé dangles upside down, her seemingly nude body swathed in red silk banners. She twists herself into lascivious shapes, using the silk as fetters: she lets go, plummeting head-first, only to catch her ankle in the fabric in the nick of time. The eroticism is disturbing, since the red banners look like streams of blood.

A strongman and his pow erful partner, Richard Jecsmen and Carmita Lorador, turn an old-fashioned adagio act into a Butoh duet. They move as meditatively as Sankai Juku, while balancing each other at gravity-defying angles. The stage revolves around them, carrying bizarrely costumed figures, while they hold still in the centre.

A tattered grey team shuffles in for the finale, eerily like the soldiers in Gloria, the First World War ballet now at the Royal Opera House. They fling white-clad girls into the air, passing them around like batons among the group. 'Banquine' turns out to be a formation tumbling routine, with flying figures bouncing off hands and heads instead of trampolines. Benoit Jutras's dramatic score, played live, takes its timing from the performers, transforming acrobatics into music-theatre.

The French clowns are fairly funny, faintly cruel. No animals, of course, in cirque nouveau - though the Soleil team could always consider a training scheme for Battersea Dogs Home, within a sniff of the circus site.

fields.headline: A tenor and his Sopranos
fields.standfirst: Andrea Bocelli's blindness has not stopped him singing for Popes and presidents. He can make big money, but his family keep his feet on the ground, writes  Peter Conrad
fields.trailText: Andrea Bocelli's blindness has not stopped him singing for Popes and presidents. He can make big money, but his family keep his feet on the ground, writes  Peter Conrad
fields.body:
I never thought I would see an Italian tenor refuse food, but Andrea Bocelli patted an incipient pot belly and scoffed at the hunger pangs of his entourage. 'I must defend my image as a romantic hero,' he said, then guffawed at the absurdity of the idea. His mouth beamed, and his eyes, otherwise locked shut, briefly peeped open to reveal a milky, glaucous murk. Partially sighted from birth, he has been blind since 12, which means that - shaggy, shapeless inside his black Armani sweater, ill-co-ordinated - he is entirely without vanity. But despite these evident disadvantages, he has indeed become a romantic hero, like a Mills and Boon leading man with a virile supply of high Cs.

Discouraged from hoping for a musical career, Bocelli qualified as a lawyer by poring over texts in Braille. Until the age of 34, he sang above tinkling glasses and muttered chat-up lines in a piano bar. Then in 1992 Pavarotti heard a demo tape of a soupy ballad Bocelli had recorded, and urged the rock star Zucchero to take him on tour. His performances created pandemonium.

Once his disc Romanza, which includes a duet with Sarah Brightman, sold 15 million copies, Bocelli decided to risk an operatic debut. Last year he sang Massenet's Werther on stage in Detroit and advertised his bravado by cantering out on an Arab stallion. He has just released a recital of Verdi arias and a complete La Bohème. Next month he appears in Mascagni's L'Amico Fritz in Verona. He knows that what he calls 'my limitation' will restrict his stage performances. 'In opera it is a necessity to stand up and then lie down. That for me is a challenge. Let us see what will be the future.'

He is happier in concerts, where his stance is devoutly introverted - head bowed, hands clasped. 'I never know where to put the hands,' he said. 'I am shy.' His arms never flail to whip up an ovation; he remains touchingly alone with the music.

The image-makers have compensated for this immobility by moving him briskly around the world, booking him to sing at touristic venues such as the Statue of Liberty or the Eiffel Tower. Tenors are phallic fellows, so next year a Bocelli concert will mark the reopening of the Leaning Tower of Pisa.

His handlers describe Bocelli as 'a phenomenon', by which they mean he's a source of phenomenal profits. But he has also been turned into a secular saint. Coveting his aura, everyone now has designs on him. After we spoke in his hotel suite, he was spirited off to record some Christmas carols for a National Lottery telecast. When he sings for the Pope at Castelgandolfo, he rallies the Catholic faithful; when he sings for Bill Clinton in LA - having been flown in on a private jet sent by Steven Spielberg - he entices Democratic Party donors to write cheques.

Bocelli can't stop people making symbolic use of him, but he has no illusions about their motives. A while ago he was invited to sing at an Italian-American gathering in Washington, where Mohammed Ali (an honorary Italian, it appears) was being celebrated. Bocelli decided at the last minute to stay home in Tuscany and made his contribution by satellite, keeping an orchestra from Lucca up until 3am to accompany him.

He was equally underwhelmed by the experience of running a few feet with the Olympic torch in Sydney this summer. 'I will tell you the sincere truth. I was very close to the concert inside the Sydney Opera House, and I thought more of that than the torch. I am a singer, not an athlete.'

His handicap makes him pitiable but also admirable, because it estranges him from the rewards of his success and excludes him from the politicking of promoters and recording company executives; he is like a child star whose work enriches his managerial elders. He protects himself by trusting only his immediate family. He is accompanied everywhere by his beefy, pigtailed, younger brother Alberto, who doesn't sing but looks as if he might have auditioned for The Sopranos.

In his memoir, Bocelli coyly recalls an early affair with a local trollop, whom he calls (in homage to the earth-mother) Gaia. He wanted a Tosca, he says - 'a woman in love, jealous, faithful, morbidly attached'. Instead his girlfriend was a promiscuous, indifferent Carmen.

Which operatic character, I asked, did Bocelli himself resemble? 'In those days,' he said, 'I was perhaps the Duke of Mantua from Rigoletto, a libertine.'

Then, aged 30, he met his future wife, who was 17 at the time, in the piano bar where he played.

'Maybe she was Gilda then, when the Duke seduces her. But we are still together, we have two boys, and our lives are not like the opera.'

Anachronistically sweet and sentimental, Bocelli sometimes attributes his career to the intercession of a guardian angel. But he also possesses a forceful, almost vindictive will.

Like all tenors, he possesses a voice which is itself a triumph over physical inadequacy. 'The tenor voice is not natural. I often sing like a baritone when I am by myself. At first, I did not have the high notes. Now they are secure, but still I do not like them - they are thin. Every day I work with an American coach to reinforce the muscles of my larynx.'

Or is Bocelli himself an answered prayer? His may not be a great voice, but - combined with a modest manner and with the personal misery he sublimates when singing - it's one that, for millions of grateful auditors, signifies goodness.
