webTitle: When is an opera not an opera? When it's Verdi's Requiem

fields.headline: When is an opera not an opera? When it's Verdi's Requiem
fields.trailText:
Verdi Requiem ENO, Coliseum, London WC2
Anne Sofie von Otter Wigmore Hall Centenary Festival, London W1
The Trojans LSO, Barbican, London EC2/Radio 3
fields.body:
Verdi Requiem ENO, Coliseum, London WC2
Anne Sofie von Otter Wigmore Hall Centenary Festival, London W1
The Trojans LSO, Barbican, London EC2/Radio 3

Yet again, topsy-turvydom strikes in the world of London opera. At the Barbican, a spectacular epic receives a concert performance, while at the Coliseum (where else?), a requiem mass gets the full stage treatment. If you must stage a requiem in an opera house - and having discussed the elusive logic for that scheme at length a fortnight ago, I'll save you a recapitulation - Verdi's isn't a bad choice.

His 1874 version of the Roman Mass for the Dead has four soloists with prominent and contrasting individual parts. It has sometimes been described as his greatest opera. Giulini, who conducted numerous and notable performances until about a decade ago, used to sternly warn his singers that 'dramatic this is; an opera it is not'. Nevertheless, it certainly has the kind of scale, grandeur and terror that you expect to find in the theatre rather than the concert hall. The apocalyptic 'Dies irae' stares as deeply into the abyss as is humanly possible. All the piece lacks is a narrative.

Still, English National Opera's decision to act it out on stage remains puzzling. That it was nothing like as gruesome as it threatened is a tribute to Phyllida Lloyd, the producer. Whether it was successful or not is hard to say. The evident enthusiasm of the audience must count for something. Lloyd mixes abstract movement with representational ideas. In the pianissimo opening, a congregation dressed in motley sobriety sits as if in mournful prayer.

Once the 'Dies irae' explodes into action, they shelter behind chairs as if experiencing an earthquake or ungodly tempest. Lights flash, trumpets sound, they rush to the front of the stage, then back, gesturing in choreographed grief. In the 'Offertorio' they place precious belongings at the front of the stage.

These short, self-contained episodes lent themselves to free interpretation and did not unduly obscure the music. Matters deteriorated when children rushed about the stage in the dazzlingly spirited double fugue of the 'Sanctus', followed by a mimed life cycle of a woman from pregnancy through childhood to old age. Suddenly, the sense of exploring the work through suggestion strayed into the murkier waters of circumstantial illustration.

At the end, out of total blackout, you hear the sound of a woman's voice sobbing hysterically as she struggles to find solace and light. This unredemptive interpretation, involving sounds uncalled for in the score, seemed to miss the point of the Requiem , which surely offers consolation and renewal. Verdi's music seems to say as much.

The stars were the ENO chorus who had committed this intricate score to memory. The urgency of their cry of deliverance, 'Libera me', made you draw breath. The soloists were uneven. The young soprano Claire Weston, a member of ENO's Jerwood Young Singers Programme, tackled her part heroically though she didn't always sound secure. Susan Parry took the mezzo part with customary skill and integrity. The tenor Rafael Rojas and bass David Pittsinger, both making their ENO debuts, were less convincing and had some decidedly off moments. Ensemble and tuning were ragged, but the performance, conducted by Paul Daniel, was heartfelt and vivid. No one can object to hearing such a formidable piece of music. Let the matter rest there (Requiescat).

The Swedish mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie von Otter, singing an all-Sibelius programme, created her own compressed dramatic monologues at the opening of the Wigmore Hall's centenary season. She had teamed up with the violinist Nils-Erik Sparf and pianist Bengt Forsberg to alternate Sibelius's songs with some of his violin duo music.

These short salon pieces are all too rarely heard. Their urbanity and grace offset the intensity of the songs, compact in scale yet full of pent-up energy and emotion. Von Otter bewitched her audience with each new mood and subtle range of inflections, whether in the uneasy supernatural gloom of 'Beneath the Fir Trees' or in the exuberance of 'Song of Spring'.

Musical drama on a colossal scale, intended for the theatre but hardly ever seen there, was found on stage at the Barbican in the London Symphony Orchestra's performances of The Trojans. This mammoth work, one of the greatest of all French operas, completed the orchestra's triumphant year-long Berlioz cycle. A fine line-up of soloists, led by Ben Heppner, Michelle de Young and Petra Lang, brought Berlioz's unwieldy account of the fall of Troy and the founding of Rome to exhilarating life. Colin Davis, who has conducted the series, has almost singlehandedly salvaged Berlioz from the white-elephant stall (helped by David Cairns's masterly biography) and restored him to the ranks of great composers. The LSO blazed with fervour and virtuosity.

Berlioz knew that his great masterpiece would be misunderstood, that Parisians would find it 'flat and dull'. With performances such as this, we begin at last to apprehend its genius. An LSO live recording is due out, but not until July, so we'll have to be patient. Mendelssohn regarded Berlioz as 'a freak, without a vestige of talent'. It is hard to think of a work by Mendelssohn, his mercurial and prodigious gifts notwithstanding, which could exert the same visceral power as that achieved by The Trojans. But perhaps his moment and his Sir Colin Davis are yet to come.

fields.headline: The Barrier method
fields.standfirst: The Thames Barrier Park, London's largest new riverside park in a 100 years, harks back to the capital's greatest open spaces
fields.trailText: The Thames Barrier Park, London's largest new riverside park in a 100 years, harks back to the capital's greatest open spaces
fields.body:
Remember when the Reichmann brothers had just discovered Canary Wharf and it still seemed almost as far east of London as Siberia? Well, drive out past the sprouting towers of the now almost complete development, past the Dome, past the new exhibition centre and out to the Thames Barrier and you are in a place that makes Canary Wharf, even as it was 15 years ago, look impossibly metropolitan.

On a cold December day, under a grey sky, the endless mud-brown river stretches apparently to the horizon. Everything is big here: the sky, the river, the bleak landscape.

Technically, you are still in Newham, a borough whose name suggests the reassuring presence of bricks-and-mortar streets, real places and a sense of permanence. And yet this particular slice of it hardly seems like a city at all. It feels as if you have ducked under the perimeter wire of an airport. In the far distance, you can see the lights of the terminal buildings, but out on the edge you are in an aviation-fuel soaked environment where nothing is on a human scale. You feel as if you have to cling on to something to avoid the dizzy, disorientating emptiness.

And that is what the newly opened Thames Barrier Park is designed to do. You can sit down and not feel overwhelmed in a setting that seems to make sense of its strange surroundings. It stands out from the scrapyards and container parks across the river with their derelict piers sprouting weeds and rusted reinforcing steel.

It has a shape that comes from planning, not expediency. And it has already had an impressively urbanising influence on its surroundings. One edge of the park is now defined by the first of a series of new housing developments planned for the area. Even before you get close, you can see that every detail has been carefully worked on, from the skimpy structure that looks out over the river to the glass pavilion in the centre of a vivid splash of green; this is a place where people have worried about the human scale.

The twentieth century did not see London exactly covering itself in glory with its parks. Indeed, it seems that we have almost forgotten how to make them. The very word has been hijacked by the builders of giant tin sheds who call industrial estates business parks and cash-and-carry warehouses retail parks.

The great old parks were based on the aristocratic landscape tradition of the eighteenth century. The twentieth-century contribution to London parks was limited to an epidemic of municipal gardening, characterised by floral clocks and lurid planting.

The team which designed the Thames Barrier Park, including the architects Patel Taylor and French landscape architects Group Signes, knew that they couldn't rely on just being pretty. While they haven't gone as far as some of the more surreal directions taken by contemporary landscape designers, such as dyeing plants purple or creating abstract patterns with manmade materials, this £12.5 million project is clearly a park of its time and it is as much a three-dimensional architectural and planning composition as it is a piece of landscape.

The first step was to make the ground safe, because the land around the barrier was so polluted with everything from tar to arsenic that it was literally worthless. That meant dumping a metre of concrete, and a major remodelling of the site contours. 'Because the land sloped up toward the river, you couldn't actually see it from most of the site,' says architect Andrew Taylor. 'We suggested cutting a deep trench across the park that provided the fill to level the land, and make the river much more visible.'

But the cut also left behind a deep court, its shape deliberately sculpted to suggest a dock, and it provides one of the series of distinct spatial experiences which characterise and give shape to the site.

In urban terms, parks could be seen as the last refuge of the desperate. Before it was abolished, the Greater London Council went so far as debating turfing over the whole of Docklands to create a giant park, so convinced were members that there would never be the money to replace the derelict acres of docks, nor the people to fill them, even if they were rebuilt.

In other places, politicians, faced with no-hope council housing that has been built and rebuilt two or three times, often have a knee-jerk response. 'Let us,' they say, 'do something once and for all, let's turn it all into a park.' However, Jane Jacobs, author of Life and Death of Great American Cities , would argue that parks are not necessarily havens of sweetness and light, but in some circumstances can be much more dangerous and damaging to a neighbourhood than the meanest of mean streets.

Nevertheless the park does have a crucial role in the development of the city. More than anything else, parks are what have given London its distinctiveness and they have created its social geography. Build the right park and people want to live next to it is a strategy that has shaped so many cities around the world. And it is in that spirit that the Thames Barrier Park, London's largest new riverside park for 100 years was created. Six years ago nobody lived within walking distance; now the population is around 6,000 and growing.

webTitle: If you wore Marilyn's dress, would you feel like a million dollars?

fields.headline: If you wore Marilyn's dress, would you feel like a million dollars?
fields.trailText: The sole of the right ballet shoe has the words 'The Sleeping Beauty' inscribed on it. The pair in which Margot Fonteyn danced in 1946 fetched £10,925. Going, going, gone. The Sleeping Beauty is dead but her ballet shoes live on. So does her pink silk tutu embroidered in gold and her black tutu in which she danced, for the first time, with Nureyev in  Swan Lake and the grey silk Dior wedding dress in which she married Dr Roberto Arias in 1956 - all these have survived and were sold at Christie's last week in a sale that raised £650,000, six times the forecast total.
fields.body:
The sole of the right ballet shoe has the words 'The Sleeping Beauty' inscribed on it. The pair in which Margot Fonteyn danced in 1946 fetched £10,925. Going, going, gone. The Sleeping Beauty is dead but her ballet shoes live on. So does her pink silk tutu embroidered in gold and her black tutu in which she danced, for the first time, with Nureyev in Swan Lake and the grey silk Dior wedding dress in which she married Dr Roberto Arias in 1956 - all these have survived and were sold at Christie's last week in a sale that raised £650,000, six times the forecast total.

Museum buyers were out in force - and British ballet enthusiasts raised £18,000 to keep the costumes in Britain. But it was Fonteyn's personal effects that made hearts race - and private collectors were outbidding each other to possess two Yves St Laurent dresses - one sold for £17,625, the other for a sensational £91,750.

Why do people buy the cast-off clothes of the famous? Is it the wish, in a metaphorical sense at least, to 'try on' celebrity? It is not just Fonteyn's personal effects that have come under the hammer. The wardrobe door never seems to close: Moira Shearer's red shoes (that she wore in the 1948 film), Elton John's Versace waistcoats, Geri Halliwell's Union Jack dress (£41,320), Leo di Caprio's prison outfit from The Man in the Iron Mask (estimated at £6,000), Keith Richards's pirate-style shirt from the Sixties (£800), Ginger Spice's boots (£5,000) and even Britney Spears's silver shoes (bargain basement at £500). And Marilyn Monroe's flesh-coloured dress, covered in 6,000 rhinestone beads (pictured left) - the one she had to be sewn into before meeting President Kennedy - fetched £760,000, just under a million dollars.

Second-hand clothes are haunted. Even when they do not belong to celebrities, they are discomfitingly intimate: a sleeve printed by a particular elbow, trousers punished by particular knees. Second-hand clothes are melancholy, too. I've patronised several shops with defeated names such as Last Chance and Change of a Dress. They tend to be dark, filled with rows of granny dresses like pressed flowers. The smell of dry cleaning cannot quite banish years of sweat. But trousers and jackets hang on in there. And second-hand shoes stay faithful to first feet. Virginia Woolf knew that shoes were especially charged with character (Jacob's Room and To the Lighthouse both testify to this) - and with melancholy.

This melancholy applies just as strongly to the clothes of celebrities - but its impact could not be more different. While those who buy from thrift shops would prefer not to dwell on the unsavoury thought of the past owners of their clothes, those who buy celebrity cast-offs think of nothing else; the melancholy is personal. This is vicarious nostalgia, souvenirs of a life the purchaser has not experienced. And even when the original owner is still alive and kicking - the clothes (take Mick Jagger's kelim waistcoat from the Sixties) will be evidence of a time that has gone. Diana's inky blue dress sold for £134,000 a few months before she died, but it would have fetched even more if it had been sold after her death. It would have become a holy relic.

There is, too, the wish for intimacy with an idol, a skin-to-skin closeness through cloth. Marilyn Monroe was said to look especially beautiful in the rhinestone dress - might that mean that some of her beauty rubbed off on it? Did she leave some of her star quality behind to shimmer between the rhinestones?

fields.headline: Born here, made over there
fields.standfirst: You may never have heard of her, but she's one of the most successful British artists in America, touring with rap giant Eminem and selling a million albums. Now Dido is coming home, writes  Sheryl Garratt
fields.trailText: You may never have heard of her, but she's one of the most successful British artists in America, touring with rap giant Eminem and selling a million albums. Now Dido is coming home, writes  Sheryl Garratt
fields.body:
Boys put his picture on their walls and worship everything he does, but feminists feel that he reinforces all the old gender stereotypes. Last Sunday, a nation held its breath as we waited to see if his crass, exploitative record would get to number one. But in the event, the atrocious Bob the Builder was beaten into second place by Eminem's gloriously inventive 'Stan'. The best record won, despite a Sun campaign against it. And if it stays there today, it will be the least seasonal Christmas number one for years.

'Stan' is a dialogue between two characters: the first the kind of obsessive, angry and increasingly deranged fan that damaged Detroit youth Marshall Mathers might have become had he not found success as a rapper; and Eminem, Mathers's more famous alter ego. It ends bleakly, with the fan locking his pregnant girlfriend in the trunk of his car and driving both of them over a bridge, but the whole thing is given an eerie sweetness by a recurring female voice apparently singing a love song to a picture on the wall. The voice belongs to Dido, a 28-year-old Arsenal fan from north London who is virtually unknown at home, but is taking America by storm. Her album No Angel has gone platinum there, selling more than a million copies (she's one of the few British artists in the US charts, with only Sade, Sting and Radiohead for company). And all because of a sample on a rap record.

It's a lovely story, but of course the reality is more complicated. Overnight success never really happens overnight. For Dido Armstrong, it took six long years. In Britain, it's her older brother Rollo who is famous, a dance-music producer who put together Faithless, one of the groups which finally established that dance music could sell albums by the million.

Dido was the musical one at home, taking weekend classes at Guildhall School of Music, but when she announced that she wanted to be a singer, Rollo advised her to forget it. By then she had a job working in a literary agent's office, and in the evenings she was studying for a law degree at Birkbeck. It all seemed too much to give up, and Rollo was convinced that luck couldn't strike the same family twice.

None the less, Dido would often turn up uninvited at his studio while he was working on Faithless, particularly when there were vocals to be recorded. She eventually she got to sing on two tracks. When Faithless began to tour, she gave up the day job and went with them, but continued to work on her own music. In October 1996, she got a publishing deal with Warner-Chappell and left to strike out on her own. By the end of 1997, Rollo says proudly, 'she could have signed to almost any record label'. She chose Arista for America, but in Europe she signed via her brother's independent label Cheeky.

No Angel is not a dance record, even though Dido co-produced it with Rollo, some of the Faithless collective and an assortment of other luminaries from the London club scene. Based around well-crafted songs with intelligent lyrics, it prompted a Washington Post critic to describe its bittersweet, sensual sound as 'makeout music for moderns'. It came out in the US in June 1999. It was supposed to be released here at around the same time, but by then Rollo had begun negotiations to sell his label to BMG/Arista, and put his release schedule on hold for the year it took to settle the deal.

Left with nothing else to do, Dido went to America to promote her record. And stayed there. Unlike most British acts, who visit for six weeks and then run home shocked at the sheer size of the country and the sheer slog it takes to get their music across, she put in the hours and the miles. With her six-piece band, she has played over 100 shows there in the past 18 months, playing some cities six or seven times. And with guitarist Vinnie Miranda, she set out to woo the radio stations. They couldn't get on-air at first, so they just played in staff canteens, often getting elbowed out of the way by an audience more interested in their sandwiches: 'I did the most demeaning things because I was just happy to be working.'

Once she was even offered as a competition prize, and ended up singing live-to-air from the porch of a fan's home in Texas. Slowly, the persistence began to pay off. 'Thank You' was a love song originally written for Bob, a London-based lawyer and Dido's boyfriend of five years. It's a simple, deliberately sugary song about how love can make even a bad day seem good: 'It's almost a joke, it's so sweet.' But people began to pick up on it. It appeared during the closing credits of Gwyneth Paltrow's film Sliding Doors, was played on the teen-soap Dawson's Creek, and formed the soundtrack to a 'controversial' sex scene between Sharon Stone and Ellen DeGeneres in the made-for-TV movie If The Walls Could Talk 2 .

fields.headline: Hail to the new Chief
fields.standfirst: At long last, the United States has a new President. He's upright, moralistic and can speak Latin. You're right - he's not George W. Bush, he's Martin Sheen, star of America's acclaimed TV show, The West Wing, which makes its debut on Channel 4 next month
fields.trailText: At long last, the United States has a new President. He's upright, moralistic and can speak Latin. You're right - he's not George W. Bush, he's Martin Sheen, star of America's acclaimed TV show, The West Wing, which makes its debut on Channel 4 next month
fields.body:
Visiting the United States in 1922, G.K. Chesterton marvelled at the country's inane Utopian innocence. Americans, convinced of their own sanctity, gave their cities names like San Francisco or St Louis, and made sure that the sacred citadels of democracy lived up to their wholesome reputations. When he arrived in Washington, Chesterton reported with amazement that 'there really has been an effort to keep the White House white'.

Successive coats of paint have had to be slapped on to maintain the glossy façade, since that pristine building is besmirched or bemired by each of its temporary inhabitants. For Kennedy, the White House was an extension of the Playboy Club, for Nixon a paranoid den of dirty tricks. Dozy Reagan used it mostly as a dormitory. Clinton treated the place as a fantasy motel. Hence the need every few years to spruce up its symbolic allure. The latest instalment in this whitewashing of the White House is the sanctimonious television drama The West Wing which begins on Channel 4 next month.

Martin Sheen plays President Josiah Bartlet, who can only be described as a more liberal and cleaner-shaven version of Jehovah, a man of intelligence and ethics, who despises political opportunism and dedicates himself to the betterment of mankind's lot. Thanks to its pious abstraction from the facts, The West Wing has been an unexpected success in America, watched by 13 million every week.

The actual outgoing President, Bill Clinton, is a burger-bloated satyr; the minority of citizens who bothered to vote for his successor in November were offered a choice between two men wearing interchangeable blue suits accessorised (for demographic reasons) with similar pairs of cowboy boots. Who wouldn't prefer the wise, witty paragon played by Sheen?

The cinema has had fun depicting the moral monstrosity of the men who, in reality, have occupied that whited sepulchre on Pennsylvania Avenue. Anthony Hopkins in Nixon captured the man's tragic, terrified isolation; John Travolta, impersonating Clinton in Primary Colors, made him a comic ogre, greedy for grease and nubile flesh. Hollywood's fictitious Presidents have usually been fools, if not outright knaves. Peter Sellers played the babbling President Merkin Muffley in Dr Strangelove. More recently, Warren Beatty rapped his way towards the White House in Bulworth, and Kevin Kline, as a clueless lookalike, replaced a comatose President in Dave.

Jack Nicholson dopily failed to defend humanity in Mars Attacks!, while in Absolute Power Gene Hackman employed executive privilege to murder his mistress. At least Harrison Ford and Bill Pullman, respectively clobbering communists in Air Force One and fire-bombing extraterrestrials in Independence Day, upheld the honour of the office by turning the President into an action hero.

The problem with the presidency is that the job, which calls for a man to act as a global conscience, can only properly be filled by a deity. Since gods seldom present themselves for election, America must make do with self-aggrandising monsters - a malevolent schemer like Nixon, a virtuoso fibber like Clinton. But Aaron Sorkin, who dreamed up The West Wing and writes most of the episodes, has made the rehabilitation of the sullied White House a personal mission. His script for the 1995 film The American President was Sorkin's trial run. In this, Michael Douglas, sweet-tempered and big-heartedly bipartisan, played President Andrew Shepherd, for whom the American people were a preacher's flock, tenderly coaxed towards enlightenment.

At the time, Clinton was accepting the prayerful services of Monica Lewinsky who, prior to curtsying, strapped on what she called her 'presidential kneepads'; Douglas, as a widower wistfully hoping for a second chance, more chastely waltzes Annette Bening around the Oval Office. Having sentimentalised the presidency here, Sorkin now sanctifies it in The West Wing .

The TV series uses sets left over from The American President and it treats this compound as if it were holy ground. When Sheen's President Bartlet sprains his ankle - impeccably green, he has chosen to fall off his bicycle rather than injure a tree - a staff member jokes that he's a klutz. The President's starchy female secretary snaps: 'I don't like irony in the Oval Office.' This bracingly freshens the air of the room where Clinton enjoyed fellatio.

Sorkin initially planned to keep the President out of sight, concentrating instead on the manouevrings of his staff, a scruple like that of those Hollywood Biblical epics which always showed Christ from behind or merely permitted his shadow to pass over the faces of ecstatic believers. But the omission would have conceded that no human being qualifies to hold this exalted office. Sorkin therefore cast Sheen, whose CV includes roles as two crucified members of America's holy family: in 1974, he played Robert Kennedy in a television film about the Cuban missile crisis, then was promoted to JFK in a 1983 mini series. (He was also a member of Michael Douglas's staff in The American President.)

Sheen's first appearance in The West Wing is a positive annunciation - the advent of a deus ex machina who might have descended on a cloud rather than deplaning from Air Force One. He strolls on, casually quoting the First Commandment - 'I am the Lord thy God, thou shall worship no other God but me' - and, bridling when he finds a coven of right-wing religious fanatics taking his name in vain, expels them from the precincts like Jesus resounding on the money-lenders. 'Get your fat asses out of my White House,' he snarls, sublimely unconcerned about the wrath of television evangelists.

Such a man is too good to get elected, too good indeed to live. Predictably, martyrdom looks imminent at the end of the first series, when Sheen, after a speech in which he beseeches God to bless America, is gunned down by an assassin; I suspect he'll be miraculously resurrected for the second season.

The President providentially intervenes in each episode as the heaven-sent scourge of homophobia, racism or whatever else Sorkin deems politically incorrect. No wonder aggrieved Republicans have claimed that The West Wing ought really to be entitled The Left Wing. But I doubt that they disapprove when Sheen, goaded to defend God's own country, starts talking like a deity who is able to deploy a nuclear arsenal. Provoked by the Syrians, he rages: 'I'm gonna blow them off the face of the earth with God's own thunder.'

Sorkin's President manages to be both a healing Messiah and a belligerent Man. He is also, to add to the role's astral unreality, a philosopher-king of the kind envisaged by Plato. On his way to the White House, Bartlet has collected a Nobel Prize for economics. The supremacy of his mind is underlined by the debility of his body, which represents the merely mortal part of him - he suffers from multiple sclerosis, gallantly borne.

Sorkin vouches for the man's genius by giving his courtiers lines which would only ever be uttered by the most self-seeking brown-nosers. 'You have a once-in-a-generation mind, sir,' says the President's doctor. A black aide who dotes on the President's daughter can't believe the company he keeps: 'I work in a building with the smartest people in the world!' Anxious to prove the point, Bartlet's Vice-President tells a grizzled spin doctor: 'You are a world-class political operative.' Can you imagine Gordon Brown murmuring such an endearment to Peter Mandelson?

Beyond these craven encomia, there's little enough evidence that politics at the White House is conducted with the cerebral finesse of a Socratic seminar. Sheen's usual mode of address is the homiletic folksiness perfected by Reagan, though he does advertise his education by quoting a Latin tag, a spasm of exhibitionism which is said to have cost him the electoral votes of the state of Texas. But the atmosphere of high-mindedness, no matter how unearned, is contagious. Rob Lowe plays a speechwriter whose proudest boast is: 'I can recite the members of Congress in alphabetical order.' The casting of Lowe, a now somewhat superannuated teen pin-up, illustrates how nimbly and deviously The West Wing balances the claims of mind and body.

He regularly takes his clothes off, though, since he's a bookish type, he keeps his spectacles on while pumping his buttocks. He gets dangerously involved with a hooker, but she, too, is using carnality to subsidise the intellect and turns tricks to put herself through law school.

Of course, the show's version of Washington is illusory, as Sorkin has conceded: 'It's a western,' he admits. Bartlet rides a bike, not a horse, and he even falls off that. Nevertheless, he carries a gun and he fires it in the interests of righteousness. But it's the extravagant idealism of The West Wing that makes it so pertinent, when American democracy looks sadly tattered.

The results of the presidential election in November were pre-empted by broadcasters eager to invent headlines; the outcome has been determined by teams of quibbling attorneys and by judges who owe their appointment to political patronage. Neither candidate began life in a log cabin, as the democratic myth stipulates. Heirs of political dynasties, they were each convinced of their hereditary entitlement to office. The voters, a virtual irrelevance, were notable mainly for their inability to punch holes in pieces of paper. But facts in America are always earnestly striving to match the exalted fictions on which the country was founded, so The West Wing has been a useful cover for these embarrassments, as if the show somehow demonstrated that the vaunted constitution still functions.

During his campaign, Al Gore spurned Clinton's offers of help, but felt obliged to defer to Sheen, whom he thought of as a more honourable presidential exemplar. He visited the set of The West Wing and assured the actors he never missed an episode. Politics, which used to be the art of the possible, has become the art of the fantastical. Bumper stickers promoted the notion of 'Bartlet For President' and the Green Party even acted on the proposal, asking Sheen to become the running-mate of Ralph Nader, its nominee.

Sheen knew better than to exchange the charmed pretence for a less satisfying reality, though the excuse he gave made him sound even holier than the intermittently bellicose Bartlet: 'I could not be President of the United States because the republic would be in jeopardy; I'm a pacifist, I couldn't take it out on a Third World nation.'

Now that the presidency has become a branch of the entertainment industry, it's no surprise that rumourmongers expect Clinton to migrate from one show to another when he leaves office next month. It has been suggested that he may run for mayor of New York. The alternative, apparently, is a job with Steven Spielberg's DreamWorks studio, which has just released a valedictory vindication of Clinton. In The Contender, Joan Allen plays a candidate for Vice-President smirkingly vilified by a McCarthyite Republican (Gary Oldman) who has disinterred a sexual scandal from her past. The facts, once more, seek their redemption in fiction.

The rueful gap between The West Wing and the actual political process points to a flaw in the country's conception of itself and in the constitu tion's diagram of a chief executive. The American creed requires the President to embody civic virtue. How can any politician, professionally dependent on graft, chicanery and corruption, possibly hope to measure up? And, as if rectitude intelligence and energy weren't enough, the job description nowadays demands telegenic stardom as well. Wouldn't it be better to leave the presidency to a professional actor?

Monarchs in Shakespeare's historical dramas are judged according to the skill with which they play the king. The presidency, too, is about performance, about projecting an image of probity and avuncular affability. 'I feel your pain,' Clinton testified when he spoke to the survivors of the Oklahoma City bomb, as if he had been studying the empathetic techniques of the Method. Actors, like Reagan or Sheen, lie for a living but escape the imputation of dishonesty.

Chesterton noted that the presidency was the last medieval monarchy, possessing unlimited power by divine right. This is even truer today, when the divine appointees like Sheen speaking with the voice of thunder, can trigger nuclear explosions. Because the office-holder is expected to be superhuman, every presidency ends in failure. If a President seems unlikely to implode as a result of skulduggery or an unwinnable war, someone can generally be relied on to shoot him.

This record of disillusionment and disaster surely means, if you stop to think, that the office itself has failed the country which reposes such naive faith in it. Why not redistribute the executive powers elsewhere, as in our constitutional monarchy, and hire a head of state from central casting? This President's only task would be to preside decorously, while others - Bill Gates, Ted Turner and the other companies to which Bush and Gore are so beholden - got on with the business of governing.

Under these circumstances, Martin Sheen would probably reconsider his refusal, since his duties would no longer include declaring war. And while the Americans are at it, we might do the same here. I suggest putting the Windsors out to pasture and installing Judi Dench, who was nominated for an Oscar when she played Victoria and won the award for her Elizabeth I, as the Queen. It's an acting role, after all, and she'd do it better than the present tired and grumpy incumbent.

During his campaign, Al Gore spurned Clinton's offers of help, but felt obliged to defer to Sheen, whom he thought of as a more honourable presidential exemplar. He visited the set of The West Wing and assured the actors he never missed an episode. Politics, which used to be the art of the possible, has become the art of the fantastical. Bumper stickers promoted the notion of 'Bartlet For President' and the Green Party even acted on the proposal, asking Sheen to become the running-mate of Ralph Nader, its nominee. Sheen knew better than to exchange the charmed pretence for a less satisfying reality, though the excuse he gave made him sound even holier than the intermittently bellicose Bartlet: 'I could not be President of the United States because the republic would be in jeopardy; I'm a pacifist, I couldn't take it out on a Third World nation.' Now that the presidency has become a branch of the entertainment industry, it's no surprise that rumourmongers expect Clinton to migrate from one show to another when he leaves office next month. It has been suggested that he may run for mayor of New York. The alternative, apparently, is a job with Steven Spielberg's DreamWorks studio, which has just released a valedictory vindication of Clinton. In The Contender, Joan Allen plays a candidate for Vice-President smirkingly vilified by a McCarthyite Republican (Gary Oldman) who has disinterred a sexual scandal from her past. The facts, once more, seek their redemption in fiction. The rueful gap between The West Wing and the actual political process points to a flaw in the country's conception of itself and in the constitu tion's diagram of a chief executive. The American creed requires the President to embody civic virtue. How can any politician, professionally dependent on graft, chicanery and corruption, possibly hope to measure up? And, as if rectitude intelligence and energy weren't enough, the job description nowadays demands telegenic stardom as well. Wouldn't it be better to leave the presidency to a professional actor? Monarchs in Shakespeare's historical dramas are judged according to the skill with which they play the king. The presidency, too, is about performance, about projecting an image of probity and avuncular affability. 'I feel your pain,' Clinton testified when he spoke to the survivors of the Oklahoma City bomb, as if he had been studying the empathetic techniques of the Method. Actors, like Reagan or Sheen, lie for a living but escape the imputation of dishonesty. Chesterton noted that the presidency was the last medieval monarchy, possessing unlimited power by divine right. This is even truer today, when the divine appointees like Sheen speaking with the voice of thunder, can trigger nuclear explosions. Because the office-holder is expected to be superhuman, every presidency ends in failure. If a President seems unlikely to implode as a result of skulduggery or an unwinnable war, someone can generally be relied on to shoot him. This record of disillusionment and disaster surely means, if you stop to think, that the office itself has failed the country which reposes such naive faith in it. Why not redistribute the executive powers elsewhere, as in our constitutional monarchy, and hire a head of state from central casting? This President's only task would be to preside decorously, while others - Bill Gates, Ted Turner and the other companies to which Bush and Gore are so beholden - got on with the business of governing. Under these circumstances, Martin Sheen would probably reconsider his refusal, since his duties would no longer include declaring war. And while the Americans are at it, we might do the same here. I suggest putting the Windsors out to pasture and installing Judi Dench, who was nominated for an Oscar when she played Victoria and won the award for her Elizabeth I, as the Queen. It's an acting role, after all, and she'd do it better than the present tired and grumpy incumbent.

webTitle: I write about art, but I've never seen the Mona Lisa

fields.headline: I write about art, but I've never seen the Mona Lisa
fields.trailText: Ever herad my name before? No? Never mind, I'm sure I haven't got one here yet. But in Germany, where I've lived for the last 30-odd years, I've had a few books published, one of which I need to make a confession about. It's been sort of haunting me ever since I delivered the manuscript: I've never seen the Mona Lisa.
fields.body:
Ever herad my name before? No? Never mind, I'm sure I haven't got one here yet. But in Germany, where I've lived for the last 30-odd years, I've had a few books published, one of which I need to make a confession about. It's been sort of haunting me ever since I delivered the manuscript: I've never seen the Mona Lisa.

'Well,' you might say, 'that's not so bad, neither have I.' You might well have been to Paris and pondered visiting the Louvre, but then gone shopping instead, happily avoiding all the arty stuff. And why not? But did you then write a book about Leonardo's masterpiece, aka the world's most famous painting? That's what I did. Worse still, I've never been to Paris either.

My books about art are ostensibly for children; they are not taken very seriously in Germany. They are not academic and therefore in many people's eyes a bit suspect, even subversive. Each book looks at one painting - metaphorically speaking - and tells simple stories about the painter and about the usually troubled times he lived in, thereby drawing the reader right into the picture. One of my books focuses on Rembrandt's biblical shocker, 'Belshazzar's Feast', which hangs in the National Gallery. (Go see it some time after you've done your shopping.) I've loved this painting for many years and studied it closely. But - it still shocks me - I've never seen the Mona Lisa.

'Well,' you might now say, 'that is unforgivable,' particularly if you've been to Paris and queued up for hours for a glimpse. But, be honest, didn't you feel slightly mocked by her smile? Wouldn't that be a true confession? She, all tranquillity behind thick glass; you, frustrated, a bit miserable, trapped in the crowd behind somebody else's less transparent back. Wasn't she a touch too pale for your taste, or embarrassingly small? Did you wonder, what's all the fuss about?

I am half-joking, of course: I believe in the brilliance of Leonardo's painting, stripped bare of the crowd - an unlikely event - as much as I am quite easily convinced about the excellence of a highly reputed but, alas, unopened wine. However, it's the idea of the wine that fires my imagination. The thrill of delaying consumption. The art of dealing with Mona Lisa therefore lies in not looking at her.

'Well,' you might say, 'I've never heard such rubbish.' I can only imagine your reaction had you seen the two postcards I kept on my desk while I was writing that childish book. One from Paris, with kindest regards from a friend who had been 'hin- und weggerissen von ihrem bezaubernden Blick' (enraptured by her gaze blah, blah, blah). The other of Woody Allen dressed up as the Renaissance Queen. I confess that I liked that postcard even better. I wish I had words to describe his beautiful hair, his grace and composure, the subtlety of his famous smile from which the infamous spectacles couldn't distract...

Thomas David's latest book, 'Marc Chagall: What Colour is Paradise?' is published by Prestel in the UK.

webTitle: Dad says I shouldn't have a mixed-race child. Is he right?

fields.headline: Dad says I shouldn't have a mixed-race child. Is he right?
fields.trailText:
My fiance and I plan to marry next May. We have been together for three years. He is Afro-Caribbean and I am white. My father, who is 72, is opposed to our marriage. He feels it would be unfair to bring up a child of mixed race. I love my fiancé, but does my father have a point? Is it unfair to bring a mixed-race child into the world?
Y.D. of Basingstoke
fields.body:
My fiance and I plan to marry next May. We have been together for three years. He is Afro-Caribbean and I am white. My father, who is 72, is opposed to our marriage. He feels it would be unfair to bring up a child of mixed race. I love my fiancé, but does my father have a point? Is it unfair to bring a mixed-race child into the world?
Y.D. of Basingstoke

I believe in honouring one's father and mother and all that, but this does not mean slavishly following a parent's opinion when he is palpably wrong, or obeying his behest when you should have long since outgrown his authority.

In this century we are so lucky to be able to rattle about the world, meeting people in various locations, maximising the chances of finding that symbiotic soul-mate everyone seeks. There are few real barriers. Consider how restricted you would have been in a rural community two centuries ago with at most a handful of eligible people available. The next village 10 miles away would have seemed like another country, and you would have been an alien in it. Just 100 years ago, rigid class distinctions would have narrowed the selection process more strictly than distance.

Mixed race? That's true of all of us. What exactly is a race, but a group of people whose forebears have lived in a given environment for long enough to have been moulded by it? Inherently fluid, changing imperceptibly over aeons, never immutable. If you go far enough back in evolutionary time, Homo sapiens originated in Africa, so we are all descended and adapted from the same dark-skinned ancestry. In history, peoples who have left the lands of their fathers to settle in a new community have fared much better by mingling and inter-marrying than those who have maintained their exclusivity. The biological differences between races are very slight, and arguably two men of different nationalities have more in common than a male and a female of the same ethnicity.

All this is theoretical, and you will have to contend with prejudices held perhaps by a minority of people, but we know how large can loom the destructive tendency of the small-minded. Prejudice is directed against other characteristics besides race; anyone who stands out from the crowd by being tall, small, moral, ugly, clever, disabled, lame, gay, blind, deaf, poor, female, old, can be a victim. You can't evade them all. You and your father show a commendably strong instinct to protect an infant as yet unborn and unconceived. You cannot, however, design a child for the shortcomings of this world, any more than you can engineer an ideal world to receive him. The best you can achieve is a stable, secure and contented home for him to be born into, a haven for retreat after future forays into the unknown. You can best accomplish that by focusing your natural inclinations and forging a lasting relationship with the man you love.

Readers' Responses

Y.D of Basingstoke should be told how incredibly difficult marriage is - quite unlike just being together - and this is when you are both the same colour. Multiply the difficulties 10-fold when you are of different races and think long and hard. For each child multiply it all over again.
M.B. of Highgate

I am Afro-Caribbean, Canadian-born. My husband's parents are Irish. We were together for three years before his parents deigned to meet me. We have now been married for four years, and we have two sons, aged two years and five months. They are surrounded by all races, mixed and otherwise. We don't expect them to have a totally trouble-free life devoid of any racial conflict, but we hope to bring them up with a sense of confidence within themselves.

You asked whether it was unfair to bring a mixed-race child into the world. What is unfair is to bring a child into this world, unloved.
T.C. via e-mail

It is not in any way 'unfair' to bring a mixed-race child into the world. On the contrary. It is to make a contribution to the future. Mixed-race children can benefit from and contribute to, two or more cultures. Migration and integration on the scale it is occurring now will ensure that mixed-race and mixed-culture children will predominate within the foreseeable future, when 'race' may even cease to be an issue of any kind.

But this effect will, at first, be rather localised. London, we are told, will be '50 per cent black' in 10 years. This will not happen in smaller towns and rural areas. So where you live could be quite relevant, but to my mixed-race five-year-old grand-daughter (who lives in Manchester) skin colour is gloriously irrelevant.

My father held similar views to your father's, but was instantly converted when he was given the new baby to hold.
J.M.S. Utrecht, Netherlands

Next Week's Dilemma

Since our baby was born three months ago, our five-year-old dog (a bitch) has been showing increasing signs of jealousy. Recently she has been growling at the baby and I'm worried she might become aggressive.

Although I love our dog very much, I do not trust her around our daughter and have suggested to my husband that we either have her put down or we give her away. My husband is rigidly opposed to this suggestion as he has owned her from a puppy and had her before we met.

I feel he is putting the dog before our daughter and the difference of opinion is causing a rift.
R.P. Ashford, Kent

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

webTitle: A beginner's guide to the West Wing

fields.headline: A beginner's guide to the West Wing
fields.trailText: The Players
fields.body:
The Players

The President Josiah Bartlet (Martin Sheen). During the recent election, you couldn't move for people suggesting that the US bypass Bush and Gore and go for President Bartlet. Usually assumed to be a Clintonesque figure, the wise, erudite, impossibly well-informed yet down-to-earth Bartlet is a liberal fantasy figure with elements of Abraham Lincoln, Teddy Roosevelt and the man Robert Kennedy might have grown into.

The Chief of Staff Leo McGarry (John Spencer). A world-weary Vietnam vet, he's the strongman of the operation. Keeps everyone else in line and is a lifelong friend of the President. He does, however, have a career-threatening skeleton in his closet.

The Press Secretary C.J. Cregg (Allison Janney). Contrary to what you would expect from her job, the most earnest , heart-on-her-sleeve and left-wing member of the team. Has an ethically dubious will-they, won't-they? relationship with reporter Danny Concannon.

The Deputy Communications Director Sam Seaborn (Rob Lowe). Brilliant but unreliable, with a personal life that's inappropriate to the job. His tendency to be a political trainspotter offsets his good looks. Presumed to be based on former Clinton spin doctor and heartthrob George Stephanopoulos.

The First Daughter Zoey Bartlet (Elisabeth Moss). The President's youngest daughter. Goes to college in Washington. Troubled by a lack of attention from her father and too much attention from her Secret Service agents. Has a relationship with Charles Young.

The First Lady Abby Bartlet (Stockard Channing). Definitely not based on Hillary. This First Lady is a doctor who is detached from the workings of the government. She is interested in ouija boards.

The Presidential Aide Charles Young (Dule Hill). Soft-spoken, well-behaved young man who runs errands for the President. Black. Jeopardises his position by sleeping with the boss's daughter.

The Reporter Danny Concannon (Timothy Busfield). Hustling, rule-breaking hack who is the favourite outlet for leaks from the West Wing staff. Flirts with press secretary C.J. Cregg.

The Vice President John Hoynes (Tim Matheson). Young, smooth, ticket-balancing, ambitious and Texan. A recovering alcoholic. Completely distrusted by Bartlet and his staff.

The Lexicon

The West Wing the west wing of the White House, where the Presidential staff are based

POTUS stands for President Of The United States

The Beltway the Washington ringroad that divides those interested in the workings of Congress and the Federal government ('inside the beltway') from the rest of the country

What the critics say

'The West Wing is a cultural signpost of the post-post-Watergate era, the first show in decades to suggest modern-day politics might involve ideals or heroism or noble intentions.'
Washington Post

'The West Wing towers above the junkier dramas that litter the television landscape... Wag the Dog meets Frank Capra. It is smart and maddening'
New York Times

fields.headline: It's not that I'm vain...
fields.standfirst: If your forehead resembles corrugated iron and your self-esteem is hurting, there's only one solution - pop down to Harley Street and get yourself poisoned
fields.trailText: If your forehead resembles corrugated iron and your self-esteem is hurting, there's only one solution - pop down to Harley Street and get yourself poisoned
fields.body:
Do you suffer the anguish of embarrassing vertical brow WRINKLES? Are your crow's feet growing feet of their own? Does your forehead crumple into UNSIGHTLY corrugated cardboard at the slightest hint of an arched eyebrow? Now you can banish those telltale signs of being your proper AGE with new improved Botox - the easy, modern way to look younger, live longer, sleep with more attractive members of the opposite SEX and improve your chances of being good at poker! All you have to do is have your head injected with deadly snake POISON every few months and...

Hang on a minute - snake poison ?

Well OK, it's not real snake poison, but it more or less does the same thing in so far as it paralyses your muscles above the eyebrows so you can't scowl any more, or embark on inadvisable shall we? games with Gail from accounts at the office party, or attract a waiter's attention without standing on a chair. Its real name is botulinum toxin and the treatment has apparently proved very popular among New York psychoanalysts who want to avoid looking surprised when their clients start telling them about their double life as serial killers. Women are having it done in their lunch breaks instead of buying birthday cards and having their holiday photos developed. Men, too, are succumbing to the lure of a youthful, relaxed, upper-facial area. Have you noticed how inscrutable Cliff Richard is looking these days? Yes. Pop's perennial prince of pap recently came out as a 'user', explaining that not even he - now pushing an astonishing 105 - can indefinitely continue to pass for a 31-year-old without calling in the builders occasionally.

And, of course, no one need ever know. It's not as if you're going to get people coming up to you at the bus stop and asking if you'd mind raising your eyebrows for a moment. It's not as glaringly obvious as dyeing your hair or suddenly to be seen bulging out of your trousers with spiffing new testicular implants. All the same, it does seem like the thin end of the wedge for a proper man in his forties to be seen dallying with cosmetic enhancements I can't help thinking, as I sit in an exclusive Harley Street clinic waiting for my initial consultation. I've been reading The Adonis Complex (Simon & Schuster £17.99), written by a trio of American psychiatrists who think that men are becoming pathologically obsessed with their looks and their weight, and, as a result, are locked into ruinous dietary and exercise regimes, leading to a cycle of compulsive cheeseburger eating, negative body-image disorders and general self-hatred. It seems men the Western world over are increasingly to be found in the bathroom removing white pubic hairs, experimenting with penile enlargement pumps and combing over their bald patches (before resorting to something called hair plugs, which I must find out more about).

It is a subject that divides the nation, or at least people I bump into. Most are happy to concede that it's preferable to genital-piercing, which has somehow managed to get in under the wire of social acceptability as a bona fide expression of personal creativity. But my 10-year-old boy is fearful that the toxin might turn me into the Elephant Man. And a woman of my acquaintance is horrified when I tell her that I am having my forehead lines finessed out, even on a temporary basis - 'It's so vain ,' she shrieks.

Ah, I agree, it would be vain, I hasten to explain, were I not merely participating in the spirit of journalistic inquiry, thereby placing myself above such personal considerations. And if I end up looking 10 years younger as a result, that's a risk you have to take in my line of work. I realise it's not exactly war reporting but...

'But if you can't move your eyebrows, how can people tell how you're feeling?' she asks.

The thing is, if your forehead looks as if a tractor has just driven over it (as mine does, by coincidence), everybody over-reads how you're feeling anyway. 'Why so glum?' they might ask as you walk into the office having just scooped £185,000 on the Lottery; or 'you seem a bit tense', when all you're doing is standing at the tea trolley weighing up the respective merits of Snickers and Mars Bars.

'But where do you draw the line?' asks my woman acquaintance.

'Weightlifting,' I say.

The consultant, a senior nurse called Ian, is quite amazed by my powerful forehead muscle. 'Very expressive,' he says, taking a step back. Apparently, not everyone's forehead is crying out for a good ironing but mine is. We drink coffee. We chat about my past medical history and he asks if I'm breastfeeding or on medication. He says the treatment takes between four and 10 days to work. He says to take care not to rub the affected area, because this can spread the toxin and result in eyebrow droop, though this is very rare and in any case wears off after only a couple of weeks of your boss wondering why you are asleep at your desk. So, I ask, whether the only real snag is that after three months you turn back into Sid James? 'What? Dead? I hope not.'

We both laugh, me slightly less because, of course, I'm the one having needles stuck in my head. But seriously, he says, eventually you probably need three or four treatments in the first year, two or three in the second, one in the third and after that your eyebrows have forgotten their lines, so to speak. fields.headline: The ultimate insider
fields.standfirst: Simon Jenkins, smooth and urbane, friend of the rich, defender of the Dome, is the epitome of the Establishment. But he thinks of himself as a new Friar Tuck.  Peter Conrad crossed cudgels with him
fields.trailText: Just as I was about to accuse Simon Jenkins of personifying the Establishment, he outwitted me by denying that such a thing any longer existed.
fields.body:
Just as I was about to accuse Simon Jenkins of personifying the Establishment, he outwitted me by denying that such a thing any longer existed.

He was talking about the Millennium Dome, that cavern of empty air inside which so much money has vaporised. Though he shiftily insisted 'It's not my Dome!', he was one of the commissioners who approved the project and he stubbornly refuses to withdraw his support now. 'At least,' he specified, 'not while friends of mine are working there.'

Jenkins has friends everywhere, mostly in high places, and once a year he and his wife, the orchidaceous American actress Gayle Hunnicutt, invite them all to a party. Numbers preclude a domestic setting: in the past they have taken over the Battersea Power Station, St Pancras Hotel, a courtyard at the Foreign Office or the Speaker's House at Westminster. When I asked Jenkins why he loved London, despite its affray, its squalor and its lack of civility, he said: 'I enjoy the serendipitous bumping into people in restaurants, cinemas or clubs. After a while, the city itself becomes a friend.'

It is a cosy, even cliquey view of the alienating metropolis, but Jenkins is, after all, the ultimate insider. This year, as well as helping to distribute millennial funds, he chaired the judging panel for the Booker Prize. Throughout the 1980s, he served on the board of British Railways and in the early 1990s headed the Commission for Local Democracy. (He personally sold the idea of an elected London mayor to Tony Blair and was tempted to run as a candidate for the London Assembly last year; he desisted because the election was so rigidly partisan.) He has been a governor of the Museum of London and a trustee of the World Monuments Fund. He even found time to edit the London Evening Standard between 1976 and 1978 and the Times from 1990 to 1992.

As if this CV were not evidence enough of his established status, let me add that Jenkins belongs to the Garrick Club. And, cannily qualifying his reputation as a metropolitan networker, he has a single, lovable antiquarian foible. The hobby he lists in Who's Who is 'looking at old churches' and he has recently published a fine guide to England's thousand best, star-rated as if he were compiling an ecclesiastical Michelin or grading guests for his next party. His book is illustrated with photographs from the archive of Country Life, the magazine which gave Jenkins his first job in 1965 when he left Oxford.

In 1992 he published The Times Guide to English Style and Usage, and he pretty much epitomises smooth English urbanity. Or perhaps he is a relic, testifying to what he has called, in a comment on the expatriate society of Shanghai in Ishiguro's novel Now We Are Orphans, 'the obsessional afterlife of Englishness'. Under his influence, Hunnicutt, the Texan belle who once played JR's mistress in Dallas, has become genteelly English. Forswearing big hair, false eyelashes, manicured nails and all the impedimenta of American beauty, she now enthusiastically gardens with a terrier snapping at her heels, collects watercolours and goes shopping in an unglamorous head scarf and raincoat like a Windsor wife.

This man has all the bases covered. How could he possibly seek to disestablish himself? The Establishment, he said, now went by a different name - less pompous, more whimsically self-disparaging. Defending the Dome, Jenkins remembered the 'fit of political rage' which prompted the Churchill government to tear down the Dome of Discovery, erected on the South Bank for the Festival of Britain in 1951. 'Somehow,' he mused, 'these big projects seem to evoke a visceral hostility in what used to be called the Establishment and was then called the intelligentsia declension, even though it summarised the downsizing of his own ambitions.'

Before the intelligentsia was declared redundant, Jenkins had hoped to join its ranks. At university, he wanted to become an academic. 'In those days, that seemed a glittering career,' he said with a grimace, acknowledging the way the universities have since been cowed by governments which refuse to subsidise dissent. So now, with columns in the Times and the Standard , he finds himself reduced to chitchat; his home, inevitably, is in the stretch of NW1 where all the members of his garrulous class seem to live.

Those who dislike Jenkins on principle see him as nothing more than an ineffectual talker. Michael Leapman, profiling him recently in the New Statesman, wrote him off as a dabbler in politics without 'firm views'. Unseated as editor of the Times, he was 'stripped of his power base' and now contented himself, Leapman claimed, with fatuous 'appointments on quangos and busybody committees'. Observer critic Deyan Sudjic, who questions Jenkins's public interventions as an architectural pundit, calls him 'the acceptable face of fogeyism', affably fronting a mindless campaign against modernism.

I'm not sure that he should be so easily dismissed. He did once unwisely remark that his collection of paintings (he specialises in English romantics like Samuel Palmer and John Piper) had made him 'a man of substance'. But he owes his substantiality to his quick, quirky, adversarial brain, not to his possessions - even if houses, horses and heirlooms were the only kind of substance esteemed by those who traditionally owned and ran this country.

Jenkins is a contradictory figure, whose irony covers the gaps between his different personae. He belongs to the Establishment, but - since he sees the newspaper columnist as a licensed mischief-maker - likes to pull its gouty leg. Failing to gain the First he coveted in PPE, he never officially joined the intelligentsia, but he has become a keen and industrious amateur scholar: his Thousand Best English Churches is a worthy adjunct to Pevsner, replacing academic sobriety with an infectious enthusiasm. And though Jenkins chatters like a virtuoso, there is always a soul-saving message behind the wit, the waspishness, the rhetoric and the agile literary parodies. He is, I suspect, a disappointed preacher, and frequenting all those churches has made him crave a pulpit.

'I'm not a churchman, not religious, certainly not Christian', he said when discussing the Thousand Best. 'But I'm the son of a clergyman turned theology professor, and in a way, I think we all end up trying to satisfy our father's ambitions for us. He had his weekly sermons to deliver, and I have my weekly columns to write.' Evasively ironic as always, this slight and dapper man sees himself as a remote descendant of Friar Tuck. 'The Reformation began 100 years earlier than people think, when wandering friars - yes, Friar Tuck was one of them - arrived in villages and began interpreting the gospel to the laity in the naves of churches. They had their flock of listeners in the pews, and I have my readers.'

But the friars, I pointed out, were transmitting the truth, whereas Jenkins in his columns merely purveys opinions, which, as an inveterate ironist, he is free to disavow. 'Yes, yes,' he said, 'so the parallel collapses. And I do sometimes worry about the risks of irony. People often write in to say "You've gone too far this time, Jenkins".' Last month, he confessed, he was tempted to defend the notion of a European army, just because everyone else was deploring it. And after the storms at the end of October he wickedly rejoiced in the sight of a Primrose Hill plane tree which had concussed the roof of a Peugeot: 'One small step for nature,' he wrote, 'one giant leap for an integrated transport policy.' Ironists are always in danger of being understood literally: on this occasion, Jenkins nervously added a waiver, admitting that the battered Peugeot did not belong to him.

His irony covers a genuine ideological uncertainty. As a conservationist, he is a natural Conservative - or at least, as he said, 'a sort of Conservative. At university, I was in the Labour Club, like everyone else, and I supported Labour through the 1960s. Then I was beguiled by Thatcherism, though later I became disillusioned. Thatcher campaigned against government regulation, but actually produced a more powerful state. Blair pledged to dismantle it, and he's done some devolving, though he still meddles from the centre. I'm basically a libertarian radical who dislikes government. Thatcher and Blair have both betrayed de Tocqueville's principle of association. Democracy isn't just about voting every four or five years and then going home to be a passive consumer of government policies.'

Jenkins's beloved churches provide him with a parable of the 'communitarianism' which de Tocqueville admired in early America. 'When those itinerant friars began preaching, the naves of churches had to be rebuilt to accommodate larger congregations, and the nave then became a place where guilds met. Local government - and I'm an obsessional localist - began there. And in some countries, that's where power still resides. Forget about the global village. What we really need is just a village. I remember meeting a man in a Connecticut church last summer. He was the town treasurer, and he'd been given a hard time at a town meeting the night before, because he'd raised local taxes. I love that folksy, old-fashioned kind of democracy. Everyone ridiculed the vote-counting in Florida, but at least they were trying to find out what local people wanted. I cheered when I heard the Mayor of Bologna reacting to the BSE scare on the radio the other day. He announced that in Bologna the eating of beef was to be made compulsory, and explained that he was a butcher!'

Jenkins had discovered a fellow ironist, skilled at finessing self-interest by making jokes. Hunnicutt has absorbed his prejudice. When they married in 1978, Jenkins insisted that she relocate to Primrose Hill. He apparently disapproved of South Kensington, where she was then living: insufficiently parochial, I suppose. She now makes a point of shopping locally and avoids the Camden Town supermarkets on principle.

But though Jenkins supports devolution, he doesn't fancy being devolved. His affection for London, and his contempt for the restless modern cult of what he calls 'hypermobility', means that he unfashionably spends the weekends in town. 'I'm not a natural second-homer. We had a cottage for a while, but I developed a syndrome known as M4 aversion. I sat next to a woman from the West Country at dinner a while ago. She asked me how I could bear to live in London so I retaliated by asking her how she could bear to live in Somerset. I said I'd hate it, that it would kill me. She thought I was appallingly rude.' Once more, his irony had got him into trouble.

Though he speculates in his book on churches about our 'forest origins' and the rural cult of the Green Man, Jenkins harbours no green thoughts or woodland longings. 'My son and I go to Wales every year to climb a mountain,' he told me, adding: 'Last year we had unspeakably awful weather.' The mountain-climbing is a dutiful exercise in male bonding, not something undertaken for pleasure. Tellingly, Jenkins announced the completion of an arduous cultural chore in 1995 by boasting to this readers: 'I have scaled the Matterhorn of art tourism. I have done the Cézanne show at the Grand Palais.' Preferring not to venture into the countryside, he favours rusticating the city: hence his suggestion - ironic of course, though it maddened the architectural critics - that Battersea power station should be left to crumble as a ruin, like a Tintern Abbey of the industrial age.

Hating centralism, Jenkins occupies a privileged niche quite close to the centre of power; deploring the standardisation of opinion, he happens to be one of the opinion-makers who enforce that conformity. 'Yes,' he conceded, 'the national media have trampled the sense of local affiliation, as Ruskin predicted the railways would do. Parliament as it withers cedes power to the press. A Minister's toughest test is on Newsnight , not at the dispatch box. But we should be grateful that each day in the press we have five serious organs of opinion, each with a different point of view.'

I began to understand the motive for Jenkins's nimble self-contradictions. He adds to the available array of opinions by having more views than one about any subject. He deliberately provokes his readers to wonder whether he can really mean what he says, and thus prompts them to mistrust the pontification of experts, including himself. Rather than preaching a dogma, he inculcates a radical, liberating creed of scepticism. Perhaps his playful manner really does mark the end of the Establishment, which used to operate by an unspoken consensus. The Thunderer - as the Times used to be known - has become a sly, teasing chatterer.

Man of many parts

Born 10 June 1943 in Birmingham.

Educated Mill Hill School; St John's College, Oxford (PPE).

1977 Became editor of the Evening Standard, aged 33.

1978 Married Gayle Hunnicutt; has one son, one stepson.

1979-86 Political editor of the Economist.

1990-92 Editor, the Times.

Jenkins is a voracious joiner of committees, boards and quangos. These include: British Railways Board; BR Environment Panel; Grade Committee on Fear of Crime; Commission of Local Democracy (chairman); Municipal Journal Ltd (director); The Bow Group (council member); Save Britain's Heritage; Historic Buildings and Monuments Commission; The Millennium Commission; Institute of Contemporary Arts (council member); Thirties Society (deputy chairman); Railway Heritage Trust (founder and director); World Monuments Fund (trustee); Museum of London (governor); Calcutt Committee on Privacy; Lady Runciman's inquiry into drugs legislation; Save Britain's Heritage; Booker Prize Jury 2000 (chairman).
