Jenkins had discovered a fellow ironist, skilled at finessing self-interest by making jokes. Hunnicutt has absorbed his prejudice. When they married in 1978, Jenkins insisted that she relocate to Primrose Hill. He apparently disapproved of South Kensington, where she was then living: insufficiently parochial, I suppose. She now makes a point of shopping locally and avoids the Camden Town supermarkets on principle. But though Jenkins supports devolution, he doesn't fancy being devolved. His affection for London, and his contempt for the restless modern cult of what he calls 'hypermobility', means that he unfashionably spends the weekends in town. 'I'm not a natural second-homer. We had a cottage for a while, but I developed a syndrome known as M4 aversion. I sat next to a woman from the West Country at dinner a while ago. She asked me how I could bear to live in London so I retaliated by asking her how she could bear to live in Somerset. I said I'd hate it, that it would kill me. She thought I was appallingly rude.' Once more, his irony had got him into trouble. Though he speculates in his book on churches about our 'forest origins' and the rural cult of the Green Man, Jenkins harbours no green thoughts or woodland longings. 'My son and I go to Wales every year to climb a mountain,' he told me, adding: 'Last year we had unspeakably awful weather.' The mountain-climbing is a dutiful exercise in male bonding, not something undertaken for pleasure. Tellingly, Jenkins announced the completion of an arduous cultural chore in 1995 by boasting to this readers: 'I have scaled the Matterhorn of art tourism. I have done the Cézanne show at the Grand Palais.' Preferring not to venture into the countryside, he favours rusticating the city: hence his suggestion - ironic of course, though it maddened the architectural critics - that Battersea power station should be left to crumble as a ruin, like a Tintern Abbey of the industrial age. Hating centralism, Jenkins occupies a privileged niche quite close to the centre of power; deploring the standardisation of opinion, he happens to be one of the opinion-makers who enforce that conformity. 'Yes,' he conceded, 'the national media have trampled the sense of local affiliation, as Ruskin predicted the railways would do. Parliament as it withers cedes power to the press. A Minister's toughest test is on Newsnight , not at the dispatch box. But we should be grateful that each day in the press we have five serious organs of opinion, each with a different point of view.' I began to understand the motive for Jenkins's nimble self-contradictions. He adds to the available array of opinions by having more views than one about any subject. He deliberately provokes his readers to wonder whether he can really mean what he says, and thus prompts them to mistrust the pontification of experts, including himself. Rather than preaching a dogma, he inculcates a radical, liberating creed of scepticism. Perhaps his playful manner really does mark the end of the Establishment, which used to operate by an unspoken consensus. The Thunderer - as the Times used to be known - has become a sly, teasing chatterer. Man of many parts Born 10 June 1943 in Birmingham. Educated Mill Hill School; St John's College, Oxford (PPE). 1977 Became editor of the Evening Standard, aged 33. 1978 Married Gayle Hunnicutt; has one son, one stepson. 1979-86 Political editor of the Economist. 1990-92 Editor, the Times. Jenkins is a voracious joiner of committees, boards and quangos. These include: British Railways Board; BR Environment Panel; Grade Committee on Fear of Crime; Commission of Local Democracy (chairman); Municipal Journal Ltd (director); The Bow Group (council member); Save Britain's Heritage; Historic Buildings and Monuments Commission; The Millennium Commission; Institute of Contemporary Arts (council member); Thirties Society (deputy chairman); Railway Heritage Trust (founder and director); World Monuments Fund (trustee); Museum of London (governor); Calcutt Committee on Privacy; Lady Runciman's inquiry into drugs legislation; Save Britain's Heritage; Booker Prize Jury 2000 (chairman).

webTitle: Bryant's faith in concrete benefits of Beazer deal

fields.headline: Bryant's faith in concrete benefits of Beazer deal
fields.trailText: Peter Long, chief executive of Bryant Group, thinks that consolidation among builders is 'appropriate'. That looks like the understatement of the century. Housebuilders have been among the worst investments of the past decade. Shares in Beazer, Bryant's merger partner, have fallen by 20 per cent over that period while the rest of the market has jumped by 50 per cent. Companies such as Wimpey and Barratt Developments, once knocking on the door of the FTSE 100 index, are now knocking on the door of the small companies index.
fields.body:
Peter Long, chief executive of Bryant Group, thinks that consolidation among builders is 'appropriate'. That looks like the understatement of the century. Housebuilders have been among the worst investments of the past decade. Shares in Beazer, Bryant's merger partner, have fallen by 20 per cent over that period while the rest of the market has jumped by 50 per cent. Companies such as Wimpey and Barratt Developments, once knocking on the door of the FTSE 100 index, are now knocking on the door of the small companies index.

Other unpopular sectors, food manufacturing and engineering, have been consolidating and streamlining furiously in a bid to win back investors' affection. Housebuilders, however, have carried on much as they were, with just the odd management buyout to ripple the surface.

The reason for the lack of consolidation is simple enough: mergers between housebuilders do not seem to work. Bigger in building does not seem to mean better; indeed, in many cases, bigger has actually been worse. Mark Hake, building analyst at Merrill Lynch, says that builders seem to work best when each division is building around 600 houses. Any higher than that, and the economies of scale disappear. Combined, Bryant and Beazer - or Domus as it will be called - will be building 900 per division.

Long and John Low, his counterpart at Beazer, think that is an old-fashioned view. Even housebuilders now routinely use computers, so a surveyor can easily manage to handle more than one site. Doors, windows, timber frames... these components are now prefabricated and finished off the site. Such modernisation means, they say, that volume housebuilding can now be done more efficiently and effectively.

But not that efficiently, judging from the meagre £20 million savings - just 10 per cent of last year's combined profits - promised from the deal. Long says it is deliberately not promising too much and adds that better working capital management will also be a key part of the merger. He believes the combined company will need only three years' stock which, based on combined sales of around 11,000 houses a year, means that 4,000 plots in the land bank will be surplus. Suspending purchases for a few months will use that up and will also cut the amount of capital tied up in stock.

Bryant and Beazer are not the only companies to be converted to the idea of mergers. Wimpey announced last week that it is to combine its two housing businesses, Wimpey Homes and McLean Homes, more than four years after it acquired the latter through an asset swap with Tarmac. It is promising £15m in savings as a result.

Others will be watching closely to see whether the two mergers produce the promised benefits. If they do, the pressure will be on to follow suit. That is, of course, if the merger goes ahead at all. Bryant's shareholders seem to be getting a good deal from the merger but Beazer is selling out at less than the value of its net assets - one of the industry's cardinal sins.

Rivals - Taylor Woodrow and Persimmon are just two that spring to mind - are likely to be considering intervening. That makes the shares in both these companies a definite hold but, until it is clear how the merger drama will be resolved, it is not worth buying them - or any others in the sector.

Rum deal could prove a winner

There is a certain logic about Allied Domecq's decision to pull out of the bidding with Seagram's wines and spirits business. Last week Allied acquired the Mumm and Perrier-Jouet champagne brands. It also claims to have signed a deal to distribute another Seagram brand, Captain Morgan. Add on the deal to distribute Russian vodka Stolichnaya, and Allied can reasonably argue that it has got all it wants, without paying the inflated price being demanded for Seagram.

Leaving aside the tricky question over whether its Captain Morgan deal will survive the legal challenges which will doubtless be launched by whoever eventually wins Seagram, there must be a question mark over Allied's decision to pull out.

Chief executive Philip Bowman will have to work hard to prove that these three brands are really enough to give the group the international scale and growth that it needs if it is to remain a force in the global drinks industry. The performance of Diageo - one of the two remaining Seagram contenders - since it was created through the merger of Grand Metropolitan and Guinness, demonstrates how useful international scale can be.

But the purchase of Seagram would also have brought significant risks - overpaying and the possibility of failing to integrate the two businesses are just two of the more severe. Allied's shares have risen sharply in recent months but still stand at a big discount to Diageo. There is at least an evens chance that Bowman's strategy will pay off, which makes Allied's shares worth a gamble. Buy.

Choice travel deals pay off

There is nothing like a spot of difficulty for bringing out the best in a company. When Peter Long (not to be confused with Bryant's chief executive of the same name) took over as chief executive of holiday company First Choice, it was all but on its knees.

Three years on, First Choice is one of Britain's best tour operators. Profits in the year to October rose by 47 per cent to £68.9m; margins are rising; and current trading is healthy. Long's triumph was to realise that we are becoming bored with the standard Costa del Sol package holiday, would prefer something different, and are prepared to pay that bit extra for it.

A third of First Choice's sales are now of more specialist holidays, from motorboats and yachting to golfing and diving. Long's next target is to increase that to half, both by organic growth and by continuing the series of small, specialist acquisitions made in the past few years.

First Choice's success will not have escaped rivals' attention, and it is likely that others will be trying to specialise more. First Choice has a clear headstart. Provided it can continue to offer the kind of service that has earned it a loyal following, there should be much more growth to come.

At less than 11 times expected earnings for next year the shares are cheap. Buy.

fields.headline: 'Weightless' work
fields.standfirst: Hi-tech firms may be the future, but can they ever fill the employment gap?  Faisal Islam on the reality of the new economy
fields.trailText: Griff Rhys-Jones is not directly responsible for last week's job losses in Luton, despite the generally poor reception for the TV adverts featuring him as a limo-loving, ginger-bearded geek who makes do with a Vauxhall. Rather than the quality of an individual ad campaign, it is the growth of the advertising industry as an emblem of the changing industrial landscape that may have affected manufacturing fortunes.
fields.body:
Griff Rhys-Jones is not directly responsible for last week's job losses in Luton, despite the generally poor reception for the TV adverts featuring him as a limo-loving, ginger-bearded geek who makes do with a Vauxhall. Rather than the quality of an individual ad campaign, it is the growth of the advertising industry as an emblem of the changing industrial landscape that may have affected manufacturing fortunes.

It took one call last Tuesday from Zurich to make 2,200 jobs disappear in Luton. The day before, in the Midlands, 1,200 workers lost their jobs at the textiles maker formerly owned by Coats Viyella. Figures out last week show that 95,000 UK manufacturing jobs were lost between August and October.

Last week was truly dreadful for British manufacturing, but can and should anything be done about it?

Consider the process by which Vauxhall's parent company, General Motors, came to its decision, and the amount of non-manufacturing work used to reach it. Vauxhall employs a public relations firm to handle some of the flak over job losses. It asked management and strategy consultants which factories should go, and sought help from lawyers and human resources consultants over redundancy packages. It spends a fortune on marketing its cars. It put one in a giant fish tank at the Birmingham motor show and used the opening notes from Madonna's hit, 'Papa Don't Preach', for its commercials. And don't forget Griff.

The economics of the 'weightless' new industries are attractive - they are high margin, high added value, and relatively low cost. Their capital requirements are small, and there is no need for stock controls and inventories. The market for weightless products - despite cultural differences - is immediately and costlessly global, driving the returns on their production even higher.

Indeed, this shift is possible even within an industry. ARM Holdings, the darling of the UK new economy, designs blueprints for the core of a microchip, but licenses out these designs to its customers to manufacture. It has quickly established a global market and is profitable.

If higher returns are a carrot to move out of manufacturing, the stick is international trade. It is no coincidence that last week's major losses were in industries where global competition is strong.

The inevitability of this shift from manufacturing to services is factored into the Government's official projections of employment prospects.

By 2009 the Government expects some 670,000 manufacturing jobs to be lost, the lion's share in engineering. A third of all jobs in textiles and clothing will go over the next decade. But employment in business and miscellaneous services will increase by 1.9 million over this time.

These projections are a continuation of a trend seen over the past 30 years. In 1971 manufacturing accounted for 32 per cent of total employment, compared with 16 per cent in 1998. Conversely, business and miscellaneous services accounted for 12 per cent of all jobs in 1971, but 24 per cent in 1998.

The strong pound may have played a part in last week's losses, but their grim inevitability is driven by globalisation. It is ironic, then, that the Luton announcement came the day after the Government released a White Paper on this subject.

One section reads: 'The reality is that all profound economic change produces winners and losers. The role of government in these circumstances is to help manage the process of change - to maximise economic opportunities for all, and to equip people, through education and active labour market policies, to take advantage of these opportunities.'

The context was the world's poorest countries, but the words are just as applicable to Luton and Dagenham, and to Alfreton in Derbyshire, where the former Coats Viyella firm had a factory.

Indeed, even given public displays of regret, these shutdowns are fully in tune with government philosophy. Improving productivity has been the mantra of this administration. Workers at the Luton plant went some way to achieving this by making sacrifices on pay and conditions.

But this is not enough. Increasing productivity may be most closely understood as squeezing ever more production from labour and capital. But the easiest way to do this is to close down low-productivity plants and open new ones, or for firms to get out of old industries and enter 'new' ones - 'creative destruction', in the words of economist Joseph Schumpeter.

The macroeconomic story is exacerbated by the peculiarities of the industries involved. Overcapacity in the car industry is global. The world motor industry could make 75 million cars a year, yet it sells only 55 million. Western markets are now mature, and future demand will come from the Asia Pacific region and eastern Europe.

In the US, GM has scrapped its Oldsmobile brand, which is the equivalent of doing away with Vauxhall entirely.

Forget, if you like, that manufacturing cars is seen as a symbol of economic virility. The real point is that it's also an important employer, directly and indirectly.

Some US government analyses rank car manufacturing with computer and microchip production as 'high-tech'. The UK's record on high-specification car design is superb, but in manufacturing terms this country is now suffering from being a first mover with dated plant. Yet manufacturing is where the most employment is.

As for the manufacturing industries seamlessly converting into high-value, weightless industries, it's worth noting that the combined workforces of ARM, Bookham and Baltimore Technologies, all high-tech favourites, is less than those 2,200 jobs lost at Luton. These companies may be worth billions, but that is partly because they employ relatively few people.

The growth of the service sector masks two divergent trends. There is a cream of very well paid jobs in technology, the media, design and professional services. But there is considerably more work in leisure services. Hairdressers and fitness instructors are among the fastest-growing occupations.

In many ways Luton is luckier than most places, given its proximity to the economic powerhouses and labour demand of London and Silicon Fen, in and around Cambridge. The prospects for axed textile workers from the East Midlands are not as rosy. Former workers have already swamped IT retraining courses.

For governments, the only clear role is to smooth the passage of workers into other jobs through education. But we're back to the same problem. The strong performance of US productivity is ascribed to high-tech manufacturing, particularly in computers. And the evidence is that Britain's performance in this sector is suffering more.

The UK may well have the highest levels of inward investment in Europe, but this is partly a result of this country's flexible labour laws. For the car industry, and in particular the Vauxhall workers in Luton, it appears to have been a case of easy come, easy go.

fields.headline: Britain blocks workers' rights
fields.trailText: At the last moment, the British have managed to stall an EU employee rights directive forcing companies to consult their workers before mass redundancies - which would prevent another Luton-type shock.
fields.body:
At the last moment, the British have managed to stall an EU employee rights directive forcing companies to consult their workers before mass redundancies - which would prevent another Luton-type shock.

The directive was due to be voted through in Brussels this Wednesday but will now be postponed to the agenda of the next meeting of the Employment and Social Affairs Council, in January.

Britain has consistently been the most obstinate opponent of consolidating workers' rights - to information and consultation on redundancy, to workers' councils with statutory participation rights, and to consultation over hostile takeover bids for their firms.

No other EU member state, apart from Ireland, has taken such a hard line in defence of employer sovereignty and an uncontrolled takeover market.

German support enabled Britain to get the directive off Wednesday's agenda, where the British might have been outvoted under qualified majority voting, but there are signs that by January the Germans may revert to their traditional 'social partnership' line.

webTitle: If our car jobs are gone,  what's left?

fields.headline: If our car jobs are gone,  what's left?
fields.standfirst: A strong pound, old plant and overcapacity mean that Vauxhall's Luton closure is only the start, says  Joanna Walters
fields.trailText: Forget the pained expression on Vauxhall boss Nick Reilly's face as he was besieged outside his smart offices in Luton last week: he knew this was coming.
fields.body:
Forget the pained expression on Vauxhall boss Nick Reilly's face as he was besieged outside his smart offices in Luton last week: he knew this was coming.

As leaders of the GM Europe strategy board, based in Zurich, Reilly and General Motors Europe chief Mike Burns had been in a huddle for months.

Reilly tried to save his plant, but bowed to the inevitable when he could not make the figures add up. The Luton plant will stop making cars in 2002 after nearly a century, and 2,200 workers will lose their jobs.

Life in the car industry across Europe, but particularly in the UK, is tough and will get tougher. Profits are negligible, say industry analysts, and a downturn is on the way. There is no room for Mr Nice Guy. Making cars is not an industrial hobby.

GM has too many factories in Europe, making too many cars which sell at decreasing prices for paltry returns.

Something had to give. And, as so often with the UK remaining outside the euro and boasting of its ultra-flexible labour laws, it was Britain that paid the biggest price.

GM's British Vauxhall operation is the loser, and no amount of encouraging words will convince a startled workforce, angry unions and an emasculated Government that the brand's last stronghold, the Ellesmere Port plant on Merseyside, is safe.

Vauxhall sources were hinting last week that the signals of impending doom had long been there, and that the announcement of the end of production at Luton in 2002 should not have been the shock it was made out to be.

This is true up to a point.

GM has been struggling to find a solution to its overcapacity problem in Europe. The decision to close Luton and reduce some output in Germany will will cut capacity from 2.4 million cars a year to 2 million. It has been keen for Britain to join the euro and this country's failure to do so, or at least flag up its intention, has increased losses. The workforce thought it had a promise that Luton would build the next generation of Vectras. But promises count for nothing in the motor industry any more, if they ever did. One day's guarantee is a sell-out the next as vulnerable companies juggle with inefficiency, high costs and cutthroat competition.

Ask Rover and Ford, which have both been through crises this year in the UK.

Xavier Gunner, European automotive analyst at UBS Warburg, says: 'GM has been struggling. The writing has been on the wall for them to have to cut back.'

UBS Warburg is predicting that sales of new cars in Europe will drop by up to 5 per cent next year from this year's level of around 15 million. Prices will drop by an average of 4 per cent - a double whammy for manufacturers and dealers.

Ford has gone through a similar process in the past three years, but handled it rather differently.

It proposed to close its Halewood factory, on Merseyside, deciding not to use it to build the successor to the Escort model, the Focus. From next year a redesigned plant and retrained workforce will start turning out the new 'baby Jag', designed to compete with the BMW 3 series.

Meanwhile, earlier this year, Ford announced it would cease UK production of cars carrying its blue oval badge from next year, with the axe falling on the Fiesta line in Dagenham, east London.

But, unlike Vauxhall's bombshell news last week, Ford gave ever-stronger hints of its decision for months before the announcement, and last week revealed it is to invest £420 million on expanding diesel engine production at Dagenham.

But there will be no switches to more glamourous products, no state bail-outs and no consolation prizes for Luton. It may be slightly easier for its younger workers to find new jobs by commuting to Greater London, but the death of the town's industrial symbol is a body blow.

Luton is not classified as deprived by the European Union so, unlike Merseyside, it is not eligible for regional assistance grants from the Department of Trade and Industry.

When the Government can talk only about helping people find new jobs through 'packages' with desultory titles such as 'Learning for Life', you know it has lost the battle.

Luton has had its share of upheavals, pay disputes and retreats-from-the-brink in the past few years. No so. After further scrutiny of the marketplace, GM Europe decided not only that it had one factory too many, but that motorists were already buying fewer Vectra-sized cars - a trend that was likely to continue.

The Vectra has sold well, but the classic, middle-sized family car sector is estimated to have shrunk by around 20 per cent in the past two years. People are buying smaller, more efficient cars instead.

So the newly modernised GM plant in Germany will be the leading factory to make the next Vectra, though some overspill production may go to Ellesmere Port as production of the Astra, slows in three years' time and the new Vectra comes on stream.

Robert Hunt, automotive business recovery partner at accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers, says manufacturers in Europe made an average return of only 10 per cent for investors last year, compared with an average of 16 per cent among top UK industrial companies.

British car dealers have bombed in 2000, with losses on turnover of 15 per cent. Components suppliers lost around 7 per cent.

Hunt says: 'This is the stark reality. And Luton will not be the last car factory to close in Europe over the next few years - not by a long way.'

webTitle: Whither the factory workers in our brave new world?

fields.headline: Whither the factory workers in our brave new world?
fields.trailText: Lasdt week's sorry events in Luton served only to confirm my feeling that despite the armies of consultants employed on its behalf, business sadly lacks real public relations skills. Why announce the closure just before Christmas?
fields.body:
Lasdt week's sorry events in Luton served only to confirm my feeling that despite the armies of consultants employed on its behalf, business sadly lacks real public relations skills. Why announce the closure just before Christmas?

Unless, of course, General Motors was afraid that come January qualified majority voting in the Employment and Social Affairs Council of the European Union would have forced it to consult the workforce before wielding the axe.

It will be scant consolation to the Vauxhall employees, but at least they live in the generally prosperous south-east, where unemployment rates are low. Some of them will get new jobs.

But if you are a production line worker, the chance of finding a similar occupation is slight, and growing ever slighter. It is also unlikely that you are going to become a dotcom millionaire, or even work for one. For many the only realistic possibility must be labouring in a DIY warehouse or behind the counter in a supermarket petrol station. And although car workers are no longer the relatively rich artisans that they were back in the Seventies, they are certainly better paid than shop assistants.

Of course, some amount of occupational change is inevitable. Just as people left the land for the the factories, so they must adapt to the post-industrial revolution. But the low pay that characterises much of the burgeoning service sector is not the only problem with this progression.

There is also the fact that most of the manufacturing job losses come in places far removed from the vacancies of the Home Counties, where the property market is so buoyant that professionals such as teachers are being priced out. What chance of an unemployed textile worker from Derbyshire getting on her bike and finding affordable accommodation? And the state of our transport system hardly encourages long-distance commuting, even if it were financially viable.

The Government fought hard for Rover and even raised an eyebrow at Ford's Dagenham executions. But their lack of reaction to the Luton massacre suggests that ministers have given up trying to prevent closures. Presumably, therefore, they have some other strategy in mind to ease the UK's transition into the brave new world.

What could it be? There is increasing talk of encouraging more high-tech clusters outside the M4 corridor and Silicon Fen, but these tend to grow organically and, in any case, assisting their development would require much more regional accountability. Let's see the White Paper.

In the meantime, we know inward investment is fickle. Shouldn't we at least be voting in Europe to extend workers' protection, not attempting to block it?

fields.headline: A high-rolling Golden Mile
fields.standfirst: Urban renewal via gambling worked in Atlantic City - and it's now on the cards for decaying Blackpool, writes  Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: In winter, Blackpool is like a pantomime Dame without her face on. It has most life at weekends, when hen and stag party revellers stagger against driving wind and rain lashing in from the Irish Sea.
fields.body:
In winter, Blackpool is like a pantomime Dame without her face on. It has most life at weekends, when hen and stag party revellers stagger against driving wind and rain lashing in from the Irish Sea.

Punch-ups are as regular as a portion of chips. This is hardly surprising given that the dwindling number of funseeking visitors are greeted by an itinerant population whose male unemployment rate hits 50 per cent out of season. Mix that with the highest density of pubs and clubs in the country, and the result is often combustible.

But don't write Blackpool off. You'd be hard pressed to find a space in the North West more beautiful than the Tower Ballroom. On a Sunday morning, dedicated waltzers glide serenely through mock Belle Epoque splendour, seemingly oblivious to the decay outside.

But Blackpool could soon be dancing to a very different tune. The Government is anxious to claw back gambling revenue which over the past few years drifted offshore. So it is considering liberalising the gaming laws for the first time in more than 30 years - since gangland turf wars forced the authorities to crack down on dodgy dens.

Next June, the Gambling Review Body will decide on whether to recommend the introduction of 24-hour, instant-membership casinos and a less restrictive gaming tax regime. If they do, the Government will draft legislation. Currently if you want to play in a casino, you apply to one of the country's 120 casinos and wait a day to have membership confirmed.

A queue of operators - mindful that gambling in the UK has been legitimised by the National Lottery - are ready and waiting to spin a wheel at a venue near you.

But in Blackpool, one casino operator is laying 'siege' to a town hall desperate for inward investment. In 1998 Trevor Hemmings, who started working life as a bricklayer but is now one of Britain's richest men, bought Blackpool Tower and the faded Winter Gardens for £74 million from Michael Grade's First Leisure. Hemmings' vehicle, Leisure Parcs, has been consolidating its holdings in the town with major land purchases.

Last August, the company showed its hand. With the Government desperate to kick-start the regeneration of Britain's coastal resorts, Leisure Parcs unveiled a plan to create three casinos in Blackpool. Ultimately, the company says, Blackpool could have 12 hotel/casinos.

Hemmings' plan is being implemented by a 40-year-old former Center Parcs executive, Marc Etches, who has spent the past few months explaining his case to Tourism Minister Janet Anderson as well as Tory leader William Hague and assorted locals.

It was his idea to take a delegation of local businessmen, hotel representatives, council officials, leisure and gaming consultants and one national newspaper journalist on a week-long fact-finding investigation to the world's gambling capital, Las Vegas, and to Atlantic City, which has used gaming as a catalyst for urban regeneration. The trip was paid for by the Blackpool Challenge Partnership. How could I say 'No'?

'Margaritas by the yard,' deadpanned Nigel Hanson, Blackpool's town centre manager, referring to a casino poster. 'That's Blackpool.'

That's as close as it gets though. To Blackpool folk and to most outsiders, Vegas is Sin City - a jaw-dropping, mind-boggling, morality defying, architectural one-off in the Nevada desert. It's America's fastest-growing city, with a new home built every 15 minutes. Vegas is now poised to spill over into the hills which until now have enclosed it in a 450-square mile basin. But growth comes at a cost. Thanks to the exploding population, the Colorado River, on which Las Vegas, California, Arizona, Nevada and Colorado rely, is no longer flowing so fast into the Gulf of Mexico.

Once seedy, Vegas has reinvented itself: for the first time ever last year, convention income outstripped the £3 billion gained from gambling. As we learn from the Scorsese movie Casino, everyone in Vegas watches everyone else. Steve Ducharme, the state's chief law enforcer, confirmed that of 500 major casino cons each year, half involve the venue's own staff.

And though Vegas is desperate to appeal to the outsider, gambling appears to be part of the city's psyche. If you're a 'low-rolling Johnny Six-Pack', the place to go is Sunset Station in a down-at-heel residential area. On a Monday morning, the punters were all middle-aged women stuffing slot machines with dollars while a fortysomething woman smiled down from a poster proclaiming: 'I made Pay Day, Play Day.'

Blackpool was aghast. 'If I saw my old dear in there, I'd drag her out,' said Roy Fisher, Blackpool's deputy council leader. 'There's a crèche in there. You wouldn't want that for Blackpool. I find that abhorrent.' Heads nodded in agreement.

It was in Atlantic City that Blackpool officials found what they were looking for: a city which has used gambling as a catalyst for regeneration. Atlantic City (AC) used to be America's Blackpool. Last century, the railroads brought wagonloads of East Coast Americans here to experience 'vacations' for the first time. The place thrived.

'Like Blackpool, Atlantic City has always been a bit naughty,' explained AC's genial third-generation Irish Mayor, James Whelan. In a country where only Nevada had legal gambling until 1979, you could always get a bet down in AC. 'We made the mistake of prohibition in the US. It never came here. It was a rumour.'

But the growth of internal flights after 1945 dealt AC a body blow. Americans chose to visit Florida and California instead. AC refused to reinvest in itself. What finally did for the place was the 1964 Democratic Convention, where reporters brandished cockroaches found in hotels in front of cameras. AC became a standing joke - much like Blackpool after the 1998 Labour conference.

By 1979, casino gambling was legal in AC. For 10 years there was a gold rush. Property developers, including Donald Trump, bought up swathes of land and refused to develop them until they had sufficient investment, which in highly leveraged Trump's case was not often.

In 1990, after New Jersey granted the city 1.25 per cent of all gambling revenue, things began to move. Since then AC has invested in transport, high-quality affordable housing and a huge convention centre.

It was a visit to the AC Boys & Girls club which convinced the 'Blackpool posse' that gaming was legit.

A £3m investment from Park Place, one of the leading casinos, seemed to have paid dividends. Troubled youngsters were offered facilities that Blackpool folk could only dream of: a full-sized indoor basketball court, computer terminals, art facilities and pool and table tennis tables. At 5.45pm, when you'd expect youngsters to be tetchy, the kids were high spirited but well-behaved.

'This is what it's all about. How can you say gambling is bad when you see this,' said Josie Hammond of the Blackpool Hotel & Guest Association. 'Why shouldn't we have casinos? Betting shops and slot machines are everywhere and no one blinks an eye.'

But it wasn't all cherry pie. Atlantic City has moved a whole swathe of its troubled citizens out of the centre and dumped them in trailer parks hidden by trees on the side of a freeway. Nevertheless, overall Blackpool was impressed.

Assuming, as is widely expected, that the Gambling Review Body advocates a liberalisation of the gaming laws, it will be up to the Government to set the regulatory and tax framework. And here comes the rub. Blackpool wants gaming to be trialled in its town. This, they believe, will make Blackpool rich again. Blackpool also wants to get a slice of the tax to invest in its own people.

Without that, the town's councillors would probably reject casinos. And that seems fair enough. Why should money generated from such a controversial activity go elsewhere?

What Blackpool is asking for is unprecedented. But then so are resort casinos. The Government, and Blackpool, have an enormous decision to make.

Ultimately, what is sad is that only through gambling, a pastime that tends to make poor people poorer, can Blackpool hope to find a way to rejuvenate itself.

Hemmings' big gamble could land him the jackpot

The jackpot will be enormous for Trevor Hemmings if he succeeds in becoming the first owner of a Las Vegas-style British resort casino.

Tens of millions of pounds could roll into his company's coffers. Hemmings' initially wants to build a 500-room hotel with slot machines, roulette wheels and card tables under the working title of The Pharaoh's Palace. The plan is then to build another two casinos. Hemmings' people believe that ultimately Blackpool could take up to a dozen casinos, although town-planning chiefs are dubious.

Hemmings' assumption is understood to be that his £120 million casino investment could start to show a return within five years. The stakes are so high that Hemmings' organisation, Leisure Parcs, has put in place a supremely efficient lobbying machine, with down-to-earth likeable 40-year-old Marc Etches at its heart.

Etches, who next month will take a group of British MPs to Vegas and Atlantic City, is supremely well connected in both political and gaming circles.

He is on first-name terms with Tourism Minister, Janet Anderson and last month dined with Tory leader William Hague. Etches has invited on the fact-finding trip Peter Moore - the Northern Irish leisure consultant who ran the Alton Towers theme park and Center Parcs - the Nineties equivalent of Butlins for the keep-fit generation.

Moore, who worked with Etches at Center Parcs, also chairs a government taskforce charged with reviving British coastal resorts.

Leisure Parcs is closely associated with London Clubs International, the UK-quoted casino operator. London Clubs employs as a consultant Bill Galston - a former chief inspector for the Gaming Board.

For Hemmings, casinos represent a slice of a gambling empire that includes the Littlewoods pool business and six racecourses. Hemmings is also in the Go Racing consortium with BSkyB and Channel 4, which is bidding to broadcast horseracing in the UK.

Ultimately, what is sad is that only through gambling, a pastime that tends to make poor people poorer, can Blackpool hope to find a way to rejuvenate itself. Hemmings' big gamble could land him the jackpot The jackpot will be enormous for Trevor Hemmings if he succeeds in becoming the first owner of a Las Vegas-style British resort casino. Tens of millions of pounds could roll into his company's coffers. Hemmings' initially wants to build a 500-room hotel with slot machines, roulette wheels and card tables under the working title of The Pharaoh's Palace. The plan is then to build another two casinos. Hemmings' people believe that ultimately Blackpool could take up to a dozen casinos, although town-planning chiefs are dubious. Hemmings' assumption is understood to be that his £120 million casino investment could start to show a return within five years. The stakes are so high that Hemmings' organisation, Leisure Parcs, has put in place a supremely efficient lobbying machine, with down-to-earth likeable 40-year-old Marc Etches at its heart. Etches, who next month will take a group of British MPs to Vegas and Atlantic City, is supremely well connected in both political and gaming circles. He is on first-name terms with Tourism Minister, Janet Anderson and last month dined with Tory leader William Hague. Etches has invited on the fact-finding trip Peter Moore - the Northern Irish leisure consultant who ran the Alton Towers theme park and Center Parcs - the Nineties equivalent of Butlins for the keep-fit generation. Moore, who worked with Etches at Center Parcs, also chairs a government taskforce charged with reviving British coastal resorts. Leisure Parcs is closely associated with London Clubs International, the UK-quoted casino operator. London Clubs employs as a consultant Bill Galston - a former chief inspector for the Gaming Board. For Hemmings, casinos represent a slice of a gambling empire that includes the Littlewoods pool business and six racecourses. Hemmings is also in the Go Racing consortium with BSkyB and Channel 4, which is bidding to broadcast horseracing in the UK.

webTitle: Santa Claus isn't coming to town. Can't get a train, dear

fields.headline: Santa Claus isn't coming to town. Can't get a train, dear
fields.trailText: Leading retailers in London are facing a disastrous Christmas as transport chaos forces shoppers to abandon the capital's shops.
fields.body:
Leading retailers in London are facing a disastrous Christmas as transport chaos forces shoppers to abandon the capital's shops.

The British Retail Consortium and City analysts have told The Observer that the crucial festive trading period could see a fall in sales in many department stores.

'Our members are the biggest retailers in the country, and they're saying that travel disruption is causing people to shop locally,' said BRC director, Pam Webber.

'It's impacting on lunchtime trade in the West End, because if people arrive 45 minutes late in the office, they feel compelled to stay there all day. Oxford Street in previous years had mounted police telling people to say on the pavements. That's just not happening this year.'

Matthew McEachran, Henderson Investec's retail analyst, said shopping centres in the regions were faring much better: 'Greater London and the South East have been weak. Commuters aren't spending an hour after work shopping. Any London-bias retailer is under pressure.'

Slack sales have forced even upmarket retailers to start sales early. Asprey & Garrard, the Bond Street jeweller, has launched an unprecedented pre-Christmas clear-out. The company, which was bought this year by Tommy Hilfiger's co-chairmen, said the sale was part of a 'rebranding exercise'.

News of a bleak Christmas seemed to be supported by John Lewis, which last Friday said its department stores' sales were down 0.6 per cent compared with the same week last year. And it is understood that Marks & Spencer is continuing to endure disappointing clothing sales. Trade sources believe that last week, M&S menswear sales were down 13 per cent on last year.

'The impression we're getting is that there's not a boom out there,' said Clive Vaughan of consultancy Retail Intelligence. 'There's a lot of discounting and there seems to be general unease.'

Flat sales contradict last week's better-than-expected National Statistics retail figures for November, which showed sales volumes in clothing and footwear rising 10.6 per cent in the period from September to November against last year.

webTitle: Diageo to auction Martell after $8bn Seagram deal

fields.headline: Diageo to auction Martell after $8bn Seagram deal
fields.trailText: Diageo and Pernod Ricard are set to put Martell brandy up for auction 'within days', if they clinch their expected $8.2billion takeover of Seagram's drinks division this week.
fields.body:
Diageo and Pernod Ricard are set to put Martell brandy up for auction 'within days', if they clinch their expected $8.2billion takeover of Seagram's drinks division this week.

Remy Cointreau and Bacardi have already made approaches over the brand, one of Seagram's top 10 sellers, industry sources say.

This weekend Diageo and Pernod are locked in lastminute negotiations in New York with Seagram's adviser, Morgan Stanley. The Anglo-French consortium had expected to sign a deal today and make an announcement tomorrow morning, but this may now be delayed slightly.

Last week, Britain's Allied Domecq pulled out of the race by failing to table a bid by last Monday's deadline. An offer by the third runner - a consortium of Bacardi, Brown Forman of the US and Sweden's Vin & Sprit - is understood to have been for less than $8bn.

A successful deal will see Pernod-Ricard challenging Allied Domecq closely for second place behind Diageo in the world spirits industry.

'Allied's biggest failure was not to recruit a partner. Without that, this was a deal it could not afford to do,' one source close to Seagram said.

Diageo is interested in Seagram's Captain Morgan rum, its Crown Royal and VO Canadian whiskies, its American whiskey 7 Crown and its vineyards. Pernod-Ricard's focus is the firm's Scotch whiskies - including Chivas Regal and Glenlivet - and Seagram's Gin.

This weekend, Allied Domecq promised Diageo a bitter fight for Captain Morgan. It claims it has pre-emptive rights over the brand following a deal with the rum's producer Destilería Serralles of Puerto Rico. A lawsuit is now scheduled for early next year in a US Federal court.

webTitle: London Clubs 'up for grabs' as profits slump

fields.headline: London Clubs 'up for grabs' as profits slump
fields.trailText: London Clubs International, the UK's leading casino operator, is 'in play' according to one of its leading shareholders.
fields.body:
London Clubs International, the UK's leading casino operator, is 'in play' according to one of its leading shareholders.

The company, which last Friday saw a staggering 42 per cent wiped off its share price, could be bought by either leisure group Rank or Gala, the bingo operator. One leading institutional shareholder told The Observer: 'The company is all up for grabs.'

Investors in LCI are concerned that LCI's overseas casino exposure is draining it of resources. Last Friday, the company, chaired by Alan Goodenough, posted half-time results showing that pre-tax profits had slumped by £7.9 million to £800,000.

This drop was caused partly by a £2.5 million operating loss at its Las Vegas casino, the Aladdin. Last August, LCI became the first British company to open a casino on the cutthroat Las Vegas strip. But sources have revealed that LCI has had to pump more finance in to the 2,100-bed luxury hotel and casino after pre-opening expenses rose dramatically. LCI is now looking to sell up to half of its 50 per cent share in the Aladdin.

Last week, the company revealed that it had to persuade its bankers to relax 'financial covenants'.

Industry sources believe Rank is monitoring LCI closely. The company, run by former Ladbrokes executive Mike Smith, was not available for comment.

In the past year Rank has sold Butlins, the Pinewood film studios, Tom Cobleigh pubs and 50 per cent of the Universal Studios theme park in Florida in order to concentrate on bingo and casinos.

Gala, the private bingo operator currently poised to buy Ladbrokes casinos from Hilton, has also been identified as a contender for LCI. 'It's the next logical step for them after the Ladbrokes casinos,' said one insider.

Institutional shareholders will be looking for a bid at over 100p, valuing the company at more than £150m. LCI shares closed last Friday at 58.5p.

LCI's disastrous results were also affected by a downturn in revenues in its Egyptian casino, caused by unrest in the Middle East. In London, revenues are down because of 'win levels significantly ahead of the same period last year'.

But casino operators are due a fillip if, as is widely expected, the Gaming Review Body liberalises the gaming laws in this country.

fields.headline: The Herbert Hoover factor
fields.trailText: There was a character in a Peter de Vries novel who operated on the Chicago exchange and the stocks he recommended were known as 'laughing stocks'.
fields.body:
There was a character in a Peter de Vries novel who operated on the Chicago exchange and the stocks he recommended were known as 'laughing stocks'.

This year there has been no shortage of laughing stocks as the South Sea bubble in new technology has met its inevitable fate. The prospect of the 'bust' which may follow the prolonged US boom has even prompted one leading City commentator, my old friend Christopher Fildes, to suggest that Herbert Hoover should have demanded a recount.

This, to my mind, is one of the best jokes to have emerged from the fracas of the US election, but it probably needs a little explanation for younger readers. Herbert Hoover was the unfortunate Republican who happened to be president of the US between 1929 and 1933, the years of the Wall Street Crash and the Great Depression. Output fell by a third during that period. It was not a good time to be president. The Democrat Franklin D. Roosevelt, president from 1933-45, presided over the recovery and the New Deal (not Gordon Brown's version) and secured a rather better place in history.

The tactics the Bush clan resorted to in order to inherit fall-out from the Clinton/Greenspan economic miracle would have done credit to Lady Macbeth. A weird dynastic form of revenge has been wreaked by what is already being referred to as 'the second Bush administration.' The Bush clan never forgave President Clinton and Vice-President Gore for gaining the credit for an economic recovery that was not noticed until after the 1992 presidential election. Bush's 'watch my lips - no new taxes' gave way to Clinton's 'it's the economy, stupid'.

Revenge it is. Many of the old Reagan/Bush favourites, such as James Baker III have reappeared on the stage, giving the impression that George W is merely the front man for the dynasty's return. These people, after all, are the American version of the British aristocrats who used to regard it as their right to run the country. Even the Founding Fathers were distrustful of the popular vote. As Justice Scalia said in one of the more revealing admissions of recent days, a recount might cast 'a cloud' over what Bush 'claims to be the legitimacy of his election.'

The whole business has, of course, cast a cloud over the legitimacy not only of the US democratic process itself, but of the presumption - which has operated since the second world war - that the US has the right to persuade other countries to approximate as closely as possible to its form of 'democratic capitalism'. Democracy comes from the Greek, and one is reminded that the Greeks had other words for this kind of thing. The Ralph Naders of this world never get very far in US politics. The US is a pluto-democracy - a democracy in which the rich and powerful compete for office, and the 'transition' to office, not to say office itself, sees a lot of campaign debts being honoured.

The most obvious economic consequence of the election is that these are 'oil men'. They want further exploration in Alaska and elsewhere; they are not too interested in energy conservation or any of that wet liberal stuff.

But what about the Herbert Hoover factor? It has now been generally recognised that the US boom is not going to go on at the frenetic pace which persuaded some commentators to fantasise about a 'new economy' that rendered previous history, as Henry Ford once observed, 'more or less bunk'.

But the shameless speed with which the Republicans-in-waiting have suddenly discovered a 'recession' is breathtaking. The US economy is not in recession yet. It has slowed down to a pace that may or may not prove to be more sustainable. History suggests that it could well enter a recession. Daily there is news of the collapse of profit forecasts and the kind of financial and banking scares which follow any unsustainable boom. The thing about unsustainable booms is that the devious and the gullible make wild calculations about the money they can make if the unsustainable is, against all the odds, miraculously sustained.

Faced with suggestions that their plans for massive 'supply-side' tax cuts ('supply-side' means they principally benefit the rich) may be gridlocked in a sour Congress, the Bush team have swiftly rediscovered 'Keynesian'-style tax cuts; they are now trying to justify their plans on the grounds that they are needed to avert recession.

We shall see. The interesting thing is that, call it Keynesian or what you will, the management of demand in the economy is very much back in fashion, both in the US and Europe. Usually this is done via monetary policy. Fiscal policy - alterations in tax and spending plans to influence the economic cycle - used once upon a time to be a staple feature of US economic textbooks. But since Congress often takes all year to agree - or not agree - the Budget, monetary policy is a more effective weapon in the US. In Britain by contrast, there is nothing other than dogma to prevent a powerful Chancellor from making far more use of fiscal policy than is fashionable.

The brief of the US Federal Reserve is to stabilise the economy - and, de facto, the financial system - but not the stock market. Rash market operators expecting to be bailed out by the Fed during a slowdown or recession may be disappointed. Many things have been learned by policymakers since the Herbert Hoover presidency. Nevertheless, the business cycle has not been abolished, and it looks as though there are rough times ahead.

Meanwhile, in a salutary reminder of US economic dominance, the Financial Times /PriceWaterhouseCoopers survey of 'the world's most respected organisations' puts eight US companies in the top 10 (led by General Electric and Microsoft), with the other two being Japanese (Sony and Toyota) and Europe an 'also ran'.

My father would have asked: 'Respected by whom?' Well, the 720 chief executives who seem to run George W Bush and the 'globalised' world, as a matter of fact.

webTitle: UK bids surge above £100bn as Lloyds toys with Abbey

fields.headline: UK bids surge above £100bn as Lloyds toys with Abbey
fields.trailText: The millennium year looks set to go down on record as the second most active ever for takeovers of UK publicly quoted companies.
fields.body:
The millennium year looks set to go down on record as the second most active ever for takeovers of UK publicly quoted companies.

With bids worth £118 billion completed or announced so far, only 1999 - with a staggering £168bn - was busier.

For City merchant bankers, millions of pounds in bonuses are now riding on a formal £18bn bid battle for Abbey National breaking out before the new year between Lloyds TSB and Bank of Scotland .

Such hostilities would not only line the financiers' pockets; with no fewer than seven of the City's top banks involved, they would also affect bankers' much-prized positions in the annual takeover league tables.

So far this year, US bank JP Morgan heads the fray, involved in deals worth £82bn. Dresdner Kleinwort Benson is close behind with £81bn. Both have leapfrogged Wall Street rivals Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, which came first and second in the UK and globally last year.

The bank with most to lose from the tussle for Abbey is the mighty Goldman Sachs, which has failed to land an advisory role. A three-way bid would see it slide down the UK league tables to an ignominious seventh place.

As Lloyds TSB, Abbey and BoS continue to play cat and mouse, however, that looks unlikely. Last week, Abbey rejected Lloyds TSB's latest £18.6bn informal offer, but failed to unveil its planned deal with BoS.

Instead, Abbey and BoS will this week lodge their plans with regulators, kicking off a 35-day timetable for expected clearance of the deal. Banking sources said Lloyds would do the same. 'All the action's now likely to take place after Christmas and New Year,' one added.

webTitle: Money writes: Computer firm blames glitch on... its computers

fields.headline: Computer firm blames glitch on... its computers
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
I bought a computer from Time in January on a year's interest-free credit with Nova Finance. I have telephoned Nova repeatedly about the payment, due on 4 January, but they claim not to have my name and details and cannot tell me where to send the money.

Time said to send a cheque to them but I am not confident that, if I do this, my agreement with Nova will be cancelled.

I am an upright citizen and do not relish being threatened with a bad debt register because no one will take responsibility for my payment.
AA, Glasgow

You are right to worry. Other readers have been caught by interest charges when trying unsuccessfully to settle loans after free credit.

Nova has now found your application but says the credit has not been set up because Time did not forward the agreement. Apparently, you are not the only customer affected. So you owe nothing to Nova and it cannot charge interest if you fail to pay by 4 January. But you still have to pay for the computer.

Nova has now agreed to make you a customer at this late stage, although you need to pay promptly to avoid interest. This is a safer way of settling your debt than sending a cheque to Time.

Time says it has bought a new IT system and does not expect this problem to recur.

Shifty surveyor: £10,000 bill

I found a run-down property to buy through a scheme advertised in a local newspaper. The person operating the scheme paid £40,000 for the house, organised a mortgage, hired builders and sold it to me for £50,000.

The building society retained £6,000, payable on completion of work demanded by its surveyor. Eventually, he approved the completed works and the remaining money was issued. I became suspicious about the surveyor's report when I discovered he had been accompanied on his visit by the vendor and that some of the work had not been done at all.

When I complained, the society sent the same man back to check. Privately, he admitted he had taken the vendor's word that the work had been done.

The Building Societies' Ombudsman says I am at fault for paying the vendor, even though I did so only because the society said the work had been done satisfactorily. I believe the surveyor misled both his employer and me as to the true state of the house. I am having to fund the necessary work myself with a further loan of £10,000.
DT, Saddleworth

Normally, ombudsmen will not re-open a file without new evidence, but I pointed out he had not seen information in your solicitor's file which, you claim, includes a forged signature. The new ombudsman for building societies took another look at your case, but backed the original decision. He says they knew of the solicitor's file.

He believes the society was not at fault, although you still argue it should be responsible for its employee's work.

You have one fight with the builder about the quality of his work and another with the surveyor who, you believe, acted unprofessionally. Your only recourse now is to the courts. You might find a no win, no fee solicitor who will take your case.

Insurance error: Bill £38 too high

On the phone, 1st Quote offered my son car insurance for £303, but he had to wait for me to come home to use my credit card. We agreed to pay an extra £12 to remove the excess and discussed, but rejected, legal expenses insurance, making the bill £315.

Yet my Visa bill showed two withdrawals by 1st Quote, for £343 and £10 - £38 too much. A 1st Quote supervisor implied I was making it all up and that the sales person could not have keyed in the wrong figures.
MR, Swansea

1st Quote is confused by your son's file which confirm he was quoted £303 but, without explanation, also shows he was charged £343. If you had been billed for legal expenses insurance, this should be shown separately, but the firm admits £343 is the price it would be. It cannot explain the £12 figure because apparently you paid £10 for excess protection. 1st Quote is refunding the amount overcharged.

I applied by phone for a Capital One Bank Platinum Visa card but they sent me a standard card, saying I did not have a big enough credit limit to qualify for the Platinum card.

The Benefits Office wrote to tell me of 'a change to my contributions' four years after my pension started, and it is being cut by 8 per cent, a significant amount. Why has it taken them so long to find out?

You could be a victim of the notorious Department of Social Security computer that has given so much trouble. You should ask for a detailed explanation and for confirmation that you can keep the over-payment.

Time said to send a cheque to them but I am not confident that, if I do this, my agreement with Nova will be cancelled. I am an upright citizen and do not relish being threatened with a bad debt register because no one will take responsibility for my payment. AA, Glasgow You are right to worry. Other readers have been caught by interest charges when trying unsuccessfully to settle loans after free credit. Nova has now found your application but says the credit has not been set up because Time did not forward the agreement. Apparently, you are not the only customer affected. So you owe nothing to Nova and it cannot charge interest if you fail to pay by 4 January. But you still have to pay for the computer. Nova has now agreed to make you a customer at this late stage, although you need to pay promptly to avoid interest. This is a safer way of settling your debt than sending a cheque to Time. fields.headline: No Vauxhall plant is safe
fields.standfirst: Ellesmere Port factory 'at risk of closure'  Union set to sue GM over 'illegal' axe for Luton
fields.trailText: Vauxhall's entire UK operations are in the balance this weekend after the head of the company failed to pledge that its Ellesmere Port factory will survive once the Luton plant shuts.
fields.body:
Vauxhall's entire UK operations are in the balance this weekend after the head of the company failed to pledge that its Ellesmere Port factory will survive once the Luton plant shuts.

Unions are considering suing Vauxhall and taking its US parent General Motors to the European Court for refusing to consult workers over the Luton decision.

And The Observer has learnt that the Ellesmere Port plant on Merseyside is on a list, handed by the unions to the Government earlier this year, of factories believed to be seriously 'at risk of closure'.

Luton was not on the list, and had been thought relatively safe, as it had been earmarked to build the next version of the Vectra car in 2002.

Then came the shock announcement last week - that 2,000 workers will lose their jobs when the factory effectively closes in 2002.

Transport & General Workers Union general secretary Bill Morris will meet the president of GM Europe, Michael Burns, early in January. Morris could call for international strike action across Europe.

Nick Reilly, chairman of Vauxhall, told The Observer he was unlikely to reverse the decision: 'The case is unfortunately pretty overwhelming.'

Vauxhall made a profit of £120 million last year, but the figure is set to be 'much lower' this year. The Luton plant is losing money on each car made, but Reilly said productivity improvements by the workers alone could not solve the problem.

GM will decide next year where to build the next Astra from 2004. The current model is produced at Ellesmere Port.

Reilly said: 'Nothing is ever guaranteed in this life, but we share with our people what we are planning, and if circumstances do not change dramatically this [the new Astra] is what will happen. We fully expect to get the new Astra into Ellesmere Port.'

Those words will ring hollow with Vauxhall workers, who heard the news of Luton's demise on the radio. Reilly admitted he had told neither the unions nor the Government that the factory was facing closure until the decision had been made.

The TGWU's chief motor industry negotiator, Tony Woodley, this weekend expressed fears for Ellesmere Port after what he condemned as 'no more than half-hearted promises'.

'The fabric of this giant company will be in jeopardy with only one plant to support it in future,' he said.

The TGWU believes GM has broken a European Union law obliging it to consult workers' representative councils before making job cuts.

Woodley said: 'This is the worst face of globalisation - a giant US company breaking European law, sacking people, closing plants and devastating communities. I want to know why Trade Secretary Stephen Byers and the rest of the Government have not condemned this disgraceful decision.'

Reilly refused to blame the Luton decision or the uncertainty over Ellesmere Port directly on Britain's reluctance to commit to the euro, despite his pro-Europe stance and his position as head of the Confederation of British Industry's economics committee.

But he did say: 'There is a question mark and a risk factor in our [financial] projections that we would not have if we were in the euro or knew we were going in.'

fields.headline: Coining it, thanks to toad god
fields.standfirst: Feng Shui can make you (a bit) rich, Sarah Shurety tells Natalie Sutton
fields.trailText: Feng Shui can make you (a bit) rich, Sarah Shurety tells Natalie Sutton.
fields.body:
Sarah Shurety relies on more than just her bank manager's advice on looking after her money. The leading Feng Shui consultant keeps her funds in the bank, but ensures her prosperity by less conventional means.

Sarah has advised many large City institutions on designing their offices for financial health according to the principles of Feng Shui. The term means 'wind and water' and includes Japanese and Indian philosophies, Buddhist teachings, astrology, plus the Chinese teaching of placement: modifying your surroundings for health, wealth and happiness.

She practises what she preaches: 'Nearly two years ago I felt I needed a change for the sake of my finances. I had to move in a south-easterly direction, but as I lived in Greenwich such a move would have taken me further out of London, and that wasn't what I wanted. I therefore had to move to Maida Vale for 10 months - it takes six months for energy to settle - before moving in my south-easterly direction to Westminster.'

It was essential for Sarah to find a correctly-shaped home with a front door facing her 'millionaire's direction'. Eventually she found a flat that looked promising. It was in a block whose communal front door faced the right way, but Sarah had to make do with her own front door facing south-west. But as this is her 'personal development direction', it was a fair compromise.

When an important financial event is taking place, such as a meeting with financiers, Sarah leaves a statue of a three-legged toad god sitting on 12 ancient Chinese coins in her office, with another coin in its mouth. This is said to create extra energy, enhancing her chances of success.

Sarah's purse is green - representing fertility and growth - and contains three Chinese coins tied with a red ribbon to protect the bearer.

Despite her obvious success and prosperity, however, Sarah stresses: 'If you set yourself up above everyone else, someone will try and knock you down. You have to do many good deeds so positive vibes are sent back towards you.' So she gives to charity fairly regularly.

Too much wealth would go against the Feng Shui aim of minimalism: 'More wealth, less health,' goes the proverb. Sarah doesn't believe in borrowing. Luckily she has no need for an overdraft as, she says, she is successfully guided in investment and business by the date, the stars and the Chinese New Year.

Savings are anathema to her: 'You come into the world with nothing and you leave with nothing.' she says. She has no dependants and modest needs.

She hopes to move to a hot country when she is 50, and doesn't want to own too much 'stuff'. 'The more you have, the less you can move.'

She believes a person's vocation and career are most important, and from this comes financial stability. For those who are sceptical about such beliefs, Sarah's attitude is simple. 'The healthiest way to approach life is with an open mind,' she says, smiling.

Everything which the Chinese calendar said would happen to her has done so.

 'Quick Feng Shui Cures' by Sarah Shurety, Rider, £17.99. Details of her consultancies are available online at www.fengshuisite.com

webTitle: Try telling farmers that spending £20 million on an office is a good idea

fields.headline: Try telling farmers that spending £20 million on an office is a good idea
fields.trailText: Farmers are engaged in a serious bout of mud-slinging over their union's move to buy a £20 million prime office block on Shaftesbury Avenue, the heart of 'theatreland' in central London, writes Nick Mathiason .
fields.body:
Farmers are engaged in a serious bout of mud-slinging over their union's move to buy a £20 million prime office block on Shaftesbury Avenue, the heart of 'theatreland' in central London, writes Nick Mathiason .

The National Farmers' Union has just bought its headquarters building from P&O. Many farmers are furious that, when they are experiencing the worst recession since the Thirties, their union is splashing out millions on an office.

Tenant farmer Wyndham Tranter, of Raglan in South Wales was forced to sell his farm in October, saying: 'Why should I be forced to work 100 hours a week for nothing?'

One NFU insider conceded that buying the office may look 'politically insensitive' but the union had the chance to make a 'sound investment for the future'. And the NFU had to act because its lease was about to run out.

The 120,000-strong farmers' union has made cuts in recent years as farmers' subscriptions tailed off.

webTitle: Web watch: Dare you take risks this high?

fields.headline: Dare you take risks this high?
fields.trailText: Internet trading - with its huge range of websites - has exposed investors to some of the world's riskiest investments.
fields.body:
Even telephone share dealing limited most investors wanting to dabble on the stock market to UK stocks and shares. But Internet trading - with its huge range of websites - has exposed them to some of the world's riskiest investments.

So what is there for those who feel the ups and downs of the FTSE All Share are just too tame?

Foreign markets

Several online brokers deal in foreign equities, although most stick to the US markets. DLJ Direct charges $20 for deals involving up to 1,000 shares in companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq, and 2 cents per share.

Investors wanting to trade in American shares must open a US dollar account to protect them against swings in currency values. MyBroker buys and sells US shares for a flat commission of $15.95 per deal. Customers are offered a multi-currency account, allowing them to trade in dollars and sterling.

Brunswick Direct claims to be the world's first online brokerage for emerging markets. Through its website, investors can buy shares in individual companies from 22 countries, including: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Israel, Mexico, Peru, Poland, Russia, South Africa, Venezuela, China, Hong Kong, India, the Phillippines and Taiwan.

There is no minimum size for deals, but you need $2,000 to open an account. The flat-rate fee is 0.75 per cent (minimum $50).

Options

Learn about buying and selling options - which each give you the right, but not the obligation, to trade in 1,000 shares - from a day trader who has played the Dax market in Frankfurt for 10 years.

Duncan Robertson, who trades online from his croft on the Isle of Skye, teaches two-week seminars for 10 people at a time, charging them £5,000 each. He promises you will come away with 'a total understanding of what you need to do to make a success of speculating on price differences'.

You will need about another £10,000 to get started - £2,000 for a live data feed, £2,500 for real time charting software and about £5,000 as trading capital. Details are on his site, learntotradefutures.com.

Once you can tell your futures from your options, you will need a broker that enables you to deal in them. Mybroker is probably cheapest, with a flat fee of £15 per trade (UK options only). InvestIn enables investors to trade in US options for $25 per deal, plus $1.75 for each further option

To trade you must open a US dollar margin, or debt, account with $2,000 and be assessed by a 'registered options principal' to make sure you are sufficiently sophisticated to cope with this risky form of trading.

Trades through InvestIn are now placed through a market maker, but the broker plans to enable investors to place their own deals directly on the market next year.

New share issues

Companies are under no obligation to offer new share issues to the public, and most find it cheaper, safer and easier to place new shares directly with institutional investors. However, several sites now offer access to new issues, particularly initial public offers (known as IPOs, where a previously privately-owned company offers shares for the first time). Investors incur no broking charges when buying new shares, and those offered through IPOs are usually 'under-priced' to ensure success.

However, IPOs often involve small companies, whose performance can be volatile, and as investors in Lastminute.com discovered, returns are not guaranteed.

Webshareshop specialises in information, prospectuses and applications for new issues. Registering is free, but the site does not offer brokering services, so you will have to go elsewhere to sell stocks on.

Interactive Investor International also provides information and analysis, and runs a chat room so you can discuss your successes, failures and tips with other investors. Again, registration is free, and it does offer stockbroking services. Other sites include www.stockacademy.com, www.peelhuntadvantage.com and www.nothingventured.com. The latter two have only details of IPOs that Peel Hunt and Durlacher are sponsoring. Both charge £50 to register.

webTitle: Help - my financial adviser's gone out of business

fields.headline: Help - my financial adviser's gone out of business
fields.trailText: Homeowners who suspect they were mis-sold endowment policies can make a complaint; and some may win compensation.
fields.body:
Homeowners who suspect they were mis-sold endowment policies can make a complaint; and some may win compensation. Address your complaint to whoever sold you the policy - insurance company salesman or financial adviser. If that gets you nowhere, you can go to the Financial Ombudsman Service.

But if the financial adviser is no longer in business, you have a problem. The Ombudsman can deal with complaints only about firms that are still trading.

You have to find the original adviser. If he or she worked for a limited company which is still operating, the firm is liable. If not, contact the Financial Services Authority Helpline. Staff there will check if the firm has been taken over by another which can pick up the pieces.

If the company has gone bust, or you dealt with a sole trader or partnership that is now insolvent, the Investors Compensation Scheme (ICS) can help.

The ICS has different rules from the Ombudsman but in practice its remit is similar: you have to show that you were given bad advice to buy an endowment and that you have actually lost money. You cannot complain about poor investment performance.

The ICS checks that the firm is insolvent, looking at the personal assets of a sole trader or each partner in a partnership, because they are still all liable. All their assets are vulnerable, including houses, cars and other businesses. If they have insufficient assets to meet a claim, the ICS declares the trader or firm in default, even if the firm no longer exists.

If the trader or partners do not have assets, the ICS cannot investigate - and you are on your own. ICS pays compensation only if the firm that gave the advice cannot. If the firm is solvent or the individual has assets, the ICS tells you to contact the person yourself. If the ex-adviser refuses to co-operate, as is most likely, your only remedy is through the courts.

ICS investor helpline 020 7367 6000 or www.the-ics.org.uk; Financial Ombudsman Service 020 7964 1000 or www.financial-ombudsman.org.uk.

If the trader or partners do not have assets, the ICS cannot investigate - and you are on your own. ICS pays compensation only if the firm that gave the advice cannot. If the firm is solvent or the individual has assets, the ICS tells you to contact the person yourself. If the ex-adviser refuses to co-operate, as is most likely, your only remedy is through the courts.
