webTitle: Property: 'Tis the season to be buying - and selling

fields.headline: 'Tis the season to be buying - and selling
fields.standfirst: Deck the halls with For Sale signs. Graham Norwood tells some moving Christmas stories
fields.trailText: Deck the halls with For Sale signs. Graham Norwood tells some moving Christmas stories.
fields.body:
On the first day of Christmas... you wouldn't want to buy a house, would you?

Nevertheless, despite a quiet autumn, the year looks set to end with more than 1,000 house sales worth £1 million or over, and house price inflation of around 9 per cent across the country, according to the Nationwide building society. And the market is getting unexpectedly busier as the holiday approaches.

'In the past people always looked for a reason not to buy, or to put off the process, and Christmas was the best excuse of all,' says David Forbes of estate agency Chesterfield. 'These days they realise procrastination can cost money, so they are prepared to bite the bullet.'

Peter Rollings of London agency Foxtons agrees: 'Recent weeks have been extraordinarily busy. It's been like a return to the busiest weeks of the spring, with more people wanting to know what's on the market.'

In London and the Home Counties, agents are preparing for the City bonus rush immediately after the holiday. In January-March this year, 30 per cent of all house purchases above £500,000 in that part of the country involved buyers working in the financial sector, according to agency Knight Frank. In 2000 some 950 City workers received bonuses of £500,000 or more. A similar surge into the property market is expected in early 2001.

For those wanting to get in before the rush, though, Yuletide is a trivial distraction. Sometimes it is the estate agents who, uncharacteristically, are turning away business from customers who want to ignore Christmas. You can end up feeling positively sorry for some of these people.

The last-minute buyer

'Last Christmas Eve I had a very keen buyer and seller desperate to agree a deal on a £2m house in Chelsea,' recalls Johnny Fuller of Chesterfields. 'They were still haggling at 9pm as I was on my mobile driving to my father's in Winchester,' he says. In a rare example of an estate agent electing not to close a deal, Fuller switched off his mobile on Christmas Day, and the pair agreed a price later than they wanted.

Christmas is about sharing

Just before Christmas 1998 Rebecca Read of Cluttons had a client selling in central London's Eaton Square. The seller said she could not complete until December 29, but the buyer wanted to be in before Christmas Day.

The solution? 'The purchaser moved in a week before Christmas and they lived together for a fortnight,' says Read.

Give yourself a surprise present

David Forbes of Chesterfields went into his office on 27 December 1998 to catch up on paperwork only to be disturbed by an American who had stumbled out of a restaurant, tired and emotional after a good lunch.

'In between hiccups he told me he wanted to buy a home, and could he look at them right now,' he recalls. 'I took him on a tour of three properties, he made an offer and they exchanged within 48 hours on a house worth £3m.'

Offer someone a home this Christmas

In the early Nineties Chard estate agent Gail Clark was checking a flat on Boxing Day for a tenant to move in the next day, and found it had been burgled. The thief had stolen minor electrical items, put cigarette burns in the carpets and smeared some of his McDonald's dinner over the furniture.

'I had to clean the flat from top to bottom, find a glazier prepared to come out on Boxing Day, buy replacement items, patch the ciga rette burns by sticking spare carpet over them, and wash the sofa covers,' she says. 'The tenant moved in happily on December 27, not realising how I had spent my Boxing Day.'

Make an estate agent happy

That is what Charles and Ann Wood have done - but they won a Christmas bonus into the bargain. 'Our new house in Pontefract was completed on 3 November, and the developer and estate agent wanted to get it off their books before Christmas,' says Mr Wood. 'So they offered us a £7,300 reduction if we moved in before the holiday - that's nearly 10 per cent of the purchase price. So we put our house on the market and moved in on 8 December. The whole process took about three weeks.'

If moving over Christmas is too horrific a thought, you may want to extend a cup of friendship to an estate agent by committing to buy one of these seasonal addresses on the market at the moment.

There is Holly House, a four-bedroom house with dis tant sea views in Suffolk (£365,000, details from 01473 234800). The same agency has a restored country home called Plum Pudding, (pictured below) costing £525,000). Or there is High Wood House, a six-bedroom family house on Oxfordshire's Christmas Common (£1m, details from 01491 843001).

During 2000, agents in the South East have already disposed of a Snowball Cottage, The Hollies, a St Nicholas Cottage and, of course, a Christmas Cottage.

Have a good one.

Unreal world

Lapland is a vast region of Northern Europe, largely within the Arctic Circle, occupying Northern Norway, Northern Sweden, Northern Finland, and the Kola Peninsula of Russia. The climate is severe, and there is very little vegetation except in the forested southern area.

Lapland's most famous citizen is, of course, Father Christmas, who occupies an impressive grotto with his elves and their toymaking workshop. The reindeer in Lapland outnumber the Lapps or Laplanders and house prices are fairly reasonable compared with this country: a sparse population means few buyers. Most dwellings consist of wooden cabins, with the odd ice palace occupied by snow royalty.

webTitle: Tessa savers set to cash in and clean up

fields.headline: Tessa savers set to cash in and clean up
fields.trailText: TESSA holders whose accounts mature next year and want to reinvest their money can afford to take their pick of the best rates as banks and building societies jostle for their custom.
fields.body:
TESSA holders whose accounts mature next year and want to reinvest their money can afford to take their pick of the best rates as banks and building societies jostle for their custom.

The Inland Revenue says £21 billion-worth of Tessas will be maturing next year as the tenth anniversary of their launch comes round.

The bulk of the Tessas - worth £14bn - mature in the first quarter, with the biggest surge in January. Following quarters see a steady trickle of maturing Tessas, between £2bn and £3bn a quarter.

Tessas, which were the brainchild of then Prime Minister, John Major, allowed people to invest up to £9,000 over five years. They were withdrawn from sale in April 1999, to be replaced by individual savings accounts, or Isas.

The Inland Revenue says that last March £30bn was tied up in Tessas belonging to as many as 4 million Tessa holders. All will have matured by early 2004.

Banks and building societies are preparing to do battle for your newly liberated savings.

Anna Bowes of independent financial adviser Chase de Vere says: 'We are going to see some very competitive rates, because the banks and building societies will want to retain their funds.'

You can carry on earning tax-free interest if you transfer the capital built up on your Tessa into an Isa. This can be either a Tessa-only Isa, or the cash component of your maxi Isa.

Your £3,000 cash Isa entitlement will not be affected if you make the switch.

But you must act swiftly - if you fail to move the money within six months of your plan maturing, it loses its tax-free status.

Bowes recommends the guaranteed equity-only Isas offered by HSBC, Bristol & West and Birmingham Midshires. These providers' Tessas have been some of the best performers to date.

webTitle: Money Observer: Just want to make money? Think again

fields.headline: Just want to make money? Think again
fields.standfirst: You'll lose money if you buy shares without clear aims in mind, writes  Rob Noble-Warren
fields.trailText: You'll lose money if you buy shares without clear aims in mind, writes Rob Noble-Warren.
fields.body:
If you think the purpose of your investment portfolio is to make money, you may be making the most common mistake there is.

The Association for Investment Management and Research (AIMR) puts it like this: 'The first step in the investment decision-making process is to develop a policy statement based on the investor's return objectives, risk tolerance, and constraints, including liquidity, time horizon, tax status, legal or regulatory factors, and unique needs and circumstances.'

Yet many private investors treat the question of 'objectives' with a balance of caution and frustration. 'To make money, to enlarge my bank account,' they explain. 'And without risk,' they add, hoping this extra information will help.

It doesn't. With no idea of what to aim for, and by when, it is impossible to optimise a portfolio. David Ward, a regular reader of our sister magazine, Money Observer , replied initially to my question about his objectives: 'I just want to make money for any future eventuality including retirement.'

When evaluating his portfolio, I recognised a pattern. He had collected 25 UK-based shares, almost all bought in the hope of a short-term return. Many holdings were initially bought in parcels of less than £1,000, which meant high average dealing costs. Even though the shares were picked for short-term deals and despite a significant amount of time and effort spent on research, performance was only 1 per cent above the market average. All in all, it wasn't working.

The solution lay in going back to the purpose of the portfolio. Planners start with the assumption that there is no chance that they, or any tipster, can be relied on to pick individual shares that will outperform the relevant index. By analysing past trends, they can reduce the overall risk and improve the chances of attaining your objectives.

Optimising the balance of market sectors in your portfolio is known as asset allocation. The AIMR points to some studies which indicate that more than 90 per cent of the variation in total returns can be attributed to the asset allocation decision. Although other research finds that the effect of asset allocation is much lower than 90 per cent, they still emphasise its benefits.

David's retirement was in 12 years' time. What he wanted was money on stand-by in case he needed it for a car or house, and some of it for growth over 12 years. He was hoping to make money by picking shares, and then use what he had made to buy what he wanted.

With all the risky prospects in his portfolio, we worked out that the minimum value he could rely on at the end of the period was £80,000. If he lowered the risk in his portfolio, he could expect at least £115,000.

Although this meant he would not have the potential to make huge gains, the new portfolio would harmonise more closely with what he wanted out of life.

Mary Summers, another Money Observer reader, described her objectives like this: 'I have a £30,000 mortgage on a property valued at £250,000. My salary is £50,000. My partner is almost retired with £100,000 (the same capital as me), mostly in an Egg account. I want to leave work in a couple of years and to raise capital on the property to buy a£150,000 boat. But we want to leave as much capital in place as possible for future growth. How?

Mary hasn't fallen for the idea that she has to make money first and then see what she can do with it. She wants the money to provide what she wants out of life now. Consequently, the design of the portfolio flows much more readily. Since the boat is to be purchased from the loan on the house - assuming she can get a loan for this - there is no need to hold anything back from the portfolio. Of the available £200,000, 80 per cent was on deposit, to produce the highest immediate income.

The rule of thumb for income portfolios is that a withdrawal rate of more than 4 per cent a year will eventually exhaust a portfolio with anything less than 50 per cent in equities?

Mary needs 7 per cent. According to a study published in last January's Journal of Financial Planning, over 20 years, the highest withdrawal rate you can reasonably expect to support from a portfolio (and have income and capital rise with inflation) is 3.5 per cent.

We suggested investing 25 per cent in fixed-interest securities, and 37.5 per cent each in large and small-cap equities (historically, this has been the best arrangement). In 10 years, she might exchange some of her capital for a guaranteed lifetime income. If she had invested her portfolio as David had his originally, the maximum withdrawal rate would be only 1 per cent.

 This article is from the December issue of 'Money Observer', on sale at newsagents at £3.50. For 12 issues at £31.97, a £10 saving, call 0870 870 1324 and quote reference MYLG001.

fields.headline: Wanted: money to travel the world before I'm too old
fields.standfirst: Turning 50 prompted one university lecturer to check that her finances will fund some fun
fields.trailText: Turning 50 prompted one university lecturer to check that her finances will fund some fun.
fields.body:
Jane Clarke

Age 51

Lives in Leicester

Occupation University lecturer

Earns £29,000

Mortgage £50,000

Debts None

Investments Tessa, Cash Isas

Pension Member of occupational scheme

Aims Pay off mortgage, top up pension to ensure enough income for travel in retirement, provide financial help for children if necessary

Jane Clarke is in her early fifties and until recently had never thought much about money or planning the future. Now she wants to sort herself out so she can retire at 60 and fulfil her ambition to travel.

'I don't want to travel in great luxury, but I do want to travel widely,' she says. Places she would like to see include South America, India and the Far East. 'I want to be young enough, and fit enough - and have enough money to enjoy myself.'

Until then she will go on working full-time as a university lecturer. Although she is fortunate to be a member of a public-sector final salary pension scheme, she is concerned about how much she will get. She has been contributing only since she went back into full-time work at 37, after bringing up her three children.

To top up her pension, she has been make additional voluntary contributions (AVCs) with the Prudential for four years. Last year she upped her contributions to the maximum ,so she is now paying 15 per cent of her salary into her pension.

But she is still plagued by doubts: 'Will I have enough for my retirement? Should I be buying added years instead of making AVCs?'.

She won't be sharing her ex-husband's pension. Theirs was a clean-break divorce two years ago.

Jane is concerned about her mortgage, too. After she divorced, she bought a property - 'smaller than a family home but big enough for friends and family to come to stay'. To cover the cost she took a flexible mortgage with Standard Life which is due to run until she is 65, though she aims to try to repay it by the time she is 60. However, so far, despite good intentions, she has not yet managed to pay any extra.

She is now wondering, as she has enough room, whether it would be a good idea to take in a lodger and use the money to pay off her mortgage, or to save more for retirement. Indeed, she feels she could start saving another £100 a month right away if she tried hard.

On the ordinary savings front, she has £1,000 in a Barclays Tessa, which she fears may be earning a low rate of interest, plus £3,000 each in two cash Individual Savings Accounts, which she opened this year and in 1999 with Barclays and Alliance & Leicester.

Part of this is money her husband gave to her when they divorced. She sees this as a combination of safety net, cash towards a new car and 'rainy day' money.

Her three children are now in their twenties, and the youngest will be finishing university this year. Thereafter, she feels she will be in a better position to save, although she would still like to help her children out financially if necessary.

More pension, less of a mortgage, more holidays, money for children. 'Am I asking too much?' she says.

Adviser 1: Gordon Wilson

Jane has taken effective action in a number of areas. However, her mortgage is due to be repaid five years after she retires. I strongly advise repaying it before she turns 60.

Any spare funds should be used to reduce the balance. Money from a lodger could help greatly and is tax-efficient, as the income is likely to qualify for rent-a-room relief. Jane could make up to £4,250 tax free.

The money she has in cash Isas would be better used to reduce her mortgage: the interest rates are less than she is paying on her loan.

Jane should provide an expenditure analysis to help establish the level of income she will need in retirement. Any additional pension planning could then aim at this level. If surplus savings remain she could consider more liquid investments, such as equity Isas.

On the current figures, at 60, Jane will probably have the equivalent of 23 years in the Teachers' Superannuation Scheme. On a salary of £29,000, this equates to a pension of £8,337 a year and a lump sum of £25,000. Her state pension will be added to this, and Jane should fill in Benefits Agency form BR19 for a forecast.

AVCs are an inflexible form of savings with, at best, modest tax advantages. The option of added years is likely to look expensive, but Jane should request a quote from her employer.

Gordon Wilson works for financial adviser Thomson and Shepherd.

Adviser 2: Sharon Linnard

Jane's priorities should be to repay her mortgage by the time she is 60 and ensure she has sufficient income for retirement.

Her mortgage allows additional repayments to be made without redemption penalties. She should ask what extra monthly repayment is needed to pay it off five years early. The money for this could be taken from the additional savings she wishes to make now and when her children finish university.

Her excellent occupational pension scheme guarantees her a good income based on years of service and her pay immediately prior to retirement.

She is already endeavouring to enhance her pension by making AVCs with Prudential. However, it would be appropriate for her to request the additional years that could be purchased by transferring from Prudential and maintaining her current contribution. Added years do not come cheap, but would give her a further lump sum and extra income.

She could switch her Barclays Tessa to one paying more interest.

She could take in a lodger and put the money towards her retirement. Further Isas could be established, but it would be advisable for Jane to look at equity Isas, which offer greater opportunity for capital growth, provided she understands the potential volatility associated with this type of investment.

Sharon Linnard works for chartered accountant KPMG.

Advice is for guidance only.

 Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

Thereafter, she feels she will be in a better position to save, although she would still like to help her children out financially if necessary. More pension, less of a mortgage, more holidays, money for children. 'Am I asking too much?' she says. Adviser 1: Gordon Wilson Jane has taken effective action in a number of areas. However, her mortgage is due to be repaid five years after she retires. I strongly advise repaying it before she turns 60. Any spare funds should be used to reduce the balance. Money from a lodger could help greatly and is tax-efficient, as the income is likely to qualify for rent-a-room relief. Jane could make up to £4,250 tax free. The money she has in cash Isas would be better used to reduce her mortgage: the interest rates are less than she is paying on her loan. Jane should provide an expenditure analysis to help establish the level of income she will need in retirement. Any additional pension planning could then aim at this level. If surplus savings remain she could consider more liquid investments, such as equity Isas. On the current figures, at 60, Jane will probably have the equivalent of 23 years in the Teachers' Superannuation Scheme. On a salary of £29,000, this equates to a pension of £8,337 a year and a lump sum of £25,000. Her state pension will be added to this, and Jane should fill in Benefits Agency form BR19 for a forecast. AVCs are an inflexible form of savings with, at best, modest tax advantages. The option of added years is likely to look expensive, but Jane should request a quote from her employer. Gordon Wilson works for financial adviser Thomson and Shepherd. Adviser 2: Sharon Linnard Jane's priorities should be to repay her mortgage by the time she is 60 and ensure she has sufficient income for retirement. Her mortgage allows additional repayments to be made without redemption penalties. She should ask what extra monthly repayment is needed to pay it off five years early. The money for this could be taken from the additional savings she wishes to make now and when her children finish university. Her excellent occupational pension scheme guarantees her a good income based on years of service and her pay immediately prior to retirement. She is already endeavouring to enhance her pension by making AVCs with Prudential. However, it would be appropriate for her to request the additional years that could be purchased by transferring from Prudential and maintaining her current contribution. Added years do not come cheap, but would give her a further lump sum and extra income. She could switch her Barclays Tessa to one paying more interest. She could take in a lodger and put the money towards her retirement. Further Isas could be established, but it would be advisable for Jane to look at equity Isas, which offer greater opportunity for capital growth, provided she understands the potential volatility associated with this type of investment. Sharon Linnard works for chartered accountant KPMG. Advice is for guidance only.  Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? webTitle: More than a token: Experience over materialism

fields.headline: Great art, sheer drama - or even some animal magic
fields.trailText: Theatre tokens, vouchers for alternatives therapies and animal adoption schemes are among the ways you can give to people who may value an experience over a consumer item
fields.body:
Theatre tokens, vouchers for alternatives therapies and animal adoption schemes are among the ways you can give to people who may value an experience over a consumer item.

More than 200 theatres in London and major provincial centres participate in a gift voucher scheme. The vouchers are available in denominations of £1, £5, £10 and £20, redeemable for tickets at any of the participating theatres. The vouchers can be bought with a credit card by calling Tokenline (020 7240 8800) or at outlets of WH Smith, Waterstones, Books Etc and Hammicks.

London's Royal Academy of Art can arrange gift subscriptions for a year's membership at £45. A spokeswoman says it should be possible to process the membership by Christmas. The fee entitles the member to unlimited visits to the gallery, along with an adult guest and up to four children. Members also have access to the friends' room for tea and coffee. For information ring 020 7300 5664/5668.

The London College of Massage offers vouchers worth £25, £35 and £45 for massages and other treatments, including reflexology and osteopathy at the college's West End treatment centre. Tel: 020 7323 3574.

For pure pampering, French cosmetics company Clarins sells vouchers for facials through 142 of its outlets at shops throughout the country. A facial will cost from £27 to £38 depending on the location of the Clarins outlet; London is the most expensive. Tel: 020 7307 6700.

The Sanctuary, the women's health spa in Covent Garden, offers vouchers that can be redeemed against products and beauty treatments for £5, £20, £50 and £100. There are also vouchers offering access to facilities and treatments. These range from £35 for evening membership to £200 for a 'total bliss' day. The Sanctuary's website, www.thesanctuary.co.uk, is promising to deliver vouchers by registered letter in time for Christmas if orders are made by 1 pm on 23 December. Tel: 08700 630 300.

If conservation is an enthusiasm for a friend or relative, London Zoo runs an 'adopt an animal' scheme. You can adopt on behalf of someone else and fees range from £25 to sponsor an ant, stick insect, rabbit or dormouse for a year, to £6,000 to sponsor an Asian elephant for a year. You can also buy 'units' of the more expensive animals for £35, which would bring such cuddly favourites as otters and meerkats -£350 for a year - within the reach of godparents, uncles and aunts.

The adoptive parents receive a certificate, a photograph of the animal of the chosen species, and a free ticket to London Zoo for every £25 or £35 given. Their name will also appear on a thank-you board at the zoo.

London Zoo's website says applications to adopt animals before Christmas must be in by Tuesday.

Details from the zoo at 020 7449 6262 or www.londonzoo.co.uk. The site also carries details for the adoption scheme at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park, where it costs £40 to adopt any animal.

Certain other charities accept purchase of membership of behalf of someone else. The Royal Society for Protection of Birds, for example, offers membership at £25 for a year. This also brings free entry to more than 100 nature reserves.

The RSPB may not be able to process a membership application before Christmas, but if you sign up now, a membership pack should be delivered to your nominated friend or relative early in the New Year. Tel: 01767 680551.

webTitle: More than a token: Savings and investments

fields.headline: All I want for Christmas...
fields.standfirst: ... is a unit trust, an equities Isa and £1,000 in a pension.  Tracey Boles on gifts you can put in an envelope
fields.trailText: ... is a unit trust, an equities Isa and £1,000 in a pension. Tracey Boles on gifts you can put in an envelope.
fields.body:
Money is a dirty word at Christmas. We all know the celebrations will cost a fortune but it's mean-spirited to think too much about it . As for giving hard cash, that's something we feel we should avoid.

But what are the options if friends and relatives really don't need, or want, more baubles for their homes? Or if the gifts they really need - mortgage paid off, car replaced, roof mended - are beyond your means? One option is to consider an investment or savings plan.

Anna Bowes of independent financial adviser Chase de Vere recommends asking three questions before making a decision: how long will the investment run for, how much money will be involved and what is the 'risk profile' of the beneficiary.

In the case of adults you should also consider what investments they hold already. For those nervous about stock market investing, a bank or building society account is a start, but the experts recommend share based investments such as a unit or investment trust for sums of more than £5 or £10. A stock market-based investment should make more over the long term than a building society account. Children in particular are ideal long-term stock market investors because they cannot get their hands on the money without parental permission until they are at least 18.

For the risk-averse, other low-risk investments include National Savings and friendly society bonds.

National Savings premium bonds are entered into a monthly prize draw instead of earning interest. You have the chance of winning £1m, but the bulk of the prizes - some 700,000 each month - are much lower. The initial investment, which must be at least £100, can be withdrawn at any time.

National Savings also offer children's bonds for under-16s which earn a fixed rate of 4.8 per cent tax free - recently cut from 5.5 per cent - provided they are not cashed in for five years. The minimum investment is £25 and the maximum £1,000 per bond.

Friendly societies offer low-risk access to the stock market. Tunbridge Wells Friendly Society's baby bond offers a tax-free return over 10 years on an investment of £25 a month or £270 a year.

Friendly society bonds normally invest in with-profit funds, which may not make as much money over the long term as a pure stock market investment. If investing for a baby, you could use a unit trust, because the investment can stay put for 20 years.

The Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds says unit trusts are ideal as a regular savings plan from £30 a month, or as a lump-sum investment starting from £500. In the case of a regular plan you could make the first payment as a present.

Chase de Vere's Bowes likes unit trusts for children because they are 'tax efficient'. The child's capital gains tax allowance, currently £7,200 a year, should ensure that they earn profit without paying tax.

And you can avoid paying income tax by choosing a trust which invests for growth rather than income. This strategy is especially suitable for children because only the first £100 of a child's annual income is tax-free if one of their parents sets them up with a gift - the rest is taxed to the parent.

There may also be inheritance tax considerations for grandparents thinking of giving an investment as a present. If their estate upon death amounts to more than £234,000, the recipients of a financial gift within the preceding seven years have to pay tax at 40 per cent.

Only one unit trust is marketed specifically at children, the Invesco Rupert Children's Fund. However, there is nothing in the nature of the underlying funds which is geared towards children and the Rupert bear freebies that used to come with the trust have been discontinued. The trust invests in FTSE 100 companies, and its performance has been middle of the road.

Bowes recommends two riskier unit trusts as gifts, Sarasin's Equisar and Merrill Lynch's Global Titans, both of which are thematic funds - they choose the best-performing companies within seven 'themes' such as healthcare, financial services and telecoms. The Merrill Lynch fund is new but the longer-running Sarasin fund has made a 200 per cent profit in five years.

Ben Yearsley of financial adviser Hargreaves Landsdown says he would choose a technology or healthcare unit trust such as Framlington Health or Invesco Global Dynamic, which selects the companies expected to do best within six themed investment sectors.

You may consider buying a gift of shares direct, but buying small portions of shares is usually expensive: most stockbrokers operate a minimum charge. The cheapest start at about £15.

But the advantage of choosing shares is that you can tailor the gift to match the interests of your friends or relatives. Football fans, chocoholics and computer nerds can all be catered for.

Yearsley says something to keep in mind for a present next year is stakeholder pensions, the Government's new low-cost private pension scheme. You can invest £3,600 a year tax free in a stakeholder pension for children and non-working parents.

He says there are pros and cons to putting your gift into a pension. On one hand 'a thousand pounds now will be worth a fortune in 60 years, but on the other you cannot access the money under any circumstances until then.

For shorter- term investments, you could look at cash Isas or with-profits savings plans. Deposits can be monthly or yearly over the 10-year life of the plan.

However, remember that the problem with investments as presents for adults is that the recipient has to sign for them, so the element of surprise is lost. Remember, too, that children cannot hold investments in their own names. The best you can do is 'designate' the investment to the child, which means tagging their name on to yours.

Rather than appealing to someone's avaricious side, you could always make a financial gift that speaks to their better nature - by giving money to charity on their behalf. If you make use of the generous tax breaks available, the value of your donation will be boosted.

Tax-effective giving means using schemes which allow the charity to reclaim the basic rate tax on your gift. The Government's Gift Aid scheme will turn a £10 gift into £12.82 after a charity has reclaimed tax.

The Charities Aid Foundation runs a charity card account which operates under Gift Aid. The account allows you to write cheques to the charity of your choice including schools, scout groups and hospitals. CAF will then honour the cheque. CAF says it will guarantee your money goes to a reputable charity. Oxfam and the National Trust are among he most popular.

Some 70,000 people currently make donations this way, and as you can open an account in another person's name, they make suitable Christmas presents. However, a 4 per cent administration charge will slightly reduce the value of your donation.

CAF also issues gift vouchers, but there is no tax advantage. The vouchers can be written for any amount and go to any charity.

More information about Gift Aid is available on the revenue's website, www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk or on 0151 472 6056.

Charities Aid Foundation: 0800 993311.

fields.headline: Try some presents from the past
fields.standfirst: Yesterday's things can be today's unusual Christmas gifts, writes John Windsor
fields.trailText: Yesterday's things can be today's unusual Christmas gifts, writes John Windsor.
fields.body:
Old coins and banknotes, bronze medieval artefacts, hand-written parchment title deeds, cigarette cards, paper ephemera, even Penny Black stamps, can be a hit as Christmas gifts because they look much more valuable than they are.

A two-millennia old coin is a wonderful thing to handle. And a set of cigarette cards or a crisp, unused wartime pound note (from £7.50) will fill grandparents with nostalgia.

The reason such things are so cheap is that pre-decimal coins, say, or cigarette cards, though no longer common currency in every household, are still plentiful in the collectors' market, and the most common items still fetch only a few pounds, whether they are inter-war, Victorian or Roman.

Hitherto, the gift market and the collectors' market have scarcely overlapped. At Christmas, shoppers scrambling for fancy soaps or hankies in high street stores seldom give a thought to the dimly lit coin dealers in the side street. But it is in such little shops that much-appreciated gifts can be found.

A fine-condition fourth-century bronze coin of Constantine the Great, the first Christian emperor, can be bought from dealers for a fiver, the price asked by London-based Coincraft.

Another London coin dealer, Philip Cohen, sells late Victorian silver crowns (minted 1887-1900), in used but pleasant condition, for £12. Scratched or dented ones are £5-£7 and mint (uncirculated) from £50. If you are giving a present to a non-collector you don't need mint condition coins. In fact, a bit of wear can add authenticity.

There is a reason why Cohen is able to offer mint-condition 1887 silver half-crowns bearing Queen Victoria's new portrait for only £25. It was the Queen's golden jubilee year and they were hoarded, as Churchill crowns were later, in the hope that they would appreciate in value. Instead, they glutted the market. Those massive, magnificent George III cartwheel pennies of 1797, which are nearly 1.5 inches in diameter and weigh an ounce, are £15-£20 from Cohen in fine condition. They were minted by the engineer Matthew Boulton to show off his new steam-driven coin press ,whose site in Soho, Birmingham, is stamped on the coin. But look sharp; some gift buyers are cottoning on to the golden jubilee half-crown and the cartwheel penny. A year ago, Cohen's price for the cartwheel penny was only £10. Another coin dealer has ordered 100 from him at his new price of £15-£20, confident that he can turn a profit.

My prize example of the very old, very famous, but very common and very cheap is the bronze widow's mite, in use in the Holy Land during Christ's lifetime. These, in good to fine condition, are being sold by Coincraft for £15.

Small and usually badly struck, they were the only coin the Romans allowed the Jews to mint. Chris Martin, London mail-order dealer in ancient art, offers them for £10, or £20 in a silver mount. Could the one you buy be one of the two that Christ saw the poor widow cast into the treasury? Highly unlikely, but possible.

Cigarette cards? For £8.50 the London Cigarette Card Company, based in Somerset, will sell you Wills's set of 50 Household Hints of 1936 - its card showing three uses for used newspapers should strike a fresh chord among today's eco-warriors, but how many of them would want to know how to bitumen-felt a garden shed? Grandpa, ex-wartime ARP, would be thrilled to receive Wills's 50 Air Raid Precautions of 1938, £30.

Grandma may have seen precious few pound notes during the war. So present her with a 1940 blue pound note with the swirling foliate design on the back, only £7.50 in very fine or £16.50 in extra fine condition from the London banknote dealer Colin Narbeth.

Narbeth, Cohen and the stamp dealer Robert Langsfield share the same shop at 20 Cecil Court, off London's Charing Cross Road. If you wish to impress ignoramuses in your family by giving them a genuine Penny Black of 1840, the world's first postage stamp (some people still think they are rare), Langsfield will sell you one for £20. It would have only three margins intact (the stamps were unperforated and they were cut with scissors) and faults such as pin holes. Average condition four-margin Penny Blacks are £60-£80.

Parchment 'title deeds' are plentiful, impressive, and cheap. Each one is made from the skin of a whole sheep, stretched, scraped and cured, and the legal rubric is hand-written in quill pen .

They were burned on bonfires when the Land Registry made them obsolete in 1926. Every one tells a story of real people - a mortgage, a tenancy, a marriage agreement, an apprenticeship.

Michael Kashden prices his Victorian mortgage agreements from £10. The more fascinating the story told by the deed, the higher the price. Among his stock, priced at £45, is the seven-year shipbuilding and carpentry apprenticeship agreement of one James Beer, aged 15, of Ramsgate, who in 1866, so it is written, promised not to reveal his master's secrets and 'shall not play at cards or dice tables' and 'shall not haunt taverns or play houses'.

My favourite is manuscript paper ephemera, which comprise the throwaway documents of everyday life that occasionally survive for generations. Examples of what you can buy from member-dealers of the Ephemera Society are: for £8, a written receipt of 1777 signed by Richard Hodgkins for 12s 11d paid for 11 gallons and one pint of beer 'for laborers in the Church yard'. For £5: Mr I. Messer's quarterly Poor Law receipt for £1/12s, signed in 1799 by the Hampstead workhouse overseer, Stephen Mallard.

A newcomer in presentable collectables are medieval artefacts unearthed by mudlarks and and metal detectors. They are not as cheap as they were three or four years ago. But Nigel Mills, a Covent Garden dealer, has published two catalogues that include a fourteenth-century buckle with a mythological beast on it, £25, a fourteenth-century brass thimble, £15, and a second-century bronze Roman brooch, £28.

If you want something really, really old, Chris Martin has, for £20, bracelets made from Egyptian beads dating from the time of Tutankhamen, 1300BC.

Coincraft (020-7636 1188). Philip Cohen (020-7379 0615). Robert Langsfield (020-7379 6975). Colin Narbeth (020-7379 6975). Ancient Art (Chris Martin) mail order (020-8882 1509). London Cigarette Card Company (01458-273452).

Michael Kashden (020 8958 1018). Ephemera Society: Valerie Jackson-Harris, bazaar officer (01923-829079). Nigel Mills (020 8504 2569), mobile (07803-200 825); his catalogues and price guides, 'Medieval Artefacts' £12 and 'Celtic and Roman Artefacts', £15 (both inc. p&p) from Greenlight Publishing, 119 Newland Street, Witham, Essex CM8 1WF (01376-521900).

Another coin dealer has ordered 100 from him at his new price of £15-£20, confident that he can turn a profit. My prize example of the very old, very famous, but very common and very cheap is the bronze widow's mite, in use in the Holy Land during Christ's lifetime. These, in good to fine condition, are being sold by Coincraft for £15. Small and usually badly struck, they were the only coin the Romans allowed the Jews to mint. Chris Martin, London mail-order dealer in ancient art, offers them for £10, or £20 in a silver mount. Could the one you buy be one of the two that Christ saw the poor widow cast into the treasury? Highly unlikely, but possible. Cigarette cards? For £8.50 the London Cigarette Card Company, based in Somerset, will sell you Wills's set of 50 Household Hints of 1936 - its card showing three uses for used newspapers should strike a fresh chord among today's eco-warriors, but how many of them would want to know how to bitumen-felt a garden shed? Grandpa, ex-wartime ARP, would be thrilled to receive Wills's 50 Air Raid Precautions of 1938, £30. Grandma may have seen precious few pound notes during the war. So present her with a 1940 blue pound note with the swirling foliate design on the back, only £7.50 in very fine or £16.50 in extra fine condition from the London banknote dealer Colin Narbeth. Narbeth, Cohen and the stamp dealer Robert Langsfield share the same shop at 20 Cecil Court, off London's Charing Cross Road. If you wish to impress ignoramuses in your family by giving them a genuine Penny Black of 1840, the world's first postage stamp (some people still think they are rare), Langsfield will sell you one for £20. It would have only three margins intact (the stamps were unperforated and they were cut with scissors) and faults such as pin holes. Average condition four-margin Penny Blacks are £60-£80. Parchment 'title deeds' are plentiful, impressive, and cheap. Each one is made from the skin of a whole sheep, stretched, scraped and cured, and the legal rubric is hand-written in quill pen . They were burned on bonfires when the Land Registry made them obsolete in 1926. Every one tells a story of real people - a mortgage, a tenancy, a marriage agreement, an apprenticeship. Michael Kashden prices his Victorian mortgage agreements from £10. The more fascinating the story told by the deed, the higher the price. Among his stock, priced at £45, is the seven-year shipbuilding and carpentry apprenticeship agreement of one James Beer, aged 15, of Ramsgate, who in 1866, so it is written, promised not to reveal his master's secrets and 'shall not play at cards or dice tables' and 'shall not haunt taverns or play houses'. My favourite is manuscript paper ephemera, which comprise the throwaway documents of everyday life that occasionally survive for generations. Examples of what you can buy from member-dealers of the Ephemera Society are: for £8, a written receipt of 1777 signed by Richard Hodgkins for 12s 11d paid for 11 gallons and one pint of beer 'for laborers in the Church yard'. For £5: Mr I. Messer's quarterly Poor Law receipt for £1/12s, signed in 1799 by the Hampstead workhouse overseer, Stephen Mallard. A newcomer in presentable collectables are medieval artefacts unearthed by mudlarks and and metal detectors. They are not as cheap as they were three or four years ago. But Nigel Mills, a Covent Garden dealer, has published two catalogues that include a fourteenth-century buckle with a mythological beast on it, £25, a fourteenth-century brass thimble, £15, and a second-century bronze Roman brooch, £28. If you want something really, really old, Chris Martin has, for £20, bracelets made from Egyptian beads dating from the time of Tutankhamen, 1300BC. Coincraft (020-7636 1188). webTitle: Education: Never too old to learn

fields.headline: Never too old to learn
fields.standfirst: Children have personal finance lessons. Now it's their parents' turn, reports  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Children have personal finance lessons. Now it's their parents' turn, reports Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Educating schoolchildren about personal finance has been a main consumer aim of the Government and its City regulators over the last couple of years. But now they are switching to a tougher target - adults.

An 'interactive adult learning program' will be available, free, on the Financial Service's Authority website by spring. Instead of just giving out facts about retirement planning, for instance, people will be able to test their understanding by trying to answer a few questions. The FSA has decided to go down this route because it has discovered that interaction is a far better learning tool than just providing information.

And it believes that there is a need to help adults make better decisions about mortgages, pensions and other financial products. 'The level of understanding is not good,' says its head of consumer education Deborah Arnott. She quotes research suggesting that 20 per cent of people approaching retirement believe that pensions are not taxable and that 40 per cent of 18 to 24-year-olds rely on friends and family for personal finance advice.

But even without the FSA's program, there are many sources of help for adults. On pensions, the Occupational Pensions Advisory Service (OPAS) runs a free helpline and the TUC also runs a pension helpline. Trade bodies such as the Association of Unit Trusts and the Association of Investment Trust Companies also produce leaflets, although people will have to remember that they have a vested interest in promoting these products. But the FSA is now trying to go a step further in spreading the word to the adult population, because it believes that publicising the availability of information is probably a tougher task than getting people, once they have the information, to understand the issues.

The FSA is now trying to encourage employers to distribute personal finance information. It hopes that more will follow the example of Sainsbury's and MBNA, the credit card bank. Sainsbury's, which is worried by the fact that 70,000 of its 170,000 staff are missing out on employer's contributions by not joining the pension scheme, has started personal finance help sessions for employees.

MBNA meanwhile has a financial education service manager, Harper Wright, who has had individual sessions with 400 of the company's 2,500 UK staff. The advice is generic. It explains, for instance, the different types of mortgages or pension schemes. Other employers might wonder what Sainsbury's and MBNA get out of this. Wright says: 'Our chairman asks the question "where will my people go for advice?" There is no longer a high street bank manager around to talk to. If people are not worried about whether they have the right mortgage, they are going to be a better employee.'

The FSA will be trying to encourage other employers to take this route. If employers are providing stress counselling, the FSA believes they could do more in this arena. 'Why not provide counselling on personal finance?' says Arnott. The main focus for employers at the moment is retirement planning, but this is usually confined to employees who are a few months off retirement. 'You need to reach them when they are making their initial decisions, such as taking out their first mortgage or starting a pension,' she says. Employers will be forced into thinking through these issues to some degree next year when they have until October to arrange access to the new 'stakeholder pensions'. The FSA is looking to the US where evidence from the National Bureau of Economic Research suggests that 88 per cent of businesses which run a pension scheme also provide some sort of financial education programme. 'The thing that really works is seminars,' says Arnott.

Employers in the UK will worry about just how much advice they can give to staff. The personal pension mis-selling scandal of a decade ago was partly exacerbated by the constraints on employers not to recommend their own pension scheme when employees decided to transfer out into a personal pension. 'That was a real cloud that hung over many employers,' says Peter Clarke, president of the Institute of Actuaries.

Another problem for employers will be how to answer the questions of employees. Some employers are concerned, for instance, about staff who are completely financially bound up with them - through the pension scheme and by holding the company's own shares. If an employer suggested that such an employee should diversify and invest elsewhere, the employee's next question is likely to be 'How?'

Some employees might also wonder about the reliability of information provided at work.

After all, some employers have invited personal pension sales staff into their premises and thereby aided the handing out of some bad financial advice, such as opting out of the State Earnings Related Pension Scheme, Serps, for example, in cases where this was a bad move. Government and regulators are considering these and other difficult questions.

The FSA, having got personal finance on to the school curriculum this September, will now have to push to encourage teachers to take up the subject. In the workplace, parts of the infrastructure are also already there, says Alan Grant, the former TUC head of education who now works in consumer education at the FSA. He says: 'There are computer resources in the workplace that could be turned over to help people with their learning. It takes a push.'

fields.headline: Places for plaice
fields.standfirst: And where to catch the ones that didn't get away
fields.trailText: And where to catch the ones that didn't get away.
fields.body:
The coming week sees the last chance to buy good fish for a while. As Peter Mann of J H Mann Ltd (7 Hillsborough Road, Sheffield, South Yorks; 0114 234 3538) explains, the fishing industry all but closes down over Christmas and New Year, after which it takes a couple of weeks before things return to normal. Some fish will not be back at their best for a long while after that; if you like plaice, buy now while it's at its best, because it goes out of condition as the year turns. Among other offerings this week should be monkfish, and fresh, uncooked Mediterranean crevettes at £17.50 per kg.

Clive Samways of Samways (9b/c West Bay, Station Road, Bridport, Dorset; 01308 424 496) agrees that, weather permitting, the run-up to Christmas produces abundant supplies of high-quality fresh fish. He buys at auction all along the south coast from Devon to Rye, selecting the best for his shop, exporting the rest. Premium quality fish comes from day boats (that go out for 12 hours) landing catches at Brixham, Lyme Regis and Looe, but bigger boats out of Newlyn stay at sea for perhaps five days, catching good-sized brill, turbot, megrim, hake, conger eel and tuna. Ask any self-respecting cook about scallops and they will swear by diver-caught ones, which Clive Samways sells, but he reckons dredged ones have had a rather harsh press, so he also sells 'beautiful quality' scallops (70p each, cut and cleaned) that have been dredged by small boats. His father-in-law, David Williams, runs the shop, and a fledgling mail-order service is now up and running.

Clive Samways is not alone is his view of dredged scallops. Phil Bowditch of Phil Bowditch (7 Bath Place, Taunton, Devon; 01823 253 500) - who, weather permitting, buys mullet, John Dory, sea bass, gurnard, sole, huss, cod, haddock, pollock and much more from Brixham day boats - is also a supporter. When caught by small boats, scallops are towed for around 20 minutes, so are still alive, free from grit, and available in larger quantities than diver-caught ones. He has less luck with prawns only because of their price. The Spanish are prepared to pay much more than we are, but since they also take large quantities of hake, megrim and cuttlefish, they help to keep the industry healthy. Phil Bowditch also has a good word for trawlers (not surprisingly, since he has one of his own), not least because some fish actually improve with a little keeping on the five-day trips: not plaice or oily fish such as mackerel, but Dover sole and turbot, for example, provided they are properly treated and kept on ice.

Phil Bowditch doesn't do mail order because 'people want to see what they are buying', but for people (like me) who don't live near a good fishmonger, mail order from a good supplier is the sensible solution. Club Chef Direct (Lakeside, Bridgwater Road, Barrow Gurney, Bristol; 01275 475 252) is taking orders up to Thursday 21 December for delivery on Friday. But the earlier an order is placed, the more it stands a chance of turning up on time. Last orders are taken tomorrow at Quayside Fish (The Harbourside, Porthleven, Cornwall; 01326 562 008). Ask about their smoked fish to tide you over the lean New Year period.

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide.

fields.headline: Sugar cubes
fields.standfirst: It's hardly diet food - but for Turkish delight, who cares
fields.trailText: It's hardly diet food - but for Turkish delight, who cares.
fields.body:
Sticky, nut-filled chunks of rose or lemon-flavoured jelly that shower you in icing sugar as you bite; an Ali Baba image of chiffon-clad harem girls and shadowy Moorish courts merely adding to their charm as you slowly chew through another fragrant lump. Christmas wouldn't be Christmas without real Turkish delight.

No one knows where or when Turkish delight was first made. Some believe it originated from the Island of Chios in the Aegean, since mastic, an aromatic resin once widely used in Turkish delight, forms the basis of the island's commerce. Others believe the Persians, master confectioners long before the Ancient Greeks, created it, while the Turks maintain that it was invented by one Hadji Bekir of Constantinople.

Today, Turkish delight is manufactured throughout the Middle East. According to Claudia Roden in her New Book of Middle Eastern Food (£14.99, Penguin), it is made by slowly simmering and stirring dissolved sugar and glucose syrup with a thickened cornflour paste. After about three hours, it should form gummy threads, at which point lemon juice, ground mastic and distilled orange flower or rose water are added, along with roughly chopped pistachios or lightly toasted almonds. It is then spread into trays and left to set for 24 hours, before being cut and rolled in icing sugar. So not exactly something you will rustle up at home.

Instead, you should visit a Middle Eastern, Greek or Turkish shop, as this is where the best quality can be found. It is sold loose, and you can mix and match your flavours, fillings, colours and coatings. Aside from the usual rose, mint and vanilla, try nougat-flavoured Turkish delight, which is vaguely reminiscent of a well cooked marshmallow. You can buy plain or walnut, hazelnut, almond or pistachio-filled Turkish delight. Many favour chunks that are coated in desiccated coconut, although this can detract from the more subtle flavourings. Beware, however, of its fattening properties. In the past, Middle Eastern ladies of leisure owed many of their curves to over-indulging in Turkish delight.

 Loose Turkish delight can also be bought from Green Valley, 37 Upper Berkeley Street, London W1 (020 7402 7385), or in Selfridges, 400 Oxford Street, London W1 (020 7629 1234) or Selfridges, One the Dome, The Trafford Centre, Manchester (0161 629 1234).

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: defending the alternative option, and how to shift a stubborn sore throat
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: defending the alternative option, and how to shift a stubborn sore throat.
fields.body:
In the light of recent overwhelming evidence that we may be on the brink of one of the most cataclysmic crises ever to challenge humankind - ecologically, biologically, psychologically, sociologically and geologically - you might expect the elder statespeople of the land to be focusing their years of presumably superior experience and wisdom on the problem of how to avoid extinction of the human race. That they are, in the midst of all this, in fact turning their attention to the apparent global threat posed by alternative medicine, ancient Ayurvedic and Chinese in particular, seems worthy of mention here.

As something of an alternative elder, I would like to add my own modest voice to the discussion, not to defend alternative or complementary healing methods - they don't need defending or even championing, having been around in one form or another gathering agreement for a few thousand years - but to help dispel any confusion that could arise and dissuade patients from seeking useful alternative help in the future.

What the House of Lords declares is true, of course: alternative medicine can be dangerous, and in certain cases can kill you. Sometimes, perhaps often, even the most highly trained practitioner may fail to diagnose a fatal disease. Occasionally, herbs prescribed may react adversely with allopathic medication and cause grave trouble. And there are bound to be cases of people being misled by charismatic healers and ending up broke, ill or even dead as a result. But the same rules apply to conventional Western medicine. You cannot remove human fallibility from the equation whichever way you swing.

Unfortunately, as alternative therapies grew exponentially and rapidly more popular over the past three decades, our general mindset didn't. We are still only just learning what it means to take responsibility for our own health and wellbeing. Many still believe doctors are responsible for keeping us alive. But the shambles of the nonetheless valiant public health service, the side effects and ineffectiveness of many prescribed drugs to do anything more than mask a disease, and the high rate of misdiagnoses and of surgical error are enough to tell us this is not necessarily the wisest approach.

My urge to pipe up on the topic was triggered by a recent conversation with a patient I was treating with acupressure to sort out a twitch in her left eye that had been troubling her for a week or more. There's a meridian, an overflow channel that conducts protective energy up the sides of the body which becomes blocked for a variety of reasons, the most common being hormonal imbalance, digestive troubles or sometimes an excess of adrenalin from too many late nights, early mornings or both. One symptom that often arises is this troublesome twitch in the eye, as the outer corner of the eye lies directly on the meridian's flight path. There is a point at the other end of the meridian, down behind the outside ankle in the dent formed between the ankle bone and the achilles tendon, that, if stimulated, can often clear a blockage and stop the twitch within seconds. You might like to locate and massage the point now in case you ever develop such a twitch.

She pointed out that normally she would have gone to her GP about it but doubted that would have been of much use, for short of toxic muscle relaxants, she wondered what a GP would be able to recommend. The same would go for many cases of IBS, headaches, back pain, almost all stress-related diseases, and in fact all the myriad conditions that alternative medicine has already proven beyond doubt to be able to help, if not altogether cure.

I'm not resorting to grandiose claims such as that alternative medicine can in theory be used to treat the most devastating disease - if the patient is willing to use the healing process, take it by the horns and with the help of grace, destiny, nature or whatever you'd prefer to call it, actually heal themselves. For as even Hypocrates, the father of modern medicine, himself understood it, nature heals, the physician merely nurses. I'm only asserting modestly that alternative medicine - self-healing in other words - practised by someone with adequate training, experience and talent, can alleviate many of life's irksome aches and pains, and can even help you die more peacefully when the time eventually comes (if not actually prevent illness altogether and prolong life considerably), and must retain its place alongside (not in opposition to) conventional medicine.

Your letters

Dear Barefoot Doctor, I've been suffering from cystitis for over a fortnight. My mother says it's because I don't wear warm enough underwear. Is this true and what can I do to stop it?
Alison Green, London

Dear Alison, your mother may be partly right as attracting cold to the lower part of the body causes kidney-energy deficit, and as the kidneys control the bladder (in oriental thought at least), this can lead to bladder inflammation. Symptoms can be alleviated by drinking cranberry juice or lemon and barley water (sugar free), as well as by taking one drop of juniper oil internally every night. Be sure to urinate before and after sex and pay special attention to sexual hygiene. Though by now if symptoms still persist, it would be wise to visit a GP as there is a risk of it leading to kidney infection if not treated.

Dear Barefoot Doctor, I had a really bad bout of flu a few weeks ago and I still have a persistent sore throat. How can I clear it up?
Andrew Waller, Nottingham

Dear Andrew, sitting comfortably, tilt your head back with jaw open. Now close your jaw until you feel a stretch through the muscles in the throat. Hold it in a relaxed manner for three or four breath cycles and release slowly. This will encourage circulation. Add one drop of essential oil of niaouli in a teaspoonful of honey and take once a day. Apply three drops of tea-tree oil in a neutral base oil as a chest rub, massaging well in between the ribs every night. Try propolis tincture and golden seal and consider a change of air.

fields.bodyText: In the light of recent overwhelming evidence that we may be on the brink of one of the most cataclysmic crises ever to challenge humankind - ecologically, biologically, psychologically, sociologically and geologically - you might expect the elder statespeople of the land to be focusing their years of presumably superior experience and wisdom on the problem of how to avoid extinction of the human race. That they are, in the midst of all this, in fact turning their attention to the apparent global threat posed by alternative medicine, ancient Ayurvedic and Chinese in particular, seems worthy of mention here. As something of an alternative elder, I would like to add my own modest voice to the discussion, not to defend alternative or complementary healing methods - they don't need defending or even championing, having been around in one form or another gathering agreement for a few thousand years - but to help dispel any confusion that could arise and dissuade patients from seeking useful alternative help in the future. What the House of Lords declares is true, of course: alternative medicine can be dangerous, and in certain cases can kill you. Sometimes, perhaps often, even the most highly trained practitioner may fail to diagnose a fatal disease. Occasionally, herbs prescribed may react adversely with allopathic medication and cause grave trouble. And there are bound to be cases of people being misled by charismatic healers and ending up broke, ill or even dead as a result. But the same rules apply to conventional Western medicine. You cannot remove human fallibility from the equation whichever way you swing. Unfortunately, as alternative therapies grew exponentially and rapidly more popular over the past three decades, our general mindset didn't. We are still only just learning what it means to take responsibility for our own health and wellbeing. Many still believe doctors are responsible for keeping us alive. But the shambles of the nonetheless valiant public health service, the side effects and ineffectiveness of many prescribed drugs to do anything more than mask a disease, and the high rate of misdiagnoses and of surgical error are enough to tell us this is not necessarily the wisest approach. My urge to pipe up on the topic was triggered by a recent conversation with a patient I was treating with acupressure to sort out a twitch in her left eye that had been troubling her for a week or more. There's a meridian, an overflow channel that conducts protective energy up the sides of the body which becomes blocked for a variety of reasons, the most common being hormonal imbalance, digestive troubles or sometimes an excess of adrenalin from too many late nights, early mornings or both. One symptom that often arises is this troublesome twitch in the eye, as the outer corner of the eye lies directly on the meridian's flight path. There is a point at the other end of the meridian, down behind the outside ankle in the dent formed between the ankle bone and the achilles tendon, that, if stimulated, can often clear a blockage and stop the twitch within seconds. You might like to locate and massage the point now in case you ever develop such a twitch. She pointed out that normally she would have gone to her GP about it but doubted that would have been of much use, for short of toxic muscle relaxants, she wondered what a GP would be able to recommend. The same would go for many cases of IBS, headaches, back pain, almost all stress-related diseases, and in fact all the myriad conditions that alternative medicine has already proven beyond doubt to be able to help, if not altogether cure. I'm not resorting to grandiose claims such as that alternative medicine can in theory be used to treat the most devastating disease - if the patient is willing to use the healing process, take it by the horns and with the help of grace, destiny, nature or whatever you'd prefer to call it, actually heal themselves. For as even Hypocrates, the father of modern medicine, himself understood it, nature heals, the physician merely nurses. I'm only asserting modestly that alternative medicine - self-healing in other words - practised by someone with adequate training, experience and talent, can alleviate many of life's irksome aches and pains, and can even help you die more peacefully when the time eventually comes (if not actually prevent illness altogether and prolong life considerably), and must retain its place alongside (not in opposition to) conventional medicine. fields.headline: Lethal cocktails
fields.standfirst: You don't have to drink every day to have a drink problem, writes Sue Webster
fields.trailText: You don't have to drink every day to have a drink problem, writes Sue Webster.
fields.body:
'I feel pretty, I feel witty, I feel pretty and witty and ga-ay.' It's Maria singing in West Side Story - but it could easily be your colleague Penny on the karaoke machine after several garish cocktails at the office party. In general, it's alcohol, not buttermilk or even the euphoric effects of being in love, which imparts such enviable confidence and apparent joie de vivre .

Nobody wants to be a killjoy. Social drinking is fun; it enhances the atmosphere at a party or casual gathering, precisely because alcohol is disinhibiting. Surveys show that men, for example, often perceive themselves to be more attractive and vivacious after a few drinks (too bad the perception is wholly subjective; women questioned about the same men don't agree).

An American magazine recently identified a new breed of social drinker, however; one for whom the party never ends - 'until they check into rehab'. Since they are evidently so adept at concealing their craving for the next gimlet, W magazine dubs these typically glamorous, successful, healthy-seeming extroverts 'Slinkers'.

Slinkers are not daily drinkers; they can go for days with nothing more than a Perrier, before heading back to the cocktail bar to get steadily hammered with their chums. The image may be straight from glossy drinks advertising, but according to the US-based alcohol recovery programme, Moderation Management, drinking like this is increasingly a problem. It may be more fuzzily defined than alcoholism; it may look more refined from the outside; but to the experienced alcohol counsellor this type of social drinking can be just the beginning of a long journey to psychological and physiological dependence.

These social drinking patterns are mirrored in the UK - it is only its less attractive appellation, 'binge drinking', which allows most of us to distance ourselves from the phenomenon. The government may have switched from weekly to daily recommended limits for safe drinking (two units a day for women, three for men) in an attempt to dissuade people from consuming their 20 units in one sitting. But Andrew MacNeill, co-director of the Institute of Alcohol Studies, says, 'People still tend to latch on to certain simplistic assumptions in order to reassure themselves that they don't have a problem. They think as long as they don't drink before 5pm, say, or as long as they don't drink every day, then they are not dependent. And there is a grain of truth in that, but there is also ample room for self-delusion. Of course it's a good idea to have a drink-free day, but many people then get into the routine of saving up their alcohol consumption for the weekend or social occasions and then go completely over the top.'

MacNeill talks of health issues (we should bear in mind that it's the amount of alcohol we consume over a lifetime that will affect our bodies in the long term), but there are also the little indignities. Vomiting over the photocopier is distasteful; waking up in a strange bed with no recollection of how you got there is slightly more dangerous. But hey, it's only once in a while, and it's nothing like being a saddo who sits at home with a bottle of Scotch getting drunk on their own. Or is it?

'Drinking at home alone is a red herring which, for many people, happens to fit with a stereotype of an alcoholic,' says Professor Richard Velleman, an alcohol and drugs expert based at the University of Bath. 'Some people may be extremely sociable in their drinking habits, but in the end realise they are becoming more dependent and that socialising is no longer the main point.'

Jon, an owner-manager of a medium-sized company, has always found plenty of reasons to work late and socialise with his clients. For him, as for many of us, alcohol is possibly just too available. 'We have a company bar, which I always thought was a great way for employees to bond together. But naturally nobody is in there drinking tonic water. We're mostly a male company and that would seem a bit weird - as if you had a drink problem. I always enjoy a drink, but at the same time I feel I should probably try to cut down. It's become a habit, really. And it has a lot to do with affluence; when I was younger, I just couldn't afford to drink so much.'

It is not only men who feel the pressure to drink when they socialise. A 50 per cent increase in younger women's alcohol consumption over the past 10 years is due in part to the development of more women-friendly drinking places. This means women's drinking is now conducted openly, and its social context lends it a respectable mantel that a solitary gin over the washing up - 'mother's ruin' - never had.

As Gillian, a self-employed PR who recently had to cope with a messy divorce, reflects: 'I have to take a conscious decision not to have a glass of wine, otherwise it's an automatic thing at the end of the day and often at lunchtimes, too. It's also a misery thing. In the past, if I've been very miserable, I've found myself ploughing through a bottle of wine alone, but I feel I should avoid that, so I tend to arrange to meet people in a bar. Thinking about it, my local has replaced the sitting room, because the sitting room means being alone. I'm embarrassed to say, I do sometimes have a drink before I go out, though, to put me in a better mood when I get there.'

Significantly, Gillian's embarrassment relates to her private consumption of alcohol, rather than what she drinks when she's in public. Sandra Farrell, a Manchester-based alcohol counsellor, also says it's a common misconception that we always associate social drinking with friends.

'Research shows we tend to drink more when we're anxious, so you're more likely to exceed sensible limits with strangers than friends. And many people will have a drink before they go out, to boost their confidence in a social situation where they don't know many people. The trouble is, a drink is like a friend in itself - there with you at a funeral, a wedding, Christmas. It helps get you through and it can be hard to resist when it's so familiar.'

Farrell, who works for a Community Alcohol Team that promotes controlled drinking, talks a lot about safe limits. But Dr James West of the therapeutic website, www.recoveryconnection.com, says that quantity isn't necessarily the issue; it's the way we drink more than how much. 'Amounts vary. But whatever they do, healthy social drinkers don't chase after good feelings by drinking more and more until they lose control.'

It's the loss of control that many so-called social drinkers relish. Some refer to it as 'taking a holiday from life' and seem unconcerned or amused that they arrive home without their shoes, for example, and with no recollection of how this happened. Such stories merely fuel the laughter at their next drinking session. Only in retrospect does such a lifestyle occasionally seem the symptom of a life leaving the rails.

Justine, a City of London banker in her early thirties, describes how she and her friends spent their twenties 'getting wasted'. 'I think we had a lot of responsibility much younger than previous generations, and it was acceptable to have a drink at the end of a long day to unwind. We never used to eat, because that makes it into a different evening - you don't want to be isolated by sitting at a table, when you could be moving around, socialising at the bar and meeting more people. More men. And a lot of girls at that age did what I did, which was not eat because you feel you can't afford the calories in addition to the wine calories.'

Justine's drinking career came to an end in rehab, after she was hauled up at work for coping less and less well with the pressures of her job. 'I was probably hungover for years, which ironically made work seem even tougher.' Justine may now be older and wiser, but so-called 'presenteeism' - employees being present but not functioning properly - is now estimated to account for a significant portion of the £2.8billion lost to British industry annually.

Andrew MacNeill has another name for the problems associated with social drinking: 'the paradox of prevention'.

'People tend to think of problem drinking as emanating from two groups - alcoholics and teenagers. In other words, from heavy drinkers. In fact, although they drink to excess less frequently, so-called moderate or social drinkers contribute more to the total pool of alcohol-related problems such as absenteeism, low productivity, health costs and so on, because there are simply more of them. So the paradox is that if you somehow prevented the heavy drinkers from drinking, these problems wouldn't disappear at all.'

After a few thousand years of acceptability, social drinking is not about to go away; it's pointless for the puritanical minority to wish that it would. W magazine quotes therapist David Burr: 'Dealing with problem drinking is anything but a science. This is what we hear all the time: "What a day I had, I sure could use a drink." If this person said, "What a day I had, I sure could use a shot of heroin," the reaction would be very different.'

The answer for most of us, therefore, is not abstinence, but education - including a sophisticated repertoire, not of cocktail recipes or chic watering holes, but of 'drink avoidance strategies'. (Some of these are given below.) As expert Dr Alan Marlatt, points out, 'A good social drinker is knowledgeable about alcohol; knows their limits, and eats beforehand, possibly even deciding before they arrive at the venue how many drinks they are going to have.'

It's also worth bearing in mind that it isn't necessarily drink that can change you from the office wallflower into the life and soul of the party. One of the myths about alcohol is that people who drink can't control how they act. Yet in a famous study conducted by Marlatt, a group of young men were given drinks they thought contained alcohol, which really did not. Their behaviour became progressively more aggressive, loud and flirtatious - implying that, as with hypnotism, you'll only grope your biggest client or sing karaoke if you really want to.

 If you feel you or a member of your family might have a drinking problem, the following recovery services may be able to help: AA helpline: 0845 769 7555 (promotes abstinence; also has religious affiliations); Alcohol and Drug Services: 0161 834 9777 (promotes controlled drinking); Drinkline: 0800 917 8282. Consulting your GP may affect any future health insurance or life assurance.

Drinking tips

 Always eat something before having your first alcoholic drink.

 Keep track of your consumption: no more than five units of alcohol in one session is a good maxim.

 Switch your drink to one with less alcohol, eg swap cocktails and spirits for beer or wine, or swap lager or wine for Spritzers or low-alcohol beer.

 Use the same wine glass for wine and water alternately, so you have to drink the water before you can have any more wine.

 Go out later in the evening to restrict the length of drinking session.

 Buy smaller glasses for entertaining at home.

 Never top up your glass; wait until it is empty.

Some names have been changed
