fields.headline: Hot date
fields.standfirst: With its high fibre, vitamin and mineral content, dried fruit is a perfect partner for the party season
fields.trailText: With its high fibre, vitamin and mineral content, dried fruit is a perfect partner for the party season.
fields.body:
If you're as well organised as my mum, you'll probably have made your mince pies and Christmas cake weeks ago. If so, you may now have a stash of leftover dried fruit tucked away in your kitchen awaiting the moment when you next feel peckish. Indeed, dried fruit can last weeks if it is stored properly, which means you can buy it in bulk without worrying about it going to waste. Small packets of dried fruit are also easy to carry around in a handbag, satchel or briefcase so that they are conveniently to hand when you need an energising and nutritious snack between meals.

The nutritional qualities of dried fruit, such as Medjool dates, Agen prunes, Lexia raisins and apricots or pears, equal those of their fresh counterparts, although the benefits to health offered by fresh and dried fruit vary. Most notably, because most of the water has been removed, dried fruit contains a higher concentration of energy-giving fructose (fruit sugar) per mouthful than fresh fruit. Unlike a chocolate, sweet or sugary biscuit, which gives an instant buzz, but then causes your mood and energy levels to crash, the boost you derive from dried fruit is normally gentle and, because it also contains fibre, it enables your blood-sugar level to remain stable.

Dried fruit therefore provides a sustained energy source, even more so if you remember to drink water between mouthfuls, because fluid helps the cellulose in the fruit's fibrous cell walls to swell, thereby providing a barrier that has an inhibitive effect on the rate at which sugar is absorbed. The fibre in dried fruit can cushion the stomach's absorption of fat, too, so if you're off to a Christmas party where you suspect that rich or fatty canapés may be served, eat a few dried fruits beforehand. This strategy will also slow down the rate at which your body absorbs alcohol and will help to keep your blood-sugar level stable, making a hangover the next day either less likely or less fierce, depending on how exuberantly you have been celebrating.

Because fibre stimulates stretch receptors within the stomach wall to send signals to the hypothalamus, the sector of the brain which registers fullness, eating dried fruit can additionally discourage you from eating too many fatty or high-calorie foods. The greater the variety of tastes, textures and other sensory stimuli a meal contains, the greater the number of satiety signals your hypothalamus receives, with the result that you will feel satisfyingly replete more quickly. Teaming dried fruit with cheese, for instance, will increase your feelings of satiety through the contrasts in taste and texture, as well as the fibre in the dried fruit.

Although eating dried fruit in moderation can help keep you trim, don't be tempted to binge, as a large intake of fructose can not only cause a dramatic sugar surge, but can saddle you with unwanted calories. The high concentration of fruit sugar can adversely affect sensitive digestions, causing cramps, pain, wind and sometimes diarrhoea. This is because the gut doesn't appreciate being exposed to large concentrations of sugar, which prompt its muscle walls to react abnormally, the fluid balance within its cells to change and its bacterial culture to become disturbed. All in all, it's best to stick to a couple of pieces of dried fruit at a time.

At this time of year, when the central heating is at full blast and we are likely to turn to alcohol and caffeine to warm us up, we can easily become dehydrated, causing the bowel to behave sluggishly and become constipated. If you are starting to feel like a dried prune, let the real thing come to your rescue: along with figs, prunes - either as they come or soaked and then puréed - are particularly effective laxatives. Providing a gentler, tastier and healthier alternative to the laxatives found at pharmacies, a couple of large spoonfuls of puréed dried fruit can stimulate even young children's bowels.

Dried fruit also contains B vitamins, which help to maintain a healthy nervous system, and magnesium, which helps the body release energy, build strong bones, teeth and muscles and absorb other minerals, such as calcium (found in dried fruits such as figs and apricots, as is zinc, the infection-fighting nutrient). Figs, raisins, apricots and prunes all contain iron, too, so they can make a valuable contribution to the health of your blood and immune system, as well as encouraging growth.

When shopping for dried fruit, bear the following in mind. First, opt for organic dried fruits rather than those that have been exposed to sulphur dioxide (SO <->2 ), which can provoke digestive problems and breathlessness in some people. This is used to prolong the shelf life, as well as to give a brighter colour (an untreated apricot is quite dark, while its treated counterpart is bright orange). Second, take the moisture content into consideration. Some have been dried so savagely that they resemble rock-hard, shrivelled bullets, and although you can soak them (a process that makes Hunza apricots particularly delicious), this negates the convenience factor of their otherwise easy transportability. Choose dried fruit that looks as though it has a little 'give' under the skin, and this will in turn give you the greatest nutritional rewards.

 Jane Clarke is a registered dietician and author of the Bodyfoods series of books.

The nutritional qualities of dried fruit, such as Medjool dates, Agen prunes, Lexia raisins and apricots or pears, equal those of their fresh counterparts, although the benefits to health offered by fresh and dried fruit vary. Most notably, because most of the water has been removed, dried fruit contains a higher concentration of energy-giving fructose (fruit sugar) per mouthful than fresh fruit. Unlike a chocolate, sweet or sugary biscuit, which gives an instant buzz, but then causes your mood and energy levels to crash, the boost you derive from dried fruit is normally gentle and, because it also contains fibre, it enables your blood-sugar level to remain stable. Dried fruit therefore provides a sustained energy source, even more so if you remember to drink water between mouthfuls, because fluid helps the cellulose in the fruit's fibrous cell walls to swell, thereby providing a barrier that has an inhibitive effect on the rate at which sugar is absorbed. The fibre in dried fruit can cushion the stomach's absorption of fat, too, so if you're off to a Christmas party where you suspect that rich or fatty canapés may be served, eat a few dried fruits beforehand. This strategy will also slow down the rate at which your body absorbs alcohol and will help to keep your blood-sugar level stable, making a hangover the next day either less likely or less fierce, depending on how exuberantly you have been celebrating. Because fibre stimulates stretch receptors within the stomach wall to send signals to the hypothalamus, the sector of the brain which registers fullness, eating dried fruit can additionally discourage you from eating too many fatty or high-calorie foods. The greater the variety of tastes, textures and other sensory stimuli a meal contains, the greater the number of satiety signals your hypothalamus receives, with the result that you will feel satisfyingly replete more quickly. Teaming dried fruit with cheese, for instance, will increase your feelings of satiety through the contrasts in taste and texture, as well as the fibre in the dried fruit. Although eating dried fruit in moderation can help keep you trim, don't be tempted to binge, as a large intake of fructose can not only cause a dramatic sugar surge, but can saddle you with unwanted calories. The high concentration of fruit sugar can adversely affect sensitive digestions, causing cramps, pain, wind and sometimes diarrhoea. This is because the gut doesn't appreciate being exposed to large concentrations of sugar, which prompt its muscle walls to react abnormally, the fluid balance within its cells to change and its bacterial culture to become disturbed. All in all, it's best to stick to a couple of pieces of dried fruit at a time. At this time of year, when the central heating is at full blast and we are likely to turn to alcohol and caffeine to warm us up, we can easily become dehydrated, causing the bowel to behave sluggishly and become constipated. If you are starting to feel like a dried prune, let the real thing come to your rescue: along with figs, prunes - either as they come or soaked and then puréed - are particularly effective laxatives. Providing a gentler, tastier and healthier alternative to the laxatives found at pharmacies, a couple of large spoonfuls of puréed dried fruit can stimulate even young children's bowels. Dried fruit also contains B vitamins, which help to maintain a healthy nervous system, and magnesium, which helps the body release energy, build strong bones, teeth and muscles and absorb other minerals, such as calcium (found in dried fruits such as figs and apricots, as is zinc, the infection-fighting nutrient). Figs, raisins, apricots and prunes all contain iron, too, so they can make a valuable contribution to the health of your blood and immune system, as well as encouraging growth. When shopping for dried fruit, bear the following in mind. First, opt for organic dried fruits rather than those that have been exposed to sulphur dioxide (SO <->2 ), which can provoke digestive problems and breathlessness in some people. This is used to prolong the shelf life, as well as to give a brighter colour (an untreated apricot is quite dark, while its treated counterpart is bright orange). Second, take the moisture content into consideration. Some have been dried so savagely that they resemble rock-hard, shrivelled bullets, and although you can soak them (a process that makes Hunza apricots particularly delicious), this negates the convenience factor of their otherwise easy transportability. Choose dried fruit that looks as though it has a little 'give' under the skin, and this will in turn give you the greatest nutritional rewards.  Jane Clarke is a registered dietician and author of the Bodyfoods series of books.

webTitle: Who Put The Bomp (In The Bomp-Bomp-Bomp)? and more of pop's most important questions

fields.headline: Who Put The Bomp (In The Bomp-Bomp-Bomp)? and more of pop's most important questions
fields.standfirst: Ever fallen in love with someone you shouldn't have? Mariella Frostrup has. Do you remember the first time? Rowan Pelling does. And who's sorry now? Not the Velvet Underground's John Cale. Music has always asked the big questions, and over the following five pages you'll find some of the answers, my friend...

fields.body:
Who Put The Bomp (In The Bomp-Bomp-Bomp)?
By Neil Spencer

Exactly who put the bomp in the bomp-bomp-bomp, the ram in the rama-dama-ding-dong and the oop in the oop-shoop, and the wop in doo-wop, remains a mystery mired in the greasy annals of teenage pre-history, back around the late 1940s and early 1950s. Maybe it's better that way, that the glories of the bomp belong not to an individual or two, but to a cavalcade of creators. You didn't need instruments, just a few guys who could sing, a stairwell for an amplifier and a dream of following heroes like The Inkspots or the Mills Brothers, or just of impressing the girls from the next block.

Just as some people fall in love with 1950s American cars, I fell for doo-wop, and for much the same reasons. It was flashy, ridiculous, and dated, but extravagant and beautiful (doo-wop groups often named themselves after cars - The Cadillacs, The Impalas, The Bel-Airs). And just as the motor industry has never indulged in chrome and fins in the same way, so pop has never equalled doo-wop's surreal Esperanto.

What was the bomp saying? That hoodlums, too, had poetry in their soul, that syrupy sentiments and vocal pyrotechnics might articulate a nobler romanticism and sweatier passion than the bland jingles of Tin Pan Alley. Its golden era, in the mid-50s, favoured slushy ballads such as 'Earth Angel' by The Penguins and 'The Great Pretender' by The Platters, though there was always room for the deeply crazed, such as 'Rang Tang Ding Dong (I Am A Japanese Sandman)' by The Cellos, which was last heard on the soundtrack to Bring Out Your Dead, Martin Scorsese being a doo-wop diehard.

Motown and The Beatles owed it big-time and without The Regents's 'Barbara Ann', The Beach Boys would have likely stayed a barbershop quartet. Today's boy bands and girl groups palely reflect its majesty. But will Westlife ever sing 'Shananana-badoo-dip-dip-dip-boom-boom-doo-wah' in perfect four-part harmony? Nah.

Do Fries Go With That Shake?
By Marion McGilvary

The fat life's a bitch and then you diet. Every morning I roll over in bed, the aftershock of my arse just a fraction of a second behind the rest of me, and think: OK, no bread. No butter. No starch. No sugar. No cashew nuts. No olives. Remember, you don't even like olives. I make elaborate dietary rules with the zeal of a Rabbinical scholar, and then spend hours looking for loopholes: no drinking. Well, no drinking at lunch. Unless there's champagne. No wine - unless it is a fine red, or a white burgundy. And then only one glass. Or maybe one each, if it's rude to refuse.

But the curves have their compensations. At last, I've something worth getting off my chest. And my new cleavage acts as a reliable decoy for everything else further south. Rather than love handles, I have footholds with rest areas and scenic outposts. This, then, is why they call it a balcony bra. But I've discovered that the reason women take refuge in serious underwiring is really nothing to do with display. What you are really trying to do is strap the damn things down.

I know, I know, the answer is simple - lose weight, eat less, drink water, exercise. But, sadly, I am a woman with large appetites.

Ever Fallen In Love (With Someone You Shouldn't've)?
By Mariella Frostrup

Well, let's face it, that's a rhetorical question if ever I heard one. Surely the definition of 'love' is a completely illogical attraction to someone you have no business being in the same country as let alone the same bed? The million-dollar question is have you ever fallen in love with anyone you should have? I did.

I had a boyfriend once who baked me cakes, picked up my dry-cleaning, told me every morning as I opened my eyes that he loved me. Sent flowers because he felt like it not because he ought to. Talked to my mother when she called and tidied up my clothes strewn throughout the flat.

I wanted to kill him. Why on earth would you want all that devotion when you can pine away for the mysterious man in the corner, earn detective stripes during subsequent weeks by uncovering every detail about his life, his friends and most importantly the places he frequents. Through sheer perseverance you finally force him to notice you. You listen understandingly while he tells you that he's not looking for a relationship, and then force him into one. The triumph is invariably followed by the discovery that what you mistook for enigma was actually a near comatic state brought on by hard drugs, heavy drinking and a brain gone numb through dating too many teenagers. Nevertheless, you stick to him like a barnacle and forgive his appalling digressions, because it's your fault.

He told you he didn't want a 'serious' relationship; just because he moved in with you three months later is no reason to disbelieve him. Three years later, you're still trying to turn him into the perfect boyfriend who bakes you cakes, tells you daily that he loves you, tidies up your clothes and talks to your mother on the phone for hours on end. Finally, it all gets too painful and tiring, so you pack up and leave. A few weeks at home licking your wounds and your girlfriends force you to stop grieving and go out.

You see a mysterious enigmatic man pretending to ignore the adoring women draped all over him and bingo. You're in love all over again!

(How Much Is) That Doggie In The Window?
By Martin Love

I always thought I'd have two children. I have one brother and my wife has a sister, so after the birth of our second child I thought that would be that. I drew a line under my baby-making days (and nights) and even considered a vasectomy - though a combination of cowardice and prudery prevented me from becoming less of a man.

But strange whisperings started emanating from the family-planning department of our home (my wife to you and me). Two was too neat, apparently. It made us look as if we didn't really like children, apparently. And then the clincher - her best friend was suddenly pregnant, with number three. Three was now the new two point four.

At first I was able to dismiss the murmurings. But they grew, until eventually it became clear my wife would feel incomplete until another fluffy-headed creature entered our lives. I resorted to emergency plan B.

In parenting circles, it is commonly known that the arrival of a puppy is a signal to the wider community that you have had your last child. 'Did you see that the Smiths have got the sweetest new dog?' 'Oh, really! So they're stopping at three are they?'

I bought the local free-ads paper and started scanning the 'dogs for sale' column. Before we knew it, we were all in the car, driving north to the home of Poppy the pointer and her good friend Alfie.

The arrival of the fifth member of our family wasn't as agonising as the third and fourth, but it wasn't without pain. She cost £250 for a start, but taking her from under the unsuspecting snouts of Poppy and Alfie left a deeper hurt which made us feel like home-breakers rather than home-builders. We're dog burglars.

But Winifred is already one of the family. And as for being a baby-substitute well, my wife doesn't seem to worry about giving out the wrong signals.

Do You Remember The First Time?
By Rowan Pelling

What sort of damn fool question is that? Even advanced-staged amnesiacs with memory gaps so large you could pothole through them remember the day they lost the cherry - and whom they lost it to. The memory is even stronger for those of us who didn't surrender our virtue in the traditional manner - as an act of alcohol-fuelled teenage rebellion at a party, or on a Cornish beach.

I was grimly determined that I would never drop my knickers for some pimply adolescent whose balls had only just plummeted and who'd return the favour by telling his mates that I was easy, or, worse still, ugly and easy: a 'monster-munch' (Sevenoaks schoolboy slang circa 1985).

I had an older and more debonair model in mind. Someone who entertained a vague notion that sex should be enjoyable for both parties. Someone who combined the qualities of Darcy, Rochester and Byron in one smouldering package. Frankly, when you consider my expectations, I'm amazed I managed to get laid at all.

I was 20 when I finally divested myself of my virginity. Not to one of my university contemporaries, but to a hawkish artist in north Oxford who was 12 years older than me. He asked me to sit for him, naked, and with the minimum of fuss I slipped from his studio into his bed. It was an entirely pleasurable experience, and at the time I thought myself in love. In the morning he served up boiled eggs then packed me off to college (a performance we repeated several times over). It set a useful precedent because forever afterwards I have associated sex with art and breakfast - gratification on all levels.

How Do You Speak To An Angel?
By Stuart Husband

My mother had a pathological fear of 'causing a fuss'. That's why, by the time she was persuaded to get herself to a hospital, the cancer was beyond inoperable. I barely had time to make it back from the Far East before it consumed her. It may have been merciful, but the brevity of her annihilation - for that's what it felt like - left us stunned and incredulous.

I went to a medium some months later; there was a dull ache in my head that I couldn't shift. Nesta lived on a Brookside-style estate in Finchley. She was white-haired and smelled faintly of violets - one of my mum's favourite flowers. Her trim little house was adorned with certificates from various psychic associations. She asked me to bring something that belonged to the person I wished to contact. All I had was an old photo of Mum, which she held picture-side-down, stroking the underside of it with her thumb. Ah yes, she said, with no preamble. Your mum's passed on. I can see her, she said. She looks like she did as a young girl, and she's with Bob, Arthur, Jane, Joan and Rusty.

I didn't recognise any of the names, and I was starting to nod out in the fumes coming from Nesta's gas fire. Then she said, your mother's been back to see you and your sisters. She named my sisters. She said, your eldest sister's marriage broke up, but don't worry, she'll find love again (it had and she has). She said, your niece plays the piano like your mother did. She wants her to keep it up (she did but, sadly, she hasn't). She said, your mum wants you to nurture your writing talent (I've tried).

The air in the room seemed to have thinned.

I could hear my heart pumping. Rearranging my limbs seemed to take a gigantic effort. Nesta said, then there's your dad. Your mum's very worried because he keeps that cup of water by the back door to throw over next door's cats when they come into his precious garden and he hasn't done it recently, even though the cats have been in (he did and he hadn't). She said, that's how she knows how upset he is. He does this a lot, doesn't he, she said, smoothing her hair back over her ears. Yes, I said. Well, she said, your mum will stand behind his chair and take his hands when he does that. He'll feel her presence. It'll comfort him.

I said, where is she now? Nesta said, in a part of her life where she was carefree and safe. I said, why would she come back? Nesta said, those who pass on feel as much pain as those left behind. She needs to see you as much as you need to feel she's still around. That need won't ever go away, but it'll diminish over time. I left feeling dazed but oddly comforted. The ache softened.

Later I asked my gran about Bob, Arthur, Jane and Joan. They turned out to be mum's best friends from her Devon childhood. Rusty was a dog from a local farm who used to play with them. They roamed all over the village, said Gran. They were happy as mice. I'm still a sceptic, albeit one that admits the inexplicable. But now when I think of Mum, I don't see her watering eyes as she coughs up blood in the morning, or her wince of pain as she takes my hand in hospital and fights for breath; I see her running through a Devon churchyard, feeling immortal, shouting at the top of her pristine lungs. And I'll always be grateful to Nesta for that.

Who's Sorry Now?
By John Cale
(Recalling the end of Velvet Underground)

Not me. I was sure we had done whatever we could. I could sleep like a baby. The Velvet Underground was synonymous with many things other than its members and their proclivities, precisely because it erected its music as a barricade. It still hides behind it.

From its inception in Andy Warhol's Factory in 1964, everything in the Velvets was shared (except the songs, which were on a case by case). The lyrics came straight from the subconscious and we had divined a theorem behind this to blend the hypnotic viola drone of my first American band, the Dream Syndicate, with a none-too-benign interest in subliminal advertising. But after the last reunion tour no one was hypnotised anymore - especially us. Collaboration was dead and the waters were poisoned. How happy was I to leave?

I was catatonic with relief. If a personal injury attorney had heard our gripes, where would he start? He called you what? And you lost how much libido? And which part of 'fuck you' exactly did you not understand?

I had hoped for greater things. Perhaps a Velvet Underground Golf Tourney - teeing off at midnight with black balls on Dartmoor; or a Test Match in the dark with fluorescent balls and wickets anything but the mediocrity we had become.

Returning to my solo work was the only sensible answer. Sadder still, it was the possibility of a last-minute apology from Lou [Reed] - looking like a hustle - that made walking away inevitable. Still, the years and days spent in the 'frolic' held me in their grip for a long time, but a scrutiny of the massacre that personal ambition can wreak revealed a centre as mysterious and menacing as any Algerian souk.

Should I Stay Or Should I Go?
By Miranda Sawyer

The tricky time is 3am. Up until that time, you can fool yourself that you'll recover: that if you go home, drink tea, sleep deep, then everything will be all right, your soul remain unblackened, your mind unscarred, your health unimpaired, your reputation sully-free.

After three, it doesn't really matter. Half past five, seven o'clock, a quarter past Tuesday; the damage is done. Go or stay, it won't make much difference in the morning. So, let's stay! But now that I am older, and drug-shy, then staying brings other considerations. My fidget-minded, eager-to-move drunken state does not always match my companions' moods, and vice versa. So, go, then But if I go too early, I'll be rattling round the sitting room, searching for videos, making late-night phonecalls, frantic, frustrated. Yet if I stay too long, my eyes will bleed from boredom with another cokehead's bilious rant, another E-freak's surreality, another drunk's tedious bluster. (And yes, that could well be my own.) Should I stay? I mean, I might, I just might have the night of my life. Should I go? It's not looking that likely It's 2.55am. What do you reckon?

Why Does A Man Have To Be Strong?
By Richard Benson

Best ask the ladies. They change their minds about this so often that the modern male, fumbling with their feelings like a teenage boy with a bra strap, can't even hope to keep up. Modern women have told modern men they want openness. Sensitivity. Vulnerability even, with the occasional tear dropped in.

But among their female friends they sometimes admit something different altogether; that sensitivity and vulnerability only really work when they're teased out of an otherwise strong, traditionally masculine man. There are those who will tell you that in an age of car-buying, beer-quaffing woman and face-cleansing, Beckhamesque males, there is little sense of men having to be strong. They're wrong. 'A man who isn't sure of himself isn't sexy,' said one marketresearcher's focus groupee this year; suggesting, surely, that the reason that a man still has to be strong is the oldest and most common reason for anything - ie, getting a shag. I don't expect the girls to agree, though.

How Do You Sleep?
By Barbara Ellen

Insomnia is the cat burglar of afflictions - striking without warning, at the dead of night, stealing away everything you hold dear. Your time, your energy, your tomorrows. Lying in the dark, staring insanely - at the ceiling, the floor, the walls, the black void that used to be your life. Come morning, we are the walking, talking undead. Vampires without portfolio. Zombies with workstations. Hollow-eyed, twitchy, caffeine-dependent messes of humanity who nod off at our desks. I've tried everything. Not drinking coffee after lunchtime. Not drinking coffee at all. Slurping down milky drinks at midnight. Emptying my mind of all the vile detritus of daily life, and instead 'visualising' something 'restful' and 'pleasant' - say a sparkly fountain or a field full of bunny rabbits. It makes no odds.

It seems that however much an insomniac strives to be 'relaxed', counting sheep invariably turns into counting problems, nursing grievances, giving people what for. I've had some of the biggest, nastiest arguments of my life while lying alone and sleepless in the dark. Unlike real life, I haven't lost one yet. Sleep deprivation is still used as a torture in some countries, and with insomnia, it is as if we are our own torturers. It's difficult to describe to non-sufferers how debilitating it is. 'Just get some sleep,' they say airily, in a way they would never tell someone in a wheelchair to 'just walk it off'. That's another downside of insomnia - whereas you are, shall we say, wide awake to your nightly agonies, the rest of the world seems fast asleep.

What Have They Done To The Rain?
By Robin Mckie

Quite a lot, really. After decades of pumping clouds of sulphur and nitrogen oxides into the atmosphere, the world's industrial nations have created clouds so acidic they could turn litmus tests into red-light districts. The heating of our atmosphere with has produced climatic mayhem. In consecutive years, the south of England is either turned into a version of the Gobi desert, or a vast, flooded basin that rivals the Everglades. Or to put it another way, a hard rain's gonna fall

If I Said You Had A Beautiful Body Would You Hold It Against Me?
By Euan Ferguson

Almost definitely not, although it's still not the crassest chat-up line of all time. That honour must go to one of England's best living poets, a notorious philanderer who once leant furtively across the table at a dinner party, his hand resting casually under the table on the knee of a lady not his wife, and tried to charm her with the phrase: 'I put it to you that your c*** is on fire' This practically unbeatable mix of crudeness and pomposity led Jonathan Coe to immortalise the line in his novel The House of Sleep, where it should probably stay forever.

There is, in fact, no real excuse for using chat-up lines these days. First, if a man and a woman want to sleep with each other from the start, they will know this instantly and subsequent conversation is a mere bagatelle, a clearing of the throat; unless the man actually attempts to enrich such conversation by moving too early to talk of coprophilia, or works in marketing, the fix is in and nature will take its happy course.

It's all in the confidence, the delivery, the eyes and the ability to listen to the answer, and come back quickly, and keep listening for a long time afterwards. Pericles's funeral oration or Homer Simpson's Beer Song, it doesn't matter: if women like the sass, they will, surprisingly often, ignore the stringwarts. (The other scenario - when the woman is more desperate for the man - is hardly worth bothering about. It's obvious from the start, or the Mancunian accent will be a giveaway.)

Perhaps there was a time when even the most rapt and magnetised couple had to break the ice somehow, with a 'Come here often?' or 'Which end of the bath do you sit at?'; back in those innocent days, before the silent, violent honesty of direct eye contact gave the game away in seconds.

But today, nobody is stupid enough to use chat-up lines with any degree of seriousness. Women know they're cheesy, men know they're cheesy, and the only decision, if you're going to use them, is do you go for simple cheddar, such as 'My name is Euan. Remember that, because you'll be screaming it later'? Or for gorgonzola? 'Well, here I am. What were your other two wishes?' Do you follow the ballsaching Michael Douglas line to Catherine Zeta-Jones ('I want to be the father of your children') by actually being dirty-cheesy? 'Nice legs... what time do they open?' or the quite fantastically unsuccessful old Scots favourite: 'D'ye like chicken?' ('Yes'). 'Well, suck this - it's foul.'

You might as well ask, simply, 'Do you mind if I chat you up for a while?' As long as you look like you like her, and look like you like yourself. With these two sorted, you could probably even risk the Bellamy Brothers.

At first I was able to dismiss the murmurings. But they grew, until eventually it became clear my wife would feel incomplete until another fluffy-headed creature entered our lives. I resorted to emergency plan B. In parenting circles, it is commonly known that the arrival of a puppy is a signal to the wider community that you have had your last child. 'Did you see that the Smiths have got the sweetest new dog?' 'Oh, really! So they're stopping at three are they?' I bought the local free-ads paper and started scanning the 'dogs for sale' column. Before we knew it, we were all in the car, driving north to the home of Poppy the pointer and her good friend Alfie. The arrival of the fifth member of our family wasn't as agonising as the third and fourth, but it wasn't without pain. She cost £250 for a start, but taking her from under the unsuspecting snouts of Poppy and Alfie left a deeper hurt which made us feel like home-breakers rather than home-builders. We're dog burglars. But Winifred is already one of the family. And as for being a baby-substitute well, my wife doesn't seem to worry about giving out the wrong signals. Do You Remember The First Time? By Rowan Pelling What sort of damn fool question is that? Even advanced-staged amnesiacs with memory gaps so large you could pothole through them remember the day they lost the cherry - and whom they lost it to. The memory is even stronger for those of us who didn't surrender our virtue in the traditional manner - as an act of alcohol-fuelled teenage rebellion at a party, or on a Cornish beach. I was grimly determined that I would never drop my knickers for some pimply adolescent whose balls had only just plummeted and who'd return the favour by telling his mates that I was easy, or, worse still, ugly and easy: a 'monster-munch' (Sevenoaks schoolboy slang circa 1985). I had an older and more debonair model in mind. Someone who entertained a vague notion that sex should be enjoyable for both parties. Someone who combined the qualities of Darcy, Rochester and Byron in one smouldering package. Frankly, when you consider my expectations, I'm amazed I managed to get laid at all. I was 20 when I finally divested myself of my virginity. Not to one of my university contemporaries, but to a hawkish artist in north Oxford who was 12 years older than me. He asked me to sit for him, naked, and with the minimum of fuss I slipped from his studio into his bed. It was an entirely pleasurable experience, and at the time I thought myself in love. In the morning he served up boiled eggs then packed me off to college (a performance we repeated several times over). It set a useful precedent because forever afterwards I have associated sex with art and breakfast - gratification on all levels. How Do You Speak To An Angel? By Stuart Husband My mother had a pathological fear of 'causing a fuss'. That's why, by the time she was persuaded to get herself to a hospital, the cancer was beyond inoperable. I barely had time to make it back from the Far East before it consumed her. It may have been merciful, but the brevity of her annihilation - for that's what it felt like - left us stunned and incredulous. I went to a medium some months later; there was a dull ache in my head that I couldn't shift. Nesta lived on a Brookside-style estate in Finchley. She was white-haired and smelled faintly of violets - one of my mum's favourite flowers. Her trim little house was adorned with certificates from various psychic associations. She asked me to bring something that belonged to the person I wished to contact. All I had was an old photo of Mum, which she held picture-side-down, stroking the underside of it with her thumb. Ah yes, she said, with no preamble. Your mum's passed on. I can see her, she said. She looks like she did as a young girl, and she's with Bob, Arthur, Jane, Joan and Rusty. I didn't recognise any of the names, and I was starting to nod out in the fumes coming from Nesta's gas fire. Then she said, your mother's been back to see you and your sisters. She named my sisters. She said, your eldest sister's marriage broke up, but don't worry, she'll find love again (it had and she has). She said, your niece plays the piano like your mother did. She wants her to keep it up (she did but, sadly, she hasn't). She said, your mum wants you to nurture your writing talent (I've tried). The air in the room seemed to have thinned. I could hear my heart pumping. Rearranging my limbs seemed to take a gigantic effort. Nesta said, then there's your dad. Your mum's very worried because he keeps that cup of water by the back door to throw over next door's cats when they come into his precious garden and he hasn't done it recently, even though the cats have been in (he did and he hadn't). She said, that's how she knows how upset he is. He does this a lot, doesn't he, she said, smoothing her hair back over her ears. Yes, I said. Well, she said, your mum will stand behind his chair and take his hands when he does that. He'll feel her presence. It'll comfort him. I said, where is she now? Nesta said, in a part of her life where she was carefree and safe. I said, why would she come back? Nesta said, those who pass on feel as much pain as those left behind. She needs to see you as much as you need to feel she's still around. That need won't ever go away, but it'll diminish over time. I left feeling dazed but oddly comforted. The ache softened. Later I asked my gran about Bob, Arthur, Jane and Joan. They turned out to be mum's best friends from her Devon childhood. Rusty was a dog from a local farm who used to play with them. They roamed all over the village, said Gran. They were happy as mice. I'm still a sceptic, albeit one that admits the inexplicable. But now when I think of Mum, I don't see her watering eyes as she coughs up blood in the morning, or her wince of pain as she takes my hand in hospital and fights for breath; I see her running through a Devon churchyard, feeling immortal, shouting at the top of her pristine lungs. And I'll always be grateful to Nesta for that. Who's Sorry Now? By John Cale (Recalling the end of Velvet Underground) Not me. I was sure we had done whatever we could. I could sleep like a baby. The Velvet Underground was synonymous with many things other than its members and their proclivities, precisely because it erected its music as a barricade. It still hides behind it. From its inception in Andy Warhol's Factory in 1964, everything in the Velvets was shared (except the songs, which were on a case by case). The lyrics came straight from the subconscious and we had divined a theorem behind this to blend the hypnotic viola drone of my first American band, the Dream Syndicate, with a none-too-benign interest in subliminal advertising. But after the last reunion tour no one was hypnotised anymore - especially us. Collaboration was dead and the waters were poisoned. How happy was I to leave? I was catatonic with relief. If a personal injury attorney had heard our gripes, where would he start? He called you what? And you lost how much libido? And which part of 'fuck you' exactly did you not understand? I had hoped for greater things. Perhaps a Velvet Underground Golf Tourney - teeing off at midnight with black balls on Dartmoor; or a Test Match in the dark with fluorescent balls and wickets anything but the mediocrity we had become. Returning to my solo work was the only sensible answer. Sadder still, it was the possibility of a last-minute apology from Lou [Reed] - looking like a hustle - that made walking away inevitable. Still, the years and days spent in the 'frolic' held me in their grip for a long time, but a scrutiny of the massacre that personal ambition can wreak revealed a centre as mysterious and menacing as any Algerian souk. Should I Stay Or Should I Go? By Miranda Sawyer The tricky time is 3am. Up until that time, you can fool yourself that you'll recover: that if you go home, drink tea, sleep deep, then everything will be all right, your soul remain unblackened, your mind unscarred, your health unimpaired, your reputation sully-free. After three, it doesn't really matter. Half past five, seven o'clock, a quarter past Tuesday; the damage is done. Go or stay, it won't make much difference in the morning. So, let's stay! But now that I am older, and drug-shy, then staying brings other considerations. My fidget-minded, eager-to-move drunken state does not always match my companions' moods, and vice versa. So, go, then But if I go too early, I'll be rattling round the sitting room, searching for videos, making late-night phonecalls, frantic, frustrated. Yet if I stay too long, my eyes will bleed from boredom with another cokehead's bilious rant, another E-freak's surreality, another drunk's tedious bluster. (And yes, that could well be my own.) Should I stay? I mean, I might, I just might have the night of my life. Should I go? It's not looking that likely It's 2.55am. What do you reckon? Why Does A Man Have To Be Strong? By Richard Benson Best ask the ladies. They change their minds about this so often that the modern male, fumbling with their feelings like a teenage boy with a bra strap, can't even hope to keep up. Modern women have told modern men they want openness. Sensitivity. Vulnerability even, with the occasional tear dropped in. But among their female friends they sometimes admit something different altogether; that sensitivity and vulnerability only really work when they're teased out of an otherwise strong, traditionally masculine man. There are those who will tell you that in an age of car-buying, beer-quaffing woman and face-cleansing, Beckhamesque males, there is little sense of men having to be strong. They're wrong. 'A man who isn't sure of himself isn't sexy,' said one marketresearcher's focus groupee this year; suggesting, surely, that the reason that a man still has to be strong is the oldest and most common reason for anything - ie, getting a shag. I don't expect the girls to agree, though. How Do You Sleep? By Barbara Ellen Insomnia is the cat burglar of afflictions - striking without warning, at the dead of night, stealing away everything you hold dear. Your time, your energy, your tomorrows. Lying in the dark, staring insanely - at the ceiling, the floor, the walls, the black void that used to be your life. Come morning, we are the walking, talking undead. Vampires without portfolio. Zombies with workstations. Hollow-eyed, twitchy, caffeine-dependent messes of humanity who nod off at our desks. I've tried everything. Not drinking coffee after lunchtime. Not drinking coffee at all. Slurping down milky drinks at midnight. Emptying my mind of all the vile detritus of daily life, and instead 'visualising' something 'restful' and 'pleasant' - say a sparkly fountain or a field full of bunny rabbits. It makes no odds. It seems that however much an insomniac strives to be 'relaxed', counting sheep invariably turns into counting problems, nursing grievances, giving people what for. I've had some of the biggest, nastiest arguments of my life while lying alone and sleepless in the dark. Unlike real life, I haven't lost one yet. Sleep deprivation is still used as a torture in some countries, and with insomnia, it is as if we are our own torturers. It's difficult to describe to non-sufferers how debilitating it is. 'Just get some sleep,' they say airily, in a way they would never tell someone in a wheelchair to 'just walk it off'. That's another downside of insomnia - whereas you are, shall we say, wide awake to your nightly agonies, the rest of the world seems fast asleep. What Have They Done To The Rain? By Robin Mckie Quite a lot, really. After decades of pumping clouds of sulphur and nitrogen oxides into the atmosphere, the world's industrial nations have created clouds so acidic they could turn litmus tests into red-light districts. The heating of our atmosphere with has produced climatic mayhem. In consecutive years, the south of England is either turned into a version of the Gobi desert, or a vast, flooded basin that rivals the Everglades. Or to put it another way, a hard rain's gonna fall If I Said You Had A Beautiful Body Would You Hold It Against Me? By Euan Ferguson Almost definitely not, although it's still not the crassest chat-up line of all time. That honour must go to one of England's best living poets, a notorious philanderer who once leant furtively across the table at a dinner party, his hand resting casually under the table on the knee of a lady not his wife, and tried to charm her with the phrase: 'I put it to you that your c*** is on fire' This practically unbeatable mix of crudeness and pomposity led Jonathan Coe to immortalise the line in his novel The House of Sleep, where it should probably stay forever. There is, in fact, no real excuse for using chat-up lines these days. First, if a man and a woman want to sleep with each other from the start, they will know this instantly and subsequent conversation is a mere bagatelle, a clearing of the throat; unless the man actually attempts to enrich such conversation by moving too early to talk of coprophilia, or works in marketing, the fix is in and nature will take its happy course. It's all in the confidence, the delivery, the eyes and the ability to listen to the answer, and come back quickly, and keep listening for a long time afterwards. Pericles's funeral oration or Homer Simpson's Beer Song, it doesn't matter: if women like the sass, they will, surprisingly often, ignore the stringwarts. (The other scenario - when the woman is more desperate for the man - is hardly worth bothering about. It's obvious from the start, or the Mancunian accent will be a giveaway.) Perhaps there was a time when even the most rapt and magnetised couple had to break the ice somehow, with a 'Come here often?' or 'Which end of the bath do you sit at?'; back in those innocent days, before the silent, violent honesty of direct eye contact gave the game away in seconds. But today, nobody is stupid enough to use chat-up lines with any degree of seriousness. Women know they're cheesy, men know they're cheesy, and the only decision, if you're going to use them, is do you go for simple cheddar, such as 'My name is Euan. Remember that, because you'll be screaming it later'? Or for gorgonzola? 'Well, here I am. What were your other two wishes?' Do you follow the ballsaching Michael Douglas line to Catherine Zeta-Jones ('I want to be the father of your children') by actually being dirty-cheesy? 'Nice legs... what time do they open?' or the quite fantastically unsuccessful old Scots favourite: 'D'ye like chicken?' ('Yes'). 'Well, suck this - it's foul.' You might as well ask, simply, 'Do you mind if I chat you up for a while?' As long as you look like you like her, and look like you like yourself. With these two sorted, you could probably even risk the Bellamy Brothers.

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: The London Community Gospel Choir
fields.trailText: The London Community Gospel Choir.
fields.body:
It's difficult, in the season of minimalist Muji cardboard Christmas trees and pared-down soft-focus Gap ads, to summon up an old-fashioned Christmas spirit. Catching yourself hoping to spy the Salvation Army is a sure sign that you are desperate for something to make the hairs stand up on your neck in memory of Christmas past. The London Community Gospel Choir's Gospel Christmas allows ample opportunity to join in a rousing chorus of 'O Come All Ye Faithful' without compromising any pretensions to a hip festive season.

Despite the choir's mission to spread the word of God through their Christian performances, it has enjoyed a long association with the music of the devil. The spine-tingling chorus from Blur's 1999 epic 'Tender' showed the group in full flight and they are tipped for another spell in the charts providing backing vocals for Courtney Pine's new single. Add to this performances for Nelson Mandela, Mel B's wedding and collaborations with artists as diverse as Diana Ross, Puff Daddy and Sir Paul McCartney, and it's clear that the choir has relevance beyond the church doors.

Part of the 50-strong choir's appeal is its accessibility. Its founder, the Reverend Bazil Meade, a glamorous figure on the UK gospel scene, instituted street-style uniform for his members. In glowing white tracksuits and trainers, the group performing live resembles a host of very urban-looking angels. 'From the outset, I wanted the choir to have a very street image,' he says. 'Sometimes the robes can make you feel like you're setting yourself too far above everyone else.'

The robes will come out on Tuesday in honour of Christmas, however, to help create a seasonally spiritual atmosphere. The audience is encouraged to join in special arrangements of traditional carols, and even confirmed atheists never fail to be moved by the choir's vocal gymnastics. As the Reverend Meade points out, 'There are always people who love what the music does to them. Its lyrical pureness attacks negativity and hatred and makes people feel good inside.' Which is more than can be said for office parties and yet another sweater.

 The London Community Gospel Choir will perform at the Barbican Centre, Silk Street, London EC2 on 19 December. Call the Barbican box office (020 7638 8891) for details.

fields.headline: The gong show
fields.standfirst: Old year's eve
fields.trailText: Old year's eve.
fields.body:
I don't know what you've got planned for New Year's Eve, but I reckon I've got a fair idea. Very little. Last year, you arranged a reunion with 30 of your oldest friends. You made a once-in-a-lifetime trip to the Maldives to say goodbye to the second millennium from a beach on an island that probably won't be here for the end of this millennium's second decade. You lit bonfires, trailing their primal light across Britain. You gathered your family around you in a wind-torn Cornish farmhouse.

You stood, fuming, ticketless and slightly drunk at Stratford tube station - well, you did if you were a national newspaper editor waiting to get to your night of nights at the Dome. You got thrillingly, dangerously crushed with three million others in the centre of London. Or you sang 'Auld Lang Syne' as if you'd never heard it before and didn't do the traditional arms-crossing bit because no one had ever dared grab your hand before Tony Blair came along - if you are the Queen, that is.

Me? I watched the fireworks from Primrose Hill. They were distant and almost silent, but more than worth the walk. Then I went home for a couple of quiet drinks with a couple of loud friends.

Whatever it was, you quite likely did something you'd never done before. That was the Millennium, though, wasn't it? Maybe we were hyped or cajoled. Maybe we just grasped a rare opportunity to step outside the envelopes into which we all wrap and lick and stick ourselves. But that was last year. This year is somewhat different. No one's talking about millions raving on the paving. No one's planning big bashes. Even at this late date, few people seem to have much idea of what - if anything - they'll do. Particularly if my completely unscientific poll is anything to go by.

'I actually don't know as yet,' said my first interviewee - single, male, affluent Islington resident, with no children but own car and residual Belfast accent. 'I'll let you know when I do.' I'm still waiting.

'Nothing very interesting,' said the second - married, female, west London, with child and own ISDN link. We swapped tales of the traditional British year-ender - of the teenage dreams (inevitably disappointed) we all carry through to adult parties, of people kissed (never the ones we wanted to kiss), of the night's quiet air of despair, of the classic, depressed tenor of New Year's Eve dos: another year over - thank God - and a new one just begun - oh, God.

This year? 'A family party,' she said. Now you may not believe this, but she actually sounded enthused by the prospect. Inevitably, I thought of Mrs Patrick Campbell's famous sigh: 'Oh, for the deep, deep peace of the marital bed after the hurly-burly of the chaise longue.'

The thought recurred with my next contact - male, married, with small children and transatlantic career. 'Going to see the Burning of the Clocks in Brighton where I now reside. Then going to bed at around three minutes past midnight.'

Or how about the next one - male, married, high earner, one child and 'colourful' past. 'As if I know yet. Burying my head under the pillow, probably!'

Those who did have plans were somehow overconscious of their modesty. Take this American-born songwriter now resident in Paris, with ambitions to be the next Serge Gainsbourg - his first steps were dreadlocks

and a dancer girlfriend. This New Year, he'll be skiing in Canada. Last year, though, that was the big one - a party at Versailles with Russian gangsters. 'This New Year seems quite a let-down,' he admitted.

It's the same, perhaps even more so, for his ex-wife - English, north London, with live-in-partner but no offspring. She said she'd be spending New Year's Eve at the computer, finishing off her biography of Serge Gainsbourg.

There was a moment, in London at least, when it looked as if it was all going to be different. When Ken Livingstone and Bob Geldof got together to plan a capital night out, there was a feeling abroad that last year's grand spectaculars would become the new norm. For the night that mathematicians, calendar-fans, pedants and sub-editors insist is the real last night of the second millennium, Ken and Bob dreamed their dreams of a giant world city celebration. They even ordered the fireworks, which duly arrived at Tilbury Docks - a couple of weeks after all manner of bureaucrats kiboshed their party.

It's been replaced by 'events and activities right across Greater London'. Culture Secretary Chris Smith added - in the authentic deadening tones of a Captain Mainwaring - that 'local authorities have responded magnificently to the challenge'. That is, they've rounded up the usual prospects: beacon lighting; high-street processions culminating in the town park; small-scale laser displays; family based, multicultural firework shows.

I made the last one up, by the way - though only by pasting together elements of real shows. Still, it does sound like the time-honoured British New Year's Eve. Say it quiet, it's back and it's proud. And in bed by three minutes past midnight.

This survey was conducted over a period of three days in the second week of December. Population was unweighted sample of friends of author who returned his calls and emails.

fields.headline: The perfect sitcom
fields.standfirst: Andy Harries, executive producer of The Royle Family and Cold Feet
fields.trailText: Andy Harries, executive producer of The Royle Family and Cold Feet.
fields.body:
Everyone can tell what makes the perfect sitcom. It either makes you laugh or it doesn't. American research into comedy has shown that if you make people watch the same show over and over they'll laugh more each time they see it. People enjoy the fact that they know what's coming up.

That's what makes Fawlty Towers such a perfect farce. The characters are simple and you know that they will behave in a certain way. You know that Basil will be obnoxious, Sybil will drive him mad and Mañuel will misinterpret everything, adding to the general madness. Although the historical setting of Blackadder was very clever, it was the familiarity of the characters and their conformity to type that made it so funny.

The perfect sitcom doesn't have to make you roar with laughter, however. The Royle Family has its roots not in traditional British sitcom, but in the traditions of Ken Loach and Mike Leigh; quite tough working-class drama, although The Royle Family shows a slightly romanticised version. It's funny partly because we recognise the domestic situations, so in a way we are identifying with the mundanity of our lives. It's a strange reflection of our times, but it helps us laugh at ourselves. It's the same with One Foot in the Grave . Victor Meldrew reflects classic armchair opinions, which makes him a mouthpiece for all our thoughts. In some cases, though, being rooted in reality is not what you need to make a perfect sitcom. Father Ted took amazing flights of fancy, but it is one of the best sitcoms because it was so well written.

Performances are vital in a sitcom but the absolute crux is great writing. What great comedy writers have in common is an acute sense of the human condition. And at the end of the day, we all need to be able to laugh at that.

Victor Meldrew reflects classic armchair opinions, which makes him a mouthpiece for all our thoughts. In some cases, though, being rooted in reality is not what you need to make a perfect sitcom. Father Ted took amazing flights of fancy, but it is one of the best sitcoms because it was so well written. Performances are vital in a sitcom but the absolute crux is great writing. What great comedy writers have in common is an acute sense of the human condition. And at the end of the day, we all need to be able to laugh at that.

webTitle: Film of the week: Meet the Parents

fields.headline: The suitor's you, sir
fields.standfirst: De Niro finds his best comic role as an overbearing ogre who torments his future son-in-law
fields.trailText: Meet the Parents (102 mins, 12) Directed by Jay Roach; starring Robert De Niro, Ben Stiller, Blythe Danner
fields.body:
Meet the Parents (102 mins, 12) Directed by Jay Roach; starring Robert De Niro, Ben Stiller, Blythe Danner

If you fancy a holiday outing to the cinema and are looking for entertainment about a family that resists the title 'family entertainment', Jay Roach's comedy Meet the Parents might be just what you're after, because it touches on a human experience as common in Kenton as in Kenya. It's about that terrifying first encounter with future in-laws. I call the film a comedy, but it's really a farce as defined by Eric Bentley in Life of the Drama, where he argues that farce is the obverse of tragedy, a situation where we laugh despite, or rather because of something very serious being at stake.

Terence Rattigan's The Winslow Boy, recently filmed with considerable fidelity by David Mamet, opens with a clever dramatic juxtaposition. Inside a comfortable suburban house a young army officer is nervously asking Edwardian paterfamilias Arthur Winslow for his daughter's hand in marriage. Outside, hiding in the garden, Winslow's son is waiting to inform his father that he has brought disgrace on the family by being dismissed from naval college for theft. This is the interweaving of tragedy and comedy. But merge these two elements - a cowering suitor who threatens to bring disgrace on a middle-class family - and you get farce. This is what John Hamburg and Jim Herzberg, the co-screenwriters of Meet the Parents do and the result is touching, frightening and hilarious.

In Woody Allen's Annie Hall there's a sequence in which Jewish New Yorker Alvy Singer visits Annie's middle-class Protestant home in the Midwest and is treated like an alien from a different planet. Meet the Parents makes a whole movie of this situation, but reverses the journey - awkward Jewish male nurse Greg (Ben Stiller) from Detroit is courting blonde middle-class shiksa Pamela, who teaches at a fancy Chicago nursery school, and she takes him East to meet her parents. They live in Oyster Bay, Long Island, a byword for Waspish exclusivity and site of President Theodore Roosevelt's summer White House. On the way the airline loses Greg's suitcase containing his clothes, wash bag and the engagement ring that was to accompany his postponed proposal of marriage. That proves to be the least of his worries.

Pam's mother Dina (Blythe Danner) is polite middle-class solicitude, but her father is another matter. First half-concealed by net curtains as he appraises the visitor from an upstairs window, Pam's father, Jack Byrnes (Robert De Niro), is an overbearing monster. He's a blood brother to those outrageous US Marine Corps dads played by Robert Duvall in The Great Santini (he was also married to Danner) and Chris Cooper in American Beauty. From their first encounter, Jack eyes this outsider with the suspicion of a store detective about a shifty customer, and over the next couple of days a psychological battle accompanies an escalating series of gaffes and appalling accidents.

Jack and Dina find it hard to cope with Greg's Jewishness, lower-middle-class background and job. Then there's his name. 'It's pronounced the way it's spelt - F-O-C-K-E-R,' says Greg. As Pam's parents lie in bed that night they realise that if she marries him their daughter will become Pamela Martha Focker.

Jack's questioning of Greg, however, is no random amateur affair. It transpires that Jack is a retired psychological profiler for the CIA and spent a year in a North Vietnamese prison camp where he 'learnt patience'. There's a terrific sequence where Greg strays into Jack's secret den, its walls covered with pictures of him with President Clinton and Colin Powell, and working undercover in the Arab world. There's also an old-fashioned polygraph and Jack straps Greg up for a routine test that includes such questions as 'Are you sleeping with my daughter?' and 'Have you ever watched a pornographic video?'

The rattled Greg shatters the urn containing the ashes of Jack's mother with the cork from a champagne bottle, nearly puts Pamela's sister's eye out playing volleyball, loses the family cat, creates a conflagration that calls for the fire brigade, turns the garden into a foul swamp by causing a cesspool to overflow and is unjustly suspected of being a pothead. All the while he's being mocked by the Byrnes's friends and shown up by Pam's rich, kind, brilliant ex-fiancé (Owen Wilson), who has become Jack's close friend since being scared off.

These incidents are briskly and plausibly handled, and our hearts go out to Greg. But what makes it so good are the complementary performances of Stiller as the decent, anxious, increasingly frazzled suitor and De Niro, who gives his best comic performance to date as Greg's cropped-haired, malevolently twinkling, permanently suspicious nemesis. There is a sharp coda which suggests that there could be a sequel, and it won't be anything like Father of the Bride 2.

fields.headline: Gray with added colour
fields.standfirst: No wonder David Gray is good - Waits and Dylan were his mentors
fields.trailText: No wonder David Gray is good - Waits and Dylan were his mentors
fields.body:
By definition, a mainstream is wide, steadily flowing and deepest in the middle. And that's exactly what you see when you stand outside a David Gray gig for 15 minutes or so, as they enter and then leave, profoundly satisfied at either end.

This mainstream is made from arm-linked couples of a certain age, cargo-pant wearers and goatee sprouters, some silver surfers dragging along red-eyed student grandchildren, a wide demographic sea, without obvious shores. Security staff have turned out their pockets for weapons and bootleg recording equipment; the table shows no Stanley knives, but a profusion of mountaineering gadgets and mini-disc players.

So it's Gray for the mainstream, the mainstream for Gray, the greyness of the mainstream... if you really wanted critically to dump on a gravelly-voiced singer-songwriter, playing to an mildly affluent audience yearning for even milder consolations, you could stop right there.

But that's what rock pundits usually feel they must do to the mainstream. They are usually frightened by its size, its implacable movements, its deep undercurrents, the way that the mood of a mass of people can rip their critiques to shreds. Even more challenging when, with an artist likeGray, the energies of the mainstream are being invoked with skill, passion and authenticity.

What happens when you make a record that talks to people right where their complex, juggled, bitter-sweet modern lives actually are? Well, this happens. A handy guy in white plimsolls, overwashed denims and a guitar comes on stage, bashfully says hello and then begins singing about 'What we gonna do when the money runs out... how we gonna find the eyes to see a brighter day?' Connection, big-time. That's the first rock of meaning that Gray drops in tonight's waters and it keeps rippling to the end.

All this is not by musical chance - Gray has woven himself from some of the finer threads of the last 30 years. If you credit his biography, the singing voice, a flexible, rasping, froggy, room-filling rumble, has been conditioned by his dad playing Bob Dylan in the family car; by his youth being wasted to Van Morrison; by his wife being wooed to Tom Waits; by his tour bus being soothed by Carole King.

The crossover twist that marks the hit records - what if Van the Man could sing to drum'n'bass? What would Dylan sound like, trancing out in Ibiza? - is faithfully reproduced here. 'Please Forgive Me' and 'Babylon' are perfectly poised between programming and performance, with Gray's lippy collaborator Clune particularly stunning on brush-drums.

Yet when Gray plays a song from one of his lost-in-America years - 'Everytime', from 1996's Sell Sell Sell - you can see what he had to leave behind to enter the sensibilities of this middle-youth market, stranded somewhere between Ikea and Homelands. And the baggage was a kind of subterranean, very homesick bluesiness. Rocking out for the only time this night, Gray spits out more ornate metaphors in one song ('Your spine a white ladder, your eyes singing sadder... nightingales calling, shooting stars falling...') than in the rest of the new album put together. As it was recorded in LA, for an American record company which wasn't giving a cold taco at the time, you can understand the overreaching.

So the much-recounted tales of how White Ladder was conceived and recorded in the domestic bedroom, trucks outside rumbling on to the master tape, with no major deal and the money running out, make perfect sense. If Gray is trading in simplicities at the moment, it's because they're the right simplicities, tempered by experience. Find me a double-earning household in Britain where Gray's music doesn't resonate - two adults doing table-top therapy amid the chardonnay, soggy joints and domestic bills - and I'll give you my winning Lottery ticket.

David Gray plays at the Brixton Academy tonight and tomorrow

fields.headline: Apology for racism turns sour
fields.standfirst: A 'Day of Reconciliation' in South Africa has divided  liberals who opposed apartheid. David Beresford reports from Johannesburg
fields.trailText: A 'Day of Reconciliation' in South Africa has divided liberals who opposed apartheid. David Beresford reports from Johannesburg
fields.body:
A new controversy over whether whites should collectively apologise to blacks for the sins of apartheid has erupted in South Africa on the anniversary of a pivotal nineteenth-century battle between settlers and tribesmen.

Left-wing and liberal whites chose to launch their campaign for a show of remorse and restitution yesterday on what used to be called the 'Day of the Vow', the day in 1838 on which Afrikaner pioneers slaughtered the Zulus at the Battle of Blood River. But before they could formally get it under way, on what is now designated by a non-racial parliament as the 'Day of Reconciliation', furious controversy broke out in the campaigners' ranks over the principles involved.

The initiative, led by a former ANC MP and diplomat, Carl Niehaus, and a former president of the Black Sash, Mary Burton, involves a 'Home for All' campaign tied in to the launch of a 'reconciliation fund'.

Signatories to the white apology include the captain of the Springbok rugby team, Andre Vos, and most of his team, actor Antony Sher, at least three constitutional court judges, editors and a string of professors from the major liberal universities. Those who are refusing to sign include Tony Leon, leader of the official opposition, the Democratic Alliance, and F.W. de Klerk, the former President whose contribution to the collapse of apartheid earned him a Nobel Prize for peace.

Objections to the white apology appear to be based, confusedly, on anti-racist as well as racist grounds. It is argued, among other things, that an acknowledgment of collective guilt merely reinforces racial stereotyping, is the heritage of colonialism and apartheid and entrenches national divisions. The movers of the campaign are described by critical colleagues as whites who know they personally have nothing for which to apologise. There is also a suspicion in some quarters of the 'confessional' approach, which is seen as an unhealthy intrusion by the churches into politics.

Critics of the proposal include poet Breyten Breytenbach, imprisoned for his anti-apartheid activities. He said that when he finished reading the proposed statements he 'had to go to the bathroom for a quiet and sad puke'.

A former member of the Human Rights Commission, Rhoda Kadalie - who was herself classified as 'Coloured' under apartheid rule - described it as a 'disgraceful declaration'. She said: 'It is the resurrection of the sorry ideology that has more to do with making white people feel good than it has for promoting justice. It is also aimed at silencing white people from being critical of the black government.'

But such critics were embarrassed to find themselves on the side of right-wingers such as the white Mineworkers Union and the mass murderer, Barend Strydom. The union boasted yesterday it had the signatures of 7,600 'white' members denouncing the confession as 'a new form of racism'.

Strydom, who shot dead seven blacks in Pretoria in 1989, said a right-wing group he belonged to, the 'Daughters of Zion', would be campaigning against the white apology.

The confusion surrounding the apology reflects a general confusion about political identity in South Africa, particularly among white liberals and the Left.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: After months of negotiations and wildcat strikes, Italy's teachers won a modest pay raise - an average increase of 300,000 lire (£94) a month, just a little over the government's last offer and well below their initial demand.
fields.body:
Pay rise ends wildcat strikes by teachers in Italy

After months of negotiations and wildcat strikes, Italy's teachers won a modest pay raise - an average increase of 300,000 lire (£94) a month, just a little over the government's last offer and well below their initial demand.

Nurses block borders over pay

Polish nurses blocked international railway lines and border crossings as part of protests for higher pay. Last week 50,000 of the country's 250,000 nurses and midwives left their jobs for several hours. Some hospitals limited admissions to emergencies only.

Tigers maul circus artist

Circus artist Rita Chhetri, 20, was mauled to death by three tigers during a show in the Indian state of West Bengal.

Prince to wed

Prince Constantijn, 33, son of Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands, is to marry Laurentien Brinkhorst, 34, daughter of the Agriculture Minister.

Controversial nuclear reactor closed over pump failure

The nuclear reactor at the Temelin power plant in the Czech Republic was shut because of a minor water-pump failure in the cooling system. The plant, not yet on line, is a point of contention with neighbouring Austria.

Christie's halt Brancusi sale

Romania has intervened to stop a private auction in New York of a 1913 Constantin Brancusi sculpture, worth about £7 million, which it said had been exported illegally. Christie's confirmed it had postponed the sale, due to take place this week.

Woman killed in plane fall

A woman who moved to Hewlett Packard's California base from its German office fell to her death from a company plane near Sacramento after opening a cabin door. A fellow passenger vainly tried to restrain Elisabeth Mathild Otto, a Dutch citizen, who was said to have been despondent about moving to the US.

webTitle: 'Lost City' of ghostly spires found below Atlantic

fields.headline: 'Lost City' of ghostly spires found below Atlantic
fields.trailText: One of the most spectacular rock formations on earth has been discovered at the bottom of the Atlantic.
fields.body:
One of the most spectacular rock formations on earth has been discovered at the bottom of the Atlantic. The ghostly white structure, with soaring spires and buttresses, possibly a million years old, has been dubbed the 'Lost City' by the American oceanographers who stumbled across it.

It is more than 3,200 feet below the surface of the Atlantic, covering an area the size of a football pitch, and surrounded by a garden of bubbling hot springs. Other such formations have been found in the Atlantic and Pacific, but at more than 180 feet high, the newly discovered ones are by far the largest underwater spires ever found.

Jeff Karson, a geologist from Duke University, North Carolina, said 'if this were on land it would be a national park'. Researchers believe it could help them understand the creation of life on Earth.

The Lost City was discovered on 4 December by the research vessel Atlantis, which was patrolling the mid-Atlantic as part of a month-long expedition to explore a submerged mountain. The researchers onboard the Atlantis had little contact with on-shore colleagues until they returned back to base at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute in Massachusetts yesterday, revealing the details of their finds.

The formations were initially spotted on a video image supplied by an unmanned research vehicle, Argo, that is towed at the end of a two-mile cable by the Atlantis. The next day, researchers explored the area in the deep sea submersible, Alvin, America's top deep-diving submarine.

The formations, which are on the flanks of a 14,000-feet mountain known as the Atlantic massif, have risen over aeons as the result of the accumulation of minerals dissolved in hot water bubbling up through cracks in the earth's surface known as thermal vents. They occur where plates in the Earth's crust collide and grind against each other. Glowing in the lights from the Alvin in the pitch-black ocean depths, some of the pinnacles resemble stalagmites, while others look like crumbling sand castles on the beach. Ledges, or flanges, of the crusty, feathery crystals jut from the spires like mushrooms.

'They rival redwood trees in height,' said Debbie Kelley of the University of Washington, an expert on hydrothermal vents. 'Above your head, the flanges trap reflecting pools of water. They look like upside-down water falls.'

Until now, ocean scientists believed they had seen all the main formations around sea floor vents in previous expeditions. But as well as its startling appearance, the Lost City also has scientific surprises. The researchers said that understanding the peculiarities of the formations may shed light on Earth's geological development, as well as conditions on Jupiter's moon Europa and elsewhere around the solar system.

The Lost City occurs on a piece of the Earth's crust that is about one million years old. Most vents occur at points where the crust is much younger. The water from the vents is relatively cool at 160 degrees fahrenheit, or about 70 degrees centigrade. The structures are composed of silica and carbonate minerals.Compared to vents in the Pacific, the mid-Atlantic vent field shows relatively little complex life. The only life seen by the scientists was dense, floating mats of micro-organisms. They took samples for DNA analysis with a robotic arm.

'Why we did not see clams, mussels or shrimp is a mystery to me,' Kelley said. 'The micro-organisms that live within these fields may be very different.'
