Glowing in the lights from the Alvin in the pitch-black ocean depths, some of the pinnacles resemble stalagmites, while others look like crumbling sand castles on the beach. Ledges, or flanges, of the crusty, feathery crystals jut from the spires like mushrooms. 'They rival redwood trees in height,' said Debbie Kelley of the University of Washington, an expert on hydrothermal vents. 'Above your head, the flanges trap reflecting pools of water. They look like upside-down water falls.' Until now, ocean scientists believed they had seen all the main formations around sea floor vents in previous expeditions. But as well as its startling appearance, the Lost City also has scientific surprises. The researchers said that understanding the peculiarities of the formations may shed light on Earth's geological development, as well as conditions on Jupiter's moon Europa and elsewhere around the solar system. The Lost City occurs on a piece of the Earth's crust that is about one million years old. Most vents occur at points where the crust is much younger. The water from the vents is relatively cool at 160 degrees fahrenheit, or about 70 degrees centigrade. The structures are composed of silica and carbonate minerals.Compared to vents in the Pacific, the mid-Atlantic vent field shows relatively little complex life. The only life seen by the scientists was dense, floating mats of micro-organisms. They took samples for DNA analysis with a robotic arm. 'Why we did not see clams, mussels or shrimp is a mystery to me,' Kelley said. 'The micro-organisms that live within these fields may be very different.'

fields.headline: The big issue :  Is 'trawling' the way to stop child abuse?
fields.trailText: Having attended each day of the David Jones trial, and being concerned with the issue of false allegations for the past 10 years, may I commend Richard Webster (Comment, last week), for what was the most thoughtful and considered reflection on theevents that unfolded at Liverpool Crown Court.
fields.body:
Having attended each day of the David Jones trial, and being concerned with the issue of false allegations for the past 10 years, may I commend Richard Webster (Comment, last week), for what was the most thoughtful and considered reflection on theevents that unfolded at Liverpool Crown Court.

Among the many issues raised, Mr Webster is correct to state that the police are not to blame for the creation of the moral panic over child abuse.

That being said, the Merseyside Police do not advance their case for restoring public confidence by statements that refute the need for a review of 'trawling' methods of investigation and, astonishingly, by refusing to prosecute those who had clearly made malicious allegations against Mr Jones. If I made the same type of false allegation against an officer of 'Operation Care', would I be granted the same immunity?
Charles Mills,
Senior Education Consultant and Ofsted Inspector
Formby
Merseyside

 Child sex abuse is not new, and nor are the attempts to deny its prevalence. Just like a Victorian judge, faced with evidence of a trade in children, argued that respectable fathers could not possibly be abusing girls and boys, so Webster claims that 'the sheer quantity of allegations does not prove anything'. All we are witnessing is a 'moral panic about sexual abuse in care homes', caused by police visiting former inmates, who invent past abuse in hope of compensation. Unfortunately, Webster's piece does not contain a shred of evidence for this.

Abuse allegations by those previ ously in care usually have to match others already made, in order to come to court. 'Trawling', therefore, is a perfectly reliable police method.
Alvin Pelss
Address supplied

 We have repeatedly heard senior figures within the child protection industry state 'no one would say that they had been abused, just for money!' With such indifference and intransigence, we see why the practice of 'trawling' for evidence and the payment of compensation has become an integral part of normal police methods.
Gail Saunders
Dinas
Powys

fields.headline: Briton injured in Saudi blast
fields.trailText: Foreign Office officials warned yesterday of the possibility of more bomb attacks in Saudi Arabia after a device placed on a car badly injured a British man.
fields.body:
Foreign Office officials warned yesterday of the possibility of more bomb attacks in Saudi Arabia after a device placed on a car badly injured a British man.

The explosion was the third attack on a Briton in less than a month and has prompted fears that a terrorist group is deliberately targeting British workers in the oil rich kingdom.

David Brown, a Scottish customer services manager for Coca Cola, suffered severe injuries after picking up what appeared to be a fruit juice container left on the windscreen of his car in the town of Al Khobar in the country's Eastern province.

The carton exploded, seriously injuring Brown's face and hands. Brown's wife was with him but was unhurt.

Saudi authorities yesterday sent specialists to Al Khobar and an evacuation team was on standby to bring Brown to Britain if necessary.

However, Saudi security sources told the state Saudi news agency that Brown's condition was stable.

Foreign Office Minister Peter Hain, said: 'This is a serious incident. The safety of the British community in Saudi Arabia is paramount.

The attack follows a car bomb on 17 November which killed a Briton, Christopher Rodway, 48, and wounded his wife. That blast was followed five days later by a car bomb which wounded two men and a woman. All three victims were British.

Officially Foreign Office officials were refusing to draw a link between the three attacks, but privately they admitted more bombs may be planted.

No group has yet claimed responsibility for the bombings.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: While they were living together publisher Jane Johnson and novelist Mike Harrison argued too much to write together. Since splitting up, though, they've become the two halves of the bestselling Gabriel King
fields.trailText: While they were living together publisher Jane Johnson and novelist Mike Harrison argued too much to write together. Since splitting up, though, they've become the two halves of the bestselling Gabriel King.
fields.body:
Jane Johnson: Meeting Mike for the first time was terrifying. He was a tremendously intellectual award-winning writer with a very fierce aspect and I was a very junior editor who had just bought the paperback versions of two of his hardback novels.

We met at a publisher's party and later had lunch and got on incredibly well. Going out with one another was difficult because Mike lived in Yorkshire and I lived in London - but added to that was Mike's obsession with rock climbing and my terror of heights. The only way I ever got to see him was to accompany him rock climbing.

We decided to make a life together and bought a cheap attic flat in Peckham Rye. It was vile, but we stayed there seven years. We had a lot of arguments because Mike was a literary writer and I was a fiction publisher: I believe writing should reach as many people as possible. These arguments spread to other things until we were falling out more than we were getting on.

When we split up, Mike stopped climbing for a while and I became completely obsessed. We also started writing novels together, as Gabriel King. We had made various aborted attempts, but never had the impetus to get going on it while we lived together. Breaking up released us to work together in a way that we could never have done before.

I had been Tolkein's editor since the 80s and I always said to Mike that we must write a big epic fantasy together. Writing is usually such a solitary and lonely business, so this was wonderful. I like to have a plan of action, whereas Mike likes to get in there and start writing the bits he's interested in. So we split the characters into two separate narratives, each taking one, and then weaving them in and out of one another.

We are now working on our fourth novel together and also on solo projects. I've just spent two weeks in New Zealand on the film set of the adaption of Tolkein's The Hobbit; I'm writing a book to come out with the film. But whether or not we are working on our own, we still rely on each other for advice about publishing negotations or someone to strike ideas off.

Mike Harrison: I was living in Yorkshire and all my money was spent on rock climbing gear and none on clothes. When we met I was wearing some ghastly tweed jacket. I was instantly besotted with Jane. Thereafter I would spend two hours a day thinking of as many excuses as I could to phone her.

Jane's personality is a combination of power and placidity. I would push her too far banking on that placidity and then get bitten. And I am incredibly intense; if I'm not on fire with something I'm not alive, and I think that tired Jane. It was like living with a maniac. I write in the same intense way. I find it difficult to write anything for weeks then I'll write non-stop for four days.

Breaking up took me longer to get over because I am such a romantic. I was a little heartbroken. The amusing or amazing thing is that we spent nearly nine years together but couldn't write a book together, and the moment we split up we were able to do it. Writing together enabled us to run the relationship down calmly rather than just flying apart. We have since gone on to form other relationships.

We came up with a name, Gabriel King: the first name had to have three syllables to read well on a cover, and be a little fey so that it could be a man or a woman. Collaborations are rare in fiction and it is very hard to make them work. At book signings Jane signs Gabriel and I sign King. Readers are often quite shocked to find that there are two of us.

We've got complimentary qualities: she's a good editor and writes much faster than me; I write very intensely and say here it is. When I work on my own I start with a very strong structure so I can write the end, then the middle and the beginning last of all. That's not possible when working with someone else. The advantage of writing in two strands is that you get two completely different tones of voice. Jane's central character sounds completely different to mine. You would have to work very hard to get that as a solo writer.

 Gabriel King's third novel The Knot Garden is published in paperback on 4 January (£10, Century).

webTitle: Rebels at the 'old' Tate resist new gallery fads

fields.headline: Rebels at the 'old' Tate resist new gallery fads
fields.trailText: John Everett Millais's Ophelia floating down the river, the racehorses of George Stubbs, the sculptures of Henry Moore - for art enthusiasts across the country, these are the works that sum up British artistic achievement. But who is coming to see them now?
fields.body:
John Everett Millais's Ophelia floating down the river, the racehorses of George Stubbs, the sculptures of Henry Moore - for art enthusiasts across the country, these are the works that sum up British artistic achievement. But who is coming to see them now?

The caretakers of some of the nation's best-loved pieces of art are protesting because they believe such works have been sidelined in favour of fashionable contemporary art. Curators at London's Tate Britain, disparagingly referred to as the 'old Tate', believe paintings by Stubbs, and the Pre-Raphaelites - Millais, Holman Hunt and Rossetti - are being under-sold to the public.

The Millbank gallery, overshadowed since last May by the new Tate Modern down the Thames, is suffering 'disintegrating morale and morals', according to unhappy senior staff.

A fellow curator, who bemoans the money and attention lavished on the £130 million Tate Modern and the hype surrounding the annual £20,000 Turner Prize for new art, said: 'I am extremely concerned. I have a strong sense of loyalty, but British art is not getting its proper due and the public are being short-changed. There is endemic discontent at Tate Britain because we are not showing the British School to best advantage. It has all been watered down in a Philistine way.'

Claims that spirits are at an all-time low is confirmed by curator Judith Collins, who leaves the gallery this week after 15 years.

'This has been a rogue or maverick year,' she told The Observer . 'There is a disparity between the two sites. The current "fragrance" of the Tate Modern is obvious, although the spaces are actually much better at Tate Britain. The whole thing has been a seismic shock.'

Collins hopes for an improvement in morale in 2001. She denied the changes had hastened her departure.

The problem began, the curators allege, when Nicholas Serota, the director of the gallery since 1988, brought in new staff for the relaunch of Tate Britain in April. The museum started to turn away from an academic approach to its collection. It was re-hung according to themes such as 'Private and Public', or 'Home and Abroad', following a trend established at New York's Museum of Modern Art and copied later at Tate Modern.

While this method, which shuns historical chronology, was judged a success at the new gallery, critics slammed the 'old Tate's' version. Many felt gems of British art from 1500 onwards had been lost in the confusion.

A cartoon on the BSE crisis by Guardian cartoonist Steve Bell hangs next to a Hogarth, while the work of Gilbert and George is in the same room as L.S. Lowry.

Several curators inside the Tate are feeling alienated. 'I would like to be able to do a proper curatorial job,' said one. 'A museum derives its life from imaginative curating - that is the fire in the belly. But we have lost tens of people over the last five years. Our reputation is going down around the world. People feel they can't say anything. When you have a power system as elaborately constructed as this one, it is hard to speak out. People feel betrayed and pushed aside,' he added.

In April, after the re-launch, the gallery attracted 162,000 visitors. Once the new rival had opened up, the figures went below 100,000 and have since fallen as low as 60,000 a month - 40,000 fewer than last year.

Serota, who oversees both galleries - along with their sisters in St Ives and Liverpool - has vowed to turn his attention to the other galleries following the launch of Tate Modern. He has decided to keep his office at Millbank and confirmed that the televised awards ceremony for the Turner Prize would continue to be held there. There have been second thoughts about the rehang at Tate Britain and the layout will be reconsidered next year.

Last summer, a plan to open two new rooms at Tate Britain next spring was delayed when the underground building site was flooded. Since then morale has slumped and staff turnover has increased.'

A Tate spokesman said: 'We are obviously concerned to improve staff morale. Any fears that important groups such as the Pre-Raphaelites are under-represented will be addressed in October when we look again at the content of Tate Britain.'

fields.headline: The loafer's guide...
fields.standfirst: The Constant Gardener
fields.trailText: The Constant Gardener.
fields.body:
You mean Charlie Dimmock? No, no, no - it's the title of the new novel by bestselling author David Cornwell.

Come again? John Le Carré to you. He took up writing while in the employ of the British Foreign Service, hence the secrecy and pseudonym, but gave it all up when he hit the big time with The Spy Who Came in From the Cold in 1963. The Constant Gardener is his 18th novel and he's made a mint, what with all those film and television adaptations. Enough cash, in fact, to donate half a mile of the coastline below his Cornish home to the National Trust.

So he was a spy, then? Oh yes. After Oxford he worked for both MI5 and MI6, and was involved with the secret service and espionage for some years, though only five of them are official. Details are sketchy; Le Carré is extremely patriotic and refuses to discuss exactly what he was up to. He takes a very dim view of the Shaylers of this world who go public and lift the lid on the undercover world.

Still another Oxbridge/aristo agent, though? Not exactly. His dad Ronnie was a full-time confidence trickster, in and out of Sing Sing and generally up to no good. But he did make sure his kids had a decent education, although fees were apparently rarely paid.

And The Constant Gardener is all about A diplomat who's also an amateur gardener whose wife gets bumped off in Kenya, so he heads off to track down her murderers - classic Le Carré stuff, in other words.

 The Constant Gardener (£16.99, Hodder & Stoughton) is on sale on 4 January

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... a dinosaur
fields.trailText: ... a dinosaur.
fields.body:
If your eyes glaze over at the thought of Anglo-Saxon pottery and Roman amphoras, then forget archaeology. But perhaps the hunt for a bonafide prehistoric monster would get your adrenaline pumping. The good news is that there could be the remains of anything up to half a million species of dinosaur out there, so your chances of naming your own variety aren't bad.

Your first option is to organise an expedition, in which case you should employ a paleontological expert. A new survey estimated that there are 4,425 archaeologists in Britain, each earning an average annual salary of £17,079 (although those working in universities and museums received up to £25,000) and it seems reasonable to assume paleontologists have comparable earnings. Membership of the Paleontological Association (which is hosting its annual conference in Edinburgh this weekend) costs £28. You'll need to visit a DIY centre for a pick, a shovel, a rock hammer and a chisel. These should all cost from £5 to £15. Next, drop by your chemist for a toothbrush and tweezers (£2 each).

By all means book flights to a remote destination, but fossil hunters really need not travel too far afield. Imagine the surprise of Larry and Sheryl Lozier of Hyde Park, New York State, when the skeleton of a 6,500kg mastodon (cause of death unknown) interrupted the deepening of their pond last year.

A swathe of Jurassic rock stretches from Dorset to Yorkshire, while rock from the Cretaceous period lies beneath south-east England. Bearing in mind that the first dinosaur ever unearthed was found in an Oxfordshire quarry in the 1600s, you're best advised to confine your search to exposed rock (for instance, at the coast) and send whatever you find to a commercial radiocarbon-dating laboratory.

The richest Tyrannosaurus Rex fields are probably in Colorado, South Dakota and Montana, in the Morrison Formation between Canada and New Mexico. Of course, you could always just buy a dinosaur. Disney and McDonald's recently coughed up £5.7m for a Tyrannosaurus named Sue for Chicago's Field Museum at a Sotheby's auction.

However, more fossils are ending up in private hands: £5,100 is the going rate for a sabre-toothed tiger skull, or a T-rex tooth, while £62,750 will bag you a pterosaur.

Archaeologist salary £17,079
Paleontological Association membership £28
Flights and equipment variable
Radiocarbon analysis £230 (plus VAT)
Tyrannosaurus Rex reproduction £72,400
Tyrannosaurus Rex skeleton £5.7m
Sabre-toothed tiger skull £5,100
Ammonites £20 each

Disney and McDonald's recently coughed up £5.7m for a Tyrannosaurus named Sue for Chicago's Field Museum at a Sotheby's auction. However, more fossils are ending up in private hands: £5,100 is the going rate for a sabre-toothed tiger skull, or a T-rex tooth, while £62,750 will bag you a pterosaur. webTitle: Walsall take a hit with no kit

fields.headline: Walsall take a hit with no kit
fields.trailText:
Millwall 2 - 0 Walsall
Walsall take a hit with no kit.
fields.byline: Nick Callow at The New Den
fields.body:
They played and then celebrated like champions, maybe not prematurely. There is still over half the season to go, but Millwall will take some shoving from the top if they can maintain the form and hunger which enabled them to replace Walsall as Second Division leaders yesterday.

Though trailing to an early Marc Bircham goal, Walsall were by far the better team by half-time and seemed set to prove that when Jorge Leitao headed against the crossbar less than a minute into the second half.

But Millwall broke from that attack to score their second goal through Steven Reid and there was only one team in it from then on.

Walsall did create further chances but progressively seemed unable to cope with Millwall's passion both on and off the pitch.

The 11,737 crowd was Millwall's biggest attendance this season but it sounded like a whole lot more when the Lions started to roar at the end of what had proved to be a significant result in the promotion race.

Millwall manager Mark McGhee said: 'If we finish above Walsall then we will be promoted. Our crowd think we're the best team in the league, but I think we were playing against the best team in Walsall so I'm very grateful for the result.'

Walsall manager Ray Graydon would probably not disagree with McGhee's assessment. He added: 'If we want to gain promotion we will have to be meaner. We created better and more chances so it is a bitter disappointment to come away with no points from a very important match.'

A bad day for the Walsall kit man too. He forgot to load the shirts onto the team bus and Walsall had to go on bended knee to borrow Millwall's away kit.

Graydon said: 'I'm not happy. The kit man simply forgot and it will be dealt with internally. I do not like unprofessionalism but it had nothing to do with the way we played because professional footballers should be able to cope with things like that.'

'The reason we lost, and not for the first time away from home, is because we missed all the chances we created.'

Millwall scented blood and compounded their air of superiority by taking the lead after only six minutes. Neil Harris cut in from the right and pulled the ball back from the by-line, it was helped on by Richard Sadlier and ran into the path of Bircham who buried a shot from 20 yards.

Walsall could have folded then but showed real steel to battle their way back into the game. They lacked similar conviction after Millwall's second goal, in the 47th minute.

Paul Ifill burst down the left and hit a telling cross to the far post where Harris nodded down and Reid steamed in to finish with a close-range volley into the roof of the net.

This was a knock-out blow and Walsall struggled to win a tackle for a while as Millwall played with added bite with the opposition's spirit seemingly broken.

McGhee added: 'We had had to defend very well up to then, but the second goal seemed to knock the stuffing out of them. I told the players before that this was the chance to prove themselves and they did just that. I also know, however, that there is still a long way to go.'

webTitle: Vega not backward in coming forward in a debut to relish

fields.headline: Vega not backward in coming forward in a debut to relish
fields.trailText:
Celtic 6 - 0 Aberdeen
Larsson and Vega hammer the Dons.
fields.body:
Advertised as a match (sic), this proved to be a catch-weight contest in which Aberdeen, predictably, found it impossible to handle opponents who had at least a stone in hand.

From the moment the first heavy blow was landed, the initial leg of Henrik Larsson's hat-trick after only four minutes, the weakened Pittodrie side were constantly exposed to the risk of a mauling. This was executed without mercy.

Defender Ramon Vega, making his debut after signing on loan for Celtic from Spurs the day before, not only marked his arrival with a double, but may have formed the misleading impression that it's like this every week. Compared to his erratic career at White Hart Lane, this must have seemed like a breeze.

It is rather like that for Celtic in home matches these days; it it becoming impossible to imagine them losing on their own ground. These latest arrivals from the north-east did not even have time in which to allow whatever apprehension they may have felt to have a paralysing effect.

In Celtic's first forward thrust, Alan Thompson played a precise pass inside Kevin McNaughton in the right-back position, giving Bobby Petta the opportunity to glide past and into the clear. As Petta made for the dead ball line, Larsson sprinted towards the near post, the low cut-back was impeccable and the Swede slipped the ball past Ryan Esson from three yards' out.

It was difficult to gauge Vega's defensive capabilities on a day when he was rarely troubled, but his contribution as an auxiliary forward could not have been faulted. On 17 minutes the Swiss player ran half the length of the pitch, signalling himself as a target, while Alan Thompson prepared to take a free-kick from just inside the Aberdeen half.

The midfielder flighted the ball towards Vega diagonally from the right and the defender took it on the drop, clipping it past Esson from six yards. The two-goal lead was the least the home side were due. While Tommy Johnson (twice) and Larsson were missing golden opportunities to give the home side an embarrassing lead by the interval, Aberdeen mustered one shot, a rather feeble effort by Cato Guntveit which sent the ball straight into the hands of Robert Douglas.

Aberdeen may have thought the suffering would diminish with the injury-enforced departure of their principal tormentor, Petta, after 57 minutes, but it was an illusion. Larsson, having squandered several good chances, suddenly found his touch and completed his treble within the space of two deadly minutes.

Johan Mjallby began the move back on his own by-line, dispossessing substitute Alex di Rocca and carrying the ball forward before releasing it to Agathe on the right. The Frenchman moved further upfield and played it forward to Johnson, who turned it inside to the unmarked Larsson. The Swede simply rolled the ball with his right foot inside Esson's left-hand post.

If that was simple, his third was spectacular. From a deep cross by Thompson on the left, the ball bounced out to Larsson on the right side of the area. He took it knee-high on the volley from 15 yards and the ball flew across the area and high to the right of Esson.

Vega completed his double with a downward header from 12 yards from a centre by Thompson, who had played a short corner with Neil Lennon on the right. Aberdeen, whose problems remain serious, had to suffer an ignominious sixth goal when young substitute Jamie Smith took Lennon's pass in the inside-left position and clipped the ball to the left of Esson from 10 yards.

fields.headline: Smith feeling heat
fields.trailText:
Everton 1 - 1 West Ham
Kanouté increases the pressure on Smith.
fields.body:
After taking the lead through Danny Cadamarteri 15 minutes from the end, Everton failed to beat the team with the worst record on visits to Merseyside and the campaign for manager Walter Smith's dismissal will grow this weekend.

On top of their disappointing defeats at the Stadium of Light and Maine Road, the spectacular home victories against Arsenal and Chelsea have quickly been forgotten thanks to a late equaliser from French striker Frederic Kanouté.

And as the match ended, applause for the most sporting gesture of the season overshadowed boos from disgruntled home supporters following an incident in the last minute when the often controversial Paulo di Canio earned an ovation from everybody in the ground - and handshakes from Everton players.

With time running out and the score at 1-1, Everton keeper Paul Gerrard had fallen heavily outside his area in attempting to retrieve the ball, and as he lay inert on the ground a centre from the right by Trevor Sinclair put the Everton defence in total disarray. But from 12 yards out Di Canio earned his own badge of merit when instead of shooting for goal - he would almost certainly have scored - he caught the ball above his head and pointed to the Gerrard, who was carried off the field.

The opening goal had looked a life-saver for the Everton management. In the 75th minute, a Stephen Hughes corner was headed fiercely goalwards by Stephen Watson and flicked past West Ham keeper Shaka Hislop by Cadamarteri.

It looked as though West Ham, beaten on 12 of their last 13 visits to Goodison Park, were going to lose again despite some bright counterattacking play, and the game eventually hinged on an inability by the Everton defence to keep a tight grip on French striker Kanouté.

For just when the Hammers looked down and out, in the 83rd minute Di Canio caught Watson in possession and from 15 yards Kanouté fired home. It was no more than West Ham deserved.

Yet Everton had started the game showing no signs of a crisis of confidence. Twice in the first five minutes enterprising midfielder Stephen Hughes brought an excellent save out of Hislop and then skimmed a 25-yard drive fractionally wide.

Just after this a flying header by Kevin Campbell went wide and West Ham were facing the expected early pressure that manager Harry Redknapp predicted.

Despite first-half territorial advantage, however, there were early warnings of the threat posed by counterattacks engineered by Di Canio, and the smooth movement up front of lone striker Kanouté, who did not find it difficult to retain possession even when harried by three defenders.

But Everton were still looking bright and purposeful in the final minutes of the first half and a snap shot from Thomas Gravesen was nearly lost by Hislop as Campbell closed in threateningly.

webTitle: Off-colour Sky Blues conquered early by Christie's priceless strike

fields.headline: Off-colour Sky Blues conquered early by Christie's priceless strike
fields.trailText:
Derby 1 - 0 Coventry
Off-colour Sky Blues conquered early by Christie.
fields.body:
How important this result turns out to be when the relegation issues are settled at the end of the season remains to be seen. But it was certainly a big one for Derby, their second in three matches and one which carried a suggestion that they might just be inching their way in the right direction. After a miserable start to their campaign, Derby's confidence has been boosted by some useful performances in the last month.

In his programme notes for this match, the Derby manager Jim Smith bemoaned the fact that not once this season had he been able to field his first choice 11. Smith, however, was grateful for the return of Stefano Eranio after a hamstring injury and Seth Johnson from suspension.

It was these two players who were the most influential in their team gaining the upper hand. Johnson is essentially a left-sided player, but did enough with his right boot to force Coventry's Swedish goalkeeper Magnus Hedman into a diving save to hold a shot curling towards the far corner.

Eranio's impact proved decisive. The Italian released Craig Burley, whose powerful drive was blocked by Hedman, the ball running loose to Malcolm Christie who calmly pocketed his eighth goal of the season.

With so much at stake even at this stage of the season it was just the early tonic Derby needed after the previous week's 4-1 pasting by Chelsea. Eranio's ability to play intelligent passes through a square looking defence was again evident when he gave Christie the chance of a run at Barry Quinn. But Derby's leading scorer lost his momentum in mid-stride and Quinn was able to snuff out the danger.

There were two half chances at the other end for John Aloisi. Turning sharply inside the penalty box he put the first into the crowd. Then he was denied by a quick thinking interception from the Derby captain Darryl Powell.

Christie had Pride Park buzzing when he spun away from Paul Williams along the right touchline, but hesitation by Eranio when Christie played the ball inside brought the move to an unsatisfactory ending.

The game was proving, as expected, tight and tense. Coventry defender Muhamed Konjic advanced to volley over a free-kick from David Thompson. Later, a dipping volley from Thompson landed on top of the net.

Derby just about deserved to prevail, although Coventry manager Gordon Strachan would probably say otherwise. It certainly wasn't pretty - but then no-one expected it to be - and they certainly were indebted to Mart Poom for a flying save in the final minute, the goal keeper proving equal to Youssef Chippo's 25-yard effort. Coventry lacked nothing in commitment but there was not a great deal of attacking threat, with few genuine chances created.

fields.headline: Jewell's double trouble
fields.trailText:
Sheffield Utd 1 - 1 Sheff Wed
Jewell's dismissal crowns scrappy affair.
fields.body:
Blinkers and colourfully tinted glasses are essential wear for local spats. When Neil Warnock intimated that Paul Jewell was one lucky manager after this terse Sheffield tussle, he must have been blinded by his own haze of red and white passion. Lucky? Admittedly Wednesday had been let off the hook by the referee a couple of times, but Jewell was also unfortunate enough to be sent off for arguing with a linesman, his second dismissal in four days.

He had reason to complain. The confused United ballboys continually sent a second ball on to the field when one went out of play, and on several occasions Wednesday found themselves trying to defend two balls simultaneously - as if they didn't have enough to contend with on enemy territory.

When Jewell tried to draw the linesman's attention to it the official asked him whether he wanted to leave the dugout. 'It happened on numerous occasions. The linesmen don't do their job and if you question them you are in the stands,' moaned Jewell. 'The referee said he agreed with me but then brought up foul and abusive language. I'm saying that's not true. I think I've been hard done by.' He is likely to face a touchline ban.

Warnock, sent off himself twice this season, had a degree of sympathy, but only because you could almost see the smoke coming from his ears when he considered the refereeing display. Patrick Suffo was elbowed in the head so severely by Steve Harkness he spent half time clutching an ice pack - 'a disgrace,' fumed Warnock - before Steve Haslam escaped a second yellow card for kicking the ball away. The United manager was enraged: 'He said to the ref: "I swear to God I didn't do it on purpose." Jesus wept. Who's looking after the game?...'

Phew. At least all the hullabaloo gave us something to reflect upon, which is more than can be said for the game itself - a dreadfully scrappy affair which failed to meet the simmering anticipation preceding Sheffield's first league derby for six years. United are optimistically aiming for the play-offs, while Wednesday are getting their act together after a wretched start. Add fear of Monday morning in the workplaces of South Yorkshire and there was a lot riding on this one.

Jewell quite rightly summed up the first half as a non-event. There was plenty of earnest endeavour, a fair amount of niggle, the odd brutal tackle, but a conspicuous absence of slick technique or subtle tactics. Titillating it was not. The game was in dire need of a catalyst to up the stakes and fire the adrenaline and it was up to Wednesday wonderkid Owen Morrison to focus everybody's minds.

Squaring up to Rob Kozluk, he goaded his opponent into aiming a punch at him. Naturally, Kozluk missed. Morrison decided to go down clutching his head anyway and referee Eddie Wolstenholme gave them both a talking to. 'A scandal!' announced Warnock.

Just before the hour bad blood between these two competitors boiled over again - after Devlin's fancy approach work Kozluk was tripped by Morrison just inside the box. Bobby Ford possessed the nerve for the occasion, summoning the power and precision to beat Pressman from 12 yards. His clenched fists encapsulated the joy of half a city.

Tension unshackled, United began to play a bit, and might have doubled their lead through Suffo. Could Wednesday find the stomach for the fightback? Blessed by a touch of good fortune they managed exactly that. Ian Hendon's free kick ricocheted violently off Curtis Woodhouse in the United wall and Simon Tracey was deceived.

At last the game sprang to life as play swung from goalmouth to goalmouth and a series of potential winners went begging. 'I'd like to know what numbers Paul Jewell's got on the lottery,' sighed Warnock. His opposite number had a pithy riposte: 'Better to be lucky than talented.'

fields.headline: Dyer still the key
fields.trailText:
Newcastle 2 - 1 Bradford
Dyer still the key as plans ahead.
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James' Park
fields.body:
Kieron Dyer remains Newcastle's most valuable asset as manager Bobby Robson is forced to raise money to reshape and strengthen the squad as he wishes. But it would be a brave man who sold him. Dyer, linked again with Leeds, can be a frustrating and peripheral figure, as he showed at times yesterday, but the manner in which he scored the decisive second goal is the reason he should be in the club's future, not the means to finance it.

With 70 minutes gone, Dyer was sent clear and angled away from goal, but his acceleration and calm finish brought his fourth goal of the season.

Its value was underlined when Robert Molenaar headed in from a corner to leave Newcastle facing an awkward final seven minutes, but they held on to inflict the first defeat on Bradford since Jim Jefferies took charge four games ago.

Newcastle's prospects were enhanced immeasurably before the start when Alan Shearer came through a test on his knee injury.

Shearer's desire to play while far from fully fit represents, in the eyes of a section of the St James's Park fans, a contrast with others who regularly inhabit the treatment room.

The most regular visitor is Marcelino, playing only his third game of the season . He certainly didn't look at ease yesterday and almost gifted Dean Windass a goal midway through a first half which had started in encouraging fashion for Newcastle with a goal after 14 minutes.

It was only the eleventh scored by Newcastle at home in the Premiership, but was unarguably the best. Molenaar must accept blame for a weak headed response to Warren Barton's equally unconvincing cross, but how Gary Speed punished him by lashing the ball in from 20 yards off the underside of the bar.

Other aspects of the opening 45 minutes were less appetising for Robson, who displayed signs of frustration at some of Newcastle's approach work during his regular visits to the touchline.

Marcelino's mistake - corrected by an alert reaction from goalkeeper Shay Given - wasn't the only worry for Robson. Robbie Blake, given a rare chance because of Stan Collymore's suspension and an injury to Ashley Ward, hooked over in the twentieth minute and was denied an equaliser by the legs of Given four minutes later.

At least the first half offered further evidence that new manager Jefferies has added some steel and organisation to Bradford , notably through the acquisition of Molenaar.

However, that won't be enough to save them from another season of struggle and certainly wasn't enough to seriously trouble Newcastle until Jefferies sent on Peter Beagrie midway through the second half.

Robert Lee and Nolberto Solano were also off-target in breaks, but they proved to be rare incidents in a curiously subdued match, in which both teams lacked sufficient imagination and ambition to take a grip on affairs until Dyer's decisive goal.

webTitle: Success requires a healthy dose of self-doubt

fields.headline: Success requires a healthy dose of self-doubt
fields.trailText: I see no reason why I should not continue to get better, nor any other manager for that matter, as long as we continue to question ourselves.
fields.body:
How good a manager am I? At this stage of my career on this side of the game, I cannot answer the question in terms of comparing myself ability-wise to all the others in the position, because so many of them have greater experience in the post than me. The only time I will be able to make a proper judgment of myself will be when I retire. It was the same when I was a player.

However, I am sure that, while I do not enjoy every aspect of managing a club - I am a coach at heart and happiest when working with the players on the training field - there isn't an aspect of the job that I do not think I can handle. Moreover, I know that I am a much better manager than I was when I started four years ago.

Though Coventry's Premiership position may suggest otherwise, the difference between me now and then is like night and day; and I like to think that I will carry on improving for the simple reason that I will never think of myself as being too big not to question my ability. This was raised recently through a newspaper interview when I was asked if Coventry's slide towards the relegation zone had created any 'self-doubts'.

I replied that I am always liable to question myself at key points in my career; that there have been around six periods during my 28 years in the game when this has been particularly pronounced. For example, when I joined Manchester United from Aberdeen, I did ask myself whether I was good enough technically to play top-flight club football in England, and cope with appearing in front of such big crowds. I did not think: 'The likes of Bryan Robson and Norman Whiteside are lucky to have me in their team.' It was the same when I took over from Ron Atkinson as Coventry's manager, and started with a League Cup defeat by Gillingham and three in the Premiership.

I am surprised the interview attracted so much attention. I would have thought that everybody in professional football has self-doubts from time to time. Football is a game in which confidence is essential and, because of its macho nature, I think there is a sensitivity among managers and players about coming across in a way that might cause them to be perceived as being mentally weak and vulnerable under pressure.

The point is perhaps best illustrated by the extent to which Bryan Robson's honesty has gone against him. It seems to me that his bold initiative in bringing in Terry Venables to help him steer Middlesbrough out of the relegation zone - or, more specifically, his admission that he does not feel confident about doing it on his own - has been seen quite negatively.

Of course, much of this stems from the fact that it represents a major change in Robson's image. His recent image as a manager seems totally at odds with the one he had as a player, when he did not appear to have self-doubts at all and was responsible for rescuing more seemingly on-field lost causes than any footballer I have known.

But appearances can be deceptive. I like to think that I was as confident as anyone as a player; hence the fact that I was the penalty-taker at all my clubs, and was only 19 when I was appointed captain of Dundee. I was also captain of Leeds United's Second and First Division Championship-winning teams, and the Scotland side.

However, the body language I presented did not mean that I never harboured self-doubts. In my view, It was not only natural for me to question myself at every major step up the ladder - it was also necessary for me to do so in order to keep progressing. That little bit of insecurity helped make me work harder. It has been the same in my managerial career, although one major change in me now compared to when I started is that I have become much more philosophical about setbacks and no longer put all the blame on myself when things are not going well. At times like these, I try not to read newspaper stories about me and Coventry - to avoid getting upset and thus expending too much negative energy - and remember the times I have bounced back from bad spells in the past.

Though it hurts to lose, I now appreciate more than ever that sometimes it comes down more to circumstances than ability. The longer I have been in the job, the more I have been prepared to take risks in terms of our style of play. Up to a point, I have widened the scope of the players and myself to make mistakes - and learn. All managers carry certain expectations; and in my case, the main responsibility concerns keeping Coventry in the Premiership.

Coventry have been in the top flight for the past 33 years, a remarkable record for our size, and one that has become increasingly difficult to maintain since the formation of the Premiership. So when assessing my development as a manager - at a time when the job is probably harder than it has ever been - I feel that I should be encouraged by the fact that there has been an improvement in our Premiership survival margins.

In the light of Coventry's present situation, it is also pertinent for me to remember that I was being described as one of the most promising young managers in England about 18 months ago. I haven't suddenly gone from being a good manager to a bad one.

I see no reason why I should not continue to get better with Coventry - especially if I retain an element of self-doubt.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: The king of comedy
fields.standfirst: Oleg Luzhny tells the one about the Arsenal defender, his oldest mate and the north London derby
fields.trailText: Oleg Luzhny tells a good one about the Arsenal defender, his oldest mate and the north London derby.
fields.body:
If you were choosing a Premiership footballer to dress up in a gold lamé jacket, stand in front of a television camera, and deliver a corny joke, Oleg Luzhny would not instantly strike you as being the most suitable.

Deadpan features, standard army haircut, an old-fashioned defender with a reticent personality - yet there he is each week on a sports show on BBC Choice with a new gag. Given his penchant for comedy, coupled with his billing on the programme as the most Ukrainian of Ukrainians, it felt right to ask him to crack a typical joke from his homeland. He looked bemused. Kiev's 'king of comedy', instead of launching into a gag, looked blank and wondered why anyone would wish to know such a thing. Understanding alien cultures can take a lot of hard work.

Luzhny admits it took him a good six months training his ear to a new language and his football to a new style before he felt comfortable with life in the Premiership. He empathises with his friend Sergei Rebrov, currently going through a similar adaptation process a few miles away at Tottenham. That said, he is confident that his old team-mate from Dynamo Kiev will settle in and fulfil the heady expectations that greeted his arrival at White Hart Lane. 'There is more to come from Sergei. He is a very good player, very quick, very clever, and he will only improve. Maybe he will become the second Jurgen Klinsmann,' muses Luzhny. 'I think he can. Why not?'

If he does it will be a tremendous achievement. Klinsmann arrived in London as a fully matured talent armed with heaps of travelling experience, charming English and the character of a born leader. Rebrov is younger, playing for a club outside his native land for the first time and came with a very basic smattering of lingo picked up through his passion for amateur radio.

Klinsmann was also an out-and-out predator, while Rebrov is a provider-come-poacher in the Paul Scholes mould. A recent lean spell has had the critics sharpening their opinions. None the less Luzhny expects his pal to rediscover his goal touch soon. But not too soon. 'He's not going to score against Arsenal, but after that he's quite welcome to score in every match,' he says.

Tomorrow's north-London hostilities will be watched with interest back in Ukraine. They are reasonably impressed with Rebrov's performances so far, but, like Luzhny, are waiting for him to find full vibrancy. Whether it's down to acclimatisation or the emergence of a fine new talent back home, Rebrov slipped down the pecking order in Ukraine's footballer of the year award, finishing third behind the magnificent Andrei Shevchenko and the prolific Shakhtar Donetsk striker Andrei Vorobei.

This will be the first occasion that pits Luzhny and Rebrov in direct opposition and these friends, who speak every other day on the phone and go round to each other's house every couple of weeks, are adamant they will treat it as just another game. Naturally they are caught up in the emotions of the derby, but they are unlikely to be overawed. 'Before, when we played in the Russian championship, our big game was again Spartak Moscow. It was a fantastic atmosphere,' says Luzhny.

Of course, Dynamo don't have neighbourly foes to speak of. In Ukraine's national championship, their biggest enmity is with Shakhtar Donetsk, a two-hour plane ride away. 'It's very difficult to play in Kiev because there are no good rivals,' explains Luzhny. This lack of competition makes a move abroad a major attraction. 'Here, every game is important. Every game you must give 100 per cent. Every game is must win, must win, must win.'

Ask Luzhny if it was a major decision to come to England or if there was ever a point during those early months when he pondered whether he had made the right choice, and he looks at you as if you are mad. The work ethic drummed into him by the stern Valery Lobanovski at Dynamo ensures that he works at his job without asking too many questions.

When Arsène Wenger bought him 18 months ago, the granite-shouldered Ukrainian captain was perceived as the first sign of a bulldozer hitting the ancient citadel otherwise known as the Arsenal back four. Breaking into the defence, though, has not been easy: 'It's very difficult to make your mark when you come to any new team. Moreover, they had played together so long and knew each other so well, it makes it even more difficult. So the first six months getting used to the English game and different tactics were a real learning period. In Kiev we used to play with one libero and Arsenal play with four defenders in a line. It took some time to get used to, but now it's OK.'

Of the three Dynamo Kiev stars who left for the West, Luzhny is the least glamorous, attracting less interest than Rebrov and Shevchenko. That has done nothing to deter his competitive spirit. Reflecting on Arsenal's battering at the hands of his old enemies from Spartak, he groans: 'Oh... I very much wish we had won in Moscow.' The idea that he might get revenge back at Highbury makes him cackle with laughter. It seems we'll have to keep guessing about the secret world of Ukrainian comedy.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: All the latest tittle-tattle plus Tales from the tabs.
fields.body:
Please, sir, may I have some more?

Who needs measly five-figure bonuses for wins, goals, trophies and league placings? Brazilian footballer Divanilson Goncalves da Silva, aka Dario, has hit on a brilliant way to earn even more. He wants overtime from his employers, Santa Cruz de Recife, for playing late at night, on Sundays and holidays. He reckons anti-social hours should mean double time. No, please, stop laughing. His former club, Gremio de Puerto Alegre, from whom he is seeking a cool £100,000 in back pay, has tried to settle his claim but Dario has rejected their offer as too small. News of his unlikely success has alerted other players in Brazil and 15 are now lining up court cases. Wonder if Luis Figo thought about trying the same stroke with Real Madrid...

Hi, I'm David. Fly me

David Seaman is becoming an air steward. This week's Hello! reveals that, during a recent auction at Richard Branson's house to help the NSPCC, the Arsenal keeper ended up paying £3,000 for the huge honour of being an air steward on a Virgin long-haul flight - all for charidee, of course. Boozy England players returning from Hong Kong are presumably not welcome on his flight. Forget all the obvious jokes about Seaman letting the trolley slip under his body during a bout of turbulence. What Said & Done wonders about is the potential offers of unscheduled stopovers from the stewards - Seaman has already been accused of looking like a 'Soho porn salesman' by one Finnish newspaper, so who knows what his male colleagues will make of that dodgy ponytail and moustache?

Third-time lucky for Duah

Spare a thought for Edward Agyeman Duah. Today the defender makes his third appearance in the African Champions League final in Accra, Ghana. The other two times, he has played on the losing side and each time missed a kick in the penalty shootout. No, his nickname is not Jonah. Today's game is worth a fortune to the winners, either Duah's team,Hearts of Oak of Ghana, or Esperance of Tunisia - a cool $1 million, to be exact, plus an appearance in next summer's second Fifa World Club Championship in Spain, another financial windfall. Hearts lead Esperance 2-1 from the first leg. Bizarrely for a major cup final, tickets only go on sale this morning. 'If we sell them before then we give the forgers a chance to copy and then print their own tickets,' admits the chairman of Ghana's FA.

Di Canio the gentleman

He may push referees, but Paolo Di Canio (pictured) is more respectful of OAPs. The Italian revealed last week that, during his first five months in London after signing for West Ham, he travelled by Tube. 'Every time I saw old people I gave my seat up to them because I am an athlete and I can stand for a few minutes.' Well done, kind sir. Despite all the talk of him returning to Lazio, Di Canio swears he adores London and claims he wants to stay here when he retires -- he plans to open a gourmet food shop. 'Not for business, just for pleasure, to give the English people the opportunity to eat really good food,' says Di Canio. Don't forget: his autobiography includes the Italian recipe for tiramisù, so he may well be serious.

Vaniteux? Moi?

Aston Villa are new men -- and that's official. Says who? The ultimate Mr Vain himself, David Ginola. 'Many of the players apply body sprays, hair gel and so on before going on the field, but that's no surprise - men everywhere are really looking after themselves now and starting to think about what's good for them, whether it's for good health or to be attractive to women,' David tells lad mag Loaded . 'There's a trend at the moment for footballers to shave off their hair, but why should I do what everyone else does?' he asks. His claim not to 'focus too much on how I look' is borne out by his own very short, simple beauty routine: L'Oreal Elvive 2-in-1 shampoo after training, Colour Fitness hair restorer to stop his flowing locks going any greyer, a shave with alcohol-free shave cream and then an aftershave balm. You see, just like the rest of us.

denis.campbell@observer.co.uk

Tales from the Tabs

Weng blanks Petit Emmanuel Petit is desperate to end his Spanish nightmare with a return to Arsenal, but Arsene Wenger is not interested. Instead, Chelsea or even Fulham could step in to bring the 30-year-old back to London.

I will spend Rio cash Harry Redknapp has not been put off after failing to land Robbie Keane, and is set to go on an almighty spending spree. "We should be spending that £18m now. It's the only way. It is all bonus money for us. Let's go and spend it."

And the rest...

Tottenham fans have been blasted by Ramon Vega after the 'Swiss miss' joined Celtic on loan. 'They want Tottenham to always be challenging for success and playing in Europe but why?' he laments.  Arsenal felt the force of a similar blast from Paolo Vernazza, who joined Watford this week. 'The last young player Arsenal brought through was Tony Adams,' he says.  Milan 's Andriy Shevchenko is the latest footballer to move into movies. Brazilian footballer Divanilson Goncalves da Silva, aka Dario, has hit on a brilliant way to earn even more. Fly me David Seaman is becoming an air steward. fields.headline: The battle of Turf Moor
fields.standfirst: Eight miles is still a long way in East Lancs - especially on the road from Burnley to Blackburn
fields.trailText: Eight miles is still a long way in East Lancs - especially on the road from Burnley to Blackburn, writes Paul Wilson.
fields.body:
Graeme Souness has been involved in some high-octane derbies in his time - Glasgow, Merseyside and Istanbul to name just a few - but he will not have experienced anything quite like the East Lancashire derby at Turf Moor this afternoon.

This particular East Lancashire derby, at any rate. Though the enmity between Burnley and Blackburn Rovers supporters is fairly well known, a rivalry between two former cotton towns eight miles apart does not normally amount to much in the grand scheme of things, for the simple reason that the two clubs are not normally playing each other.

One has to go back to 4 April 1983 for the last League meeting of the Rovers and the Clarets, an occasion distinguished, if that is the word, by a lengthy stoppage in play caused by Burnley fans setting on fire and partly demolishing the old Ewood stand that housed them.

Ah, the good old days. Burnley supporters claim they were merely drawing attention to the urgent need for urban regeneration in Blackburn, several years before Jack Walker was struck by the same idea. It would be considerably more difficult to dismantle any part of Ewood now, and that is part of the trouble. For while Rovers have spent at least a portion of the past 17 years transforming their stadium and their training facilities, employing Kenny Dalglish and Alan Shearer and carrying off the Premiership title in 1995, Burnley have only gradually pulled themselves back from the brink of dropping out of the League and in all probability out of existence.

Some thought this derby might never be played again. One or two Blackburn supporters were rash enough to turn that claim into a boast. To say Burnley fans have been eagerly awaiting this afternoon's encounter, confirming as it does that one club have moved back up to their proper station while the other have come back down, would be to risk the understatement of the season. Or the past 17 seasons. One Burnley follower expressed the view several years ago, when the two clubs were still moving in opposite directions, that while he was looking forward to the eventual resurrection of the derby he feared such a game might have to be played in Beirut.

That precaution has been deemed unnecessary, though the police and the two clubs are trying just about everything else. Blackburn supporters are being bussed into their neighbours' ground under police escort. Supporters buying tickets at Ewood are being told that unless they accept a seat on transport the club are providing their safety cannot be guaranteed. Police also tried to shut down Burnley town centre, shops as well as pubs, for the afternoon of the game.

Ordinarily this should not have proved too difficult for a 4pm kick-off on a Sunday, but Burnley intends to be open for its last big shopping Sunday before Christmas. For this reason, attempts to have the kick-off brought forward were resisted. A morning or lunchtime start would have meant a crowd of about 22,600 emptying into a busy town centre - despite the bucolic name, Turf Moor is one of the most centrally situated of football grounds - but a 4pm kick-off leaves plenty of time for a good drink before the game, assuming fans can find someone to serve them.

The possibility that they might presumably explains why the clubs held a joint press conference four days ago, to appeal for calm and common sense. 'Please stay away if you intend to cause trouble,' said Burnley manager Stan Ternent, a touch optimistically. 'I hope this occasion can be remembered as a great game of football,' said his counterpart Souness. 'It might only take one lunatic to set something off and spoil it.'

Heaven forbid anyone does anything provocative like planting a team flag in the opposition's centre circle then. Blackburn fans will be so heavily guarded by police there seems little prospect of interaction between supporters, but trouble between Burnley fans and police cannot be ruled out, particularly as not everyone who wants to see the gamed can get a ticket.

Violence apart, it is difficult to imagine the match passing entirely without mischief. Blackburn supporters organised one of the most famous stunts of all when they hired an aeroplane to fly over Turf Moor during an (unsuccessful) Fourth Division play-off 10 years ago trailing the message 'Staying Down Forever'.

Despite that memorable incident, most of the passion in this rivalry comes from the Burnley end. Blackburn do not hate Burnley with anything like the same venom; in fact they have spent the past decade trying to forget they were ever involved in anything so parochial as an East Lancashire derby. This arrogance alone riles Burnley all the more.

'They have been trying to ignore us, but we've come back to haunt them,' said Edward Lee, sports editor of the Burnley Express . 'Blackburn didn't want to know Burnley a few years ago, they were telling everyone their derby games were against Manchester United and Liverpool. Funny, we all thought, you never hear anyone in Manchester or Liverpool talking about derby games with Blackburn. It goes without saying that people in Burnley were happy to see Blackburn relegated. It was a fitting punishment for trying to turn their back on their roots.'

Burnley would never have done such a thing, not even with Walker as a benefactor. Not that the Clarets would have welcomed Jack Walker as a benefactor. 'Burnley fans have thought about this a lot, and we all wish Jack Walker had been born somewhere else,' Lee said. 'It wouldn't have bothered us if he had been so generous to Bolton or Blackpool, anyone but Blackburn. We do not wish he had been born in Burnley, though, because we know it wouldn't have made any difference. The old board would have turned him away. There is some money at Burnley now, but only because the club was virtually reborn a few years ago after almost going out of business. The old board was perfectly capable of showing millionaire backers the door, as the present chairman and vice-chairman know only too well. In fact it is often said that had Jack Walker been born in Burnley he would still have all his money.'

One of the great attractions of this rivalry is that because the two towns are separate entities - eight miles is still a long way in Lancashire - there is hardly any point of contact between the two until the day of the game. Blackburn papers run Blackburn news only and vice versa for Burnley. It is not like Liverpool, Glasgow or London, where media outlets have to pretend a strict neutrality.

Only Radio Lancashire, which covers both clubs, is in that position this afternoon, and chief commentator Howard Booth has booked himself a seat on the fence already. 'I think it will be a draw, and I hope there won't be any trouble,' he said. 'There is no point pretending these supporters like each other, though. I think the police are right to be cautious, because apart from the troublesome element, both these clubs have a lot of family supporters. You see a lot of women and children at both grounds, and it is not uncommon for three generations from the same family to watch the game together.

'That may not sound like a recipe for disaster, but what has happened to these two clubs is pretty unique. There aren't many clubs who have done what Blackburn have done, and there aren't many places as insular as Burnley. Old Firm derbies might be the most intense, passionate footballing events in these islands, but none of those meetings will have been as feverishly anticipated as this one. I just hope, with the television cameras present, everyone stays calm and lets two great clubs do themselves justice.'

webTitle: Ruddock off, but Hendry still Braveheart

fields.headline: Ruddock off, but Hendry still Braveheart
fields.trailText: Division One review.
fields.body:
Three thirty-somethings hogged much of the spotlight yesterday, but not all were seen in a flattering light.

Crystal Palace's Neil Ruddock was sent off for foul and abusive language at Crewe. Upset by the award of a penalty to the home team, he incurred the referee's displeasure by continuing to make his feelings about it known even after Palace's Latvian keeper, Alex Kolinko, had saved the spot kick (from Shaun Smith) and Colin Little had given Crewe a 41st- minute lead.

Fortunately for Ruddock, Dougie Freedman scored 10 minutes from the end to give Palace a 1-1 draw,

Meanwhile, Colin Hendry and Carlton Palmer, two 35-year-olds from the Premiership, had mixed fortunes as they took first steps towards resurrecting their first-team careers - and emphasising their leadership qualities - with their debuts on-loan for Bolton and Watford.

Hendry's image as the soccer equivalent of Braveheart was brought into sharp focus by his duel at Wimbledon with John Hartson. The Welsh centre-forward is not the sort of player anyone can relish facing when not 100 per cent physically. However, Hendry, who admitted that he was rusty after being frozen out of the first-team at Coventry, handled it quite well.

Hartson did not score; and Bolton, who are banking on Hendry's experience to give their defence greater consistency, gained a 1-0 win through a goal by Dean Holdsworth.

With Fulham coming from behind to beat Tranmere 3-1, thanks in no small measure to two goals from Luis Boa Morte, that Bolton win kept the gap between the two teams at the top to 10 points.

Bolton, who have Hendry for three months, are hoping that he can do for them what he did for Blackburn on his return to Ewood Park in 1991. One of Kenny Dalglish's first signings there, Hendry is widely acknowledged to have been one of the key figures in their leap from the First Division to the Premiership title. Today, Hendry's appetite for being in the thick of the action seems as big as ever. He has taken a pay cut to go to Bolton, and their manager,

Sam Allardyce, who believes that his experience can help bring greater consistency to their defence, says: 'I admire what he has done. It has become quite rare - so many Premiership players who are not regular members of their first teams seem happy to sit on their big contracts and just pick up their money.'

Palmer, who like Hendry has also been rendered surplus to requirements by Coventry, gave a good account of his leadership qualities, too, in the 3-3 draw against West Brom.

It was a match that might well have made him feel his age, because Watford, 2-0 ahead at one stage, found themselves trailing 3-2. Tommy Mooney got Watford's equaliser eight minutes from the end, thus enabling them to end a run of five successive defeats. It can only get better, according to Watford's manager Graham Taylor.

He knows Palmer as well as anyone, having been England manager when the player gained his 18 international caps. He says: 'He has a lot of experience, and I know he can lead both in the dressing room and on the pitch.

At the other end, bottom of the table QPR gained only their third win of the season, 1-0 at the expense of Nottingham Forest. Of the teams immediately above them, Huddersfield drew 1-1 at Portsmouth while Grimsby overcame Norwich 2-0.

One of the best individual performances came from Gillingham striker Carl Asaba, who made the best possible comeback after injury by scoring two goals in the surprise 4-0 win over Preston. Stoke's Peter Thorne scored a hat-trick in the 3-0 win at Bristol Rovers, as did Barnet's player-manager Tony Cottee in the 4-2 win against Scunthorpe.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Game's identity crisis
fields.trailText: Football leagues across Europe are on full alert as the instance of false passports spreads among Europe's top league's.
fields.body:
Football leagues across Europe are on full alert as the instance of false passports spreads. At the end of last season several players in the Italian league were found to have false documents and now French officials fear they have fallen victim to the same fraud.

Arsenal almost got caught out when they tried to sign Brazilian player Edu. He was discovered with forged papers. by officials at Heathrow before the club closed the deal worth a reported £8 million.

Free transfers and free movement around the EU can bring untold riches for those that steal passports.

The latest scandal came to light in a clash between French rivals Toulouse and St Etienne early this season. Suspicions were aroused about St Etienne goalkeeper Maxim Levitsky and the Brazilian Alex. The match programme announced that Levitsky was Greek and Alex Brazilian, yet a few months earlier Levitsky had appeared as a Ukrainian and the Brazilian as Portuguese.

The club initially gave the excuse that the Ukrainian had only received his Greek papers in May because of the influx of Chechen refugees into Greece while Alex had reverted to Brazilian nationality because the club had sold a Russian and Alex would not be occupying a 'foreigner's' place. The French league has a quota of three non-EU players per club.

But sensing a public relations disaster St Etienne last week began legal proceedings against persons unknown in an attempt to get to the bottom of the affair. The French football league thinks the problem may go much deeper and is urging all clubs to lodge foreign passports with their local prefectures for verification before the end of January. There are 78 players in France who claim dual nationality, but none holds a French passport.

The ball was set rolling in April when police in Luxembourg broke up a ring of criminals who trafficked false passports between Brazil and Portugal and the Portuguese government admitted that several thousand passports had been stolen from embassies across the world.

In May two Brazilians from Italian first division club, Udinese, were detained by Polish border officials for holding false Portuguese documents. Italian police investigated and found others in the same club with forged documents.

Later in May French club Strasbourg's Argentinian defender Diego Garay was held by German police and questioned for seven hours. Garay claimed he was of Italian descent but his passport was forged. Strasbourg were obliged to return him to his former club Talleres Cordoba.

fields.headline: Dundee enjoy divine intervention
fields.trailText: Scottish Premier League review.
fields.body:
Outside Celtic's demolition job on Aberdeen, the next best performance in the Premier League yesterday was at Kilmarnock, where Dundee fought back from two goals down to win 3-2.

Dundee, with their star striker Claudio Caniggia ruled out because of jetlag after his flight back from Argentina, fell behind after only three minutes through Christophe Cocard. With Steve Milne squandering a chance to draw level, Martin Baker put them further in trouble by claiming his first Kilmarnock goal for three years from Cocard's cross.

That Dundee were able to recover stemmed from a mistake by Kilmarnock's keeper, Gordon Marshall, in allowing an Ivan Bonetti shot to slip under his body. Milne did the rest with two goals in the last 14 minutes. Player-manager Bonetti said Caniggia followed the game on the radio. 'He phoned me after the game and told me he was praying,' said Bonetti.

Hibernian, inspired by Russell Latapy, had a 2-0 win over St Johnstone. Stuart Lovell scored their first goal with a left-foot strike from the edge of the box and Mixi Paatelainen added the other with a header.

Motherwell and Dunfermline had 2-0 wins over Hearts and St Mirren. In both cases, the opposition could count themselves fortunate that the victory margin was not more emphatic.

Dunfermline's success was highlighted by a goal from Chris McGroarty, who dribbled through the defence before the finishing touch.

Derek Townsley, scorer of one of Motherwell's goals, had the distinction of one of the day's most agonising misses. He put himself in an excellent position after a 50-yard run, but pulled his shot wide with only the keeper to beat.

Colin Hendry took an encouraging first step towards resurrecting his first-team career - and emphasising his leadership qualities - on-loan for Bolton.

Hendry's image as the soccer equivalent of Braveheart was brought into sharp focus by his duel at Wimbledon with John Hartson. The Welsh centre-forward is not the sort of player anyone can relish facing when not 100 per cent physically. But Hendry, who admitted that he was rusty after being frozen out of the first-team picture at Coventry, handled it quite well.

Hartson did not score; and Bolton, who are banking on Hendry's experience to give their defence greater consistency, had a 1-0 win through a goal by Dean Holdsworth.

fields.headline: Brown ready for Houllier hotshots
fields.trailText: Whatever the rumours and whoever Houllier picks up front, rejuvernated United defender Wes Brown is up to the task, writes Ian Whittell.
fields.body:
The Liverpool family's apparent degeneration into dysfunctionalism has centred around a simple but irrefutable mathematical equation this season - three into two will not go. And when the three are Michael Owen, Robbie Fowler and Emile Heskey, passionate opinion and dissent both in and outside the ranks looks sure to follow.

Manager Gérard Houllier must wrestle with this conundrum again at Old Trafford this afternoon. For Sir Alex Ferguson it is not even an issue.

Whatever Houllier's solution - Heskey (if fit) and Owen the favourite, Heskey and Smicer a surprise second favourite, Heskey and Fowler trailing third - Ferguson has the utmost faith in a young defender, barely 21 and barely back from a year out of the game following knee ligament surgery.

'I think Wes Brown being out for a year has helped him on two counts,' says Ferguson of a young player over whom he can scarcely conceal his enthusiasm. 'For one, he has probably looked at his whole life, as a young person in the game, and thought, "I hope I get back."

'Secondly, there is a joy to getting back playing after watching football from the sidelines for a year. Giving him a year to get over the cruciate knee injury completely was of great benefit to the lad and he has come back without any semblance of the injury.

'But those two factors have helped the lad blossom. He has been absolutely unbelievable, his performance level is incredible. He is, without question, the best natural defender this club has had for years and years.

'At 13, he could smell danger anywhere in the penalty box, he was always there to snip it out. All the things he has added to his game - his use of the ball, his timing in tackles and in the air - have added to him. He has become a really top player. He is quite laid-back off the pitch, but on it he is a winner.'

Brown's precocious calm under pressure, his unflappable reading of the game will again come under close scrutiny this afternoon, whoever his direct opponent turns out to be. Owen and Fowler have both been heavily criticised by Houllier of late and Friday morning dawned at the club's training ground with a story claiming that the pair can barely conceal their dislike for each other.

It was an allegation Houllier was swift to nip in the bud, but one that he accepts is part and parcel of the modern game, both in terms of the Catch 22 nature of the current rotation system employed by clubs - damned if you pick 'em, damned if you don't - and the intense media gaze placed upon the business.

'I understand now that we have everyone available up front, which hasn't been the case for the past two and a half years, that people are trying to stir things up or drag down our team spirit,' said Houllier.

'That's the modern game. We just have to live with that and the players ignore it. Six months ago, I was criticised for bringing Emile Heskey to the club because some so-called experts said he would never get a game because he would always be behind Robbie Fowler and Michael Owen. But he is good enough and I think you need to have three or four strikers of that quality.'

Of course, that theme is a familiar one to Ferguson, who in recent seasons should have patented his formula for keeping four international calibre strikers concurrently happy.

'In our game you have to have the rotation system but you get panned when it doesn't work,' said Ferguson. 'That's crazy, when you think about it. What do you do? Wait for a player to drop dead on his feet?

'You have a pool of players and there has to be a time to take the risk because it's a big picture. That's what Gerard did when he left out Heskey last week and I think he did the right thing.'

Soap-opera machinations and personality clashes, alleged or otherwise, aside, none of this will matter today when one of British sport's most hostile rivalries is renewed. For supporters on both sides, the identity of who is wearing the respective shirts is almost incidental.

'It is always the most important game of the calendar, for a million reasons,' said Ferguson. 'The history, the culture of the two cities, the fact they're only 40 miles from each other, the success of the clubs over the years. Whatever it is, it's a bag of emotion and passion, a terrific match.'
