fields.headline: Brazilian congress begin football crackdown
fields.trailText: The so-called 'black box' of Brazilian soccer could be prised open next year when Congress resumes it's investigations into the chaotic state of Brazilian football.
fields.byline: Brian Homewood in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
The so-called 'black box' of Brazilian soccer could be prised open next year when Congress, which is investigating the chaotic state of the country's national sport, resumes after its end-of-year-recess.

The two Congressional commissions of inquiry, which are probing Brazilian football, celebrated their last full working week of the year last week by voting to extend the reach of their investigation.

The most dramatic development came in the Senate's commission, whose members voted on Wednesday to investigate the bank accounts of 15 leading clubs, 29 club directors and ex-directors and six directors of the Brazilian Football Confederation, including president Ricardo Teixeira.

Meanwhile, the parallel commission in the lower house voted on Thursday to question four more ex-national team players, including Romario. The lower house will also interrogate an agent known as Ted Junior, accused of promising to find foreign clubs for teenage would-be soccer players and then abandoning them abroad. He is one of a number of agents believed to be involved in what is described as 'the trafficking of minors'.

Other problems include the failure of the CBF to hold the national championship this year, a farcical fixture list, which frequently forces teams to play three games a week, and constant changing of the rules of competitions.

This has been aggravated by a series of scandals and suspicions over what happens to the millions of dollars clubs receive from television fees and the transfer of star players abroad.

Adding to the controversy, a number of Brazilian players have been caught in Europe this year with fake Portuguese passports, while national team coach Wanderley Luxemburgo was sacked in September amid a series of allegations of improper practices.

Congressmen also hope to determine how much influence multi-national sportswear giants Nike have in the running of the national team, which they sponsor.

The former Fifa president Joao Havelange, the former Brazil coach Mario Zagallo and the striker Edmundo, a member of the 1998 World Cup team, are among those to have been previously interviewed by the lower house, mainly in connection with the Nike contract.

However these hearings initially produced more entertainment than serious revelations. Edmundo's presence caused chaos in the lower house, with politicians, secretaries and cleaning staff alike abandoning their posts to catch a glimpse of a player known as 'The Animal'.

Havelange spent much of his interrogation praising his own 24-year reign in charge of Fifa, even digressing at one point to tell the inquiry that 800,000 trees had been planted in Dubai in the last 10 years.

Since then, however, the investigations have taken on a more serious tone. At the end of last month, the Senate commission interrogated Luxemburgo for five hours and revealed that the ex-coach's income had exceeded $9million (£6.4m) in the last five years.

After asking Luxemburgo to justify his earnings and hearing the reply 'I'm very disorganised' on numerous occasions, Senators told him his explanations were unconvincing. Luxemburgo is likely to be re-questioned at a later date and also faces a grilling in the lower house commission.

The Senate also heard from CBF president Teixeira who told them that the confederation had cash flow problems - despite a contract with Nike, which he said is worth an average of $16m (£11.4m) a year and which he described as the best of its type in the world.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Why I had to give Barry a 'bung'

fields.headline: Why I had to give Barry a 'bung'
fields.trailText: A simple case of rearranging a cancelled Worthington Cup quarter-final fixture? A costly and confusing run-around, writes Alan Smith.
fields.body:
It is stressful enough being a manager when you have a big game coming up, but it is not much better when one is called off. Regular readers may recall that this time last week we at Crystal Palace were preparing for our Worthington Cup quarter-final against Peter Reid's Sunderland. Unfortunately, the game had to be postponed because of heavy rain and that was when the problems really began.

There is no simple way to rearrange a football match these days, it seems. Agreeing a new date with Sunderland, which we tried to do as soon as the game was postponed, settling for this Tuesday, was easy enough. But unfortunately the complications soon began.

The first problem was that our original game was to have been shown live on Sky television, with both clubs being paid £100,000 in appearance money. But Sky had already agreed to televise the FA Cup replay between Northwich Victoria and Leyton Orient this Tuesday, so they could only fit us in on Wednesday.

That would have been difficult for us as we are playing Blackburn Rovers in a League game on Friday evening because the Sainsbury supermarket that adjoins our ground does not want us playing on the last Saturday before Christmas!

Having sold them the land on which they built their store, which closes during our matches, we have had to reach an agreement with them over when we play, and they were quite firm about wanting to remain open on this important Christmas shopping day.

We had initially suggested a 5pm kick-off on Saturday evening, but Blackburn did not want that, so we could not shift our Friday fixture. That meant playing on Tuesday and thereby losing the revenue and prestige of playing in a televised game, or switching to Wednesday and having to play two big games in the space of three days, which was clearly unacceptable. Our financial people did not want to lose the money but, understandably, I did not want to put my players under the strain of two games with just one day's rest in between.

Then we considered another plan. If we could persuade Northwich and Orient to switch to the Wednesday, we could play Tuesday and still get the television income. Northwich were quite happy to switch days for a reasonable fee in compensation, but Orient were harder to deal with, because their chairman, Barry Hearn, drives a hard bargain.

Eventually we agreed a fee and could start to plan for a Tuesday game, but in between all of these negotiations we had to liaise with the FA and Nationwide League as well as the Metropolitan Police, to whom we pay a lot of money to regulate our matches. We also had to make sure the referee and officials could fit in with the plans.

The postponement also changed the players' plans completely. They trained on the Sunday and Monday before the game, stayed overnight in a local hotel and were supposed to be off the day after the game. But because it was called off, they had to come in for training on their day off, and miss out on what would have probably been a family Christmas-shopping day.

They also planned to go on a short 'bonding' break to Ireland after yesterday's game at Crewe, but this has now had to be cancelled. So I had to ring up the airline to try to get a refund on 30 or so flights, as well as cancel their hotel rooms in Dublin. And as tomorrow is the night before the Sunderland game, the players and their wives will now have to miss out on the chairman's Christmas party at the Berkeley Hotel.

So all in all, a costly and time-consuming business for all involved, not least the supporters, who had a wasted journey last Tuesday.

And it also adds to our fixture congestion which will include six games in 17 days - assuming we do not have any more falling foul of the weather!

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Falling for the first snow
fields.standfirst: Nigel Lloyd  takes a tumble on the  Premier Neige in the French Alps after flouting the 'universial laws of alignment'
fields.trailText: Nigel Lloyd takes a tumble on the Premier Neige in the French Alps after flouting the 'universial laws of alignment'.
fields.body:
It was a fine feeling in Val d'Isère last weekend waking to sunny blue skies on Saturday, the day of the eagerly awaited Criterium of the Premier Neige, the first World Cup Downhill race in Europe each winter. Austria's Hermann Maier celebrated by winning it and, next day, the Giant Slalom consolidated his overall lead.

Away from the manicured racing slopes, we too set off to enjoy our 'first snow' of the winter on the French Alps. And despite less than average depths for mid-December, 30cm on lower slopes and 80cm higher up, there was some great skiing.Instructors from the Mountain Masters ski school soon had us up on Madeleine before taking the chairlift into Fornet, which had opened for skiing for the first time this season.

The enthusiasts even found some acceptable off-piste for which they had been howling since their full English breakfasts in our chalet. Though it was cold - my usually warm toes slowly froze as we worked our way up and down the upper runs on Fornet and the Pissaillas Glacier - there was no wind and it became warm work. There's a new four-seat Cascade Express lift up to around 3,000m, which cuts the time it takes to get to high altitudes.

After a leisurely lunch in Auberge L'Arolay near the base station of the Fornet cable-car, I surprised myself by agreeing to do more first-day skiing. With the lifts shutting at 4.15pm, it meant skiing down Solaise in failing light as the worn piste froze over. It had by now become cold enough for the snow-making guns to add their own little blizzards.

My instructor, Bernard Cheseau, chose this moment to expound his Ski Mastery philosophy, which is about 'aligning yourself with the universal laws for the purpose of skiing'. To please him, I abandoned my sliding survival techniques and concentrated on breathing in at the start of each turn and trailing my poles on the snow in an attempt to 'move in balance with the slope and embody complete control'.

'Stop if you feel it's Red,'Bernie said, 'and only go on Green.'

Alas, my descent was done on Amber. It included four twisting falls, when I came out of one or both of my bindings and slid some distance. Bernard was patient, holding my skis steady as I won each battle to click my boots back in.

The others, waiting for us down in the Bananas bar, had almost given up hope when, long after dark, I limped in. The chalet Land-Rover came to drive us up the private road to the magnificently sited Chalet Rubis.

After a wonderful dinner we watched through the floor-to-ceiling windows as the celebration fireworks lit up the town. Then it began snowing. Wonderful large, crystal flakes were floating down through the still night sky.

I was out again last Sunday morning, all aches and pains forgotten, as we skied on the 10cm of new powder. The sun was shining, the sky was cloudless, and holiday skiers - many Britons among them - were celebrating the start of what may well be a wonderful Alpine winter.

There was just time for a terribly slow quick lunch in the bustling La Grande Ourse before flying back to the rain-swept UK. But who cares? The skiing makes it all worthwhile.

Where to stay

Chalet Rubis sleeps eight people. It is available for £699 for the single weeks starting Sunday 7 January and 14 January, instead of the usual £935. The price includes return Club Class BA flights from Heathrow to Geneva, transfers, ski hosting, resort transport, great food and drink as well as comfortable bathrobes. From Scott Dunn Ski: 020 8767 0202.

webTitle: Stoic Smith moves with the times

fields.headline: Stoic Smith moves with the times
fields.trailText: Masochism? A psycho-sexual disorder? Only something similar could have driven Alex Smith to apply for the vacancy at Dundee United last August, writes Glenn Gibbons.
fields.body:
For men in any other occupation, the urges which prompt football club managers to rush joyfully towards jobs guaranteed to induce pain and misery would be categorised by psychiatrists as a form of psycho-sexual disorder, almost certainly related to masochism.

Those afflicted invariably evince the classic symptoms: they are helpless to resist their impulses, believing themselves to be perfectly normal, wondering why other people don't have these feelings. Only the badly stricken, for example, could have accepted without the slightest compunction - indeed, with relish - the vacancy which arose at Dundee United last August, when Paul Sturrock finally regained his sanity and quit.

Alex Smith is a serious case, and has been since adolescence, when he began to develop a dedication to the game bordering on the pathological. He became a manager immediately after completing his playing career and has been one for more than 30 years, taking enough buffetings at places such as Stirling Albion, St Mirren, Aberdeen and Raith Rovers to discourage a fighting bull.

The prospect of regenerating Dundee United, who had been sliding towards irretrievable breakdown for a decade, would be regarded by Smith as something to cherish rather than dread. Nothing that has happened since has had the slightest impact on his buoyant optimism. Even a visit from Rangers this evening will not be enough to cloud this veteran's sunny outlook, despite a record which 'boasts' a single victory and 15 defeats from 19 outings and bottom place in the Premier League.

'That's where you get your motivation from, an incurable optimism,' says Smith. 'I never go into any match, with any team, thinking we'll lose it. In the minutes immediately after a defeat, your mind instantly goes forward to the next engagement and you believe that will be better.

'Even when we went to Ibrox earlier in the season and nobody else in the world thought we had a prayer, I truly believed that if we did what I thought we could do and Rangers didn't perform at their best, we could take something from the game. It's always like that, it's why we love it so much.'

Of course, Smith has been long enough and sufficiently successful in the game - the Scottish Cup won with St Mirren, the same trophy and the League Cup won with Aberdeen and needing only a draw in the final match with Rangers to secure the 1991 championship - to know that irrational optimism has to be supported by astute manipulation and preparation in the construction of a decent team.

The main problem at United in the past 10 years or so has stemmed from the intransigence of Jim McLean, the former manager and chairman, who found it impossible to cope with the great changes in football. Used to success on the back of home-bred and reared players, McLean took longer than most to recognise Scotland's diminishing production of young talent.

When he finally accepted the inevitability of having to visit the market and do business with agents, he proved to be a very unsound judge. Tannadice has been littered for years with overpaid, substandard foreigners, who are merely passing through.

Smith has noticeably taken steps to reverse the process, ridding the club of a cluster of third-rate imports - including three from that improbable supplier of brilliant footballers, Honduras - and reintroduced a Scottish strain. The arrivals of the former Rangers and Watford midfielder, Charlie Miller, the ex-St Mirren and Scotland under-21 defender Jamie Fullarton and the former Morton and Oxford United striker Derek Lilley are testimony to his intentions.

'I really do think it's necessary at a club like this,' said Smith. 'I think it makes for a better dressing-room.' However an awful ankle injury to Fullarton has deprived him of that promising player's services for the rest of the season - the kind of misfortune which tends to visit struggling clubs - and it remains to be seen whether or not Lilley and Miller will be helpful influences.

Miller, now 24, is particularly interesting, because he was a precocious talent who broke into the Rangers' first team as a teenager. But he tended to take the left-hand path in his private life, fell out of favour and was sent to Watford by Dick Advocaat when the Dutchman succeeded Walter Smith at Ibrox in 1998.

'When I came here,' said Advocaat, 'they told me what a great player Charlie was at 19. I had him at 22 and he had all the natural talent you could need, but he wasn't applying it. In the end, it was Charlie who came to me and asked what would be best for him. I told him he should go to a club where he could start playing again.'

Smith believes that Miller is still does not have the physical conditioning necessary to complement his ability and has arranged a regime during the winter break specifically for the midfielder's benefit.

'Last year, the club went to Florida during the January break when in third place in the league,' he said. 'Between their return and the end of the season, they only won one match. This year, we're going nowhere. I've told the players they are to be sent home after the game on 2 January and they are not to see me again until the 11th.

'But not Charlie. He'll have what you would call a mini pre-season, because we have to get him back to proper condition. I've told Charlie he has to realise that, by his early thirties, he could make himself a wealthy man. I have to get him to look back on his mistakes.

'I think there is maturity there now, because he's married and has two kids, but he still needs guidance. I reminded him that he must have been very special to get into that Rangers team as a teenager.'

Miller could return the favour by reminding Rangers of what they lost with a punishing performance at Tannadice tonight.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: Historic tours | Campagne trail | New look on Kos
fields.body:
Historic tours

The newly opened Great Court at the British Museum is an appropriate starting point for an English tour in the 2001 brochure of the British Museum Traveller (020 7436 7575). The six-night Architecture of England itinerary includes behind-the-scenes viewings, a reception and lecture in Europe's largest-covered square before moving north to visit historic monuments and buildings including York Minster, Hadrian's Wall and Alnwick Castle. The tour, which departs on 22 July, costs £870 including half-board accommodation. The brochure features more than 50 history, art and culture tours around the world.

Campagne trail

Vacances en Campagne (08700 771771) marks its silver jubilee by holding its 2001 prices at this year's levels. The new brochure offers couples discounts of 20 per cent in low and mid season and four weeks for the price of three in low season. The sister brochure Vacanze in Italia (08700 780186) introduces a new region: Calabria, at the toe of Italy. It is offering similar low and mid season discounts.

New look on Kos

Activity holiday specialist Mark Warner (08708 480 480) is developing its beach club on the Greek island of Kos for next summer, adding nine new floodlit tennis courts around a heated swimming pool and sports bar. New Greek-style bungalows are being built and the bedrooms and public areas of the existing hotel are being refurbished. The bungalows cost from £544 per week in early season. Eight of the nine Mediterranean beach clubs feature tennis coaching. Three resorts are reserved for adults at certain times of the year.

webTitle: Travel news: What your job says about your holiday

fields.headline: What your job says about your holiday
fields.trailText: You can tell a lot about a person's holiday habits from their profession, according to a new survey carried out by Thomson Holidays.
fields.body:
Secretaries do it the most, accountants are the most adventurous and journalists need to have a drink to enjoy it - you can tell a lot about a person's holiday habits from their profession, according to a new survey carried out by Thomson Holidays.

According to its findings, secretaries are among the most fre quent travellers: 38 per cent travel abroad at least three times a year, favouring sunny, long-haul destinations such as Mexico, Barbados and Thailand.

Those with a head for figures also have a good head for heights. One in four accountants favours an active break with rock climbing, skiing and snowboarding listed as their favourite pastimes.

Eighty two per cent of the journalists and PRs reveal their ideal activity would be wine-tasting, and two-thirds rate bar-hopping as a favourite way to pass their time on holiday. The biggest party animals are nurses, with 45 per cent selecting clubbing in Ibiza as the perfect break.

webTitle: Travel news: Branson offers rainy days refund

fields.headline: Branson offers rainy days refund
fields.trailText: Never one to let a marketing opportunity pass by, Richard Branson has come up with a Sunshine Guarantee to launch his new travel venture.
fields.body:
Never one to let a marketing opportunity pass by, Richard Branson has come up with a Sunshine Guarantee to launch his new travel venture, Virgin Travelstore.

From next summer people who book a package holiday through Virgin Travelstore will be entitled to a refund of up to £250 if they experience three consecutive days of above average rainfall, as determined by the local Met office. But before you rush to book, the offer does not apply to holidays taken in the UK.

The money-back offer applies to holidays taken in Spain, Portugal, Cyprus, Greece, Turkey, Tunisia and Malta between July and September.

'The weather has a profound effect on the quality of peoples' holidays. We've had snow guarantees for winter holidays so this seemed like the logical next step,' said Virgin Travelstore managing director Ed Sims.

The new Virgin company will sell package holidays, flights, hotels and car hire through a choice of booking channels: on the high street through Virgin's 120 V Shops, and via Digital TV, teletext and a website (www.virgintravelstore.com) that went live last week. There are also plans to install travel agency desks in selected Virgin Megastores in February that may specialise in youth and clubbing holidays.

Sims said Travelstore would offer clients impartial advice and there would be no bias towards selling Virgin holidays or flights. 'Clients are just as likely to be sold a Thomson Holiday or BA flight as a Virgin holiday or flight,' he said. However, there will be tie-ups with other Virgin products: for example, a free case of Virgin Wine or discounted membership to Virgin Active health club may be offered as a booking incentive on certain holidays.

Features of the new website include a search facility for resorts with children's clubs and free legal advice from the Consumers' Association on common holiday problems.

webTitle: Christmas: Gifts for your true loves

fields.headline: Gifts for your true loves
fields.standfirst: Once upon a time the 12 days after Christmas were just a warm-up for the biggest party of the season - Twelfth Night, marking the arrival of the Three Wise Men in Bethlehem to see the baby Jesus. But apart from the traditional panto on Boxing Day, what other ways are there to celebrate in the days leading up to 6 January?  Sally Varlow offers some ideas
fields.trailText: Once upon a time the 12 days after Christmas were just a warm-up for the biggest party of the season - Twelfth Night, marking the arrival of the Three Wise Men in Bethlehem to see the baby Jesus. But apart from the traditional panto on Boxing Day, what other ways are there to celebrate in the days leading up to 6 January? Sally Varlow offers some ideas
fields.body:
Boxing Day: Heed the call of the wild

'A partridge in a pear tree' may look very fine, but nothing beats thousands of winter migrants winging in for an evening feed at Slimbridge Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust in Gloucestershire (01453 890333). You can watch from a hide (with live commentaries at 3.30pm and 4pm), perch in an observation tower, explore pens and ponds with a Christmas Quackers' trail, or play in the children's Discovery Centre. Top of the flocks are the great Bewick's swans.

Welney, the trust's reserve near Wisbech in Cambridgeshire (01353 860711), gets the Whoopers. Any WWT site scores more than 'seven swans a swimming'.

Move on from Slimbridge to Bristol for more wildlife in Wildscreen@Bristol (0117 915 5000). Opened six months ago, Wildscreen uses multi-media displays and 75,000 living creatures to show where life came from and where the environment is heading.

27 December: Walk off the Christmas pud

If you've spent hours glued to Harry Potter on the radio or PlayStation 2, the National Trust has a post-Christmas programme of guided walks - none too demanding - led by wardens and foresters at some of its properties. Today's are at Kingston Lacy, Dorset; Clumber Park, Nottinghamshire; Prior Park, Somerset; and Holmwood Common, Surrey. Search the trust website (see overleaf) for details and any changes, or call 020 8315 1111 (office hours).

28 December: Go to the ballet

It wouldn't be Christmas without 'nine ladies dancing'. For Nutcracker fans (who don't mind queueing for day tickets): the Royal Opera House (020 7304 4000) has the Royal Ballet in cracking form as usual. The London Coliseum (020 7632 8300) presents English National Ballet's modern take on the classic Christmas story. And Birmingham Royal Ballet brings its popular version to the new Lowry Centre in Salford (0161 876 2000). If Sugar Plum fairies are out, the Royal Festival Hall, London (020 7960 4242), has a new adaptation of the favourite Dickens story, A Christmas Carol. Ballet meets modern dance, acrobatics and stilt-walking, set to pop music and carols.

29 December: Take a sleigh ride in the sky

From Port Isaac to Penzance, Cornwall takes its Christmas lights seriously. In a dozen different harbours, the quaysides, boats, streets and buildings are lit with thousands of coloured lights and spangly setpieces. They are beautiful from the ground, but they are breathtaking from the air. British International offers evening helicopter rides from Penzance over two of the most spectacular displays at Newlyn and Mousehole. Flights last eight minutes, cost £15 per person, and take off (weather permitting) between 5.30pm and 7pm (also on 22, 27 and 28 December). It's the next best thing to a sleigh ride over the rooftops (01736 363 871).

30 December: Get a taste of Christmas Past

Hampton Court Palace (020 8781 9500) has Tudor-style Christmas events all day (27 December - 1 January). See a royal feast cooked in the vast kitchens and follow it in procession to the Great Hall. Meet a court jester, hear period music on early instruments, and join a traditional dance through the state apartments. Allow at least three hours, or you'll miss some of the jugglers, entertainers and costumed guides.

Fountains Abbey, near Ripon, North Yorkshire (01482 888158), is one of many historic sites with school holiday activities. There are pastimes and puzzles, such as draughts using abbots and monks, in the barn; Victorian games outside, and a winter explorers' trail through the deer park.

New Year's Eve: Party on the streets

Cardiff rings in 2001 with Calennig, which is Welsh for New Year's gift. This is Wales's answer to Hogmanay: a three-day carnival, starting on 30 December, with fairgrounds, a children's zone in the City Hall, live music and fireworks. The climax comes on New Year's Eve, with a lantern procession from Cardiff Castle, a 'Space Oddity' family fire show, top bands on the Calennig music stage and a fireworks display as the finale (029 2087 3690).

New Year's Day: Steam into 2001

The annual timetables on steam train lines generally run on until today. Nene Valley, Cambridgeshire, the home of the Rev A.W. Awdry's original Thomas the Tank Engine, operates Thomas's Winter Warmers (01780 784444). The Icknield Line, from Chinnor in Oxfordshire to Princes Risborough in Buckinghamshire, has Mince Pie Specials (01844 353535). Didcot Railway Centre, in Oxfordshire,gets up steam at the old Great Western depot (01235 817200). Isle of Wight Steam Railway offers reduced price Hangover Specials (01983 884343) and The Bluebell Line in Sussex is on track as usual (01825 722370).

2 January: Get your skates on

Open-air ice skating is the new rock 'n' roll, in winter at least, and Edinburgh claims the biggest and best outdoor rink. Winter Wonderland, in East Princes Street Gardens, has twinkling lights, music, hot food, games and rides for non-skating youngsters; not to mention Edinburgh Castle as a backdrop. Today is the end of the city's Hogmanay festival but the rink remains open, with boots for hire, evening sessions and star turns until 7 January (0131 220 6260).

Liverpool has an outdoor rink near St George's Hall for smaller children, and in London the newly-restored Somerset House has a full-size rink in its eighteenth-century courtyard, which is open daily between 11am and 10pm (0207845 4670).

3 January: Laugh at a live panto

Booking tickets is a bit easier by now. (Oh no, it isn't. Oh yes, it is!) For fairy-tale plots and look-behind-you jokes catch Cinderella at the Theatre Royal, Bath (01225 448844); the Theatre Royal, Brighton (01273 328488), and the Derby Playhouse (01332 363275). Aladdin is at the Bradford Alhambra (01274 752000) and Theatre Royal, Plymouth (01752 267222). Peter Pan flies in to the Theatre Royal, Lincoln (01522 525555); the Yvonne Arnaud, Guildford (01483 440000), and the Tron Theatre, Glasgow (0141 552 4267).

Babes in the Wood is at the Mercury, Colchester (01206 573948) and the Bristol Old Vic (0117 987 7877).

Dick Whittington is at the King's Theatre, Edinburgh (0131 529 6000) and Theatre Royal, York (01904 623568).

For a non-traditional alternative (and it is, very) try Alice in Boogie Wonderland, the Rock 'n' Roll Panto at Liverpool 's Everyman Theatre (0151 709 4776). Or Dorothy and the circus performers, with definitely no animals, in The Wizard of Oz Christmas Circus at Blackpool Tower (01253 292029).

4 January: See a classic on stage

Dramatisations of children's classics come in all shapes and sizes. For the over-fives the Manchester Library Theatre presents Mary Norton's The Borrowers (0161 236 7110). At Basingstoke in Hampshire, the Haymarket Theatre (01256 465566) does its own delightful thing with Jungle Book the Musical .

The Royal Shakespeare Company's new musical The Secret Garden is at Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 403403; matinees sold out).

The RSC's previous hit, The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe , has moved to Sadler's Wells, Rosebery Avenue, London (020 7863 8000).

Try tubing, whizzing downhill on giant squashy tubes, over snow or dry tracks. The first place in Britain to have this cool new sport is Lecht 2090, at Strathdon, Grampian (01975 651440). One of Scotland's smallest ski areas (good for kids and starters), Lecht is now a year-round family activity centre. As well as skiing and snowboarding it has quad bikes (for eight-year-olds-plus), the UK's first 'Devalkarts' and mini karts (for four to 10-year-olds) on a bouncy-castle type track. Or make for the Cairngorm Reindeer Centre, at Aviemore, and join the daily cavalcade (weather permitting) to feed the friendly reindeer. Warm waterproofs essential (01479 861228)

Or watch Leominster Morris men perform the age-old wassail ceremony in apple orchards at Aymestrey, Herefordshire. This is not designed for young children, but is fine for older ones. From the Riverside Inn the dancers parade with flaming torches, lighting bonfires and a 'thorn cage lantern' as they go, and pour cider round a tree to bid the sun return and ensure a good crop (01544 388686).

You can watch from a hide (with live commentaries at 3.30pm and 4pm), perch in an observation tower, explore pens and ponds with a Christmas Quackers' trail, or play in the children's Discovery Centre. Top of the flocks are the great Bewick's swans. Welney, the trust's reserve near Wisbech in Cambridgeshire (01353 860711), gets the Whoopers. Any WWT site scores more than 'seven swans a swimming'. Move on from Slimbridge to Bristol for more wildlife in Wildscreen@Bristol (0117 915 5000). webTitle: Book of the Week: The Art of Travel

fields.headline: Book of the Week
fields.standfirst: The Art of Travel by Francis Galton, with an introduction by Dorothy Middleton  (Phoenix Press, £12.99)
fields.trailText: The Art of Travel by Francis Galton, with an introduction by Dorothy Middleton.
fields.body:
Francis Galton spotted a gap in the market when exploring south-west Africa in 1850-51. He discovered that those who have to 'rough it' in a foreign land found it difficult to obtain useful information from the natives of a country 'whose aquaintance with bush lore was exceedingly partial and limited'.

The Art of Travel - 'or shifts and contrivances available in wild countries' - was a compendium of practical advice for 'explorers, emigrants, missionaries or soldiers'. Galton encouraged 'those who mediate travel' to go for it as long as they had health, a craving for adventure and a moderate fortune. He advised how to organise expeditions, what to wear and take - don't forget the inflatable pontoon - how to set up camp and what to eat, especially the 'revolting food that may save the Lives of Starving men'. There are useful sections on the latest techniques in signalling and how to bury letters for later travellers without alerting the natives. Today's reader will be intrigued by the social attitudes. The chapter on 'the management of savages' is instructive. Galton's suggestion - 'a frank, joking but determined manner, joined with an air of showing more confidence in the good faith of the natives than you really feel' - is still the best way to deal with a difficult French gendarme.

But his advice to grab any food left behind in their encampments by fleeing natives won't go down well in Islington. 'It is absurd to be over-scrupulous,' he says reflecting the political correctness of his day. Perhaps these Victorian values are set to return as a Bush administration succeeds the Clinton era. Eight editions of The Art of Travel were published between 1855 and 1893. This paperback edition may be as compelling for those seeking to please an armchair traveller this Christmas.

webTitle: Fury as India cashes in on the allure of the Taj Mahal

fields.headline: Fury as India cashes in on the allure of the Taj Mahal
fields.standfirst: Muslims and tourists driven out by huge rise in charge for admission to historic monument
fields.trailText: Muslims and tourists driven out by huge rise in charge for admission to historic monument
fields.body:
It is Friday afternoon and at the Taj Mahal a large group of Muslims are gathering for prayers. Lurking in the shrubbery nearby, several squads of Indian police officers armed with sticks keep a close watch on the proceedings. A few small boys who arrive late plunge their feet into a ceremonial pool before dashing to the mosque, caps askew.

The crowd later spills out into the main courtyard. Several demonstrators unfurl a black banner and start shouting. They also wave posters carrying a picture of the Taj, beneath one of history's more esoteric slogans: 'Love & sacrefy [sic] symbol.' There is a brief standoff with the police, before the protesters surge out through the Taj's formal gardens and head down the road to deliver a petition to Agra's district magistrate.

These are troubled times indeed for India's most famous monument. And it is not just Agra's vociferous Muslim community which is unhappy. Last month the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) - the body responsible for preserving the country's heritage - dramatically raised admission prices for the Taj Mahal and other important sites.

Muslims who had previously got in free on Fridays along with everybody else suddenly found themselves charged 10 rupees. If you are poor, have to pray five times a day, and have a large family, this soon mounts up, they pointed out. Muslim leaders describe the move as an insidious blow to the freedom to practise their religion, and said it confirmed their worst suspicions about India's right-wing Hindu nationalist-led government.

But the ASI reserved its most blatant whammy for foreign tourists who now have to pay 960 rupees (£14) to get in. The fee used to be 15 rupees (22p).

Already many dazed backpackers, after checking their now out-of-date Lonely Planet guides, are giving the Taj a miss. The cost of a day's sightseeing in Agra, including the newly expensive Red Fort and the Mughal palace at nearby Fatehpur Sikri, now comes to £28.

The increase has provoked some foreigners to emulate the militant tactics adopted by Agra's Muslims. Two weeks ago a group of Japanese tourists staged a sit-down protest in front of the mausoleum, built by the Mughal King Shah Jahan to enshrine the body of his wife. Others, including Andrew Lubran, of Colchester, have written angry letters to the local Agra papers complaining of India's 'racist policy' to Westerners. The new Taj entrance fee was 'excessive and insulting', he said.

Agra's shopkeepers, tour guides, rickshaw wallahs and touts have been moaning too, as their business evaporates. Several cheap guesthouses next to the Taj have gone bust. 'We are the country of Gandhi. We have an ancient culture. We are against these racist entrance fees,' Abhinav Jain, who runs the Agra Marble Shoppe said.

The ASI has defended its new policy by pointing to the fact that other countries such as neighbouring Sri Lanka and Russia also charge a dual tariff. It cites the example of the Hermitage in St Petersburg, where non-Russians pay nearly £7, 10 times what the locals do.

'It's a great building but it's not worth 960 rupees to get in,' Oxford student Aoife Smith said yesterday, as she strolled past one of the Taj's minarets. The country's 14 world heritage sites, including the erotic temples at Khajuraho, and at Konarak, Orissa, are nearly £7 each. Other previously free lesser ruins cost more than £3.

Indian's tourism minister Ananth Kumar has been strangely reluctant to defend the new charges. When The Observer finally caught up with him, next to a tea urn at a party, and asked him how he justified the hike, he failed to answer, smiling glassily before moving off with a posse of grim-faced aides.

The ASI's director Komal Anand was more forthcoming and said the extra revenue would be 'ploughed back' into restoring India's 3,606 mostly crumbling monuments - a claim few tourism industry observers believe has much credibility.

Unless the Indian authorities back down, the affair threatens to destroy the classic India year out, as immortalised by William Sutcliffe and other traveller-novelists. Guides at the Taj Mahal estimate that 50-100 foreign students a day are now turning up at the red sandstone front gate - only to leave again without going inside.

'We were so disappointed by these price rises,' Helen Walton, 23, travelling round India with her boyfriend Miles Ross, 25, said. 'They were totally unexpected. No one minds paying a little bit more - say 100-200 rupees - but $5, $10, even $20 is totally out of backpackers' budgets. It's really sad, because it means we're simply not going to things at all, which can't be what the government wanted. We are now heading off to Nepal instead.'

The backlash has already spread as far as Britain, where last month angry tour operators bent Kumar's ear over breakfast in London. With brochures already printed, they complained that the extra entry fee costs would now come directly out of their profits. They also wondered how the hike could be reconciled with India's aim of increasing tourist numbers from 2.4 to 4 million. 'This is a huge blow to Indian tourism. We are very upset,' Arjun Sharma, of SITA Travels, explained. 'It comes on top of an increase in the Indian visa fee from £19 to £30.'

Most operators were now planning to drop several monuments from their future itineraries, he added.

Back at the Taj itself, as sun sets over the Yamuna River, and garlands of marigolds float downstream, the Muslim demonstrators are gradually dispersing. With each passing Friday it seems more likely that they will get their way. They, after all, have votes, unlike foreign backpackers.

Staff at the ASI ticket booth have already put up a homemade cardboard sign which reads: 'Fridays free' - even though they are supposed to charge. The walls outside the ticket grille have been daubed with graffiti, which reads 'Black Day' and - in Hindi - 'ASI thief'. No one wants to be beaten up next to the world's most famous monument to love.

'Muslim people made the Taj. Shah Jahan was a Muslim King,' Mehtab Pappu, 22, from Agra, said. 'All we want is to be allowed to come here and pray.'

What price a wonder of the world?

Other world attractions and what they charge...

The Colosseum in Rome, Italy: £3.15

The Great Wall of China: At the main tourist spot in Badaling admission is £2.05.

The Inca city of Machu Picchu, Peru: £6.80; students £3.40

The Parthenon in Athens: £3.58; students £1.79

Stonehenge in England: £4 for adults, £3 for students.

Walt Disney World, Florida: 1-day pass, adults (age 10 up) £33.09; children, £28.62.

The Millennium Dome, Greenwich, London: Adults £20, children £15.50

webTitle: Sedan highlight a petit problème for French city clubs

fields.headline: Sedan highlight a petit problème for French city clubs
fields.trailText: In le Championat, the Sedan boar is about to roar while bad time's continue for France's giants.
fields.body:
This is a tale of two wild boars. When Sedan won the French Cup finals of 1956 and 1961, they were accompanied by a boar named Dudule. When the club next reached the final, in 1999, Dudule was dead, and the boar who succeeded him could not prevent Sedan losing to Nantes.

Now the new animal is back home just across the border in Belgium, waiting for its day of glory to arrive. That may be about to happen, because Sedan (nicknamed The Boars) stand second in the French league, only a point behind Bordeaux. This is quite extraordinary for a club from a depressed town of 18,000 where little has happened since France lost a battle to Prussia in 1870 and Louis Napoleon surrendered to Bismarck in a peasant's cottage.

The town's football club flowered in the Sixties, thanks to players such as Roger Lemerre, now manager of France, and Zacharie Noah, father of the tennis player Yannick, but later they came close to dropping into the amateur leagues.

This season Sedan are drawing crowds almost the size of the town's population, helped by the 1,500 or so diehards who cross the border each fortnight from Belgium, repairing after the match to the Mickey Bar. They particularly enjoyed seeing the Boars beat Paris Saint Germain 5-1, particularly as most Parisians think Sedan is just the name of a métro station.

This would normally be the prompt for a eulogy to a plucky little town straight out of an Asterix story. The problem is that in France today Sedan are quite typical; banal, even. Various smaller animals are now contesting Europe's most exciting league. In the French phrase, it is the révolte des petits.

Lille, the cold northern town where the cuisine is hearty and Belgian, provides the team in third place, trailing Sedan by a goal difference of one. In eighth place are the Breton village side of Guingamp, one spot above Paris Saint Germain. Also snug in mid-table are Troyes, from the Champagne region, another petit who recently put five goals past the Parisians. And all these heroics, of course, follow last season's run by fourth-division Calais to the Cup final.

This is a bad time for France's giants, who cannot afford to keep the country's best players at home. Paris Saint Germain are ninth, and you have to look even lower to find Monaco and Olympique Marseille.

The revolt of the petits becomes quite astounding when you reflect that France is bigger than England, and that club football is almost as big there as it is here. Crowds have surged since the French won the World Cup: from an average 15,000 at a first division game in 1997-98 to 25,000 so far this year. And the little French clubs are much smaller than the little English ones: Troyes is half as big as Ipswich, Sedan one-seventh the size, while Guingamp barely even makes it on to the map.

The petits have various things in common. All are from the north and east of France, where people have always liked watching football. (Oddly, however, most of the great French players are not. A notable feature of a celebrated television documentary about Les Bleus was the plethora of southern accents.)

Secondly, all the petits won promotion in the last two seasons and subsequently spent almost nothing on players. They compensate by fielding much the same team every week and working hard. Guy Lacombe, Guingamp's manager, attributes his team's success to 'solidarity'; Alex Dupont, at Sedan, cites 'solidarity and humility'; and Lille's director general Pierre Dréossi emphasises 'the notion of solidarity'.

The petits also receive solidarity from their town halls. French mayors are traditionally happy to fund local football clubs. So Guingamp get £3 million from their region and a handy £140,000 from the town, which may have something to do with the fact that Guingamp's mayor, Noel le Graët, used to run the football club and indeed the French league.

The question is how long a French revolution made outside Paris can be allowed to last. The petits are suspicious. 'At half time the Monaco directors drank champagne with the referee!' complained the Guingamp player Hubert Fournier after a recent encounter. In the end, the referees won't be the problem. It will be television money. When Le Graët ran the league, he tried to redistribute the cash to small clubs, and stopped big clubs from going millions into debt to buy players. This summer he was deposed, and the new man, Gérard Bourgoin, is a champion of the rich. Over the next four years clubs will have £800 million of TV money to divide. Little will go to Sedan.

In a year or two, the boar could find itself marinating in a dry red wine, its aspirations crushed.

fields.headline: Stuck on the  Brickadilly line
fields.standfirst: Sheryl Garratt  has some gripes about Legoland,  but is outvoted by the children
fields.trailText: Sheryl Garratt has some gripes about Legoland, but is outvoted by the children.
fields.body:
For younger children and their parents, Legoland at Windsor is a dream of a theme park. Big enough to be exciting, small enough for little legs to walk around, it feels safe, with wide, open paths that allow you to keep an eye on your children when they run ahead and too few white-knuckle rides to attract large groups of teenagers or people without children. There's enough indoor activity to make it bearable in bad weather, and even a few little details and jokes built into the bricks to amuse adults too.

We first took our son when he was two, and he was entranced by the trains moving round the models of European cities and landmarks built out of 28 million bricks in Miniland. We've been back a couple of times a year ever since, and now that he's almost five, he's more interested in the Brickadilly Circus fairground rides or in steering cars and boats around the courses in the Traffic Zone. His friend Alex, visiting for the first time, was amazed by pretty much everything.

Too young for the Dragon roller-coaster he'd seen in the TV ads, Alex rode instead on the Dragon's Apprentice. He was terrified, but afterwards declared it the best bit of the day. After seeing the realistic-looking moving dinosaur models nearby, he sighed that all his wishes except one had come true. Then he closed his eyes and asked, loudly, to find himself in Pokémon land. Sadly, we were unable to deliver that particular dream, but a hot chocolate and a doughnut from a food stall seemed to compensate nicely.

This was the first day of Legoland's Christmas season, and there were carols on the bandstand by the entrance. Lego Christmas trees were dotted throughout the park. The usual train had been decorated with snow and Christmas presents, with Lego models illustrating the 12 days of Christmas around the route. A 25-minute Peter Pan panto offers a welcome respite from the cold, although the people sitting in the middle did get covered in (soap sud) snow at the end.

But when it comes to Christmas, most kids want to see Santa. Last year, Legoland turned the circus tent into a toy factory, with rows of Lego reindeer in their stables and a rather distant Father Christmas appearing occasionally on a high balcony to wave at the children below. This wasn't too popular, so this year a closer encounter costs £2.50 per child extra.

By early afternoon, however, these had sold out, and the booth outside the tent was besieged by pleading parents who had promised their children they'd see Santa. If they'd known what was inside, they perhaps wouldn't have argued so strenuously. A recycled bit of last year's toy factory made the entrance seem exciting, but after that we shuffled slowly into a passage decorated with a few fairylights that was more grotty than grotto. The children were bored, stressed parents were arguing, a baby just up ahead cried interminably with nothing to distract her from her misery.

After waiting more than 45 minutes, the boys were ushered in by a wise-cracking assistant dressed as an elf, and sat awkwardly on stools at Santa's side for a photo (a further £3.99). He asked what they wanted for Christmas without once making eye contact or showing interest in their halting answers. Four-year-olds don't want ironic elves and world-weary Santas: they want to believe in the magic, and they should be indulged. Both of them left with a present of Duplo bricks, the biggest of which had flowers on. Alex said he'd give it to his little sister.

The park was advertised as open until 6pm, but by 4pm nearly all the little food and drink stalls dotted around it had closed. Most of the rides are ill-lit, and nearly all were operating with fewer staff, making the queues as long as they had been earlier. The paths around the park were murky, and a place that had seemed warm and welcoming despite the rain suddenly began to look sinister. Miniland was advertised as illuminated, but the lights turned out to be mostly in the trees. Many of the models were dark, and even when people could make out the shapes, they couldn't read signs explaining what they were. A few well-placed spotlights would have made all the difference.

But these are the carpings of an adult. The real critics should be our two nearly-five-year-olds. As we pulled out of the car park, I asked what they'd liked best. 'Everything!' they both cried. I pressed for details, but there was no reply. They were both fast asleep. And smiling.

Starter kit

Legoland is open 10am-6pm every day except Christmas Day until 7 January.

Tickets cost £18 for adults, £15 for children (aged three-15) and £12 for seniors.

Information/bookings telephone 08705 040404 or visit www.lego.com/legoland/windsor.

webTitle: Graham: Wage structure held me back

fields.headline: Graham: Wage structure held me back
fields.standfirst: Sugar steps down
fields.trailText: George Graham has revealed that the notoriously tight wage structure at Highbury helped limit Arsenal's chances of sustained success when he was manager at the club.
fields.body:
George Graham has revealed that he was opposed to the notoriously tight wage structure at Highbury when he was manager there, but his failure to challenge the board of directors over the issue limited Arsenal's chances of sustained success.

Graham, now manager of arch-rivals Tottenham, could find himself with money to spend at last if Alan Sugar finally does sell his controlling interest - as seems likely after weekend speculation. He goes into tomorrow night's north London derby still aiming to bring Spurs the sort of success he enjoyed down the Seven Sisters Road at Arsenal. He won six major trophies in eight years between 1986 and 1994, making him the most successful manager in Arsenal's history, yet he claims he could not take them on to the level occupied by Manchester United because the board were not prepared to pay the transfer fees or wages demanded by top players.

'My biggest problem was that I was not strong enough to stand up to the board over money, in terms of wages and bringing in top players,' he said. 'Everybody thought it was me who kept the tight wage structure in place, but I just went along with it. It's nonsense to think that a manager can determine the wage structure.'

After Graham left the club following his infamous 'bung' scandal in 1994, Arsenal changed policy to become one of British football's big spenders, signing world-class players such as Dennis Bergkamp, Marc Overmars and Thierry Henry for substantial fees.

Arsène Wenger won the double two seasons ago, but Graham does not believe they can overtake United now. 'Although Arsenal may have been the most famous club in the world back in the Thirties, they were never going to be as big as United.'

His brief at Tottenham, meanwhile, is simply to get the club back to a position alongside Arsenal and the rest of the pack chasing United, and he is confident that youth is the key - at least for the moment. A decade ago he produced an outstanding crop of young Arsenal players including Tony Adams, Paul Merson and David Rocastle and Graham believes teenagers such as Ledley King and Alton Thelwell can help Spurs move back towards the elite. Both have made a big impact since playing in Tottenham's 2-1 win over Liverpool last month.

Graham said: 'It's been great to give them their opportunity - and we've got a lot of other exciting ones for the future coming through. The things that youngsters bring are loyalty and affection for the club, and the fans know that. I'm trying to build for long-term success here, like I did at Arsenal and was doing at Leeds. The youth academy is of paramount importance - what price would you put on the value of those players who have come through at Manchester United, for example?

'These things tend to go in cycles. When I first came to London as a player in the Sixties, West Ham and Chelsea had superb youth set-ups, and now I think it could be turning full-circle for Spurs.'

Darren Anderton returns from suspension for Tottenham, who may have Sergei Rebrov back in attack after two games out with a thigh strain.

fields.headline: Sugar steps down
fields.trailText: Alan Sugar is finally quitting Spurs after nine years in charge of the club. Amid mounting hostility from fans, Sugar will sell up and step down as chairman in the next few weeks.
fields.body:
Alan Sugar is finally quitting Spurs after nine years in charge of the club. Amid mounting hostility from fans, Sugar will sell up and step down as chairman in the next few weeks.

Sugar told Observer Sport last night 'I'm definitely moving out of my position. A decision has been made. We are looking for a good custodian to replace me as [both] chairman and owner. We will be looking for someone else to take my place in the next month.'

Confirmation of Sugar's departure comes 24 hours before his team take on Arsenal at White Hart Lane in the north London derby. Those fans who have used increasingly direct tactics to force Sugar out will celebrate at the game. A sustained protest campaign, including posting Sugar's mobile phone number on the internet, has taken its toll on Sugar and his family.

Although Sugar arrived as something of a saviour in 1991 as part of a consortium whose public face was Terry Venables, he alienated many fans by hiring George Graham and failing to invest heavily in players.

Stelios Haji-Ioannou, founder of the Easyjet cut-price airline, had been identified as the likeliest buyer of Spurs, but last night he said neither he nor his brother, Polys, who has a 6 per cent stake in the club, was interested in buying out Sugar.

A much more likely buyer is ENIC, the international leisure and new media group who already own part of Rangers, Vicenza, Slavia Prague and FC Basel. ENIC sources made clear last night they would definitely like to do a deal - at the right price.

Sugar is thought to want 90p for each of his shares. They are currently priced at 52p and ENIC want to spend no more than 75p-80p. There is speculation that Sugar will now try to convince Barry Hearn to sell him Leyton Orient, where he would install his son Daniel as boss.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: So, you want to be like Wills
fields.standfirst: Generations of students have seen it as a rite of passage. So how do you plan your year out?  Joanne O'Connor  offers some advice
fields.trailText: Generations of students have seen it as a rite of passage. So how do you plan your year out? Joanne O'Connor offers some advice.
fields.body:
If you didn't know better you might think Prince William's recent stint cleaning toilets and staggering under the weight of huge logs in a cold, damp corner of deepest Patagonia was some kind of terrible punishment. But no, like thousands of young students before him, the future King of England is simply enjoying that modern rite of passage - the Gap Year.

It is not a new phenomenon. Young, wealthy Victorians would have embarked on a grand tour of Europe's capitals before taking up their chosen profession. Today's 'gappers' can be found working behind a bar in Sydney, soaking up the rays on a beach in Koh Samui or, like Prince William, doing something worthy in a distant outpost.

A survey of 3,000 university applicants by student and youth travel specialist STA Travel showed that 83 per cent intend to take a gap year to travel and work abroad. Predictably, Australia is still the favourite destination, but student travel agency usit Campus says current hotspots also include New York, New Zealand, Thailand, South Africa and Latin America (compared with the Greek Islands, Amsterdam, Paris, Afghanistan, Kathmandu and Morocco in 1967, when Prince Charles was a student).

But rather than collecting friendship bracelets and growing dreadlocks, some 56 per cent of those who called usit's Gap Year hotline this summer said they wanted to work abroad, the most popular choice being teaching English in South America.

The good news for those of us who missed the boat the first time around is that (theoret ically at least) it's never too late to take a year out. Though some schemes do have an age limit, organisations such as VSO and Raleigh International value the skills and experience the more 'mature' person can offer.

Choosing what to do

Can you see yourself diving to map out coral reefs in Puerto Rico, teaching English in a Japanese classroom, helping to build a health clinic in Africa or tracking wolves in India? The choice can be daunting but the amount of time and money you have at your disposable will no doubt narrow the options.

Other factors such as whether you wish to learn a language or gain work experience also come into the decision-making process.

Organisations such as Gap Challenge, GAP Activity Projects, Raleigh International and VSO specialise in placing students with overseas projects: participants can expect to be working as part of a team on an environmental, conservation, care work or community-based project, usually in a developing country. Most of these organisations require a commitment of between three and six months, though Earthwatch offers shorter two-week placements and Project Trust requires a minimum of one year.

Teaching English is the most popular occupation and there are a number of organisations, such as the JET Programme (020 7478 2010) and Caledonia Languages Abroad (0131 621 7721), that specialise in placements with overseas schools and colleges. They can also arrange accommodation with local families and tuition in the local language.

Other sources are charities and religious organisations linked with specific projects. For example, the South America Mission Society (020 8502 3502) offers work with Gypsy communities in Andalucia, while Sports Coaches Outreach (0212 689 7395. email score@iafrica.com) is a South African organisation that uses volunteers on six-month placements to teach sport to children and adults in poor communities.

You may also want to look closer to home. The British Trust for Conservation Volunteers (01491 839766) has placements from one day to six months on UK projects where you can try your hand at tree planting and repairing dry stone walls.

What does it cost?

William's Chilean project was organised by Raleigh International. The minimum fundraising target to participate in the 10-week expedition is £3,200 but all flights, accommodation, food, insurance and visas are covered by Raleigh.

Specialist gap year agencies charge a placement fee - this could be anything from £500 to £2,000, depending on what's included. GAP Activity Project's fee of £490 does not include airfares, insurance or medical costs, although accommodation and food in the host country are usually free and pocket money is paid in most cases.

Language teaching specialist i-to-i charges a fee of £1,295 for a three-month placement teaching English in India. This includes food and accommodation, 40 hours' TEFL training and support from a co-ordinator in the destination. It does not include flights, or travel insurance.

It can work out more expensive to go through a specialist agency but there are advantages - most will offer pre-departure orientation and training, and emergency support and back-up in the destination.

Contact STA Travel or usit Campus for discounted airfares and round the world tickets. Boots' Gap Year insurance policy costs £365 for one year's cover.

Planning your trip

The key to a successful gap year is planning ahead. If you are taking a year out between A-levels and university it is recommended that you apply while at school for deferred entry. You will also find that places on expeditions or voluntary projects fill up months in advance and you will need to allow plenty of time to raise funds for the trip.

An excellent starting point is to check out the gapyear website which has useful tips on everything from health and visas to fundraising.

Taking a Gap Year by Susan Griffith, published by Vacation Work includes a directory of charities, organisations, religious groups and language schools offering placements, work experience (paid and unpaid) and overseas study.

STA Travel has produced a Year Out booklet (020 7361 6166) and its website (www.statravel.co.uk) has a special year out section. For specific inquiries you can telephone the Year Out Hotline (0161 830 4715).

usit Campus produces a Gap Year Guide (0870 240 1010) and from 20 January will post up to date gap year information on its website (www.usitcampus.co.uk).

Key organisations

BUNAC: Help out at an American summer camp or spend a year on a work experience placement in Canada, New Zealand or Australia. (020 7251 3472)

fields.bodyText: If you didn't know better you might think Prince William's recent stint cleaning toilets and staggering under the weight of huge logs in a cold, damp corner of deepest Patagonia was some kind of terrible punishment. But no, like thousands of young students before him, the future King of England is simply enjoying that modern rite of passage - the Gap Year. It is not a new phenomenon. Young, wealthy Victorians would have embarked on a grand tour of Europe's capitals before taking up their chosen profession. Today's 'gappers' can be found working behind a bar in Sydney, soaking up the rays on a beach in Koh Samui or, like Prince William, doing something worthy in a distant outpost. A survey of 3,000 university applicants by student and youth travel specialist STA Travel showed that 83 per cent intend to take a gap year to travel and work abroad. Predictably, Australia is still the favourite destination, but student travel agency usit Campus says current hotspots also include New York, New Zealand, Thailand, South Africa and Latin America (compared with the Greek Islands, Amsterdam, Paris, Afghanistan, Kathmandu and Morocco in 1967, when Prince Charles was a student). But rather than collecting friendship bracelets and growing dreadlocks, some 56 per cent of those who called usit's Gap Year hotline this summer said they wanted to work abroad, the most popular choice being teaching English in South America. The good news for those of us who missed the boat the first time around is that (theoret ically at least) it's never too late to take a year out. Though some schemes do have an age limit, organisations such as VSO and Raleigh International value the skills and experience the more 'mature' person can offer. Choosing what to do Can you see yourself diving to map out coral reefs in Puerto Rico, teaching English in a Japanese classroom, helping to build a health clinic in Africa or tracking wolves in India? The choice can be daunting but the amount of time and money you have at your disposable will no doubt narrow the options. Other factors such as whether you wish to learn a language or gain work experience also come into the decision-making process. Organisations such as Gap Challenge, GAP Activity Projects, Raleigh International and VSO specialise in placing students with overseas projects: participants can expect to be working as part of a team on an environmental, conservation, care work or community-based project, usually in a developing country. Most of these organisations require a commitment of between three and six months, though Earthwatch offers shorter two-week placements and Project Trust requires a minimum of one year. Teaching English is the most popular occupation and there are a number of organisations, such as the JET Programme (020 7478 2010) and Caledonia Languages Abroad (0131 621 7721), that specialise in placements with overseas schools and colleges. They can also arrange accommodation with local families and tuition in the local language. Other sources are charities and religious organisations linked with specific projects. For example, the South America Mission Society (020 8502 3502) offers work with Gypsy communities in Andalucia, while Sports Coaches Outreach (0212 689 7395. email score@iafrica.com) is a South African organisation that uses volunteers on six-month placements to teach sport to children and adults in poor communities. You may also want to look closer to home. The British Trust for Conservation Volunteers (01491 839766) has placements from one day to six months on UK projects where you can try your hand at tree planting and repairing dry stone walls. What does it cost? William's Chilean project was organised by Raleigh International. The minimum fundraising target to participate in the 10-week expedition is £3,200 but all flights, accommodation, food, insurance and visas are covered by Raleigh. Specialist gap year agencies charge a placement fee - this could be anything from £500 to £2,000, depending on what's included. GAP Activity Project's fee of £490 does not include airfares, insurance or medical costs, although accommodation and food in the host country are usually free and pocket money is paid in most cases. Language teaching specialist i-to-i charges a fee of £1,295 for a three-month placement teaching English in India. This includes food and accommodation, 40 hours' TEFL training and support from a co-ordinator in the destination. It does not include flights, or travel insurance. It can work out more expensive to go through a specialist agency but there are advantages - most will offer pre-departure orientation and training, and emergency support and back-up in the destination. Contact STA Travel or usit Campus for discounted airfares and round the world tickets. Boots' Gap Year insurance policy costs £365 for one year's cover. If you are taking a year out between A-levels and university it is recommended that you apply while at school for deferred entry. You will also find that places on expeditions or voluntary projects fill up months in advance and you will need to allow plenty of time to raise funds for the trip. An excellent starting point is to check out the gapyear website which has useful tips on everything from health and visas to fundraising. Taking a Gap Year by Susan Griffith, published by Vacation Work includes a directory of charities, organisations, religious groups and language schools offering placements, work experience (paid and unpaid) and overseas study. fields.headline: Mummy, I've never seen snow
fields.standfirst: Kit Spring found a way to grant her daughter's wish by visiting Lapland, where there's no shortage of the white stuff. (She hadn't counted on being forced to drive a team of huskies, though)
fields.trailText: Kit Spring found a way to grant her daughter's wish by visiting Lapland, where there's no shortage of the white stuff. (She hadn't counted on being forced to drive a team of huskies, though).
fields.body:
For four winters now, a little face has been pressed against our sitting-room window, anxiously scanning the sky and willing white flakes to fall. My daughter Abigail is eight, and until last week, because of the recent mild winters in southern England, she had no memory of ever having seen snow. It was her dearest wish to see it, play in it and do all those things that children do in picture books.

As the snow was obviously not going to come to us, there was only one thing for it, so we packed our bags and headed for Lapland. We flew to the tiny airport of Kittilä, in northern Finland, which must be unique in having a real live reindeer waiting to greet visitors as they come down the plane steps.

And there was snow! Lots of snow. Never mind that the Finns are bemoaning their mildest winter for 40 years, there was enough of the white stuff to enchant Abigail, who sat and gazed in awed silence as we drove for an hour through twilit pine forests to our hotel in the isolated village of Yllas and the snow sparkled and shimmered in the moonlight.

The plane had been delayed, so there was nothing for it but to fall into bed. Next morning, however, we were up and out in the snowy landscape. Abigail, absorbed, gathered the snow up, kicked through it, made footprints in it. With the pine forests all around and the wooden houses, it felt like being in the middle of a children's folk tale.

Our first adventure was to be transported, snugly wrapped round with reindeer skins, across a frozen lake in a sleigh pulled by huskies. In the afternoon, we got into even closer contact with the snow when we took the ski bus up the fell that towers over the village. There, we discovered the sheer exhilarating joy of tobogganing. We were soon zooming down the slope by a full moon, even though it was only three o'clock in the afternoon, because there are only about four hours of daylight in Finland at this time of the year.

Afterwards we sat with hot drinks in front of a blazing fire in a fairy-lit restaurant. Finland is so crisp and cold on the outside and so toasty and cosy on the inside - it's bliss to go from one to the other.

The package tour that we were on includes activities such as toy-making and cookie-baking, reindeer sleigh rides, and the chance to try kick-sleds, which are like walking frames on skis. There are organised games for the children before dinner, but there is plenty of free time for other excursions.

We decided to go on a husky safari. We were taken to a husky farm deep in the forest. It was snowing and the dogs were baying. They are beautiful creatures: small, affectionate and incredibly intelligent.

I was slightly taken aback when I realised that I was going to have to drive my own team. I was taken off to meet my dogs, and then shown how to put a harness on and how to attach my dogs to the lines. I fumbled with frozen fingers. Abigail, looking like a little Michelin woman in her thermals, was bundled into the leading sleigh.

We stood on the runners behind our sleds waiting for the signal. The dogs' excited howling was so loud that it was impossible to hear anything else. When we took off, it was at such a rate, I was convinced I'd be thrown off, but I stayed on.

The next hour was magical as we drove 10 miles through the deepest forest, with the only sound the metallic clanking of the sleighs. How an experience can be both exciting and peaceful, I couldn't have told you until that day.

The next day we attended a Lappish good luck ceremony. An old lady in colourful costume blessed us with cold water and a swig of reindeer milk (which tastes exactly like Bailey's) and smeared our faces with charcoal from the fire in the hut where we were gathered.

But what about Father Christmas? He turned up on the last night after a gala dinner. The children watched excitedly from the window as he drew up outside the hotel in his sleigh, magnificently authentic in his reindeer-skin boots. I ignored Abigail when she pointed out that he had originally 'got out of a van'. I wasn't going to have my illusions shattered.

On our last morning we went out for a final walk in the forest. Abigail lay down and made angel wings in the snow. Large flakes were falling. It was completely peaceful. 'Listen,' I said. 'What can you hear?' 'Nothing.' 'And what's the best thing about this holiday?' 'The snow... And breakfast.'

 Kit Spring flew to Lapland with First Choice (0870 750 0001) and stayed at the Hotel Yllaskaltio. Four nights full board (with day three at half board) cost £719 per adult, and £585 per child for a twin-bedded room.
