fields.headline: Poetry in locomotion
fields.standfirst: Alan Road  discovers what moved Edward Thomas to capture the charms of a Cotswold village
fields.trailText: Alan Road discovers what moved Edward Thomas to capture the charms of a Cotswold village.
fields.body:
Yes, I remember Adlestrop -
The name, because one afternoon
Of heat the express train drew up there
Unwontedly. It was late June.
The steam hissed. Someone cleared his throat.
No one left and no one came
On the bare platform. What I saw
Was Adlestrop - only the name
And meadowsweet, and haycocks dry,
No whit less still and lonely fair
Than the high cloudlets in the sky.
And for that minute a blackbird sang
Close by, and round him, mistier,
Farther and farther, all the birds
Of Oxfordshire and Gloucestershire.
Adlestrop, by Edward Thomas (1878-1917)

Remember Adlestrop? I've been there. Which is more than Edward Thomas could say. As far as we know, the poet whose 16-line gem immortalised the name of a tiny Cotswold hamlet never alighted at its station where his train had stopped, 'unwontedly', as he so memorably recalled.

Because of, or maybe despite, the efforts of generations of schoolteachers, the poem remains a firm favourite, appearing in countless anthologies. When BBC TV canvassed viewers for the Nation's Favourite Poems, Adlestrop steamed in at No 20, which may explain why a signpost on the A436 near Stow-on-the-Wold announcing 'Adlestrop 1' proved impossible to ignore.

Thomas's lines encapsulate that moment known to every railway passenger from the days of steam: the sudden silence that descended when a train made an unscheduled stop and the countryside that had hitherto been no more than a passing kaleidoscope was revealed in all its beauty.

For succeeding generations, the poignancy of the poem was increased by the knowledge that so soon after that magical June day in 1914 the lights would be going out all over Europe and much of the England that the Thomas poem celebrated was about to disappear forever. Thomas himself was killed three years later at the battle of Arras.

The poet captured a moment that this new century cannot reproduce, but not just because of the passing of the age of steam. Today the silence would be broken by a shrill chorus of mobile phones. No one would hear the poet's blackbird for the chatter of inane young men and women in smart suits telling indifferent PAs and passengers at large: 'I'm on the train... We've been delayed at somewhere called Adlestrop...

Adlestrop is at the heart of the Cotswolds, that golden triangle of countryside enclosed by the M4, M5 and M40. Britain's largest Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty is a patchwork of rolling fields spread over modest hills and divided by meticulous dry stone walls and teeming hedgerows.

In late August the distant stubble fields were stained with poppies, but the hedgerow willow-herb and meadowsweet that Thomas admired had wilted and all the haycocks had long since been replaced by giant yellow 'toilet rolls', produced by today's technology and left in the fields.

The area owes much of its popularity among fugitives from the breezeblock belt to the beauty of its local stone. This honey-coloured limestone, which mellows with age, appears to have absorbed millennia of warm sunshine. Buildings seem to grow out of the bedrock beneath the red earth.

Cotswold stone imposes a certain egalitarianism on the region. It may be found in majestic medieval churches, manor houses and humble cottages alike. In Stow it even lends dignity to a public convenience.

Adlestrop,with its population of fewer than 100, is little more than a triangle of absurdly picturesque houses. Front doors are framed by hollyhocks and thatch roofs are contained in nets. At the top of the village a sign 'To our church' betrays a certain pride.

Martin Edwards is chairman of the parish meeting (Adlestrop is too small to rate a council) and is on the rota for mowing the churchyard grass. In June St Mary Magdalene was packed for an Edward Thomas reading and music recital, he recalled. The computer consultant and his wife Julia escaped here from a one-bedroomed flat in Islington.

The village is proud of its literary link and happy to welcome the odd literary pilgrim, but would not want an Edward Thomas burger bar. 'We've got a church, a post office and a village hall, and that's enough,' Julia murmured. One resident did offer B&B, but he moved away and there is now no visitor accommodation available.

Though quaint, Adlestrop is just one of many charmingly eccentric names to be found hereabouts. Great Rollright, Little Rissington, Evenlode, Temple Guiting, the Swells and the Slaughters - Upper and Lower - are all in a 10-mile radius. According to Anne Harvey's excellent anthology, Adlestrop Revisited (Sutton Publishing, £12.99), the name dates from Saxon times and could mean the Village of someone called Tatel.

Long before he retired to live in Lobs Cottage, schoolteacher John Gillett was extolling the merits of the poem during an English lesson at his boarding school. 'Adlestrop. What a lovely, sleepy name,' he enthused. 'I don't know whether the place exists or not.' Whereupon Diana Jones leapt up and said: 'Of course it does. We pass it every time we go on holiday.'

He could not know that one day he would buy a couple of cottages here, vacated by redundant estate workers, converting them into an idyllic retreat for his retirement.

Dorothy Price is sole survivor of the original residents. Until 1998 this frail septuagenarian ran the village post office. Literary pilgrims and railway buffs still consult her, as her grandfather, father and husband were all employed at Adlestrop Station. She is still in touch with Myfanwy, the poet's 90-year-old daughter.

Most frequent inquiry posed by visitors is, 'Where is the station?' The answer is, it isn't. In 1966 the station was axed by Lord Beeching, the Doctor Death of rail surgery. It was almost a mile outside the village, between Railway Cottage, a seventeenth-century residence with mullioned windows, and Railway House, once the stationmaster's home.

All that remains is the Adlestrop platform nameboard that might be the one the poet saw from his compartment window. It is preserved on the edge of the village in a bus shelter that somehow creates the ambience of a shrine. Beneath the nameboard is a genuine platform seat decked out in the GWR's chocolate-and-cream livery. The poem is reproduced on a neat brass plate.

As I stood reverently before it, as thousands of the poet's admirers must have done before me, a blackbird - maybe a descendant of the one that sang in 1914 - dumped accurately and prolifically on me from its perch in the venerable oak tree above. Even Thomas, by all accounts a chronic depressive, would have had to smile.

A framed version of his poem also hangs on a wall of the church at the top of the village. In the visitors' book across the nave, entry after entry in differing hands say simply, 'Yes. I remember Adlestrop'.

Where to stay

Stow Lodge Hotel, The Square, Stow-on-the-Wold, Gloucester GL54 1AB Tel 01451 830485 B&B single from £62. Bould Farm, Bould, nr Ledbury, Chipping Norton OX7 6RT Tel 01608 658850 B&B single £30.

Where to eat

The Fox Inn, Lower Oddington, nr Stow-on-the-Wold GL56 0UR Tel 01451 870555.

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst: Freddie Teo, concierge at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel, Kuala Lumpur
fields.trailText: Freddie Teo, concierge at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel, Kuala Lumpur
fields.body:
Any famous guests?
Some of the famous people who have stayed here include Shirley Bassey, Jackie Chan, Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins, Gong Li, the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia and the Crown Prince of Cambodia.

Any unusual requests?
There was one request from a group of British journalists who were visiting for a golf trip. At one o'clock in the morning, when I was off-duty, the group called to ask for some bananas, so I headed off to Chinatown to get some.

What shouldn't business travellers miss?
A short city tour is imperative and will include the Kuala Lumpur Tower, the fourth tallest telecoms tower in the world, which houses a revolving restaurant and an observation platform, and the Petronas Twin Towers, the pride of Malaysia and the world's tallest buildings. The sky bridge connecting the 41st floors is open to the public daily. But there are many other sights too: the Batu Caves, a Hindu temple complex consisting of three grand caves. Or Istana Negara, the King's official residence, where visitors can see the changing of the guard daily. The colonial Merdeka Square marks the spot where the Malayan flag was hoisted up for the first time, while the 18-pointed star shape of the National Mosque's main dome represents the 13 states of Malaysia unified by the five pillars of Islam.

What about shopaholics?
Suria KLCC, the city's largest shopping centre, is located adjacent to the hotel. The Central Market is a good spot for local handicrafts, while excellent bargains can be found at Downtown Chinatown nearby. It's a sidewalk market that opens in the early evening. Kuala Lumpur's night markets are popular - they are great places to absorb local culture and enjoy spicy foods.

What do you suggest for a night out?
Many of the hottest entertainment spots are within walking distance of the hotel. Our own Pacifica Grill and Bar, with its open kitchen and garden views, is one of the most popular restaurants in Kuala Lumpur. Bintang Walk has a stretch of stylish, alfresco restaurants and pubs. If you are willing to take a 15-minute taxi ride there are two rows of chic restaurants in the Bangsar suburb which are popular with expatriates and young people.

webTitle: Taylor's men show that spirit is worth more than class

fields.headline: Taylor's men show that spirit is worth more than class
fields.trailText:
Leicester 3 - 1 Charlton
Spirit wins over class for Taylor's men.
fields.body:
Leicester are the sort of club who seemed destined to be written off by reporters and opposition alike. Yet while Peter Taylor's team may frequently lack elegance or class, they more than make up for those deficits with an abundance of spirit and enterprise.

Against a composed Charlton the home side were frequently out-played for large amounts of the game, yet they kept their nerve, and more importantly their shape, to first equalise through Ade Akinbiyi and then overwhelm their opposi tion thanks to late goals from Matt Elliott and Arnar Gunnlaugsson .

In truth, the end result flattered Taylor's side and was slightly unfair to Charlton, who played the more attractive football but crucially paid the price for missed first-half opportunities.

Goalkeeper Tim Flowers returned between the posts for Leicester and conceded a goal within six minutes as Charlton dominated the early exchanges. Flowers had been called into action after only two minutes when he was handily placed to save comfortably from Jonatan Johansson after Claus Jensen played the ball in. Within four minutes the Finnish striker had given Charlton the lead after receiving Graham Stuart's pass and firing low past Flowers.

At this stage Leicester seemed strangely subdued with Matthew Jones, their new £3million signing from Leeds, little more than a spectator in the opening 20 minutes. However just as it seemed as though Peter Taylor's side had lost the fight, which has stood them in such good stead this season, Ade Akinbiyi dragged them back into the game with a 34th minute equaliser.

Leicester manager Peter Taylor decided to shake things up for the second half, bringing on Trevor Benjamin up front for the ineffective Steve Guppy. But Charlton remained the stronger side and almost regained their lead in the 68th minute when Mark Kinsella sent a 20-yard shot narrowly wide after a corner from Jensen had only been partially cleared.

That all changed after Callum Davidson was replaced by Stefan Oakes, who revitalised the flagging home side. Oakes floated in a corner from the left in the 79th minute and Elliott nodded the ball home at the near post. Leicester then sealed victory on the stroke of full-time when Gunnlaugsson chipped the ball over Dean Kiely.

fields.headline: Ginola salvages Doug's day
fields.trailText:
Aston Villa 2 - 2 Man City
Ginola salvages Doug's day.
fields.body:
To have one international in Gareth Southgate asking for a transfer might be considered unfortunate - that his England team-mate David James has followed suit does not suggest so much as carelessness on Aston Villa's part but a minor crisis.

Not even a mesmeric second-half performance by David Ginola which earned Villa an unlikely point after Lee Hendrie had been sent off is likely to encourage their disquieted supporters.

Two League Cup victories are all Villa have to show for 18 years of Ellis rule - the natives are extremely restless. On Friday a Birmingham city-centre billboard was hijacked by dissidents and adorned with the words 'spend or go Doug'. Suitably warned, Ellis banned banners from Villa Park yesterday. Inevitably, though, some slipped through.'You are without doubt the weakest link Ellis, goodbye!' proclaimed one.

Freedom of speech, however proved difficult to inhibit. And with City's fluorescent lime-green socks the only articles to shine in a largely torpid first half, there were plenty of opportunities for the Villa malcontent to voice their feelings.

With just 10 seconds gone the Villa faithful almost had something to get really agitated about on the pitch. Shaun Wright-Phillips broke through and took James and the Villa defence by surprise with a snapshot that was just wide of the goalkeeper's right hand post.

It didn't help the home side that Paul Merson was mishitting passes and looking as though he was tired of always being the recipient of Man of the Match awards.

But when the former Arsenal fielder suddenly burst into life in the 20th minute Villa came within inches of going in front. Collecting the ball on halfway, Merson drifted past one visiting midfielder before, spotting Nicky Weaver off his line, he delivered a deft chip that bounced to safety off the City goalkeeper's right-hand post.

Villa showed some long overdue urgency after the break with David Ginola at the heart of the revival. Accused by manager John Gregory of carrying a spare tyre, perhaps due to putting the Michelin Guide to too much good use, the French winger set up three moments of menace within 10 minutes of the restart.

One telling cross was intercepted by Weaver, another headed over the bar by Dion Dublin before Lee Hendrie volleyed a third wide. With Ginola in match-winning mood Gregory switched his formation to 4-4-2 with the Frenchman operating as a conventional winger.

But within four minutes of the switch Villa's new-look rearguard was unhinged when Paulo Wanchope set up Haaland to put City in front. Inevitably it was Ginola who played a major part in bringing Villa level when, in the 70th minute, he delivered the cross for Dublin to head home.

Parity lasted just three minutes until City substitute Mark Kennedy's left-wing cross-shot was fumbled by James and Wanchope tapped home the loose ball.

Villa's hopes of quietening their increasingly disgruntled supporters looked dashed when Hendrie was sent off for the second time this season following an exchange of words with referee Andy D'Urso. But Ginola was not finished, volleying home a half-clearance two minutes from time to have his name on the Villa supporters' lips rather than that of their beleaguered chairman.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Bates out in FA rethink
fields.trailText: Ken Bates will be ousted as chairman of troubled Wembley National Stadium Limited this week and be replaced by a 'troubleshooter' appointed by the FA and WNSL.
fields.body:
Ken Bates will be ousted as chairman of troubled Wembley this week. He will be replaced as boss of Wembley National Stadium Limited by a 'troubleshooter' appointed by the Football Association and WNSL.

Sir Roland Smith, chairman of Manchester United plc, is among the frontrunners to succeed Bates. An announcement is expected this week, possibly after the FA's board meeting on Thursday. The FA may also indicate that they are in theory happy to accommodate athletics at a rebuilt Wembley, provided an array of practical problems can be solved.

The official line is likely to be that Bates, who has been widely blamed for Wembley's failure to raise the £410m needed to rebuild Wembley, has 'stood down' as chairman. But insiders say the Chelsea chairman is going before he is pushed. He will probably remain as a member of the 12-strong WNSL board.

Bates has attracted huge criticism for his stewardship of the ill-fated project, largely over the perceived problems of trying to turn Wembley into 'Chelsea Village Mark II' complete with hotel, offices and restaurants. Banks in the City refused to believe that these costly extra facilities -- which had pushed the price up to £660m - would prove viable and refused to lend any money until the project had been scaled down. It was the banks' stance, coupled with fears that the Wembley as envisaged by Bates could prove to be football's equivalent of the Millennium Dome, that forced the FA on 8 December to take control of Wembley and 'de-Village it'.

Bates's robust personal style had apparently alienated potential backers of the project and contributed to the departure of a series of key Wembley personnel. He lost the confidence of both the FA and his fellow directors of WNSL, who complained about 'obsessive secrecy' practised by Bates and Bob Stubbs, Wembley's managing director.

The shortlist of potential candidates to replace Bates includes two existing WNSL directors, Clive Sherling, chairman of the Football Licensing Authority, and Sir Rodney Walker, chairman of UK Sport. Discussions continue today to identify other contenders.

In a further move to tighten their grip on Wembley, the FA will put several heavyweight figures from within football on the Wembley board. Sir Roland will join the board even if he does not come on as chairman. FA insiders say his business background, and independence from the conflicting vested interests involved in the Wembley fiasco, make him an ideal candidate. It is not yet clear if he wants to be chairman.

Once the new leadership is finalised, the FA will decide whether to change plans and build a stadium capable of hosting the 2005 World Athletics Championships and a future Olympic Games, or stick to building a revamped football arena. Influential voices, including Sports Minister Kate Hoey and the British Olympic Association, are keen to model the new Wembley on the Stade de France, complete with a permanent running track and some form of moveable seating.

FA sources say that both chief executive Adam Crozier and Premier League chairman Dave Richards are 'genuinely open-minded' about the possibility of athletics returning to Wembley. It was removed from Wembley's calculations a year ago after a bitter row between WNSL and Chris Smith, the Culture, Media and Sport Secretary.

If Wembley were to be remodelled to incorporate athletics, it would mean ripping up the plan to build a new athletics-only stadium at Picketts Lock, north London. Given the delays so far, however, an athletics-friendly Wembley might not be open in time to host 2005.

The FA's attitude will be influenced by whether the Government and Sport England agree to make available a further £40 million of Lottery money earmarked for Picketts Lock.

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: Milton Keynes Snozone | Kentwell Hall | British Library
fields.body:
Join comedy writer Alan Gilbey and actor Steve Wells for a 'festive, funny and informative' saunter through the side streets of Spitalfields, London. Meet at the Bishopsgate entrance of Liverpool Street station at 6.30pm. Cost £5 (020 7375 0441).

Perfect your parallel turns at the Milton Keynes Snozone, Europe's largest indoor real snow slope. Ring ahead to book a slot. £20 an hour for adults, £14 children (01908 230 260).

Buy fresh local produce and handmade gifts at a Christmas Craft and Farmers Market in the grounds of sixteenth-century Tudor manor house Kentwell Hall, Long Melford, Suffolk (01787 310207). Open 9.30am-3pm.

Trace the life and works of Oscar Wilde through personal letters, photographs, manuscripts and sound recordings at the British Library, Euston Road, London (020 7412 7000). Open 11am-5pm. Admission £4.50, free to under-18s.

Join Lady Suffolk as she prepares for a Georgian Christmas at Marble Hill House in Twickenham (020 8892 5115). Activities from noon-4pm. Adults £4, children £2.

Who are the trendsetters in contemporary art? Find out at The Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery's British Art Show (0121 303 2834). Open 12.30pm-5pm. Free.

Take a torchlit walk through historic Lancaster with a costumed Georgian guide to celebrate St Nicholas Day. Meet at the John O'Gaunt Gateway of Lancaster Castle at 7pm. Adults £3, children £1.

Visit Viva Leeds! a temporary exhibition of satirical and political postcards from the Eighties and Nineties on show at Leeds City Art Gallery (0113 247 8248). Open 1pm-5pm. Free

See the lighting of the tree and Blessing of the Crib at Liverpool Anglican Cathedral's Christmas service, St James Road (0151 709 6271). 3pm. Free.

Hear tales of Christmas past at Pendennis Castle (01326 316594), near Falmouth, Cornwall. Celtic legends, Arthurian tales and fairy stories will be recounted between noon and 4pm. Adults £3.80, children £1.90.

fields.headline: Gordon's goal tonic
fields.trailText:
Middesbrough 1 - 0 Chelsea
Gordon's goal tonic provides home comfort.
fields.byline: Paul Wilson at The Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
Graham Taylor once remarked that his successor as England manager needed to be lucky, and though Terry Venables has had a few ups and downs since then, he has clearly not lost the magic touch.

His Middlesbrough side were no more than workmanlike here, but work they did, and a goal from a second-half substitute Venables had only just thrown into the fray brought up an improbable first home win, which lifts them off the bottom of the Premiership.

Well, not that improbable. Chelsea have still not won away all season, but created enough chances to win here, only to be let down by indecisive finishing.

Something Venables admits he failed to appreciate until he arrived on Teesside was the extent of the club's injury list. He probably didn't appreciate Boro's ability to compound that problem with red cards either. It is one thing to lose eight players through injury, though when you have half that number also missing through suspension - including Ugo Ehiogu, who has only been at the club five minutes, and Hamilton Ricard, who was dismissed in a reserve match - it begins to look like carelessness.

Chelsea, in fairness, have Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink suspended at the moment, but when they bring in reserves of the quality of Eidur Godjohnsen it is easy not to notice.

For some bizarre reason, both these sides seemed to want to catch the other on the break. One could understand Chelsea's reasoning, being not only the away team but actually possessing a front three quick and clever enough to strike effectively, but it was more difficult to work out why Boro kept defending too deep and leaving Brian Deane alone up front.

Chelsea's own defence was as unconvincing as one would expect on a December day with the wind whipping in from the North Sea. Franck Leboeuf was left out and Marcel Desailly initially looked as if he wished he had been, but Boro lacked the men in advanced positions to take advantage of a couple of early misunderstandings.

The visitors also struggled to handle the runs of Keith O'Neill, who took up some great positions but - even in the current crisis - is not the best finisher on Teesside. O'Neill ran clear to pick up a wonderful long ball from Steve Vickers as early as the 12th minute but could not keep his shot on target, then managed to fall over in the penalty area when trying to reach a tempting Deane cross from the right. The defender's best chance of all came in the 37th minute, when he looked certain to open the scoring after a weak punch from Ed de Goey fell at his feet, but though he appeared to have the goal at his mercy Gus Poyet arrived at the last second to make a vital block.

Who says Chelsea don't put themselves about away from home? Poyet's real job was at the other end, operating with Gianfranco Zola just behind Gudjohnsen, a position from where he nearly scored on the half hour. Mark Schwarzer got across well to the Uruguayan's long shot, but was lucky to concede only a corner and not an own goal when the ball rebounded off the post and his back.

It was also Poyet who put Gudjohnsen away two minutes later for what amounted to Chelsea's best chance of the first half, and it was hardly his fault if the striker wasted a good position by shooting tamely at Schwarzer.

Chelsea brought on Leboeuf at half time and switched Desailly to left back in a back four, which had the effect of opening up the game. And the Boro defence. Zola, found superbly by Leboeuf, was unlucky to see no takers for a cross pulled back across goal from the right byline.

fields.headline: Armstrong provides answer
fields.trailText:
Ipswich 3 - 1 Southampton
Armstrong helps close the gap.
fields.body:
Alun Armstrong always looked a sharp striker at Stockport County, and with Middlesbrough in the First Division. Injury then intervened and, it seems, Bryan Robson did not deem him a Premiership player. Two goals on his home debut for Ipswich yesterday, though, suggested that he might have helped Boro out of the hole that Robson instead needs Terry Venables to fill.

Southampton had controlled the first half and led through James Beattie's eighth goal in seven games, but their defensive organisation was disturbed by the arrival of Armstrong, a bargain £800,000 signing from Boro, as a second-half substitute. Goals by James Scowcroft and Armstrong within five minutes changed the picture; Armstrong provided the signature brush stroke to cement third place.

Ipswich's pre-eminence has been unexpectedly earned, in more ways than one. A fortnight ago they lost 1-0 at home to the then bottom club Derby County, only to go to Anfield last Sunday and inflict on Liverpool a first home defeat of the season. Yesterday's challenge was more of the Derby variety, though from the outset Southampton looked more competent opponents still, buoyed, too, by a home win over Leeds last weekend.

They were cutely organised by Glenn Hoddle into a 4-3-3 formation, with the wide attacking players Kevin Davies and Marian Pahars dropping deeper to form a midfield five when Ipswich were in possession. Barely had that become evident, though, when Saints stunned home team and fans with a goal.

There seemed little danger when Wayne Bridge played the ball wide to Pahars but in a flash the Latvian dashed inside Gary Croft and went round Tony McGreal before standing up a cross. In came Beattie ahead of Hermann Hreidarsson at the far post to loop a header past Richard Wright. Beattie might even have had a hat-trick within the first 10 minutes, almost turning home Jo Tessem's low cross but allowing Croft to deflect the ball by finishing too casually, and diving to head Bridge's low cross just wide.

Ipswich sought to channel everything through Jim Magilton and gradually his composure on the ball in midfield brought them back into the game. The decisive moment coming as their manager George Burley threw on Armstrong for the second half with Scowcroft now pushed wide as a third forward.

The move paid immediate, remarkable dividends. First, after Jason Dodd had fouled Jamie Clapham, Magilton curled in a low free kick from the left and Scowcroft was on hand to touch home from close range. Then, with Southampton still adjusting to new marking require ments, Armstrong met Magilton's corner with a downward header that a flailing Paul Jones could only help into the net.

Hoddle countered by introducing Hassan Kachloul, dropped to the bench after his red card against Leeds, and Uwe Rosler and the pair almost combined for a late equaliser, Wright kicking away the German's downward header from the Moroccan's cross. The tide, and the tables, had turned, however, and the game was safe for Ipswich when Armstrong turned home Magilton's cut-back.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Heard the one about the Skoda?

fields.headline: Heard the one about the Skoda?
fields.standfirst: With a helping shove by VW and clutch of motoring awards, SkodaAuto is having the last laugh
fields.trailText: With a helping shove by VW and clutch of motoring awards, SkodaAuto is having the last laugh.
fields.body:
Skoda Octavia
Price from £13,200
MPG 34.9
Engine size 1984cc
Max speed 123mph
0-62mph 10.9 seconds
Driven wheels 2

Trousers, muesli, muffin, Skoda... there aren't many words which raise a snigger every time they're mentioned. And the list is about to get shorter. You see, Skoda is no longer a laughing matter. Since Volkswagen put its technical know-how behind SkodaAuto at the beginning of the 90s to gave the ailing manufacturer a £2bn shove, Skoda has been on the road to recovery. Sales have gone up by more than 100 per cent, the vehicles are available in 70 countries around the world and last month Autocar presented Skoda with the prestigious Manufacturer of the Year award. Not bad when you consider that a few short years ago, Skoda was a failsafe in every stand-up's comedy act, and a friend of mine had to put up with jeers and abuse every time he stopped simply because he was driving a Skoda. ('It was much worse when I had the Lada,' he once remarked.)

And I have to admit I expected to be on the receiving end of plenty of tired jokes myself when I took delivery of the new Octavia estate (I thought it would be just the excuse my neighbours needed to wheel out old gems, such as: 'What do you call a Skoda with no wheels? A skip!'), but the word already seems to be out on these born-again Skodas. A cabbie told me that taxi drivers were snapping them up (a sure sign of economic sense), and Matt the photographer told me that the Octavia is basically a VW Passat with £5,000 off the asking price. As a colleague put it: 'If you don't mind the badge, the cars are great.' It seems that if this were the glamorous world of fashion, then the Skoda would be Volkswagen's diffusion line.

My father, who was joining me and the Octavia Elegance on a pre-Christmas booze-buying trip to Calais, gave the car his 'Canny Scotsman' seal of approval - an accolade that Skoda will no doubt be putting in the prize cupboard alongside its Manufacturer of the Year award. (My father, by the way, is a man who puts value for money ahead of all other considerations in matters of both wine and cars.)

Given that our sole purpose in going to France to buy wine was to save money, it seemed fitting that Dad and I were making the crossing in a car which offers all you'd expect from a £20,000 car at a fraction of the price. The Octavia is, in other words, the motoring equivalent of snapping up a decent bottle of St Emilion for a fiver.

The Octavia comes with a choice of high-performing engines, ABS is standard, and EBS (electronic brake-force distribution) features on all the turbo-charged versions. The car is solidly built (galvanised-steel bodywork comes with a 10-year anti-corrosion guarantee) and the doors close with a very reassuring clunk. But, more than this, there's the impression that every detail has been considered. The internal lights seem to go on and off when you want them to, the 'Climatronic' heating system automatically brings the car up to your goal temperature without being asked, and the luggage hooks in the cavernous boot are in chrome. There are also airbags everywhere and everything's electric. The whole package being rather neatly summed up by the box of complimentary mints we found in the glove compartment which bore the legend: 'Skoda Health Warning - preconceptions can seriously damage your health.' One small niggle, though: the seats - which could be firmed up or softened according to how delicate your stomach felt - were pretty uncomfortable in either setting and were far too short in the thigh for anyone over about 5ft 6in.

What really impressed us was the size of the estate - with the seats down we managed to load in almost 40 cases of wine, 100 bottles of beer, half a dozen bottles of spirits, a ton of cheese and two bars of chocolate (well, we had to buy something for the children). And we still had room for more. We were fairly pleased with our haul until we pulled into the queue of axle-grating, suspension-busting bootleggers we were sharing the last train back under the Channel with. (And all for personal consumption, M'lud, of course - though the pair who bought 4,800 cigarettes might have had trouble persuading his honour of that.)

Compared to them, we felt positively restrained in the free-for-all which passes for cut-price continental shopping. The Auchan supermarket we visited on the outskirts of Calais was stuffed with sweating, red-faced Brits dragging heaving trolleys of cheap red wine and lager. The whole impression was made surreal by the fact that we had gone over on Halloween, so all the staff were dressed as ghouls and vampires. The shopping complex, by the way, is a neat precis of the three cornerstones of 21st-century life: it has a supermarket, a steak and chip restaurant and a pornographic cinema (which maybe accounts for some of the red faces).

Through the course of the day, my father and I discussed why VW hadn't simply rebranded the Skoda. Surely it would have been easier to launch a new car than attempt to steer Skoda away from its old reputation. But VW has enabled Skoda to make such a complete U-turn in its fortunes that by the time we were hurtling along the motorway back towards the high prices and limited choices of Britain's supermarkets, we felt that strange glow of satisfaction which comes from challenging any establishment orthodoxy. (Though it's possible that the 40 cases of red wine might have had something to do with the glow.) We felt like auto pioneers.

After finally unloading the Octavia estate, we were both happy to toast Skoda's undoubted success with a bottle of our hard-won Christmas booty. Our one regret being that with Skoda straightening out its act, a bright star in the world of automotive jokes had gone out. But for old time's sake... 'How do you double the value of a Skoda? Fill it with petrol!'

webTitle: Iran puts government assassins in the dock

fields.headline: Iran puts government assassins in the dock
fields.trailText: A sensational case due to begin this week has raised fundamental questions about the future of Iran, exposing tensions between Islamic conservatives and liberal reformers who want to separate politics from religion.
fields.body:
A sensational case due to begin this week has raised fundamental questions about the future of Iran, exposing tensions between Islamic conservatives and liberal reformers who want to separate politics from religion.

The case is coming to court amid renewed doubts about whether President Khatami will stand for re-election next year. He is seen as uniquely capable of reconciling older values with the changes demanded by younger liberals impatient with clerical dogma.

In the dock next Saturday will be 18 people - three principals and 15 accomplices - charged with assassinating five dissident writers and politicians in 1998. They are said to have been part of a 'terror machine' working for the establishment.

The accused are described routinely in the Iranian media as 'rogue elements' of the Intelligence Ministry. They were led by Saeed Imami, a senior ministry official, reported to have committed suicide in detention in June 1999 by drinking hair remover while having a bath.

According to one witness, the five victims were just the tip of the iceberg. Akbar Ganji - detained since April on different charges - claimed that 80 dissidents had been assassinated by Intelligence Ministry operatives. At this time the ministry was run by Ayatollah Ali Fallahian during the presidency of Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, from 1989 to 1997.

Ganji, 41, an investigative journalist, was responding to charges arising from his newspaper articles on the 1998 'serial killings'. He gave his evidence in Tehran's revolutionary court, which deals with matters that threaten national security.

The framework for Ganji's revelations was provided earlier by Saeed Hajjarian, 47, editor of a banned pro-reform daily and chief strategist behind the reformist victory in the February parliamentary elections. He survived an assassination attempt in March, but was left partly paralysed. Hajjarian, who is close to Khatami, said recently: 'The terror machine functioned in the brain and nervous system of the establishment.' He said the machine had been activated before the election of Khatami in 1998. But he added: 'Apparently those who made the machine forgot to turn it off, or maybe they wanted it to continue working and claim more victims.'

Khatami must decide soon whether he wants to run for office again in May. Last July his spokesman asserted he would do so, but more recently said it was 'too early to say'. Some signs of his own frustration had emerged at a conference on the constitution last month. He remarked that 'after three-and-a-half years as President, I don't have sufficient powers to implement the constitution, which is my biggest responsibility. In practice, I am unable to stop the trend of violations, or force implementation of the constitution'.

He explained that he had refrained from elaborating on his opponents' anti-constitutional activities in order to avoid tension. Now, he pointed out that conducting closed-door, no-jury trials of journalists and political activists was a violation of the constitution. Ill-defined charges of 'disturbing the public opinion' and 'undermining the establishment' were being used by hardline judges to convict moderates.

The statement of the mild Khatami covered only part of the story. Stung by their defeat in the 1997 presidential and 2000 parliamentary elections, conservatives have used all the levers of power they possess to intimidate reformers.

'Conservatives run the judiciary, where they interpret the legislation any way they like, and hand out verdicts that promote their politics rather than implement the law,' said a senior Iranian journalist in Tehran. 'They control the army, police and Baseej [militia] which they use as their executive arm. They run the mass media, the state-owned Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting. They control certain sectors of the economy. Thus we have two parallel, but unequal, systems here.'

Yet Khatami's opponents are divided. 'The hardliners don't want him to run. But pragmatic conservatives feel differently. They know he is solidly Islamic and can be controlled. He has no appetite for fighting.' Even so conservatives are expected to field their own candidate. The current favourite is Muhsin Rezaei, 50, a non-cleric. He is deputy chairman of the Expediency Council, which checks legislation against the constitution and Islamic principles. Rezaei was commander-in- chief of the Revolutionary Guard from 1981 to 1997.

But he is not expected to do much better than his conservative predecessor, Speaker Ali Akbar Nateq-Nouri, a cleric who secured 25 per cent of the vote in 1997 against Khatami's 70 per cent.

Khatami is probably the only senior cleric who has a genuine rapport with the country's youth. They share his views on marrying Islam with democracy, establishing a civil society and the rule of law, and furthering political liberalisation. He is therefore an invaluable asset to the Islamic regime.

fields.headline: The new England - worth shouting about
fields.standfirst: Former England captain Mike Brearley says the near farcical ending of the series should not overshadow England's glory
fields.trailText: Former England captain Mike Brearley says the near farcical ending of the series should not overshadow England's glory.
fields.body:
The last test ended in a mixture of farce and morality play, a play whose message looked especially moral if you were supporting England.

Graham Thorpe likened batting on Monday evening in Karachi to playing for Wrecclesham in the Flora Doris trophy. It's always fun when Test cricket takes off its fine clothes and makes a brief appearance in ragged jeans and T-shirts. Not that it was much fun for Pakistan, especially when no fielder moved for Thorpe's last boundary; no one except the batsman seemed to have seen the ball.

But the other element was as clear as daylight: Moin Khan's team deserved to lose. In the words of another leader, who had, perhaps like Moin himself, a short span remaining, 'I wasted time, and now doth Time waste me.' That was Richard II, who was liable to sit upon the floor and tell sad stories of the death of kings, something that most Pakistan captains and ex-captains must, in their own style, also do.

There are occasions when an umpire will act not necessarily in accordance with the letter of the law, but within its spirit: Steve Bucknor did just that (I'm not sure what his colleague, Nazir Mohammed Junior, had to say). Among the memorable images from the highlights of the last innings included Bucknor tapping his watch, on at least three occasions, in Moin's direction, and Moin, sulky, defiant and defeated near the end, like a minor villain at the morality play's denouement. (Though to be fair, he was generous when facing unwelcome cameras a few minutes later, and the minorities in Pakistan must have been cheered by the fact that a Christian (Yousuf Youhana), and a Hindu (Danish Kaneria) both made the team.)

To stay with Moin for a minute: Pakistan were psychologically defeated by an England team who were more clued up, more positive, and more determined. Moin showed himself to be fearful of defeat rather than eager for a chance of victory. I thought the chances were about even when England started their last innings. If I had been in Moin's place, I should have tried to get England out.

That would have meant keeping two fielders in catching positions for the spinners, and inviting the big hit. Instead England won by the nurdle and the run-steal. Nothing could have suited Thorpe better than to be given licence to push the ball for ones and twos without any risk of being caught off an edge on to the pads, and without having to essay glory shots on a pitch taking spin.

Pakistan's rather unathletic fielders were outrun, and their bowlers lost their line in an atmosphere of negativity and resignation.

But England seized their chance with passion and determination. It can be difficult to risk defeat after an arduous tour. There are voices that caution against an approach that could, as they would say, 'risk throwing away all the hard work we've done'.

Overall England took the series by stealth, creeping up and snatching the loot at the last minute. But the conviction was plain to see, and bold as brass. Once they sniffed victory caution went out of the window. Perhaps the biggest achievement of the whole campaign was in persuading the players, especially the fast bowlers, to make the best of what has all too often been regarded as a bad job.

This attitude was apparent in the non-Test matches too, in which England remained unbeaten. England teams overseas - including ones I have captained - have used the early matches too much for practice, too little for getting into the habit of winning. Part of this new attitude revealed itself in Nasser Hussain's obvious respect for Pakistan, its country and its umpires. He personally showed admirable restraint after two poor decisions in one Test.

Sky too, incidentally, went out of their way to show interest and curiosity in the culture of Pakistan, with good short clips featuring bicycle repair men and carpet shops, while The Mirror had the brilliant idea of sending Ian Botham's mother-in-law, and then broadcasting her admiration and pleasure for what she found. What a change from the cheap jibes about bananas and mother-in-laws that used to be so plentiful from the commentary boxes and dressing rooms in the subcontinent.

I read recently that Darren Gough had been fed up, counting the days, after a wicketless first Test. But someone must have talked to him, encouraged, cajoled, enthused him to bring into play all his assets - bouncers, yorkers, reverse swing, change of pace, off breaks, even a rare leg break. Instead of moaning about the dead pitches, England's quicker bowlers set about their task with a will, and with full licence to use all this variety to tease a response from unhelpful surfaces.

Andrew Caddick, too, though less versatile, stuck to the job, never - at least openly - complaining. All round, though, the greatest revelation was Craig White. He was the selection of the series last summer, and has grown in stature since. In Pakistan, after three noughts in the one-day matches, he scored a fine century in the next match, at Rawalpindi, and has not looked back. I think he would have been my choice as man of the series. In addition to his batting, where he alone of the England team was able to dominate, he enabled Hussain to keep pressure on in the field, at stages of the game when on such pitches a fast bowler is traditionally reduced to mere defensiveness.

England's mistake in selection was a double one; they were wrong to pick Ian Salisbury, and the team lacked balance in going to Pakistan with only two spinners. This meant that there was no back-up in case of injury or loss of form - an unthinkable situation when it comes to other departments in the team. Moreover, we have rarely in England produced top-class leg-spinners. The selectors must have been persuaded to take this gamble by the world-wide change in pitches and skills, which has seen a gradual decline in finger spinners. On most contemporary Test pitches, finger-spinners are reduced to being stock bowlers. Here they did turn the ball. Incidentally, another Pakistan mistake lay, it seemed to me, in replacing the accurate off-spinner, Arshad Khan, with a batsman for the last Test - another defensive ploy. But Salisbury has never looked good enough.

At his best he does not spin the ball sharply, or get it to dip in, à la Warne. Nor does he have a deceptive googly. And at his worst he is money for old rope, as Yorkshiremen, who recognise a long-hop when they see one, might put it. With him, Hussain's success lay in not showing his impatience too much, and in helping Salisbury himself never to give up, whether batting or bowling. Salisbury himself cut a forlorn, but never, to his credit, downcast, figure.

Fortunately the orthodox finger spinner, Ashley Giles, had an outstanding tour. He reminds David Sheppard of Hedley Verity - tall, probing, accurate.

I was impressed by the confident way in which he was able to vary flight without losing accuracy; it is not easy for so tall a man to give the ball a zip while at the same time allowing it to rise above the level of his hand. It will remain to be seen how far the better grassed pitches elsewhere in the world will emasculate his threat, once England leave Sri Lanka.

Finally, both Hussain and Duncan Fletcher come out of the tour with their relationship and reputation enhanced. They seem to have instilled in the players a willingness to learn - even Michael Atherton is said to have devoted hours in the nets to gain an improved technique against spin - and to struggle through, making the most of their assets.

webTitle: Two moments that changed English cricket

fields.headline: Two moments that changed English cricket
fields.trailText: This is a tale of two wickets that stand out as pivotal in wiping out for England the longeur of hundreds of bad hours that went before them.
fields.body:
Sport is about moments. A moment might last hours or a second and, in cricket more than any other sport, the significance of the split-second incident is shaped by preceding events of considerably longer duration than that.

So it was in Karachi last week and so it was at Lord's last summer. This is a tale of two wickets, two moments that stand out as pivotal in wiping out for England the longeur of hundreds of bad hours that went before them.

The first came at 36 minutes and 16 seconds past four o'clock on Friday 30 June, the second day of the second Test against West Indies at Lord's.

It was an extraordinary match in what turned out to be an unusual series. The events that had gone before were these: West Indies led the five-match series 1-0 and then had scored 267 in the the first innings. England settled in for one of their regulation collapses and, by lunch on the second day, were still 10 short of an improbably small follow-on target of 68, with five wickets left. They limped on, finishing their innings 133 behind and staring defeat in the face yet again.

And then it all kicked off. At just gone 4.36pm in fading light, Darren Gough found himself looking up from third man at a catch coming his way that would turn the series.

Andy Caddick, who had curtailed the West Indies first innings with the first ball of the day (Walsh lbw), now got Sherwin Campbell, on four, to flash and nick. Gough ran, clutched and pouched. It started a collapse of English proportions. West Indies were all out for 54, their lowest total against England, who went on to win the Test, then the series, 3-1. Had Gough dropped that chance... who knows?

It was a strange series, inasmuch as England won the Tests easily because of the regular capitulation of the West Indies batsmen. There was no obvious contest, no battle.

But it was a victory that signalled a revival. They would put it in the bank and build on it in Pakistan. Not many observers expected England to prevail in the tough environment of the subcontinent, but a drawn series would constitute further improvement and put the team in reasonable shape for tougher times in Sri Lanka and then the ultimate examination, the Ashes series next summer against Australia, whose pre-eminence seems unchallengeable.

However, it turned out better than anyone dare dream, and when the key moment came, it came in the gloom again, almost unnoticed at the end of a long day, near the end of an arduous, tense tour.

The Tests in Lahore and Faisalabad were grinding stalemates. There was not a lot between the sides, although we had expected Pakistan to be more aggressive. Their tactic, hardly new for them at home, was to wait for the moment. If it did not come, they would not chase it. They were sure England would crack eventually against their superior spin bowling and England, equally, were determined not to give them that opening.

Michael Atherton's remorseless century at Karachi, a performance that pleased all but a few critics with its commitment to survival at all costs for nine hours and 35 minutes, allowed England the luxury of waiting for their moment. It came on the fourth day.

At precisely 10 minutes and 27 seconds past five o'clock last Sunday afternoon, as the sun snuck through gaps in the western stand, leaving the rest of the ground in shadow, Ashley Giles, bowling left-arm over the wicket into the rough outside the leg stump, got one to curl, dip and spit. The scuffed ball snapped past the slanted bat of Inzamam-ul-Haq like a rattlesnake. The big man, a centurion in the first innings and his team's most reliable batsman (at least when not running between wickets), seemed rooted in a dream world. Perhaps he was thinking of the meal he would consume shortly after sunset to break his Ramadan fast, not long away now. Maybe he was expecting the umpires to intervene and call an early finish, as they had done on every day of the series. What he did not expect was that delivery from Giles to get him out.

The moment was suspended for Inzi as he sensed the ball sliding past his thrust-forward left pad and under his dangling bat at an unplayable angle. He'd thought about sweeping, but decided against it when he saw the amount of turn and his stroke stopped mid-swipe. He could only hope it would carry on to the safety of Alec Stewart's gloves, but then he heard the ball bang into off-stump, heard the bails clatter to the ground, heard Stewart's mad celebration, then that of Nasser Hussain and the other close fielders. Inzi was done.

From that point on in, England were afforded a glimmer of victory. Until then, the draw was by far the favoured result. Now, with Inzi out for 27 and the total wobbling at 71 for three, Pakistan were nervous. They have a long and inglorious history of disintegrating in the final innings.

If Inzi had hung on for seven balls, he would have been granted the refuge of an early stoppage for light. He could have had his meal, his sleep and his wicket. He could have returned refreshed in the morning to kill off the match completely. As it was, his dismissal exposed the tail, Saqlain coming as night-watchman. The spinner would not last long the following morning and England's bowlers worked their way through the remaining wickets before the batsmen took the stage for the most dramatic and unlikely of wins.

There have been many other moments of split-second drama in Test history - Eric Hollies bowling Don Bradman for a duck in the last Test in the great man's farewell appearance at The Oval in 1948 or Shane Warne announcing his arrival in England with 'the ball of the century' to bowl a brilliantly bemused Mike Gatting on the second day of the first Test in 1993. Late on Sunday evening, we passed Giles on his way out of his hotel. There was a spring in his step, and ineffable calmness dressing his sun-brown face. He knew, no doubt, that he had put himself - for a moment at least - in pretty decent company.

fields.headline: Video Releases
fields.standfirst: The Manchurian Candidate | Life Is Sweet | Moonraker | For Your Eyes Only
fields.trailText: The Manchurian Candidate | Life Is Sweet | Moonraker | For Your Eyes Only
fields.body:
The Manchurian Candidate
(1962, 15, MGM, DVD/Retail)
This seminal political thriller (adapted from Richard Condon's novel) stars Laurence Harvey as an American soldier brainwashed in the Korean War to become an assassin back in the States. A witty satire on both sides of the Cold War, it launched a seemingly endless cycle of paranoid conspiracy movies. Janet Leigh, Frank Sinatra and Angela Lansbury co-star, the debts to Hitchcock are repaid with interest, and this welcome DVD features interviews with Sinatra and screenwriter George Axelrod, and a commentary by director John Frankenheimer.

Life Is Sweet
(1990, 15, Cinema Club, VHS/Retail)
One of Mike Leigh's best pictures, a sad, compassionate, truthful comedy of lower-middle-class life and aspirations in a north London suburb. Alison Steadman, Jim Broadbent, Claire Skinner, Jane Horrocks, Stephen Rea and Timothy Spall (who opens and closes Britain's worst gourmet restaurant) do well by the heroes and heroines they impersonate and, through personal research, helped create.

Moonraker
(1979, PG, MGM DVD/Retail)
Roger Moore ambles through another spectacular 007 venture confronting Hugo Drax (a strong performance by Michel Lonsdale as the man Kingsley Amis, in his classic The James Bond File, nominated as Fleming's best villain). It's not a patch on the original 1950s novel, but production designer Ken Adam's sets are superb and this DVD, like the other in the series, is packed with additional material.

For Your Eyes Only
(1981, PG, MGM, DVD/Retail)
The well-produced Bond DVD series is approaching completion (the final five appear in early 2001), and this one stars Roger Moore in the fifth of his seven appearances as 007. He's chased (and mostly chaste) across Europe while recovering a top-secret naval device and, in a touchingly dated finale, is thanked by a grateful Mrs Thatcher. Stirring pre-credit sequence, good stunt work, pallid villains.

webTitle: Focus: The year Hollywood lost the plot

fields.headline: The year Hollywood lost the plot
fields.standfirst: The old magic seems to have deserted the studios, with one of the worst crop of films in living memory.  Ed Helmore  and  Vanessa Thorpe  report
fields.trailText: The old magic seems to have deserted the studios, with one of the worst crop of films in living memory. Ed Helmore and Vanessa Thorpe report
fields.body:
This year at the movies was:

a) The worst in a decade.

b) The worst in history.

c) So bad, the Academy should cancel the Oscars.

d) All of the above.

This ballot, published as the headline to a review of the year in films in Rolling Stone magazine, captures the common feeling of audiences and critics toward Hollywood's latest output.

Battlefield Earth, Red Planet, Mission to Mars, Quills, Proof of Life, Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2, Gone in Sixty Seconds, Coyote Ugly, Pay it Forward, Remembering the Titans, What Lies Beneath, Autumn in New York, The Perfect Storm, The Beach, Duets, Bounce, The Sixth Day, The Next Best Thing - just a random sampling of the film industry's output this year. Forgettable? Forgotten them already, or at least trying to, say the pundits. 'Every year has lousy movies,' says Rolling Stone critic Peter Travers, 'but Team 2000 launched a relentless assault.'

The problem, film critics - and some in the industry itself - suggest, is that the business has lost its nerve. 'The steam has run out of Hollywood and the studios are collectively showing fear of failure,' says Graham Fuller, entertainment editor of the Sunday edition of the New York Daily News . 'This has led to a lack of adventurousness about the films being financed and they prefer to stick to the old formulas. The trouble is the old formulas are past their sell-by date.'

The situation, according to tipsters for this year's Oscars, is so dire that only three films stand out as best picture contenders: Ridley Scott's Gladiator, Julia Roberts and her push-up bra in Erin Brockovich and Steven Soderberg's forthcoming Traffic, based on the 1989 Channel 4 drug trade documentary and starring Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones. Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is hotly tipped, but it's hard to imagine a film spoken in Mandarin taking the top award. Others may emerge at the last minute - Cast Away, starring Tom Hanks, for instance - but for the moment the US election phrase 'unprecedented uncertainty' seems most apt.

'The creative crisis has allowed films like Crouching Tiger and Traffic, either of which could take best picture, to fill the vacuum. But neither looks nor feels like a conventional Hollywood film,' says Fuller. 'Until two or three years ago the studios were consistent at churning out big movies. They may not have been quality films, but they were effective. That efficiency has evaporated.'

So uncertain is the situation that Dreamworks, Steven Spielberg's company, has decided to re-release the animated Chicken Run for best picture consideration - a signal they believe a movie starring plasticine fowl could be better than any starring flesh-and-blood actors.

British cinemas too have been affected by the bad year. The lack of action blockbusters or event movies that usually bring in the cash has hit hard. Even George Clooney in The Perfect Storm failed to make the predicted financial splash. Niche market movies such as Guy Ritchie's Snatch and Stephen Daldry's Billy Elliot have also failed to draw in the mass audiences that cover the overheads for distributors and cinema chains.

In Hollywood, creative problems are begining to hurt where it hurts most - on the balance sheet. With few certifiable hits, the industry suffered a box-office slump in the middle of the year and sales were still down 17 per cent on last year by mid-November. Ron Howard's The Grinch has done much to pull up overall receipts at the end of the year (it is nearing the $200 million mark in its fourth weekend), but some studios have only escaped with a squeak.

Even more ominous, cinema attendance is down for the second year in a row and theatre owners, who face flat fees and a huge glut of multiplex screens, are beginning to complain loudly. In London the year saw the last screenings at the Golders Green Ionic and at the Hampstead Odeon, and the vulnerability of smaller picture houses has been reflected across the country.

But cinema owners are not complaining as loudly as audiences. A recent Wall Street Journal article offered a suggestion to moviegoers fed up with claptrap: just walk out. In a rarely advertised but increasingly widespread practice, theatres will now give money back or free passes to disgruntled customers - in some case, even if you've seen the whole show.

The British director Simon Monjack is depressed. He has worked in the States for most of his adult life and says he has rarely seen a weaker list of probable Oscar nominees. 'There has been a wholesale abandonment of the screenplay,' he said. 'Look at the films in serious contention. Gladiator and Erin Brockovich have pedestrian scripts that don't have anything to add to the cultural debate.'

The biggest box-office draws in London this Christmas have been Charlie's Angels, The Grinch, and Woody Allen's Small Time Crooks. 'We have seen a year with no really big blockbusters,' said Philip French, the Observer film critic. ' Gladiator has been a stupendous success, admittedly, and I think a well-deserved one. But there have not been any of the surprise successes, like The Sixth Sense last year. Even a popular film like Stephen Daldry's Billy Elliot, which has had critical success on both sides of the Atlantic, has only been shown for shorter runs.'

Pinning the blame for this low creativity is difficult. The cost of the average Hollywood film (around $60m including marketing) has simply made it too risky. It's not directors or actors who rule, argues Rolling Stone's Travers, it's the marketing departments. 'If you can sell the public crap, you're a genius. Nothing new about the hustle, but now those who scam us are getting admired for their artistry.'

Others blame the loss of orginality on the use of focus groups, but Hollywood has always used test audiences.

Then, of course, the actors can be blamed. With so few certifiable movie stars, a vacuum exists where action stars like Sylvester Stallone and Arnold Schwarzenegger once guaranteed box office. A-list actors now dictate terms, and those terms are becoming ever more favourable. Last week the Hollywood Reporter predicted that, even with The Grinch's $200m, Universal may still not make a profit. Not only had the film cost $125m to make but its star, Jim Carrey, was getting 17 per cent of the gross after his $20m dollar fee was recouped.

The genre hit hardest by Hollywood's crisis of confidence is the big budget action-adventure. More than half a dozen have bombed and most have been slated by critics. Action writers say they have been overwhelmed by special effects. 'They say, "We don't know who this guy is, but we know we want him to go tumbling down the air shaft",' says Jurassic Park co-writer David Koepp. 'Nothing makes sense. It's all backwards.'

Under the current system, movies like Billy Elliot, Croupier and Best in Show fall through the cracks where no obvious demographic is served. What happens when these artistic successes are labelled failures? 'Film makers and audiences lose their compass,' says Travers.

In fickle Hollywood what has been a bad year for films may turn good next year. Then again, with the business terrified of an actors' and writers' strike next summer, a spate of cheap comedies and horror films is being rushed into production.

'Movies are at a turning point,' says Travers. 'What happens when quality films fight for distribution and mainstream crap dominates the multiplexes? Big fish eat little fish.'

The golden age of blockbusters

The early Eighties proved a lucrative time for the big Hollywood studios, with a succession of huge hits

1980

Biggest grossing: The Empire Strikes Back

Oscar winner for Best Picture: Ordinary People

1981

Biggest grossing: Raiders of the Lost Ark

Oscar: Chariots of Fire

1982

Biggest grossing: ET- The Extra Terrestrial

Oscar: Gandhi

1983

Biggest grossing: Return of the Jedi

Oscar: Terms of Endearment

1984

Biggest grossing: Ghostbusters

Oscar: Amadeus

1985

Biggest grossing: Back to the Future

Oscar: Out of Africa

fields.headline: Vintage reading
fields.standfirst: A taste of this year's 10 great wine books
fields.trailText: A taste of this year's 10 great wine books.
fields.body:
After a couple of poor crops, when wine publishers seemed to have given up on serious wine books, the millennium vintage has yielded a shelf-load of decent tomes. There were no great wine books written this year, but plenty of good ones: more cru bourgeois than Chteau Latour.

If you're looking for general themes, three volumes on wine tasting suggest that the much-missed Jilly Goolden (she of the strange dress sense and 'wheelbarrows of Ugli fruit' fame) was on to something after all. Apart from that, there's one amusing general introduction to wine, an extremely welcome survey of the Italian wine scene, an offbeat book on modern wine styles and a fascinating survey of the last century in the cellar and the vineyards. In short, plenty to keep wine lovers occupied between the Morecambe and Wise reruns.

KISS Guide to Wine by Robert Joseph and Margaret Rand
(£12.99, Dorling Kindersley)
***(*)

KISS is short for the Keep It Simple Series rather than a naff radio station tie-in. The book is illustrated with a mixture of cartoons and terrible photography (several of them look like out-takes from Abigail's Party ), but don't let that put you off. This is a witty, deceptively simple introduction that covers everything from phylloxera to decanter care via wine styles and spot-on advice about shopping.

Real Wine by Patrick Matthews
(£14.99, Mitchell Beazley)
**

Not as engaging as Matthews's previous book (the award winning The Wild Bunch ), this reads like a series of interesting but disjointed magazine articles. Matthews looks at the modern wine world from the 'narrow focus' of California, examining 'natural winemaking' (whatever that means) in a quirky if slightly confused manner. Matthews believes that by being more 'French', the Californians are making better wines. Tasting some of the things produced on the West Coast, I'm not so sure.

Jancis Robinson's Wine Tasting Workbook
(£16.99, Conran Octopus)
***

A reworking of La Robinson's Masterglass, published more than a decade ago, this is a handy and frequently illuminating primer for people who are starting to develop an interest in wine. Clearly designed and commendably well written, her 'wet' guide seeks to explain 'why different wines taste the way they do, so that_you can maximise your enjoyment'. Sounds like a laudable aim.

Essential Winetasting by Michael Schuster
(£20, Mitchell Beazley)
****

Michael Schuster's London-based wine courses are some of the best in Britain, presented in an intelligent, systematic, but accessible format. This is the distillation of all those hours of teaching. It tells you how to taste, evaluate and enjoy wine - taking you beyond what Schuster calls 'its beverage function' to something far more interesting. Particularly useful is a series of practical tastings, which encourages you to compare and contrast different wine styles.

The Wine Experience by Gérard Basset
(£25, Kyle Cathie)
**

More opinionated and more personalised than Essential Winetasting (especially on competitions and the contentious practice of giving scores to wine), Basset's book takes you inside the mind and palate of one of Britain's leading tasters. There's plenty of good advice on offer, some of which covers similar ground to Schuster, but the book is less reader-friendly. More pictures and a clearer structure would have helped.

The Oxford Companion to the Wines of North America, edited by Bruce Cass
(£30, Oxford University Press)
***

A spin off from Jancis Robinson's seminal Oxford Companion to Wine , this looks at Canada, Mexico and the United States in more detail. There are more than 500 entries, covering everything from active dry yeast to Donald Ziraldo (why is there no entry on Zinfandel, America's near-native variety?), as well as a series of rather solemn essays on things such as demographics, microbiology and the US distribution system. It's a pretty dry read, but a useful reference book if you're interested in the North American wine scene.

Tuscany and its Wines by Hugh Johnson
(£16.99, Mitchell Beazley)
*(*)

A few thousand words of text are padded out with lacunae of white space (pages 32 and 33 are hilarious) and some arresting photography by Andy Katz in this optimistically priced coffee table offering from Mitchell Beazley. Johnson writes beautifully, as ever, but his words can't disguise the fact that the book is short on research and insight. Only worth buying for the pictures.

The New Italy by Daniele Cernilli and Marco Sabellico
(£25, Mitchell Beazley)
****(*)

For an extra £8.01, you'd be much better off with a copy of this sumptuous guide to Europe's most complicated wine producing nation. The authors rightly describe Italy's 300 denominations and 50,000 wineries as a 'fascinating chaos', but they have picked their way through the muddle with admirable clarity. The book covers the country's most important grape varieties and moves through Italy, region by region, from the northwest to Sicily. The result is the best book on Italy in the English language. My book of the year.

The Wines and Landscapes of Spain by Jeremy Watson
(£12.99, Pavilion)
**(*)

Watson's short introduction is a showcase for the watercolours of Murray Zanoni as much as a wine book. It's a gentle if indulgent look at the Iberian wine scene, examining Spain's so-called 'quiet revolution' from an aficionado's perspective. The book moves around like a distracted mosquito at times - from Miguel Torres to Pinot Noir to Catalan gastronomy to Merlot in the space of one manic page - but some of Watson's comments are spot on. I just wish he'd been nastier about Cava.

A Century of Wine, edited by Stephen Brook
(£25, Mitchell Beazley)
****

The wine business has been through seismic changes in the last 100 years, as this fascinating, well researched book makes clear. It's divided thematically and geographically with contributions from some of my favourite wine writers. The essays are of variable quality, but the best of them (Andrew Jefford on Wine, Geography and Transport, Anthony Hanson on Burgundy, Joanna Simon on the Rest of France, John Platter on South Africa) are full of original insights. A book to read and enjoy.
