webTitle: Reassurance: Will there be life after Equitable?

fields.headline: Will there be life after Equitable?
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean  answers the questions facing anyone who has a stake in the troubled firm
fields.trailText: Neasa MacErlean answers the questions facing anyone who has a stake in the troubled firm.
fields.body:
More than 1 million people who have their money entrusted to Equitable Life are wondering what action to take after the insurer closed its doors to new business earlier this month. Equitable, the world's oldest life office, was unable to continue trading on its own after the House of Lords decided it must honour its obligations to pay high rates on annuities - some pegged at 12.5 per cent - to the 90,000 holders of its Guaranteed Annuity Rate policies. Estimating these liabilities at £1.5 billion, it was forced to cease trading after no buyer could be found for the troubled business.

Here are some of the main questions that policy holders may be asking.

What is the worst-case scenario?

In theory, Equitable Life could go bust and be unable to pay its debts. Policyholders would then have to rely on getting compensation through the Policyholders Protection Act. However, pensions lawyer Robin Ellison of Eversheds thinks it 'unlikely' that the fund would pay out on all Equitable products - and the Policyholders Protection Board admits that the situation would be a complicated one. It is also unlikely that Equitable will be allowed to go under: the Government - which is trying to encourage people to build up their own private pensions - has too much to lose from letting them get into a bigger mess.

What is the best-case scenario?

Some in the City still believe that a buyer could be found from somewhere through the time-honoured old boy network. Although there would still be considerable disruption, investment returns might start to improve since the business would be part of a going concern again. At the moment, Equitable is itself predicting a decline in its investment returns following its decisions last week to stop operating on a continuing basis, to stop taking new business and to close down in 20 or 30 years when it has paid all its existing obligations.

What is the most likely scenario?

Returns on with-profits pensions, with-profits annuities, endowments and AVC (Additional Voluntary Contribution) plans will be lower than those in well-managed and healthy firms. This is because Equitable will have to take a cautious investment approach to ensure it can meet its liabilities. It will therefore cut back on equity investments and build up fixed-interest investments - assets which provide a more consistent but lower level of income. Most financial advisers see this as the most likely outcome. Independent financial adviser Towry Law expects returns to be 2 per cent lower a year than they would have been otherwise.

Should I cease making payments into Equitable Life with-profits policies?

Your first priority is to avoid making irrevocable decisions, which you might later regret. But nor do you want to throw good money after bad. You might want to stop making payments on a with-profits personal pension or AVC plan, for instance.

Since advisers expect that investment returns will be better through other insurers, you might want to start a new plan for future payments elsewhere. The new stakeholder pension - starting in April - could be an option for many people. Charges have to be kept at 1 per cent or less a year. For employees earning under £30,000 a year, it could be used instead of a personal pension or - in addition to belonging to their employers' pension scheme - as a substitute for an AVC.

You will not be penalised for not making further payments.

However, holders of endowment policies cannot take the option of keeping the plan within the Equitable and stopping payments. 'Endowments either have to be encashed or continued in full, which is not the case with other insurers,' says Clive Scott-Hopkins of adviser Towry Law. Unless you are near the end of the policy, you will probably want to consider cashing in your plan.

Should I transfer my with-profits policy to another insurer?

On a with-profits personal pension or AVC, you will currently have to pay a 10 per cent penalty for transferring. Equitable Life could, if it wanted, up this 'market value adjuster' to 25 per cent in future if it needed the money. Against this, you have to weigh the prospect of lower returns on your investment for the remaining years of its life. Towry Law and Annuity Direct both believe that people with more than five years left to go before retirement would be better off taking the 10 per cent hit now and getting annual returns which could be 2 per cent higher a year from another provider.

You might be able to avoid the 'market value adjuster' by being clever with your terminology and actions once you are over 50. At the moment, you escape the Equitable Life adjuster if you are deemed to be retiring. You can be counted as retiring if you draw some of your pension: you could keep most of your fund invested by going into a 'phased retirement' plan and encashing a small sum on your theoretical retirement date.

What should I do about the Equitable Life endowment which underpins my mortgage?

Recognise, as explained above, that the endowment could underperform and might not be enough to repay your mortgage. About 12,000 people use Equitable Life policies to back a mortgage. When it reviewed their performance two months ago, Equitable concluded that only 250 of them might not pay off the mortgage. With the subsequent bad news, this figure is likely to be higher.

But, under the current regulatory requirements, Equitable does not have to look at the figures again for another three years. And when they review the situation, they will have to use projected growth rates of 4, 6 and 8 per cent - rates set down by the Financial Services Act. They will not use the lower rates of return which they actually anticipate.

So, worried mortgage-holders might want to ask for another projection from Equitable and ponder the situation themselves. If you think there could be a shortfall, you might well want to start saving to plug the gap in an individual savings account or in some other product with another provider.

What is the prognosis for my unit-linked policy?

In theory, investors in unit-linked plans are better off than those in with-profits. While Equitable can dip into the with-profits fund to meet its own debts, the value of unit-linked policies relates to market performance and charges. There is no 'market value adjuster' for someone leaving a unit-linked plan. But there could be knock-on effects, and Equitable unit-linked plans are not an ideal place to be. Charges could go up - and ambitious fund managers will probably want to work somewhere that has a future.

What will my employer do about our Equitable Life AVC scheme?

'We are getting a lot of questions from worried pension scheme trustees,' says a spokesman for Legal and General. All sensible employers whose AVC schemes are run by Equitable will be considering their options. Better employers will think of setting up a new AVC scheme for future contributions. 'It's hard to see why employees would want to continue paying AVCs into the Equitable,' says Amanda Davidson of independent financial adviser Holden Meehan.

Apart from the prospect of reduced investment returns, AVCs are likely to attract the 'market value adjuster' penalty if the policyholder wants to transfer them out before retirement. But many pension scheme trustees could be cautious and slow to move. Some may wait until April when they can point employees earning under £30,000 towards a new 'stakeholder pension' instead of an AVC. Consider stopping your AVCs and paying them into an individual savings account if your trustees have not set up an alternative AVC scheme yet.

Some employers have set up their main 'money purchase' occupational pension schemes with Equitable. Trustees should be considering making new arrangements in future - and may be more likely to do so quickly if they get some encouragement from staff.

Stopping contributions immediately might not be such a good idea on these schemes if an employee is then going to lose the benefit of their employer's contributions.

What can I do about my Equitable Life annuity?

If you are drawing an annuity - including a with-profits annuity - you cannot switch out. If your annuity is a traditional one with a fixed income, you will continue getting that fixed income. If it is a with-profits annuity, you are in an unpleasant situation from which you cannot escape. 'These people are on a hiding to nothing,' says Davidson.

If you have one of the now-famous Guaranteed Annuity Rate products, you should probably stay with it if you have yet to retire but are close to retirement. A payout rate of 12.5 per cent a year is an attractive one. But, if you have several years to go, you might think again. Increasing inflation - albeit an unlikely prospect now - would reduce the attractions of such a policy.

Also, the size of the fund you build up will be hit by Equitable's poor investment prospects, as explained above. Some people building up GAR entitlements may decide that these risks are not worthwhile.

What should I do about the term insurance policy I bought from them?

About 200,000 people have Equitable term insurance policies (life policies that pay out a lump sum on death within a set term) and should probably hang on to them. The insurer was particularly attractive to smokers because it did not load premiums against them. The insurer says that all these policies had fixed terms for the duration - so your premiums cannot go higher than the sums you agreed with them at the outset.

Where can I get more information and advice?

Equitable Life (helpline 0870 900 8020); Holden Meehan (free advice sheet); Towry Law (free advice sheet) 0845 788 9933; FSA.

webTitle: Nurses' pay rise leak angers Milburn

fields.headline: Nurses' pay rise leak angers Milburn
fields.trailText: Health Secretary Alan Milburn reacted with 'fury' to reports yesterday that nurses were in for a bumper pay rise of 8 per cent ahead of the election
fields.body:
Health Secretary Alan Milburn reacted with 'fury' to reports yesterday that nurses were in for a bumper pay rise of 8 per cent ahead of the election. Milburn - battling to stem a flood of nurses leaving the NHS - fears that raised expectations will lead to bitter disappointment when he officially announces the nurses' pay deal tomorrow afternoon.

A Department of Health spokesman said: 'Ministers are furious about ill-informed speculation about pay rises that can only lead to exaggerated expectations. We're fed up with the NHS being used as a political football.'

There were reports yesterday that ward sisters and ward manager nurses are in line for an 8 per cent rise, far more than the 5 per cent the Royal College of Nurses thinks is likely. The Government is also expected to announce a £1,000 extra cost of living allowance for nurses in London, where the short ages are worst. The department will also announce the pay deal for doctors this week, with a 3 per cent pay rise expected.

Nurses' pay has risen to the top of the political agenda because the haemorrhaging of staff is hampering government plans to modernise the NHS. The Government said in the summer that recruitment of staff - both doctors and nurses - is now the biggest obstacle to improving the NHS.

There are an estimated 70,000 nurses of employable age who have left the NHS but might be encouraged to return. The Government faced severe embarrassment last week when it was revealed that the 20,000 nurses it has pledged to recruit by 2004 will be largely part-time rather than full-time, as had been suggested.

A recent study showed that the NHS will need to recruit 110,000 nurses to replace the 90,000 expected to leave in the next three years.

webTitle: Success built on failure - it's an effing joke

fields.headline: Success built on failure - it's an effing joke
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news
fields.trailText: The online world may be filled with doom and gloom, but that suits Robert Kaplan fine. Known as Pud to 6 million visitors to his website, fuckedcompany.com, and 45,000 recipients of his email newsletters, Kaplan has made going bust, if not a virtue, at least a source for his considerable humour.
fields.body:
The online world may be filled with doom and gloom, but that suits Robert Kaplan fine. Known as Pud to 6 million visitors to his website, fuckedcompany.com, and 45,000 recipients of his email newsletters, Kaplan has made going bust, if not a virtue, at least a source for his considerable humour.

Kaplan, 24, started the site for himself and his friends. Visitors choose five dotcoms. If the chosen company starts having problems - layoffs, funding problems, or total collapse - the player gets points.

There are now more than 20,000 players and more than 2,400 internet companies are listed as heading for the scrap heap. Moreover, the site has become a valued place for anyone involved in the internet, since dotcom insiders are invited to list new f***s there first. As a measure of its importance the site was recently named Yahoo Site of the Year and made Time magazine's 'Best of 2000' list.

As hundreds of dotcoms collapse or struggle for survival - an estimated 31,000 workers have lost their jobs this year - Kaplan is not short of ammuni tion. Every f*** gets a brief synopsis of why it was such a bad business idea in the first place.

Last week, for instance, RealNames.com laid off 20 employees. 'Good job!' wrote Kaplan. 'The funny part is that they say it has nothing to do with the current state of the dotcom business - rather, it's a "sign of success" because it has to do with a "restructuring" and a change of business model. So what makes that different than any other dotcom these days?'

Kaplan insists: 'It started out just for fun and it's still just for fun.'

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Lower Standard
fields.body:
Lower Standard

Is Associated Newspapers tightening the purse strings in advance of the expected onslaught from the Express?

Lt-General Max Hastings returned from holiday to find that no less a setting than Somerset House had been booked for an Evening Standard Christmas party.

It appears that the princely price tag of £4,000 proved excessive even for the paper's Londoner's Diary. Partygoers were last seen heading for the Earl Percy pub in Ladbroke Grove, Greater Notting Hill, which sounds posh but cost a more reasonable forty quid.

Silent voice

The red-tops were surprisingly quiet over the hunt for Claire Swire. The salacious, but private, email she sent to her lawyer boyfriend, Bradley Chait, found its way in to inboxes all around the globe, prompting a global hunt for Ms Swire.

Of course the papers' lack of coverage of this story has nothing to do with their own entanglements over stray emails. Nothing to do with the acrimonious departure of a Sun gossip columnist over alleged misuse of such messages. And nothing at all to do with the ongoing DTI investigation into the 'City Slickers' share-tipping scandal, which is focusing on internal Mirror emails.

As 'Voice of the Mirror ' proclaimed last month: 'The bald truth is that private emails should stay just that.'

We look forward to an extension of this principle to people's lives.

Cherie? Not quite

Talking of which, if the Mirror is going to splash long-forgotten pictures of Cherie Booth's punk days over its front page, it should at least get the right person. The pictures were released to publicise Before They Weren't Famous, a new BBC show fronted by Angus Deayton which finds amusing footage of people who look similar to the way famous people may once have looked.

Perhaps this cutting-edge, satirical look at people from bygone days is designed to balance the Beeb's new-found interest in telegenic news presenters. We should be told.

The salacious, but private, email she sent to her lawyer boyfriend, Bradley Chait, found its way in to inboxes all around the globe, prompting a global hunt for Ms Swire. Of course the papers' lack of coverage of this story has nothing to do with their own entanglements over stray emails. Nothing to do with the acrimonious departure of a Sun gossip columnist over alleged misuse of such messages. And nothing at all to do with the ongoing DTI investigation into the 'City Slickers' share-tipping scandal, which is focusing on internal Mirror emails. As 'Voice of the Mirror ' proclaimed last month: 'The bald truth is that private emails should stay just that.' We look forward to an extension of this principle to people's lives. Cherie? Not quite Talking of which, if the Mirror is going to splash long-forgotten pictures of Cherie Booth's punk days over its front page, it should at least get the right person. The pictures were released to publicise Before They Weren't Famous, a new BBC show fronted by Angus Deayton which finds amusing footage of people who look similar to the way famous people may once have looked. Perhaps this cutting-edge, satirical look at people from bygone days is designed to balance the Beeb's new-found interest in telegenic news presenters. We should be told.

fields.headline: Woodhead backs Tories on schools
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Former chief schools inspector Chris Woodhead has finally declared what many people have long suspected: that he supports Tory party policies on education.
fields.body:
Former chief schools inspector Chris Woodhead has finally declared what many people have long suspected: that he supports Tory party policies on education.

To the embarrassment of Labour, which backed him in a series of rows with teachers, Woodhead has suggested that the education system would be safer in Tory hands.

The disclosure comes as The Observer has learnt that the Commons' education select committee report into Ofsted's performance, due to be published later this week, will be critical of Woodhead. The report says that no future chief inspector should be allowed to become such a focal point in the education debate and talks of the need for a new era of inspectors.

In an article for next month's Reader's Digest magazine, Woodhead is asked if education is safer in Tory or Labour's hands.

After first saying it would be wrong for him to answer a party political question, he adds: 'Yet it is clear to everyone that successful headteachers want the freedom to manage their own destiny. Tory plans for more autonomous schools do chime with many in the profession. So does the strong line William Hague has taken on discipline and exclusions.'

He does not mention Labour but is earlier quoted as saying: 'I have found it increasingly difficult to defend some aspects of government policy.'

Woodhead has come under fire from politicians and teaching unions who claim that by making the remarks, he has broken the 'gagging' terms of the three-month, unpaid, leave of absence he was granted after his sudden resignation last month.

Liberal Democrat education spokesman Phil Willis said: 'I think this is the strongest statement yet Woodhead has made about his politics. It is well known he is negotiating a book deal and I can only imagine it may well be published before the general election which will cause maximum damage and embarrassment to the Government.'

Liberal Democrat MP Evan Harris, a member of the education select committee, said: 'Once again he has strayed into areas which are not in his remit and I have grave concerns over such right-wing views surfacing now. But overall I rejoice that after alienating teachers from the Labour party he can now go on and alienate teachers from the Tory party.'

webTitle: Leader: Blair must be frank with Bush

fields.headline: Blair must be frank with Bush
fields.standfirst:
Special friends, but more truthful

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Special friends, but more truthful
fields.body:
It was no surprise that the first leader to congratulate George W Bush on his capture of the White House was our own Tony C Blair. Prime Minister and new President have been showering respect on each other amid a welter of reassurance that the Special Relationship will endure as before.

Beneath the froth of international diplomacy, it is evident that there is actually going to be a change in the terms of trade between Number 10 and the Oval Office. Blair will never be as in tune with Bush, a man he will meet for the first time in the New Year, as he was with Bill Clinton, his fellow member of the international brotherhood of the Third Way. More important, the new Republican regime in Washington will not have identical priorities to Britain.

The key points on the map of the Bush presidency will be Russia, the Middle East, so crucial to America's oil supplies, and the Pacific, where China is identified as the strategic threat. So we must expect a White House less engaged with the problems of Northern Ireland. We must prepare for a United States unwilling to expend its blood and treasure in Europe. Colin Powell, expected to be the new Secretary of State, holds to the doctrine that no war is worth an American life. Condoleeza Rice, the new queen of National Security, has talked about withdrawing from peacekeeping operations in Kosovo.

A more unilateralist America can be regarded as a frightening challenge or it can be seized as an opportunity to recast the relationship in a more grown-up way. While America and Britain will continue to enjoy common interests, it is time to drop the pretence that they are always the same. The environmental unfriendliness of the new order in Washington should impel Britain to find a louder voice in criticising America's unwillingness to take its fair share of responsibility for polluting the planet.

Instead of being a mute, London should be a candid friend to the US about the dangers of Bush's enthusiasm for the colossal expense of National Missile Defence. Our refusal to participate in this lunatic scheme may prevent America making a mistake which will harm others and itself. That is what true friends are for.

fields.headline: Bush chooses Powell
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the US elections
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Colin Powell, often described as the most popular man in America,  yesterday became the nation's face on the world stage, appointed as Secretary of State by  President-elect, George W. Bush. It was Bush's first and most important nomination; and the event - at a school near his ranch in  Crawford, Texas - marked the launch of his  embryonic presidency.
fields.body:
Colin Powell, often described as the most popular man in America, yesterday became the nation's face on the world stage, appointed as Secretary of State by President-elect, George W. Bush. It was Bush's first and most important nomination; and the event - at a school near his ranch in Crawford, Texas - marked the launch of his embryonic presidency.

Powell, military hero and apparently reluctant politician, is a star, certainly more popular than Bush himself. The Republicans are banking on his appointment to dispel the pall of illegitimacy that still hangs over the incoming President, as well as forge the next era in US foreign policy.

Powell was offered but declined the same job by President Clinton. His most public role to date has been to work with disadvantaged young people.

The announcement is the perfect springboard for Bush's triumphal entry into Washington on Tuesday, when he plans to meet President Clinton and the vanquished Al Gore.

The identification with Bush's father is immediate; General Powell is best known as architect of the Gulf War, the high water mark of George Bush Senior's administration.

Yesterday's was a star performance by the retired General, raising fears among some Republicans that he may tower over the new President. While Bush looked an uncomfortable junior partner at his own debut, Powell exuded authority and humanity - and even humour when he joked that he was 'frankly glad' the ceremony 'wasn't at the ranch. I don't do ranch-wear very well; I come from the South Bronx,' he said, 'and let me tell you, those cows look scary'.

Powell becomes the first African-American to become Secretary of State - a point he himself emphasised. Bush also displayed his enthusiasm for the fact that 'a kid from the South Bronx can acceed to the office once held by Thomas Jefferson'.

Powell is also not the only African-American in the US's new international team: Condoleeza Rice, an expert on Russia and Bush's foreign policy guru during the election, is likely to head the National Security Council.

Yesterday was Bush's first showcase event as President-elect, and he used to the occasion in indulge in statesman-like rhetoric: 'We must consult with our allies and friends in times of calm,' he said, 'so that we work together in times of crisis'.

He said of his new appointee: 'Wherever he goes, and whoever he meets, the world will see the finest of the United States of America'.

But the appointment of Powell is far more of a coup for Bush than it is for the nominee. General Powell has long been regarded as presidential material himself, and the Republican party has been trying for years to lure him into office.

Despite his fame for winning the war against Saddam, Powell is not an interventionist. His inclinations are much closer to Bush's drift towards isolationism and a scaling back of US responsibilities in Europe and the world - a policy which deeply alarms other leaders.

One of the most controversial of Bush's proposals is to quit the Balkans. Yesterday, Powell said he wanted to 'consult' with the allies before making an assessment, adding that he saw a role for other forces, such as the police, to relieve the military.

webTitle: Bush cash linked to death hospitals

fields.headline: Bush cash linked to death hospitals
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the US elections
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: America's President-elect, George W. Bush, held an investment in a company that leased a chain of psychiatric hospitals where patients died and the conditions were so appalling that many were shut down,  The Observer reveals today.
fields.body:
America's President-elect, George W. Bush, held an investment in a company that leased a chain of psychiatric hospitals where patients died and the conditions were so appalling that many were shut down, The Observer reveals today.

The hospital chain - Charter Behavioral Health Systems - was exposed by a CBS television documentary last year after the deaths were reported. CBS had filmed widespread malpractices, acknowledged by government regulators. This led to a criminal investigation of Charter, which continues.

What was not revealed was the fact that Charter's hospitals were leased to the company by a property trust, Crescent, in which Bush purchased shares in 1994.

The Charter connection leads to the heart of Bush's business network in Texas. Crescent was founded by his closest business partner and the man who made him rich: genius investor and Texas bil lionaire Richard Rainwater. Rainwater was the major investor with whom Bush bought into the Texas Rangers baseball team in 1989 during his father's presidency. The investment was the source of Bush's biggest windfall and his folk hero status in Texas. He sold the baseball stock for a profit of $14.9 million, and Rainwater became part of the Bush circle.

Bush sold his shares in Crescent at a profit of $114,000 in 1988, after they had been put into a blind trust following his election to the governorship of Texas in 1994.

The Charter hospital scandal connects Bush's Crescent investment to the squalid story of its tenant's hospitals, and focuses attention on policies to which the Bush administration in Texas has been committed - self-regulation in private health care, the environment, energy and guns .

There was no reason why, or suggestion that, either Bush or Rainwater knew what was happening inside Charter's hospitals. Charter filed for bankruptcy earlier this year.

During the election hiatus, Bush's Vice-President-elect, Dick Cheney, committed the upcoming administration to forging ahead with its proposals for reducing government's role in health care.

Rainwater's office referred The Observer' s calls to Crescent, where a spokeswoman, Sandra Porter, said Charter was a tenant and separate from the property company, as was Crescent Operating.

Crescent was 'not calling the shots' in Charter hospitals, but acting only as landlord. Crescent, she said, 'works in partnership with people that we believe to be experts in what they are doing' .

webTitle: Gory film fuels Japanese fears over youth violence

fields.headline: Gory film fuels Japanese fears over youth violence
fields.trailText: Japanese anxieties about a rising wave of juvenile violence were projected on to the big screen yesterday with the opening of a controversial film that the nation's education minister had tried to block.
fields.body:
Japanese anxieties about a rising wave of juvenile violence were projected on to the big screen yesterday with the opening of a controversial film that the nation's education minister had taken the unusual step of trying to block.

Tens of thousands of mostly teenage movie fans queued for up to two days to be among the first to see 'Battle Royale', a gory tale of delinquent secondary school students who are forced to kill one another to survive.

The film, which stars internationally renowned actor and director Takeshi Kitano, depicts the worst fears of a famously crime-free nation that has been horrified this year by a series of brutal murders by teenagers.

Set in the near future, when police are powerless to control an epidemic of youth crime, the movie is a modern-day version of 'Lord of the Flies' with automatic weapons and large servings of gratuitous violence. It depicts the struggle between a class of troubled teenagers who are dispatched to an uninhabited island, armed to the teeth, and then told to fight to the death.

In one scene, a student stuffs a bomb into the mouth of a classmate's severed head and throws it into a room where three of his competitors are hiding. Another blood-splattered episode shows a girl slicing through the neck of a classmate with a sickle even as the victim begs for mercy.

The film is restricted to viewers over 15, but politicians have argued that the graphic violence might prompt copycat incidents and add to the already worrying level of youth crimes.

Earlier this week the education minister Nobutaka Machimura urged cinema operators not to screen the film, and he called on distributors and producers to exer cise more self-restraint with regard to films that might be a bad influence on children.

His appeal was a significant break from the Japanese government's usual stance of non-interference towards violent films, television, manga cartoons and video games.

The shift comes at the end of a year in which the media has been filled with reports of a breakdown of classroom discipline and an outbreak of murderous crimes by 17-year-olds. In May a youth hijacked a bus and killed a passenger, in June aboy battered his mother to death, in August a 17-year-old stabbed three neighbours to death, and this month a boy detonated a home-made bomb in a video store.

Kinji Fukasaku, the director of 'Battle Royale', said his film would highlight the problem of youth crime, without adding to it. 'The more violence, the better,' hesaid. 'Politicians who don't know anything about movies are just making a fuss.'

fields.headline: 'Bongo Bongo' MP faces race inquiry
fields.trailText: A senior Tory is to be investigated by the Commission for Racial Equality over an alleged racist outburst in the House of Commons. The comments about 'Bongo Bongo land', a reference to Africa, were made by senior right-winger David Maclean at the end of last month in a debate discussing the modernisation of Parliament.
fields.byline: by Martin Bright, home affairs correspondent
fields.body:
A senior Tory is to be investigated by the Commission for Racial Equality over an alleged racist outburst in the House of Commons. The comments about 'Bongo Bongo land', a reference to Africa, were made by senior right-winger David Maclean at the end of last month in a debate discussing the modernisation of Parliament.

The former Home Office minister described Westminster Hall, the Commons' secondary chamber, as 'the Bongo Bongo parish council room above the policemen's caff'. He suggested the hall, recently adapted for minor debates, was often reminiscent of an African banana republic. His remarks backfired when a woman listening in the public gallery reported him to the Commission for Racial Equality.

Maclean's words echo comments made by the late Alan Clark, the former minister and MP for Kensington and Chelsea, who caused a furore by describing Africa as 'Bongo Bongo land'.

Ministers and Liberal Democrat MPs last night slammed the Tory party leader for failing to root out institutional racism in his ranks. The three major parties are committed to a CRE initiative to root out prejudice in politics. A CRE spokesman confirmed last night that it was investigating the complaint and would be writing to Tory Party Vice-Chairman Stephen Norris, who has responsibility for ethnic minority recruitment within the party.

Party leader William Hague will be under intense pressure from the more liberal wing of the Conservative Party, including Norris, to distance himself from the remarks. The Conservative Party last night said he was raising the matter within the party, but could not comment before he had discussed the comments with Maclean.

Maclean was not available for comment last night.

fields.headline: The adman cometh
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Glazer is part of a brave new wave of British directors beating a path to Hollywood's door, writes  Vanessa Thorpe
fields.trailText: Jonathan Glazer is part of a brave new wave of British directors beating a path to Hollywood's door, writes Vanessa Thorpe.
fields.body:
Jumpy, grainy, ironic, boyishly amateur; we British thought we knew exactly how we liked our modern gangster movies. But Jonathan Glazer is about to surprise us.

Glazer is part of a new wave of British advertising directors moving into feature films. Only a brave few have attempted the crossover since Ridley and Tony Scott, Adrian Lyne, Alan Parker and Hugh Hudson went to Hollywood in the early Eighties. It's not that London's new generation of advertising whiz-kids haven't considered it: they've been thwarted, first by the recession of the early Nineties, which led to a slump in big-budget 'showcase' commercials of the kind that tend to catch a movie producer's eye, and then by the film business's infatuation with theatre directors such as Sam Mendes, Nicholas Hytner and Stephen Daldry. That's changing now, with producer Martha Fiennes and directors Simon West, Simon Monjack and Glazer cleverly using bigger budgets and renewed confidence in the advertising industry to attract the attention of backers and producers.

Glazer's first film, Sexy Beast, which was shot in Britain and Europe and opens next month, revisits Guy Ritchie's now familiar Snatch gangland turf but with a terrifying and grown-up ferocity. There are no slow-mo shoot-outs and no mockney camaraderie between handsome young hoods. Instead, extraordinarily, the screenplay emerges triumphant, and characterisation is vindicated as a far more frightening tool than a flip attitude to violence could ever be.

So far, the 34-year old Glazer is best known for his award-winning television advertisement for Guinness, called 'Surfer'. It made such an impact last year that recent polls have already pronounced it one of the most popular adverts of all time.

Sexy Beast is more technically restrained than 'Surfer' - which features a wave of surf morphing into stampeding white horses - and it also thumbs its nose at the spate of ironic gangster films it follows. Glazer says he was working on the project before the gangster phenomenon began but, by chance, the contrasting tone of Sexy Beast is timely. Far from laddish, it is a world-weary dream, which slides slickly into nightmare. Ray Winstone is Gal Dove, a retired heavy who, while happy in Spain with Amanda Redman, is persuaded back into crime by Ben Kingsley's Don Logan - a portrayal that gives new meaning to the word 'insistent'.

Glazer, an art school graduate whose first love was the theatre says he wanted 'the words and the actors' to dominate his debut feature. None the less, the track record of young commercial directors-turned-filmmakers was also in the back of Glazer's mind as he filmed. In the past couple of years Simon West has gone from directing Budweiser ads to making Hollywood blockbusters - Con Air and The General's Daughter. But the visual bombast of West's hits is at odds with most of his peers. Martha Fiennes graduated last year from producing commercials to the historical epic Onegin, starring her brother Ralph.

Before them - and with rather more of a fuss - Tony Kaye made the transition from British Rail and Guinness to shoot his first feature film in Hollywood, American History X.

In fact Guinness is more than good for prospective film directors. The careers of Hugh Hudson, Alan Parker and Ridley Scott were also enriched by it. And during the Seventies, British television advertising in general functioned as a training ground for Hollywood, honing the talents of Adrian Lyne, Ridley's brother, Tony, and David Puttnam.

Yet Glazer's contemporaries, including Simon Monjack, who directed Nike's Michael Jordan campaign, and is also about to release his first feature, Two Days, Nine Lives, have had an even bigger playground at their disposal: the music video.

'In a sense music videos gave me the greatest freedom of all,' says Glazer. 'The sort of freedom you get from having all the time you want to shoot things in the way you want to. It really is a toybox for a director.'

Glazer and Jamie Thralls, whose impressive debut The Lowdown is released next year, have both made award-winning videos for Radiohead. Glazer has also worked with Jamiroquai, Blur and Massive Attack.

'There is a greater degree of commercial risk in making an advertisement than a music video, so you are more restricted. Although you are still trying to sneak your own ideas in,' he says.

'I hope I always showed a healthy disrespect for the conventional demands of how to sell something. Instead, I worried about how to construct images that would transcend the industry and be remembered by ordinary people.'

The switch to feature films has been 'an education'. For a start, both Glazer and Monjack have had to adjust to the marathon shooting schedule and the comparatively low budgets.

'A Guinness commercial might only take five or six days to shoot,' says Glazer. 'But you actually have more time to get things right. In features, if you want a red car and a white car turns up you just have to use it.'

Monjack, whose debut movie is a thoughtful drama about a group of recovering addicts in a rehab clinic, agrees: 'Suddenly you are encouraged to forget all the wonderful things you were once able to do in adverts. After all, I have worked on individual adverts that cost more than the £3m it took to make this film.'

The school of advertisement-trained directors does have its faults, as Monjack and Glazer admit.

'We have bad habits,' said Glazer. 'We rely too heavily on cuts. The filmmakers that really inspire me, such as Fellini and Kubrick, have a fluidity and a simplicity.'

But there is no question that the advertising alumni have had a major impact, says Gavin Smith, the editor of New York's Film Comment magazine.

'One of the styles that has taken over recently is pastiche,' he says. 'It has taken a hold in comedy and in action films such as Charlie's Angels , and it is influenced by these advertising-trained directors.' In fact, Charlie's Angels was filmed by the Gap ads veteran McG.

Not surprisingly Glazer is now being courted by Hollywood. He is currently toying with three projects, one of which is set in Las Vegas but 'has nothing to do with gangsters'. But he has no intention of disavowing his commercial roots.

'If there is a crossover between these worlds, we should not be snobby. After all, Ridley Scott and Spielberg are both still picking up from the hyper-realism of new music videos and advertisements.'

And yet Glazer's own first work is clearly a tentative move away from the world of visual hyperbole. If the exuberant expenditure of drinks and car adverts marked the mood of the very end of the last century, the whiz-kids are now learning self-effacement. There is a fresh search for content.

'I wanted to find simplicity in a script to help me get away from excess,' says Glazer. 'I wanted the basic building blocks of four actors sitting around a table.'

Adland's pioneers

Ridley Scott

Most famous ad: Hovis

Signature films: Alien, Blade Runner, Gladiator

Impressive visual stylist.He says: 'Advertising was my film school. I was able to be the insane perfectionist, controlling all the elements in one neat capsule.'

Tony Scott

Most famous ad: Sure deodorant

Signature films: Top Gun, True Romance

Films are slick, loud and profitable. He says: 'Critics have attacked my movies and called them feature-length commercial; but I think that's a cheap shot and a snob response.'

Alan Parker

Most famous ad: Cinzano

Signature films: Midnight Express, Evita

Head of British Film Institute, he gravitates towards smart mainstream fare. He says: 'You could say the construction of British commercials today was probably set by us - by me - in those days, and the look by Ridley.'

Hugh Hudson

Most famous ad: British Airways

Signature films: Chariots of Fire, Greystoke.

He says: 'I want to make films that reach people. I'm not interested in art for art's sake.'

fields.headline: Hamlet
fields.trailText: Philip French: I was riveted by this film, by the prodigality of its invention and the sense of adventure
fields.body:
According to Daniel Rosenthal’s intelligent and handsomely produced Shakespeare on Screen (Hamlyn £20), there have been more than 50 movies for the cinema or TV of Shakespeare’s most frequently staged play, ranging from Laurence Olivier’s Oscar-winning film of 1948 to Kurosawa’s 1960 thriller, The Bad Sleep Well.

Rosenthal’s book is so up-to-date that it covers the very latest movie Hamlet, in which the New York independent director Michael Almereyda, taking his cue from Aki Kaurismäki’s quirky Finnish comedy, Hamlet Goes Business (1987), relocates the play to the modern corporate world of Manhattan. Unlike Kaurismäki, who uses scarcely a line of the original, Almereyda sticks to a pared down version of Shakespeare’s text, giving none of the characters additional lines.

Taking the famous formulation Isaiah Berlin made in his essay ‘The Hedgehog and the Fox’, Olivier’s film was a hedgehog work with one big idea (‘This is the tragedy of a man who could not make up his mind’) while Almereyda’s is a fox-like film, bristling with endless little ideas. It’s the work of a highly intelligent man who, as the preface and appendices to his published script (Faber £4.99) demonstrate, has thought long and profitably about the project.

His Hamlet (Ethan Hawke) is the intellectual drop-out son of the recently deceased head of the Denmark Corporation. It’s now run by a smooth, new CEO, Claudius (Kyle MacLachlan), who’s married Hamlet’s mother (Diane Venora). This Hamlet has pictures of Nietzsche, Baudelaire, Malcolm X and Poe on the wall of his room at the Elsinore Hotel; he watches James Dean in Rebel Without a Cause on TV, records his life on camcorder, and, like everyone else, is surrounded by electronic equipment and observed on CCTV.

He starts out as a self-pitying counter-cultural malcontent, walking the streets of Manhattan like Holden Caulfield, a woolly hat pulled down over his ears, his reflection constantly seen in the gleaming mirror surfaces of the city. When Horatio (Karl Geary) and Marcella (as Marcellus becomes as Horatio’s lover) bring news of his father’s ghost (Sam Shepard), he’s gradually stirred to action, but his natural decency restrains him from a revenge murder, and he walks through the shelves of the action movie section at a Blockbuster store as he delivers the ‘To be or not to be’ soliloquy.

The movie brings out clearly the parallel father-and-son story with a sympathetic, slightly smug but never mocked Polonius (Bill Murray), while Liev Schreiber’s Laertes is one of the strongest, most assertive I’ve ever seen. Right from the start, Ophelia (Julia Stiles), a professional photographer, is shown as if on the edge of an abyss, invariably placed beside water. She anticipates her own suicide while gazing at her reflection in Claudius’s swimming pool, and finally goes round the bend on the spiralling ramps of the Guggenheim Museum.

But this isn’t just a family story, because unlike Olivier’s film and the current National Theatre production, Fortinbras is a looming presence, the tougher young business tycoon who, in headlines in USA Today, is seen making takeover bids for the Denmark Corporation. In a final TV broadcast, his success as corporate raider is announced in a news bulletin in which famed US newscaster (and former Panorama presenter) Robert MacNeil delivers lines normally spoken by Fortinbras and the Player King. The latter has been dropped from the cast because The Mousetrap, Hamlet’s play-within-the-play to expose Claudius, has become an avant-garde video film shown in the Denmark Corporation’s private cinema.

I was riveted by this film, by the prodigality of its invention and the sense of adventure. I wasn’t too impressed by the speaking of the verse, which is at times extremely sloppy, even when naturalism is sought. And despite Carter Burwell’s eclectic score, which draws on Brahms, Tchaikovsky, Liszt and Bob Dylan, I wasn’t particularly moved as I was by the infinitely less imaginative production starring Simon Russell Beale on the South Bank. But I look forward to seeing it again, when the novelty will have worn off.

webTitle: This looks a nice place to stop...

fields.headline: This looks a nice place to stop...
fields.standfirst: In the 75 years since motels first appeared, they have become one of Hollywood's most evocative locations and a metaphor for angst and alienation, writes  Philip French
fields.trailText: In the 75 years since motels first appeared, they have become one of Hollywood's most evocative locations and a metaphor for angst and alienation, writes Philip French
fields.body:
The old mission town town of San Luis Obispo is situated near the Pacific, halfway between Los Angeles and San Francisco. I've stayed there twice, once driving north in 1958, the second time driving south last year. Neither visit left much of an impression. A few days ago, however, I was invited to contribute some thoughts on motels in the cinema to the Radio 4 programme Front Row, and discovered to my astonishment that the very first motel had been unveiled 75 years ago this week in San Luis Obispo. It was called the Motel Inn, the architect was Arthur Heinman, and each suite had a bathroom, telephone and car-port. Collecting my thoughts, I was surprised by the amount of time I'd spent in motels (mostly by proxy, but some of it real), and by the role they had played in the twentieth century.

One of the major changes in the cinema and in real American life has been the shift from the train and the hotel to the car and the motel, from a nation confidently progressing together on a preordained track to an anxious collection of isolated individuals frantically free to make individual journeys in any direction. A hotel is a society in miniature; a house is a symbol of family and continuity; the motel has become a metaphor for angst and alienation.

It wasn't always thus. In the pre-war years, the motel (usually called a motor-court and a rustic, timbered place) could be a romantic, hopeful spot. Think of idealistic reporter Clark Gable putting up the 'Wall of Jericho' curtain between himself and fleeing heiress Claudette Colbert in the cabin they shared in Frank Capra's It Happened One Night (1934), or shy academic Gary Cooper proposing to stripper Barbara Stanwyck after accidentally entering her hut in Howard Hawks's Ball of Fire (1941). But things changed. The motel is where an affectless girl comes between friends in Monte Hellman's existential Two-Lane Blacktop (1971), and where the betrayed cadet chooses to commit suicide in Taylor Hackford's An Officer and a Gentleman (1982).

Motels are places for assignations and illicit sex, for planning crimes and dividing the spoils, for insecure people in transit or desperate people on the run. There's always the chance that you'll wake up alone, robbed after a night of passion, or that the place will be surrounded by cops (as in Bonnie and Clyde (1967) or this year's Way of the Gun) and you've the choice of shooting it out or getting handcuffed.

Fugitives, like the sympathetic heroines of Ridley Scott's Thelma and Louise (1991) or the repellent duo in Oliver Stone's Natural Born Killers (1994), book in to watch their own legends grow in nightly instalments on TV as they cut their swaths across the country. Motels are located on the edge of cities, identifying their patrons as marginalised, or they are out in the wilds of the Midwest, dwarfed by the big sky and the majestic landscape.

Their ugliness is an architectural joke in bad taste that mocks, and is mocked by, the natural world. They have a dispiriting anonymity. At one end of the spectrum are the homogeneous, sanitised-for-your-protection motels belonging to franchised chains that from San Diego up to Maine bear the logos of Howard Johnson and Ramada and offer identical services to America's middle-class tourists and protect them from local colour. At the other end of the spectrum - the one preferred by most Hollywood filmmakers - the rooms are squalid, cigarette-scarred, kitsch-decorated, the thin-walled suites located behind flickering neon signs and fetid swimming pools.

The upmarket places were acidly satirised in Richard Lester's Petulia (1968), where would-be adulterers George C. Scott and Julie Christie book into a San Francisco motel so impersonal that you never meet the staff or other guests. The experience of staying in downmarket versions is cleverly caught in Christopher Nolan's Memento (2000), whose protagonist suffers from short-term memory loss and has to take Polaroids so he can recognise the LA motel he's living in.

The motel started to peak cinematically in the late 1950s. The perceptive Louis Malle, creating the first ripple of the French New Wave, wanted to present a new, Americanised Paris in his 1958 debut, the thriller Lift to the Scaffold. So he shot against a background of modern buildings and neon-lit bars and persuaded Miles Davis to provide a score. Having recently visited the States, he wanted a pair of mixed-up teenagers to find a gun in the glove compartment of an American convertible they steal and to use it for a random killing at a motel outside Paris. He found that France's only motel was in Normandy and rather than build a set near the capital he shot it there.

Curiously, Malle's picture preceded the two greatest American motel movies, both made by directors he revered. In Orson Welles's last Hollywood film, A Touch of Evil (1958), upright Mexican narcotics cop Charlton Heston takes his American wife Janet Leigh from an evil border town to the sanctuary of a small remote motel. Then leaves her without a car. Big mistake. The manager is a twitching maniac played by Dennis Weaver, and a band of leather-clad drug fiends move in to put her in mortal danger. She survives, as you can see tonight at 11.55pm on BBC2, in the definitive version of Welles's masterpiece.

Leigh waasn't so lucky two years later. Seeking a safe haven, she checked into the Bates motel, going to the earliest cinematic grave ever visited on a movie star and gaining immortality in Hitchcock's Psycho (1960). Anthony Perkins, clearly influenced by Weaver, creates an archetypal figure as the dodgy pro prietor, reminding us that Vladimir Nabokov had noted that 'motor-court operators' fall into three categories - 'the reformed criminal, the retired teacher and the business flop'.

Significantly, Hitchcock, in shooting the trailer for Psycho , excluded the actors and any scenes from the film. He concentrated on the motel, conducting the audience around the set, contrasting the sinister gothic house on the hill with the unthreatening motel in the foreground.For him, the motel and the house were characters too.

Since the 1950s, a genre has grown up to celebrate this motel culture - the road movie - and a rich repertory of actors has sprung up to inhabit it and provide it with a sweaty, fleshy, lived-in dimension. They include Ed Harris, Harry Dean Stanton, Steve McQueen, Harvey Keitel, Warren Oates, Woody Harrelson, Jeff Bridges, Randy Quaid, Stacey Keach, Tommy Lee Jones, Tuesday Weld, Will Patton, Bill Paxton, Billy Bob Thornton, Dennis Hopper and Kris Kristofferson. Kristofferson's 'Me and Bobby McGee' became the theme of life on the road and was the defining motif of Two-Lane Blacktop .

Anyone who's visited America has a pungent memory of an encounter at a roadside diner or motel. The extreme forms are to be found in two classic road movies of the Seventies. In Bob Rafelson's Five Easy Pieces (1970), Jack Nicholson famously humiliates an overly punctilious waitress. In Martin Scorsese's Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore (1974), Ellen Burstyn, who won an Oscar in the role, is on the receiving end. Beaten up in a motel room by her new lover, Harvey Keitel, she then absorbs insults and injuries as a waitress in an Arizona diner.

Three figures command this terrain. All country singers and balladeers are part of it, but Frank Zappa broke new ground with his album about his life on tour with the Mothers of Invention. This led to 200 Motels (1971) which he co-directed with Tony Palmer. It's an amusing time-capsule of a picture.

More important are the contributions of Vladimir Nabokov and Sam Shepard. Nabokov's Lolita (1955) is not only one of the last century's greatest novels, it's also an unparalleled account of life on the road in postwar America.

Nabokov, the fastidious prose commentator on life in the hinterlands as observed from a car window, is dealing with aberrant sexuality. The novel's narrator, the smug paedophile Humbert Humbert, seeks to disguise his perverse attractions to his New England nymphet by absorbing her into the confused texture of the motel, though he admits that Lolita prefers 'real' hotels.

Born during the Second World War, Sam Shepard, one of America's greatest playwrights, grew up on the road, moving from place to place with his parents, a US soldier and his wife. In the early 1980s, he drifted around the south-west, recording his autobiographical reflections in a series of poems, essays and stories he published as Motel Chronicles (1982). Shepard became the poet laureate of the motel world.

His finest single play, Fool for Love (1983), is about an incestuous affair between a brother and his half-sister, set in a dilapidated motel. This is a Greek tragedy transposed to the American south-west, and the role of its loser hero, a failed rodeo performer, was created on the San Francisco stage by Ed Harris, performed off-Broadway by Will Patton and played in Robert Altman's 1986 movie by Shepard.

Taking a drive

The first motel ever is situated on US 101 at San Luis Obispo in California - half way between San Francisco and Los Angeles - and was built in 1925 and originally called the Milestone Motel (it is now known as the Motel Inn). The architect was Arthur Heinman and the Spanish revival building cost him about $80,000.

For $1.25 a night travellers got a two-room bungalow with a kitchen and private adjoining garage. The units faced on to a central courtyard with a swimming pool and picnic tables.

In 1934 visionary architect Frank Lloyd Wright incorporated a motel in his design for a utopian city called Broadacre. Lloyd Wright planned a ramp for visitors to drive their cars virtually into their motel rooms.

Britain's most famous motel is probably the fictitious Crossroads motel, allegedly sited near Birmingham and the venue of ATV's soap opera that ran from 1964-88 - attracting over 17 million viewers at its peak.

Poet Joseph Brodsky advocates there should be a poetry book 'in every room in every motel in the land'.

Fugitives, like the sympathetic heroines of Ridley Scott's Thelma and Louise (1991) or the repellent duo in Oliver Stone's Natural Born Killers (1994), book in to watch their own legends grow in nightly instalments on TV as they cut their swaths across the country. Motels are located on the edge of cities, identifying their patrons as marginalised, or they are out in the wilds of the Midwest, dwarfed by the big sky and the majestic landscape. Their ugliness is an architectural joke in bad taste that mocks, and is mocked by, the natural world. They have a dispiriting anonymity. At one end of the spectrum are the homogeneous, sanitised-for-your-protection motels belonging to franchised chains that from San Diego up to Maine bear the logos of Howard Johnson and Ramada and offer identical services to America's middle-class tourists and protect them from local colour. At the other end of the spectrum - the one preferred by most Hollywood filmmakers - the rooms are squalid, cigarette-scarred, kitsch-decorated, the thin-walled suites located behind flickering neon signs and fetid swimming pools. The upmarket places were acidly satirised in Richard Lester's Petulia (1968), where would-be adulterers George C. Scott and Julie Christie book into a San Francisco motel so impersonal that you never meet the staff or other guests. The experience of staying in downmarket versions is cleverly caught in Christopher Nolan's Memento (2000), whose protagonist suffers from short-term memory loss and has to take Polaroids so he can recognise the LA motel he's living in. The motel started to peak cinematically in the late 1950s. The perceptive Louis Malle, creating the first ripple of the French New Wave, wanted to present a new, Americanised Paris in his 1958 debut, the thriller Lift to the Scaffold. So he shot against a background of modern buildings and neon-lit bars and persuaded Miles Davis to provide a score. Having recently visited the States, he wanted a pair of mixed-up teenagers to find a gun in the glove compartment of an American convertible they steal and to use it for a random killing at a motel outside Paris. He found that France's only motel was in Normandy and rather than build a set near the capital he shot it there. Curiously, Malle's picture preceded the two greatest American motel movies, both made by directors he revered. In Orson Welles's last Hollywood film, A Touch of Evil (1958), upright Mexican narcotics cop Charlton Heston takes his American wife Janet Leigh from an evil border town to the sanctuary of a small remote motel. Then leaves her without a car. Big mistake. The manager is a twitching maniac played by Dennis Weaver, and a band of leather-clad drug fiends move in to put her in mortal danger. She survives, as you can see tonight at 11.55pm on BBC2, in the definitive version of Welles's masterpiece. Leigh waasn't so lucky two years later. Seeking a safe haven, she checked into the Bates motel, going to the earliest cinematic grave ever visited on a movie star and gaining immortality in Hitchcock's Psycho (1960). Anthony Perkins, clearly influenced by Weaver, creates an archetypal figure as the dodgy pro prietor, reminding us that Vladimir Nabokov had noted that 'motor-court operators' fall into three categories - 'the reformed criminal, the retired teacher and the business flop'. Significantly, Hitchcock, in shooting the trailer for Psycho , excluded the actors and any scenes from the film. He concentrated on the motel, conducting the audience around the set, contrasting the sinister gothic house on the hill with the unthreatening motel in the foreground.For him, the motel and the house were characters too. Since the 1950s, a genre has grown up to celebrate this motel culture - the road movie - and a rich repertory of actors has sprung up to inhabit it and provide it with a sweaty, fleshy, lived-in dimension. They include Ed Harris, Harry Dean Stanton, Steve McQueen, Harvey Keitel, Warren Oates, Woody Harrelson, Jeff Bridges, Randy Quaid, Stacey Keach, Tommy Lee Jones, Tuesday Weld, Will Patton, Bill Paxton, Billy Bob Thornton, Dennis Hopper and Kris Kristofferson. Kristofferson's 'Me and Bobby McGee' became the theme of life on the road and was the defining motif of Two-Lane Blacktop . Anyone who's visited America has a pungent memory of an encounter at a roadside diner or motel. The extreme forms are to be found in two classic road movies of the Seventies. In Bob Rafelson's Five Easy Pieces (1970), Jack Nicholson famously humiliates an overly punctilious waitress. In Martin Scorsese's Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore (1974), Ellen Burstyn, who won an Oscar in the role, is on the receiving end. Beaten up in a motel room by her new lover, Harvey Keitel, she then absorbs insults and injuries as a waitress in an Arizona diner. Three figures command this terrain. All country singers and balladeers are part of it, but Frank Zappa broke new ground with his album about his life on tour with the Mothers of Invention. This led to 200 Motels (1971) which he co-directed with Tony Palmer. It's an amusing time-capsule of a picture. More important are the contributions of Vladimir Nabokov and Sam Shepard. Nabokov's Lolita (1955) is not only one of the last century's greatest novels, it's also an unparalleled account of life on the road in postwar America. Nabokov, the fastidious prose commentator on life in the hinterlands as observed from a car window, is dealing with aberrant sexuality. The novel's narrator, the smug paedophile Humbert Humbert, seeks to disguise his perverse attractions to his New England nymphet by absorbing her into the confused texture of the motel, though he admits that Lolita prefers 'real' hotels. Born during the Second World War, Sam Shepard, one of America's greatest playwrights, grew up on the road, moving from place to place with his parents, a US soldier and his wife. In the early 1980s, he drifted around the south-west, recording his autobiographical reflections in a series of poems, essays and stories he published as Motel Chronicles (1982). Shepard became the poet laureate of the motel world. His finest single play, Fool for Love (1983), is about an incestuous affair between a brother and his half-sister, set in a dilapidated motel. This is a Greek tragedy transposed to the American south-west, and the role of its loser hero, a failed rodeo performer, was created on the San Francisco stage by Ed Harris, performed off-Broadway by Will Patton and played in Robert Altman's 1986 movie by Shepard. Taking a drive The first motel ever is situated on US 101 at San Luis Obispo in California - half way between San Francisco and Los Angeles - and was built in 1925 and originally called the Milestone Motel (it is now known as the Motel Inn). The architect was Arthur Heinman and the Spanish revival building cost him about $80,000. For $1.25 a night travellers got a two-room bungalow with a kitchen and private adjoining garage. The units faced on to a central courtyard with a swimming pool and picnic tables. In 1934 visionary architect Frank Lloyd Wright incorporated a motel in his design for a utopian city called Broadacre. Lloyd Wright planned a ramp for visitors to drive their cars virtually into their motel rooms. Britain's most famous motel is probably the fictitious Crossroads motel, allegedly sited near Birmingham and the venue of ATV's soap opera that ran from 1964-88 - attracting over 17 million viewers at its peak. Poet Joseph Brodsky advocates there should be a poetry book 'in every room in every motel in the land'.

fields.headline: The suitor's you, sir
fields.standfirst: De Niro finds his best comic role as an overbearing ogre who torments his future son-in-law
fields.trailText: Philip French: ...what makes it so good are the complementary performances of Stiller as the decent, anxious, increasingly frazzled suitor and De Niro, who gives his best comic performance to date
fields.body:
If you fancy a holiday outing to the cinema and are looking for entertainment about a family that resists the title 'family entertainment', Jay Roach's comedy Meet the Parents might be just what you're after, because it touches on a human experience as common in Kenton as in Kenya. It's about that terrifying first encounter with future in-laws. I call the film a comedy, but it's really a farce as defined by Eric Bentley in Life of the Drama, where he argues that farce is the obverse of tragedy, a situation where we laugh despite, or rather because of something very serious being at stake.

Terence Rattigan's The Winslow Boy, recently filmed with considerable fidelity by David Mamet, opens with a clever dramatic juxtaposition. Inside a comfortable suburban house a young army officer is nervously asking Edwardian paterfamilias Arthur Winslow for his daughter's hand in marriage. Outside, hiding in the garden, Winslow's son is waiting to inform his father that he has brought disgrace on the family by being dismissed from naval college for theft. This is the interweaving of tragedy and comedy. But merge these two elements - a cowering suitor who threatens to bring disgrace on a middle-class family - and you get farce. This is what John Hamburg and Jim Herzberg, the co-screenwriters of Meet the Parents do and the result is touching, frightening and hilarious.

In Woody Allen's Annie Hall there's a sequence in which Jewish New Yorker Alvy Singer visits Annie's middle-class Protestant home in the Midwest and is treated like an alien from a different planet. Meet the Parents makes a whole movie of this situation, but reverses the journey - awkward Jewish male nurse Greg (Ben Stiller) from Detroit is courting blonde middle-class shiksa Pamela, who teaches at a fancy Chicago nursery school, and she takes him East to meet her parents. They live in Oyster Bay, Long Island, a byword for Waspish exclusivity and site of President Theodore Roosevelt's summer White House. On the way the airline loses Greg's suitcase containing his clothes, wash bag and the engagement ring that was to accompany his postponed proposal of marriage. That proves to be the least of his worries.

Pam's mother Dina (Blythe Danner) is polite middle-class solicitude, but her father is another matter. First half-concealed by net curtains as he appraises the visitor from an upstairs window, Pam's father, Jack Byrnes (Robert De Niro), is an overbearing monster. He's a blood brother to those outrageous US Marine Corps dads played by Robert Duvall in The Great Santini (he was also married to Danner) and Chris Cooper in American Beauty. From their first encounter, Jack eyes this outsider with the suspicion of a store detective about a shifty customer, and over the next couple of days a psychological battle accompanies an escalating series of gaffes and appalling accidents.

Jack and Dina find it hard to cope with Greg's Jewishness, lower-middle-class background and job. Then there's his name. 'It's pronounced the way it's spelt - F-O-C-K-E-R,' says Greg. As Pam's parents lie in bed that night they realise that if she marries him their daughter will become Pamela Martha Focker.

Jack's questioning of Greg, however, is no random amateur affair. It transpires that Jack is a retired psychological profiler for the CIA and spent a year in a North Vietnamese prison camp where he 'learnt patience'. There's a terrific sequence where Greg strays into Jack's secret den, its walls covered with pictures of him with President Clinton and Colin Powell, and working undercover in the Arab world. There's also an old-fashioned polygraph and Jack straps Greg up for a routine test that includes such questions as 'Are you sleeping with my daughter?' and 'Have you ever watched a pornographic video?'

The rattled Greg shatters the urn containing the ashes of Jack's mother with the cork from a champagne bottle, nearly puts Pamela's sister's eye out playing volleyball, loses the family cat, creates a conflagration that calls for the fire brigade, turns the garden into a foul swamp by causing a cesspool to overflow and is unjustly suspected of being a pothead. All the while he's being mocked by the Byrnes's friends and shown up by Pam's rich, kind, brilliant ex-fiancé (Owen Wilson), who has become Jack's close friend since being scared off.

These incidents are briskly and plausibly handled, and our hearts go out to Greg. But what makes it so good are the complementary performances of Stiller as the decent, anxious, increasingly frazzled suitor and De Niro, who gives his best comic performance to date as Greg's cropped-haired, malevolently twinkling, permanently suspicious nemesis. There is a sharp coda which suggests that there could be a sequel, and it won't be anything like Father of the Bride 2.
