fields.headline: Rik Mayall: Forever young
fields.standfirst: Two years ago his future was hanging in the balance after a horrific bike accident. But even that didn't persuade him to take life seriously. Lynn Barber finds out why Rik Mayall will always be the Young One
fields.trailText: Two years ago his future was hanging in the balance after a horrific bike accident. But even that didn't persuade him to take life seriously. Lynn Barber finds out why Rik Mayall will always be the Young One.
fields.body:
My role for the first 15 minutes was to sit there poleaxed, thinking may-be he is brain-damaged. He was chattering 19 to the dozen, pulling faces, switching voices, sometimes talking in camp actor tones, sometimes shouting like he did in The Young Ones, sometimes putting his face close to mine and whispering, then leaping up and pacing about, striking poses, hugging himself, then throwing himself back in his chair. And whenever he forgot a name he shouted: 'Come on, brain!', which certainly made me go 'Ouch,' thinking of the terrible brain trauma when he fell off his quadbike and was in a coma for five days. He was telling endless luvvie anecdotes, hopping from one to the other, dropping names which meant nothing to me, generally 'wibbling' as he calls it, determined not to let me get a word in edgeways. But gradually I was able to lob in the odd question and, even more gradually, he started answering them in his own elliptical way.

At one point he said, movingly, 'Can't you see? I'm frightened of interviews. I'm so frightened, I'm making you nervous.' And it was true. Of course he is extra frightened of interviews now, because he hates talking about his accident; but he was always frightened of interviews, saying, 'I don't want people to know who I am.'

Ade Edmondson says he always lies in interviews anyway, to make himself more interesting. Like most actors, he thinks he's boring; like most actors, he's more obsessed with his career than he wants to let on. But, unlike most actors, he is terrified of sounding pretentious - he has a mental audience of fellow comedians ready to fall about laughing if he says anything serious. So whenever we approach serious ground, he leaps up and creates a diversion - once, most alarmingly, by rolling the top of his ear lobe and pushing it into his ear.

We were on the stage of the Richmond Theatre, because he was doing a play there, A Family Affair. It has been on tour, but will not come the West End, because he starts filming Harry Potter in January. He is very excited about doing Harry Potter , even though he has a small part (Peeves), because ' Everyone is in it!' But he is even more excited, in fact deeply heartfeltly grateful, to be back on stage. A Family Affair is the first theatre work he has done since his accident and marks an important milestone in his recovery.

Annoyingly, though, we are supposed to be talking about his new children's film, Merlin, The Return, which comes out at Christmas, and there is a film company PR hovering about to make sure that we do. At one point, the PR pops out and Rik starts raving about the theatre, and then, as soon as the PR returns, he switches smoothly mid-sentence to, '... and that's why Merlin was my happiest film experience'. But, actually, he filmed it over a year ago - it was one of the first things he did after his accident - so it is ancient history now and there is a lot of, 'Come on, brain!' while he struggles to remember the names. Anyway, it's an engaging film, with lots of sword fights and battles and horses, and brilliant special effects. His own children, Rosie, 13, Sidney, 11 and Bonnie, 4, all loved it - 'And not just because Daddy told them to.'

But he says it's been really odd, doing this theatre tour, that so many people have come up to him and said, 'Ah, Rik, it's really nice to see you back,' when he thinks he's been back for two years. But mainly he's been filming abroad, and some of the films haven't come out yet. The accident, which almost killed him, happened in April 1998, soon after his 40th birthday. He had just joined his family at their holiday home in Devon and went off for a ride on his quad bike.

Shortly afterwards, his wife glanced out of the window and saw the bike upside down in the yard and him unconscious underneath it. He had suffered a fractured skull and two brain haemorrhages. There were doubts at first about whether he would live, and then about whether he would be permanently brain damaged.

He woke from his coma to see his wife Barbara, his parents, and his old friend Ade Edmondson all in tears round his bed. Over the next few days in hospital, he thought he was being held prisoner and kept trying to escape - once he asked his son Sidney, then aged nine, to bring a getaway car. When he was transferred to a hospital in London (pulling faces and mooning out of the ambulance window en route), he did escape, walked out and got a taxi home. His wife pretended everything was fine till he went to bed, then called an ambulance and got him back to hospital.

For the first few weeks, he was high as a kite, with an attention span of zero and a habit of scrambling his words - he would ask for a bike when he meant a biscuit, and (a good Freudian touch) asked his wife for some lesbians when he wanted a piece of paper. Ade Edmondson says that in the first weeks he made good progress but then he seemed to stick for a long time at a sort of eight-year-old phase, and everyone was desperately worried that that was as far as he'd get. But then he started improving again and, eventually, five months after the accident, was able to think about work.

He says that his 'primary terror' all the time he was convalescing was that he would never be able to act again - and acting was all he had ever done. So it was a nervous moment when he sat down with his beloved agent, Aude Powell, and went through the job offers. 'It was really brain-shredding. I didn't know whether I'd be able to read and be in character. And I did a little voiceover for some kids' stuff and I had to play two frogs - which, at the time, felt demanding - because one of them talked like this [deep voice] and one talked like this [squeaky voice] and it was quite, you know, technical . So, that was making me nervous. But I went in and did it and I've never been so fucking happy in my life! That was September 1998 and I thought I can fucking do it! My life was back.'

He did a cameo spot in BBC1's Jonathan Creek, then made the film Guest House Paradiso with his old mucker Ade Edmondson. Ade directed and arranged the schedule so Rik could do most of his scenes in the morning, when he was at his best, then have lunch alone and sleep. And he organised a masseuse to loosen him up for the fight scenes. 'Ade was just really - but discreetly - caring. Well, of course he was, he's my best mate.' Unfortunately, the film was panned, but that doesn't seem to have bothered them - they are now planning another excremental epic about sending shit into space. One of the great advantages of being at the Richmond Theatre, Rik says, is that Ade lives nearby and they can write together again while Ade's wife Jennifer Saunders is off touring with Dawn French.

Ade said last year that Rik was 'still slightly odd. Not odd, but his memory is not the same and he finds it difficult to concentrate if there is more than one stimulus in the room.' I noticed the latter while I was talking to him - a car alarm went off in the street and he yelped, 'Whadda fuck is that?' and was very jittery till it stopped. Also, he suddenly started pronouncing the name of the film Merlynn , though maybe he was being funny. Once or twice, he seemed to have lost the conversational plot and started re-answering questions he'd answered earlier, but I imagine he was always pretty scatty anyway.

But obviously there are, he says, differences in his life now. He likes to spend silent time alone, drawing. 'I'm afraid it's not very rock'n'roll. I'd like to say to relax I steal cars and get out of my face on crack and rob banks, but I don't - I doodle, I draw. I like expressing myself. I'm just very very interested in me , I'm afraid. Pathetic, isn't it?' And he likes solitude more than he used to, perhaps because of the accident, or perhaps simply because of ageing. 'When you're an experienced celeb - which I am - you sometimes just need a bit of space, when you're not "on". I'm always on! I'm walking down the high street and someone might come up and say, "Hello, Rik!" And do I want to say, "Fuck off?" No.'

Another major difference is that he can no longer drink because he is on anti-epilepsy pills, Phenytoin, which stop working if mixed with alcohol. He was a very happy drinker before - 'I liked to get pissed, misbehave, get overexcited and mess about. But I wasn't drinking a bottle of vodka for breakfast. I wasn't pissed when I fell off the bike.' And now he feels that staying sober is a small price to pay to avoid epilepsy. 'If you've ever had an epileptic fit, it's really fucking terrifying, because you don't know where you're going, your systems fail you. We're in a very difficult area now, because it's in my interests as an actor not to say that I am liable to epilepsy. Because otherwise people might say, "Oh, I was going to ask him to play Hamlet!" But I have had a couple of seizures. And it's always when I forget to take the pills.'

The first was last year, when he was in a recording studio, luckily very near his house in Ladbroke Grove, west London, and felt peculiar. He said he'd better go home and someone walked him to his front door, and he went upstairs and got as far as his daughter Rosie's room and lay down on the bed. Barbara was out, taking the kids to school, and when she got back, 'She heard, "Doongadoongadoonga..." from upstairs and she goes upstairs and she realises it's coming from Rosie's bedroom - "Doongadoonga" - and she looks through the crack in the door and there's me on the bed banging up and down and she thinks, "No! No ! Surely not! Wanking on our daughter's bed? I'll have to shoot him!" And then - she says this by her own admission - she thought, "Oh, thank God, he's only having an epileptic fit!" [He recounts all this with roars of laughter.] So she called the ambulance boys and they came in and smacked her because she had her finger in my mouth trying to stop me biting my tongue - mustn't do that, because these people are strong !

'So, next time it happened, I knew what was coming. I was at Gatwick airport, flying out to Canada to do Kevin of the North earlier this year. I shouldn't be telling you this, really, but I will. I was by the bookstall, and I couldn't tell the difference between colour and sound. I could see the colour of sound, and I could hear the things I could see, and I knew it was declining, my ability to understand what was going on. And I went up to a complete and utter stranger - whoever it was, thank you - and said, "You've got to help me." I had to decide what to say, and think how to say it - "You've got to help me" sounds easy. I got it out somehow, and then I collapsed.'

Anyway, he says, 'It turned out fab,' because the film company paid for Barbara to accompany him to Canada and she brought Bonnie, the youngest, and they all had a good time. But, obviously, epilepsy remains an ever-present worry. He will have a three-year check-up next Easter, and perhaps slowly come off the Phenytoin, but he would rather stay on the pills and not drink than risk another fit. 'I mean, yeah, it's a bit of a complete fucking nightmare drag not to have a pint, but I have found a way of taking great pleasure in it. I have never woken up with a hangover, which is great. I am cleverer, fitter, healthier. I have more coherent time. I'm very very happy now.

There's also something - whether it was my parents, or my school, or my friends - that has taught me, or bred me, to be optimistic. And combative. So that when something shitty happens, the very fact of dealing with it is good for you.'

Suddenly he breaks off irritably, and says, almost to himself, 'I'm constantly talking about this - yayayaya. That's my next job - to give up cowardice.' Cowardice? 'Because I should be nicer to myself than that. I mean, stop apologising. I'm frightened of being interviewed, can't you see?'

I think I see - he wants to give up the cowardice of always being too nice, too obliging; he wants to gain the courage to tell people like me to fuck off. He resents being made to be serious. He was never meant to be a thinker - when he left school, he threw his satchel into the River Severn and vowed never to read a book again - he wants to go back to being a happy little airhead. But, of course, ageing is against him, quite apart from his accident - he can never be that careless innocent again.

It is very striking, reading his old interviews, to see how often before his accident he used to say he'd had a charmed life. He told The Mail, in 1993, 'I had a very happy childhood, happy teenage years and I was famous by the time I was 22. A charmed life.' And he told The Independent , 'My tradge as a celeb is that nothing terrible ever happened. I've just had a very nice time.' He grew up in Droitwich, Worcestershire, with an older brother and two younger sisters. His parents were both teachers - his father was head of drama at a teachers' training college, and encouraged him to act. Aged eight, he had to come on stage as a beggar boy and rummage in a dustbin and find a bar of chocolate and smear it round his face, and he got a big laugh and everyone was pleased so, naturally, he thought, 'This is the job for me.'

He had a happy time at King's School, Worcester, and then he read drama at Manchester University and teamed up with Ade Edmondson and wrote The Young Ones and was a star by the time he was 22. There was one messy period when he was having an affair with Barbara Robbin, a make-up artist, while still living with his first partner, Lise Mayer, and they both got pregnant at the same time. He ditched Lise, married Barbara, and Lise lost her baby. But Lise eventually forgave him and he is obviously deeply happy with 'my Barb'. So, yes - a charmed life.

But it is quite unusual to go round saying you've had a charmed life - most people who've had one take it for granted. But, he explains: 'I've always tried not to be complacent. Because I think good lefties are not complacent or, if they were, they would try to get rid of it. Not that I am a red exactly, but...' And he suddenly leaps up, worried that he is getting too serious, and starts shouting, 'I am deeply honoured and proud of the fact that Benjy [Ben Elton] and Harry [Enfield] got asked to No 10 Downing Street, and they didn't ask me. Yeah! Yeah! I'm still too fucking dangerous! The only reason they didn't ask me is because I might be baaaaaad !' And he leaps around the stage, strutting and snarling and sticking his crotch out like Rick in The Young Ones.

I sit there, smiling indulgently, thinking, why does he do it? This was a question that puzzled me even when he was in his thirties, and even more now he is in his forties. Why does he keep going back to this role - be it Rick in The Young Ones or Rich in Filthy Rich and Catflap or Richie in Bottom - they're all the same, really. It seems to play the part in his psyche that, say, Dame Edna plays for Barry Humphries. It is a role - but it's a role that he also uses in real life, as a way of being rude and aggressive without being offensive because he is 'only joking'. Is that why he does it - as a form of release? 'Yes - all that evil stuff, the violence and so on - you can't just leave that bit, it's got to come out.'

But it has another effect too - it's a way of sort of desexualising himself. He is an extremely handsome man - in fact mesmerisingly attractive - but it is as if he doesn't want people to know it, or as if he doesn't want to acknowledge it. But he immediately reverted to another Rick role with Ade Edmondson as if he wanted to obliterate that idea.

The usual theory is that this is out of loyalty to Ade, who has never really developed a solo career, but I'm not so sure. Rik obviously loves Ade deeply and says unblushingly that their on-screen relationship is like a marriage, with him as the wife. He also seems to respect Ade as the greater intellect - Ade, he always reminds interviewers, got a 2:1 from Manchester, whereas he got a 2:2. It seems crazy that it should matter 20 years down the line, but evidently it does. Ade is brighter, he insists, and also more organised.

'He looks after me and I look after him, but he doesn't really need me to look after him - except to be his mate. Without being too sexist about it, he's the bloke and I'm the girl. I'm technically incompetent but emotionally believe myself to be in command. He is technically extremely competent and actually in command, but far too wily to let me know that. But it's a complete 50:50. He types, I pace.' So will he and Ade go on writing lavatory humour till they drop? Yes , he roars, 'It's not all lavatory humour! Some of it's violent! We're growing older now and we need to do something about being old and violent and angry.' And, as he has already admitted, he needs the release for 'all that evil stuff'.

But, I told him, you are handsome enough to have had a straight-hero career - 'Yes. Go on!' he beams - but you seem to deliberately sabotage it. 'Ah well,' he says, suddenly dropping all his shouting and diversions, 'You've got me all serious now because you said I was handsome. Um. I've only ever done what I wanted to do. And I'm not being falsely modest when I say I'm not the world's most intelligent man. I'm much more emotional than I am cranial. And I'm probably not capable of having a plan. I never wrote The Young Ones because I wanted to be Alan B'Stard later. I never wanted people to think I'm sexy. I think it embarrassed me, actually, wanting to show off, display how gorgeous and lovely I am. I could not do that!'

Why not? Because Ade would give him a bad time? 'Oh, damn right! But so would the audience. If I had set out purely to be attractive, desired , then I would have gone out of fashion by now. I would have been, oh, the face of 1984 - and now what I am going to do? All I really want is - fucking hell this is going to look so wanky! - but it's true. Like Henri, in this play, [ A Family Affair ] is a lonely, selfish, resentful, unhappy man and - forgive me - but it's emotional exercise, it's like going for a run, taking your emotions for a workout. Or finding things out about yourself. Stage acting especially - the beauty of stage acting is that you don't have a commander. There's no one getting you up at four in the morning and saying, 'What I want you to do, Rik, is stand on that mark, then look to the right, a little wistfully. OK?' And that's your fucking work for the day! But with the audience, it's: "I think I'll get everyone to think I'm great." I like doing what I do, and I don't like being told what to do. But circumstances have forced me to. No ! They haven't! I'm very fierce about my independence.'

Oh, I have got the hang of him now - he meant to say circumstances have forced him to do films rather than plays since his accident, but he won't say it because it sounds self-pitying. And also, as he is dutifully aware, he is supposed to be publicising Merlin . As if on cue, the PR interrupts to say the photo-grapher has arrived. I try to delay my farewell by asking for a glass of water, and Rik says 'Yes, me too, but I'll have slightly more than Lynn. Because I am famous .' As soon as the PR has gone, he starts raving again about having an audience - 'It's so sensual. You can feel what might make them sad, or excited, or scared - you sense them, you find out what they're like. It's intercourse! Because I give them what they want and they give it back to me.' And then the PR comes back and he switches smoothly to talking about Merlin and then it is time for me to go - just when I was beginning to delude myself that I understood him.

 Merlin, The Return opens on 22 December.
fields.bodyText: My role for the first 15 minutes was to sit there poleaxed, thinking may-be he is brain-damaged. He was chattering 19 to the dozen, pulling faces, switching voices, sometimes talking in camp actor tones, sometimes shouting like he did in The Young Ones, sometimes putting his face close to mine and whispering, then leaping up and pacing about, striking poses, hugging himself, then throwing himself back in his chair. And whenever he forgot a name he shouted: 'Come on, brain!', which certainly made me go 'Ouch,' thinking of the terrible brain trauma when he fell off his quadbike and was in a coma for five days. He was telling endless luvvie anecdotes, hopping from one to the other, dropping names which meant nothing to me, generally 'wibbling' as he calls it, determined not to let me get a word in edgeways. But gradually I was able to lob in the odd question and, even more gradually, he started answering them in his own elliptical way. At one point he said, movingly, 'Can't you see? I'm frightened of interviews. I'm so frightened, I'm making you nervous.' And it was true. Of course he is extra frightened of interviews now, because he hates talking about his accident; but he was always frightened of interviews, saying, 'I don't want people to know who I am.' Ade Edmondson says he always lies in interviews anyway, to make himself more interesting. Like most actors, he thinks he's boring; like most actors, he's more obsessed with his career than he wants to let on. But, unlike most actors, he is terrified of sounding pretentious - he has a mental audience of fellow comedians ready to fall about laughing if he says anything serious. So whenever we approach serious ground, he leaps up and creates a diversion - once, most alarmingly, by rolling the top of his ear lobe and pushing it into his ear. We were on the stage of the Richmond Theatre, because he was doing a play there, A Family Affair. It has been on tour, but will not come the West End, because he starts filming Harry Potter in January. He is very excited about doing Harry Potter , even though he has a small part (Peeves), because ' Everyone is in it!' But he is even more excited, in fact deeply heartfeltly grateful, to be back on stage. A Family Affair is the first theatre work he has done since his accident and marks an important milestone in his recovery. Annoyingly, though, we are supposed to be talking about his new children's film, Merlin, The Return, which comes out at Christmas, and there is a film company PR hovering about to make sure that we do. At one point, the PR pops out and Rik starts raving about the theatre, and then, as soon as the PR returns, he switches smoothly mid-sentence to, '... and that's why Merlin was my happiest film experience'. But, actually, he filmed it over a year ago - it was one of the first things he did after his accident - so it is ancient history now and there is a lot of, 'Come on, brain!' while he struggles to remember the names. Anyway, it's an engaging film, with lots of sword fights and battles and horses, and brilliant special effects. His own children, Rosie, 13, Sidney, 11 and Bonnie, 4, all loved it - 'And not just because Daddy told them to.' But he says it's been really odd, doing this theatre tour, that so many people have come up to him and said, 'Ah, Rik, it's really nice to see you back,' when he thinks he's been back for two years. But mainly he's been filming abroad, and some of the films haven't come out yet. The accident, which almost killed him, happened in April 1998, soon after his 40th birthday. He had just joined his family at their holiday home in Devon and went off for a ride on his quad bike. Shortly afterwards, his wife glanced out of the window and saw the bike upside down in the yard and him unconscious underneath it. He had suffered a fractured skull and two brain haemorrhages. There were doubts at first about whether he would live, and then about whether he would be permanently brain damaged. He woke from his coma to see his wife Barbara, his parents, and his old friend Ade Edmondson all in tears round his bed. Over the next few days in hospital, he thought he was being held prisoner and kept trying to escape - once he asked his son Sidney, then aged nine, to bring a getaway car. When he was transferred to a hospital in London (pulling faces and mooning out of the ambulance window en route), he did escape, walked out and got a taxi home. His wife pretended everything was fine till he went to bed, then called an ambulance and got him back to hospital. For the first few weeks, he was high as a kite, with an attention span of zero and a habit of scrambling his words - he would ask for a bike when he meant a biscuit, and (a good Freudian touch) asked his wife for some lesbians when he wanted a piece of paper. Ade Edmondson says that in the first weeks he made good progress but then he seemed to stick for a long time at a sort of eight-year-old phase, and everyone was desperately worried that that was as far as he'd get. But then he started improving again and, eventually, five months after the accident, was able to think about work. He says that his 'primary terror' all the time he was convalescing was that he would never be able to act again - and acting was all he had ever done. So it was a nervous moment when he sat down with his beloved agent, Aude Powell, and went through the job offers. 'It was really brain-shredding. I didn't know whether I'd be able to read and be in character. And I did a little voiceover for some kids' stuff and I had to play two frogs - which, at the time, felt demanding - because one of them talked like this [deep voice] and one talked like this [squeaky voice] and it was quite, you know, technical . So, that was making me nervous. But I went in and did it and I've never been so fucking happy in my life! That was September 1998 and I thought I can fucking do it! My life was back.' He did a cameo spot in BBC1's Jonathan Creek, then made the film Guest House Paradiso with his old mucker Ade Edmondson. Ade directed and arranged the schedule so Rik could do most of his scenes in the morning, when he was at his best, then have lunch alone and sleep. And he organised a masseuse to loosen him up for the fight scenes. 'Ade was just really - but discreetly - caring. Well, of course he was, he's my best mate.' Unfortunately, the film was panned, but that doesn't seem to have bothered them - they are now planning another excremental epic about sending shit into space. One of the great advantages of being at the Richmond Theatre, Rik says, is that Ade lives nearby and they can write together again while Ade's wife Jennifer Saunders is off touring with Dawn French. Ade said last year that Rik was 'still slightly odd. Not odd, but his memory is not the same and he finds it difficult to concentrate if there is more than one stimulus in the room.' I noticed the latter while I was talking to him - a car alarm went off in the street and he yelped, 'Whadda fuck is that?' and was very jittery till it stopped. Also, he suddenly started pronouncing the name of the film Merlynn , though maybe he was being funny. Once or twice, he seemed to have lost the conversational plot and started re-answering questions he'd answered earlier, but I imagine he was always pretty scatty anyway. But obviously there are, he says, differences in his life now. He likes to spend silent time alone, drawing. 'I'm afraid it's not very rock'n'roll. I'd like to say to relax I steal cars and get out of my face on crack and rob banks, but I don't - I doodle, I draw. I like expressing myself. I'm just very very interested in me , I'm afraid. And he told The Independent , 'My tradge as a celeb is that nothing terrible ever happened. I've just had a very nice time.' He grew up in Droitwich, Worcestershire, with an older brother and two younger sisters. His parents were both teachers - his father was head of drama at a teachers' training college, and encouraged him to act. Aged eight, he had to come on stage as a beggar boy and rummage in a dustbin and find a bar of chocolate and smear it round his face, and he got a big laugh and everyone was pleased so, naturally, he thought, 'This is the job for me.' He had a happy time at King's School, Worcester, and then he read drama at Manchester University and teamed up with Ade Edmondson and wrote The Young Ones and was a star by the time he was 22. There was one messy period when he was having an affair with Barbara Robbin, a make-up artist, while still living with his first partner, Lise Mayer, and they both got pregnant at the same time. fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: A portrait of the 'great English writer' who never got over Dickens' greater commercial success
fields.body:
Thackeray
DJ Taylor
Pimlico £15.50, pp494
Buy it at BOL

Literary greatness does not conceal warts; it offers no immunity against snobbery, jealousy and malice. William Makepeace Thackeray's Vanity Fair was never enough, for all its high critical standing, to reconcile its author to the greater commercial success of his rival Charles Dickens.

No matter that aristocratic and intellectual opinion of his day tended to dismiss Dickens as a sentimental caricaturist: Thackeray slowly became obsessed by him. A genuine admiration for Dickens's books was poisoned by an acute jealousy over his superior sales.

That the animosity had become mutual emerged from the Garrick Club affair in 1857. Its ostensible cause was an article written by the scandal-mongering journalist Edmund Yates which accused Thackeray of toadying to aristocrats and of being hypocritical in his beliefs and sentiments.

But it really was a proxy war between Thackeray and Dickens, to whom gossips had retailed Thackeray's remarks about Dickens's repudiation of his first wife. The episode, which split the Garrick and left a lasting residue of bitterness, forms a climax to DJ Taylor's absorbing biography, deservedly praised when it appeared in hardback last year.

Thackeray was only 52 when he died of a stroke in 1863. His reputation has since gone slowly downhill, perhaps because his output was vast, variable and aimed at different markets. Taylor himself makes no bones about the fact that he is a fan: an accomplished novelist himself, he believes that Thackeray was 'the great English writer [writer, you note, not novelist] of the nineteenth century. And perhaps of all time.'

And yet Taylor does not bludgeon us into agreement. He lets Thackeray's life speak for itself and persuades us, almost, to visit his hero's neglected oeuvre. But be warned: even Taylor admits that some of it - for example The Virginians, hailed as a masterpiece in its day - is unreadable.

webTitle: Speaking with the Angel edited by Nick Hornby

fields.headline: Speaking with the Angel edited by Nick Hornby
fields.trailText: A colleciton of 12 short stories from GIles Smith, Robert Harris and Helen Fielding
fields.body:
Speaking with the Angel
Edited by Nick Hornby
Running time 6 hours
Penguin Audiobooks £12.99

It is no secret that Nick Hornby's son is autistic. I mention this because Speaking With the Angels, a compilation of 12 short stories by established writers, has been edited by Hornby to raise money for the Treehouse Trust for autistic children.

Robert Harris's 'PMQ', read by a prime-ministerial Neil Pearson, is a wonderful satire on political misdemeanours, leaving the listener to judge the honesty of 'a pettifogging political pygmy'. Patrick Marber rediscovers music and teenage sex in a story called 'Peter Shelley'.

In 'Last Requests', an Alan Bennett-style monologue by Giles Smith, Miriam Margolyes reveals herself as the queen of vocal-cord contortionists as she takes on the character of a cook preparing last meals for prisoners on a fictional death row while reflecting on the last hospital meal her husband had before he died.

But the outstanding story in this collection is 'NippleJesus' by Hornby himself. Read by Ray Winstone, who is ideal for the role, this deeply layered observation challenges social stereotypes through a picture of Jesus constructed entirely from nipples and breasts. The listener's opinions are swung pendulum-like - first one way, then the other.

In 'Last Requests', an Alan Bennett-style monologue by Giles Smith, Miriam Margolyes reveals herself as the queen of vocal-cord contortionists as she takes on the character of a cook preparing last meals for prisoners on a fictional death row while reflecting on the last hospital meal her husband had before he died. But the outstanding story in this collection is 'NippleJesus' by Hornby himself. Read by Ray Winstone, who is ideal for the role, this deeply layered observation challenges social stereotypes through a picture of Jesus constructed entirely from nipples and breasts. The listener's opinions are swung pendulum-like - first one way, then the other.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: A refreshing contribution to the ever-growing Beatles literature, plus The Constant Eye, Ship Fever, Broke Heart Blues and Murmur
fields.body:
The Brian Epstein Story
Deborah Geller
Faber £8.99, pp180
Buy it at BOL

From this collection of transcripts emerges the fascinating story of a 'well-dressed' and volatile businessman who managed to nourish both his failed theatrical intentions and attraction to boys by stage managing a group of cocky, leather-clad talents.

But it seems Epstein's own theatrical aspirations were fulfilled: his projected image as the mature, aloof adult looming in their shadows was a fantastic act as he was secretly their biggest groupie. As his friend, the rock manager Simon Napier-Bell observes, the only time Epstein let go was at a US concert: '...he just screamed like one of the girls, which he said is what he'd always wanted to do from the first minute he'd ever seen them'.

Deborah Geller's candid book is a refreshing contribution to the estimated 400 Beatles books in existence, providing a vivid portrait of the Sixties drug scene, homosexuality and the Jewish community of the North, all of which appear to have contributed to his 'accidental' death in 1967.

The Constant Eye
Candida Clark
Vintage £6.99 pp200
Buy it at BOL

Sam and Mia meet in the street and they instantly slip into dangerous relationship. Sam is a writer and Mia feels more betrayed by his writing than by the thought of his affairs. Believing words are more important than women, Sam refuses to see Mia as anything other than his muse and creates his own separate world by enclosing their experience in his writing.

Candida Clark's second novel is a depressing account of a couple's lack of confidence in the ability of words or love to overcome their belief that life is about 'scepticism and separation'. It is an engrossing, passionate and manipulative novel, coaxing us with breathless stream-of-consciousness which drags the reader through the interior life of a man and woman wrestling with their solitude. Social realism it is not.

Ship Fever
Andrea Barrett
Flamingo £6.99, pp254
Buy it at BOL

As in her previous novel The Voyage of the Narwhal, Canadian writer Andrea Barrett once again uses an idiosyncratic blend of history and fiction in her first collection of short stories. Barrett's meticulously researched, original and vivid stories are a tribute to forgotten and unappreciated scientists whose passions have gone unnoticed.

Each story introduces us to array of displaced characters, all on a voyage of discovery: two women's quest to prove that swallows don't hibernate underwater; an ageing naturalist who embarks on a journey to forget the thousands of animals that died in his service. The final short story of a physician working on a tetanus-ridden ship of Irish immigrants is a moving conclusion to this collection. Each tale is grounded in detailed social commentary, and Barrett's careful investigation emphasises women's invisibility in the scientific record.

Broke Heart Blues
Joyce Carol Oates
Virago £7.99, pp502
Buy it at BOL

Joyce Carol Oates's twenty-ninth book plunges us into a world of preppies, hoods, cheer leaders, geeks and jocks. And all of them stand in awe of the James Dean of their school, John Reddy Heart. John's presence at a murder and subsequent flight intensifies his legendary status and his story is told and mythologised through a chorus of his classmates reminiscing about their lost innocence, lamenting 'after high school in America, everything is posthumous'. This humorous study of modern celebrity and hero worship addresses Oates's common themes, the difference between appearance and reality and the loss of innocence, but her usual undercurrent of scrutiny has been replaced by eerie sentimentality.

Murmur
Tim Earnshaw
Indigo £6.99, pp196
Buy it at BOL

Earnshaw's second novel is a glimpse into the corrupted inner life of a group of LA Advertising executives. After 20 years of sterile chatter, Leverton, the director of the ad company, turns his attention towards the conversation of manmade objects. He talks to cars, telephones, watches... all but a guitar bore him. Klein, an intelligent and sassy female employee, turns sleuth in a bid to find the source of her boss's silent voices. Her investigations through an obstacle course of caviar-laden canapés, a nymphomaniac wife, and most awkwardly, the cool disinterested gaze of Leverton's partner, lead Klein and then the reader towards a surprisingly slushy conclusion.

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: The book that John Steinbeck spent 35 years practising for
fields.body:
East of Eden
John Steinbeck
(Penguin Classics £7.99, pp601)
Buy it at BOL

'I've been practising for a book for 35 years,' said Steinbeck of his most ambitious and autobiographical novel. East of Eden was first published in the summer of 1952 and by November had become the nation's number-one bestseller.

Set in the farmland of California's Salinas Valley, the novel follows the relationships of two families, the Trasks and Hamiltons, and draws heavily on the biblical stories of Adam and Eve, and Cain and Abel, exploring the relationships between parents and children, between brothers and between people, history and place. Steinbeck also wrote of the book: 'It has to have a universal quality, or there is no point in writing it.'

East of Eden also probes the nature of marriage and sexual love, through the person of one of Steinbeck's most memorable characters, Cathy Ames, a wild, independent but amoral woman, described as 'a monster'. At a time when American women were expected to find fulfilment in being home-makers, a woman without love for family bonds is dangerous and demonic. This strange, sweeping novel remains Steinbeck's most considered meditation on national and personal identity, 'the story of my country and the story of me'.

fields.headline: Come on... it's a gift
fields.standfirst: Still looking for that last-minute present? Here are some top tips from The Observer's critics
fields.trailText: Still looking for that last-minute present? Here are some top tips from The Observer's critics
fields.body:
While it's been impossible this year to avoid either the ubiquitous Zadie Smith or any member of the Amis family, 2000 has also been a strong year for history, biography and political writing as well as cookery, art and sport books, and Observer writers Andrew Rawnsley, Nigella Lawson and Peter Conrad have all received critical acclaim. Literary Editor Robert McCrum offers some suggestions for books for Christmas, together with what The Observer's critics said about them at the time.

Memoir & biography | Politics | Cookery | Stocking fillers | The arts | History | Crime & thrillers | Sports | Pop Culture

Fiction

1. Michael Collins The Keepers of Truth (Phoenix)

'[It] achieves the satisfactions of the conventional novel [readability and strong characterisation] while unfolding a bleak, utterly contemporary picture of a society in terrible dissolution.'

2. Zadie Smith White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton)

'A teeming, comic novel of multiracial Britain viewed through the lives of two families. White Teeth has already earned its author comparisons with Salman Rushdie and the kind of media attention not often lavished on a new writer.'

3. Aleksander Hemon The Question of Bruno (Picador)

'Short stories inspired by the break-up of Yugoslavia. Hemon has been compared to Kundera and Nabokov, but he is triumphantly his own man.'

4. Helen Simpson Hey Yeah Right Get a Life (Cape)

'Simply brilliant. Individual stories give only a suggestion of the cumulative, terrifying force of the whole book. She displays herself as a writer of unusual power.'

5. Penelope Fitzgerald Means of Escape (Flamingo)

'An exquisite, posthumous collection of stories... There's charm here, but it's closely allied to wit and shares with it a piercing quality.'

Memoir & biography

1. Martin Amis Experience (Cape)

'An almost mythic tale of lost daughters and absent fathers, of betrayal and death and dentistry.'

2. Dave Eggers A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador)

'A witty, postmodern memoir by New York's literary wunderkind.'

3. Adam Sisman Boswell's Presumptuous Task (Viking)

'[It] has an exhilarating narrative clip and its scholarship, though robust, is lightly worn. In the overcrowded field of Boswellian studies, it stands out as a major achievement.'

4. Lorna Sage Bad Blood (Fourth Estate)

'A deceptively simple account of a Second World War childhood in deepest Flintshire, which makes sense of the enormous and bewildering changes in society in the last century.'

5. Humphrey Burton Menuhin (Faber)

'An important reappraisal of the last century's greatest violinist by the doyen of musical biographers.'

Politics

1. Andrew Rawnsley Servant of the People (Hamish Hamilton)

'The most readable contemporary history to be written since New Labour was elected.'

2. Michael Heseltine Life in the Jungle (Hodder and Stoughton)

'Crammed with detail and serious explanation about many of the issues that have mattered most to Heseltine and Britain over the years.'

3. Alan Clark Diaries, Into Politics (Weidenfeld & Nicolson)

'Clark is always on the sexual prowl, and finds the oddest things provoke his turbulent libido.The book is sinister, despite [Clark's] brilliant prose talent and his irresistible wit.'

4. Donald MacIntyre Peter Mandelson: the Biography (HarperCollins)

'Peter Mandelson's common role as the "Prince of Darkness", a modern Machiavelli and a "greasy pole politician" are dispelled in Donald MacIntyre's considered and very readable biography.'

5. George Monbiot Captive State: the Corporate Takeover of Britain (Macmillan)

'The most astute young political and ecological cartographer of his time shows that the riptide of privatisation loosed in the 1980s is now a broad flood of hypercapitalism reaching every nook of our daily lives. The book sits happily between journalism, polemic and historical document.'

Cookery

1. Nigella Lawson How to be a Domestic Goddess (Chatto)

'A roll call of everything you have always intended to make for those you love but somehow never have. Nigella has produced a truly seductive read.'

2. Ruth Rogers, Rose Gray The River Cafe Book Green (Ebury Press)

'Focusing on the freshness and seasonality of fruit and vegetables, this addition to the empire includes delicious standard dishes along with intriguing combinations.'

3. Rick Stein Rick Stein's Seafood Lover's Guide (BBC)

'A chatty and informative account of Stein's fishy travels around the UK, published to accompany the TV series.'

4. James Martin The Deli Cookbook (Mitchell Beazley)

'A book for those who don't have time to slave over a hot stove, but do have a well-stocked local deli.'

5. Nigel Slater Appetite (Fourth Estate)

'An essential source of inspiration for anyone who wants to cook every day.'

Stocking fillers

1. Alan Bennett A Box of Alan Bennett (Profile Books)

'Two short stories and a poignant piece of non-fiction. A perfect christmas gift.'

2. Rowan Pelling (ed) The Erotic Review - Bedside Companion (Headline)

'The Erotic Review conveys an almost eighteenth-century delight in the physicality of sex. Never mind its smirkingly tasteful covers or old-fashioned line-drawings, it is very bawdy indeed.'

3. The Redstone Diary (Redstone Press)

'Another year's worth of an impressive, witty and thought-provoking blend of visual and verbal play.

4. Terry Gilliam Pocketful of Python 1 (Methuen)

'Pythons' quirks and confusions are captured in this addictive series.'

5. Ranulph Fiennes Beyond the Limits - the Lessons Learned from a Lifetime's Adventures (Little, Brown)

'An informative and lively lesson in the do's and don'ts of the professional adventurer, with stunning photography.'

The arts

1. Peter Conrad The Hitchcock Murders (Faber)

'Conrad has certainly done his homework on Hitchcock, he is the critic as magician, at least as tricky as the film director he so much admires.'

2. Richard Eyre, Nicholas Wright Changing Stages (BBC)

'A serious book for serious theatre-lovers with literary critical zingers scattered through the text.'

3. Mary Ann Caws Dora Marr With & Without Picasso (Thames & Hudson)

'A fascinating and intimate portrait of French intelligentsia.'

4. WF Velhuysen, JL Locher The Magic of MC Escher (Thames & Hudson)

'Allow yourself time to look at this book because Escher's tangles and mind games demand hours of staring and puzzlement. A fantastic collection.'

5. Ross King Brunelleschi's Dome (Chatto & Windus)

'An extraordinary account of the greatest architectural puzzle of the age, King's investigation surveys the dome's complex and terrifying building strategies while describing its turbulent social back-drop.'

History

1. Frank Kermode Shakespeare's Language (Viking)

'Kermode's book on Shakespeare's 'dramatic verse' is partly about how Shakespeare is, and has been heard. It also suggests interesting questions about the difference between reading and listening.'

2. Peter Ackroyd London (Chatto)

'We are invited to see London as a living, breathing creature, greedy, bestial, even demonic. It is a work on the level of Mayhew's London, raw and compelling.'

3. Patrick Wright Tank (Faber)

'Wright's style throughout is discursive, even languid, and his breadth of reference exciting.'

4. Ian Kershaw Nemesis (Viking)

'Kershaw's Hitler is mediocre, not monstrous, a blundering amateur rather than a malevolent genius.'

5. Roy Porter Enlightenment (Penguin)

'A book which has understood the age, which sees it clearly and, a surprisingly rare virtue, loves and sympathises with its dashing, dazzling spirit.

Crime & thrillers

1. John Le Carré The Constant Gardener (Hodder)

'It may use the form of the thriller but its moral and artistic concerns go well beyond the task of entertainment.'

2. Elmore Leonard Pagan Babies (Penguin)

'A triumphant return to form for America's finest crime writer.'

3. Minette Walters The Shape of Snakes (Macmillan)

'This psychological thriller combines compassion and a strong social conscience with a ruthless ability to create unease, suspense and, sometimes, horror.'

4. Jonathan Lethem Motherless Brooklyn (Faber)

'A witty, ambitious book that blends self-conscious meta-fiction with aural lyricism and inquires into the complexity of the brain's "wheels within wheels".'

5. Ian Rankin Set in Darkness (Orion)

'Eleventh novel featuring Inspector Rebus, choleric, compassionate loner. A masterful creation.'

Sports

1. Paul Kimmage Full Time: the Secret Life of Tony Cascarino (Simon and Schuster/Town House)

'Possibly the best insight yet into the lives, loves and fears of a professional footballer. Unmissable.'

2. Nick Tosches Night Train (Hamish Hamilton, £17.99)

'Eloquent and poignant story of the boxer Sonny Liston'

3. Lance Armstrong, Sally Jenkins It's not about the Bike - My Journey back to Life (Yellow Jersey Press)

'In the William Hill Sports Book of the Year, Armstrong, two-time winner of the Tour de France, recounts how he kept riding through his battle with cancer'.

4. Gideon Haigh The Story of Jack Inerson - Mystery Spinner (Aurum, £18.99)

Inerson took up cricket at 31 - became one of Australia's best bowlers, and killed himself at 58. This is extraordinary story.

5. Andrew Jennings The Great OIympic Swindle (Simon & Schuster)

'Jennings investigates the corrupt and complex Olympic family of dodgy officials, spin-doctors and scapegoats who dictate who gets gold.'

Pop culture

1. Malcolm Gladwell Tipping Point: How Little Things can make a Big Difference (Little, Brown)

'Anticipating consumer choice is the philosopher's stone of modern business. A compelling subject.'

2. The Beatles The Beatles Anthology (Cassell)

'The Beatles have bared all for this image-heavy book, allowing unseen archive photographs and unpublished documents. A refreshing gleen into a well-trod subject.'

3. Naomi Klein No Logo (HarperCollins)

'A book which has developed a life of its own. Klein's anti-corporate call to arms is fluent and undogmatically alive to its contradictions and omissions, and positively seethes with intelligent anger.'

4. Michael Lewis The New New Thing (Coronet)

'A profile of Jim Clark in his Silicon Valley, embodies the unstinting entrepreneurial spirit at the centre of the modern Californian gold rush.'

fields.headline: 'I don't miss Smiley'
fields.standfirst: John Le Carré on his new novel, women and why he avoids other English writers
fields.trailText: John Le Carré on his new novel, women and why he avoids other English writers
fields.body:
John Le Carré was born in 1931. His third novel, The Spy Who Came in From the Cold, secured him an international reputation, which was consolidated by the acclaim for his trilogy Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy, The Honourable Schoolboy and Smiley's People. The Constant Gardener is his eighteenth novel.

Observer: What is The Constant Gardener about?

John Le Carré: At the level that is closest to me it's about somebody making an interior journey and discovering, after a flawed life, some kind of morality. Beyond that it's about the same subject that I've written about right from the beginning, which is man's relationship with the institutions he creates - whether they're intelligence institutions or commercial. Beyond that again, it's about what we now have in place of nations: a corporate ethic subscribed to - to my total frustration - by the present government. The extraordinary belief that at the centre of corporations lies a moral purpose, some humanitarian self-restraint. It's nonsense.

Obs: Was there a moment of inspiration for the book?

JLC: It was cumulative. Since The Honourable Schoolboy I have started paying much more attention to the Third World. I found myself drawn repeatedly to former colonies. Cumulatively I was aware of the level of repression and bullying which was happening in the name of western democracy.

Obs: It's a very polemical book, but it also has two characters - Justin and Tessa Quayle - who are among your most successful. Did you find it hard to marry the political side of the novel with the fictional?

JLC: Well, I didn't really because the motor is one and the same. The motor is inside Justin after Tessa's death. He takes over her role. He completes her work for her. This story could not have occurred without the moral anger and equally the moral anger could not have been expressed without those circumstances and those characters. My own life has been so messy and zigzag at times that it's actually quite a consolation later in life to discover what I do care about. So I had that in common with Justin.

Obs: Can you talk about the title, The Constant Gardener?

JLC: Well, constant in the sense of true, and in the sense of loyal. Then there was a literary echo with 'the constant nymph'. It was just a surprising word and it was pretty.

Obs: Did you look for this subject or did it come to you?

JLC: I wanted to do corporate behaviour in the Third World. After the Ken Saro-Wiwa business in Nigeria I thought very seriously of oil. Once I started talking off the record to people in the pharmaceutical industry, and to those few brave people who have tried to unmask its activities, I didn't look back.

Obs: Your last novel, Single and Single, was published two years ago. This seems to have been written fast.

JLC: It was written fast. Once it got going there was very little industrial waste, very little going back, rewriting. I've had perhaps three or four books which seem to have been carried by a surge. The Spy Who Came in From the Cold was one, and so was The Little Drummer Girl. If you get all the bits right at the beginning and you come into the story at the right place and you've got the premise identified with the main characters, then you're up and running.

Obs: Justin Quayle, like the main characters in all your books, wrestles with his love for the state and his duty to himself and his conscience. Do you think betrayal is your essential theme?

JLC: Self and state, self and institutions.

Obs: Did you always want to be a writer?

JLC: Yes, I really think I did.

Obs: Can you remember a point when you said to yourself, this is what I want to do?

JLC: Yeah, at Sherborne. I won the poetry prize with a perfectly ghastly poem which I've tried to destroy all copies of. And then, when I went into the secret world I shared a room with a writer called John Bingham, the Lord Clanmorris. John, by example, really encouraged me. He wrote whenever he had a spare moment, and it seemed a wonderful thing to have a book running as a kind of subtext in your life. When I began writing, I thought it would be a sort of antidote to the routine of a civil service existence.

Obs: Up to that point you'd imagined yourself being a lifelong civil servant?

JLC: Yes. I think they imagined it too. I suffered some kind of almost hallucinatory sense of story when I went to Berlin and saw the Wall beginning to go up. And I wrote The Spy Who Came in From the Cold in about five or six weeks. Sometimes, as with this book, I could go for 14, 15 hours at a shot. I wrote great chunks and didn't alter much. It was the same feeling that I'd got it right, I'd got the characters, it just seemed wonderfully easy.

Obs: Who are the writers you read as a boy, and who do you admire?

JLC: I read at the heavier level masses of Bernard Shaw, Galsworthy. And then I loved, still love, our mutual friend PG Wodehouse. Conan Doyle I thought was terrific. I still think that, although he never really brought it off, Somerset Maughan was the most polished narrative stylist of his period. Quite extraordinary. And then of course I read Evelyn Waugh and Graham Greene and Orwell. Those were my people up to 16, when I removed myself from Sherborne and chucked it all in favour of German literature.

Obs: Obviously a big influence.

JLC: It was a very big influence. Stories of the education of one man, which this is, and Heinrich Hölderlin and the Nibelungenlied. They always carried the same moral search.

Obs: Graham Greene described childhood as 'a writer's bank balance'. Do you think that's true of you?

JLC: In that sense I was born a millionaire. I mean it just was extraordinary.

Obs: In the past the women in your books have been untrustworthy and faithless, but Tessa, a marvellous character, is unswerving. Is this a turning point ?

JLC: It is a sort of change in me. Going back to childhood, I had no example of a mother, because she disappeared and we were nomadic. So I never sustained relationships with women of any age, let alone girlfriends. For years I had a very, very untidy love life. Latterly it's come all right.

Obs: You've always written thrillers or novels of adventure. Why is this? In The Constant Gardener you write: 'If you can't deal with reality then dream up a conspiracy.' Is that a clue?

JLC: We were born into a great tension, my brother and I, in that our life was pretence. We were projecting ourselves as nice middle-class, short-back-and-sides young men. We learned quite quickly that our dad was a con man, that life was extremely dangerous. That tension never left me. I'm sure that if I wrote the most passive-seeming suburban novel, I would still be looking for a bunched, tense, perilous arrangement of events at the end of it.

Obs: Do you miss Smiley?

JLC: No, I don't. I think I've done him. Alec [Guinness] cured me of him. I couldn't really write him without thinking of Alec and Alec's voice. Also, the older I got the more I wanted to write about young people.

Obs: In America you're treated as a great novelist, over here as a great genre writer. Why?

JLC: I don't know. I now have a much larger readership in Europe than in the US. And there I seem to get by as somebody who's commented on our own time. In this country, actually to persist with one subject and to work that field as I have done is simply perceived as hack work. The notion that you might be using a microcosm to illustrate a larger context is considered pretentious.

On the whole I've avoided the company of my fellow English writers and that world. I think that it threatens me in a number of ways. Envy is always up and running. I've made a lot of money out of writing, I've made a name. But more particularly I fear for myself that I could be drawn towards their standards and their pretensions. I don't read them. I've dipped into McEwan, walked away again, and dipped into a number of highly rated contemporary writers. I feel we're simply not in the same ball park. I don't mean I'm better or worse, I mean we're just doing completely different things. So I just feel completely out of step with the English literary scene.

Obs: Does that trouble you in any way?

JLC: Not at all. I think I've been so fortunate. With that whole secret world stuff I was a round peg in a round hole. It was a comedy of English manners and attitudes. I was able to write about, as you might say, the period pains of a post-imperial Britain which had had the appalling problem of winning two wars on the trot and had a self-perception that was completely irrelevant to the rest of the world. It goes on and on and on. All those changes that seemed to hang in the air earlier, they simply haven't taken place. The public schools aren't threatened, the Establishment still runs Britain. Go and sit in the Atheneum or any London club, you see the same suits, the same faces, the same furtive little eyes looking at you.

Obs: You're nearly 70. This is a book that could have been written by a man a generation younger. It's full of energy and full of drive.

JLC: It just feels like my best time now.

Obs: So do you think this is the beginning of a surge of new writing?

JLC: I hope it is, obviously. I hope it is.

Obs: What do you think your place is in English literature?

JLC: That one, thank heaven, is not my problem. As in most other departments of British life, for the few people who can actually do it, there are a great number of commentators who say how it should be done [laughs]. For that huge literary bureaucracy, we mustn't take their bone away.

fields.headline: An uncommercial traveller
fields.trailText: There's still a surprising amount of evidence for 'braining up'.
fields.body:
People often complain about 'dumbing down' in British and American publishing. I would not be so rash as to argue that mass culture does not have its demerits but, writing as one for whom the glass is half-full not half-empty, there's still a surprising amount of evidence for 'braining up'.

Just as the much-abused BBC has recently contrived to screen two landmark documentary series - Simon Schama's History of Britain and Richard Eyre's Changing Stages - so the British book trade continues to publish volumes of the highest quality and cultural importance. You'll hear a lot about Naked Chefs, Posh 'n' Becks and the Beatles this Christmas, but look carefully among the piles of Domestic Goddesses and you'll find books that could have been published at any time during the last 100 years.

Consider, for example, the recently published volume of Dickens's journalism The Uncommercial Traveller and Other Papers, edited by Michael Slater and John Drew (J.M. Dent £30, pp476). This fourth volume in a fascinating series marks the conclusion of a superb scholarly enterprise, brilliantly edited, exquisitely printed and competitively priced - an absolute must for anyone interested in Dickens and the Victorians.

The picture of English literary life presented in these pages is eerily familiar. There are the Grub Street feuds: Dickens's battle with Leigh Hunt's family over his portrait of the 'odiously parasitic and cunningly careless' Harold Skimpole in Bleak House. There is the unscruplous press gossip about the writer's private life and his vain attempts to answer back: The Tattlesnivel Bleater, Dickens's brilliant parody of the worst excesses of provincial journalism. And there is the inescapable politics of literary London: Dickens's back-scratching review of his friend (and biographer) Forster's life of Walter Savage Landor. What, of course, is not familiar in these pages, because it is unique, is Dickens's astounding journalistic energy, or to put it another way, his genius.

When this volume opens, in 1859, Dickens has just closed Household Words and replaced it with a new vehicle for his journalism All The Year Round. He launched the new magazine, which was to place much greater emphasis on new fiction, with a serialisation of A Tale of Two Cities. Later on, in response to falling circulation, he also serialised Great Expectations here.

Apart from fiction, Dickens wrote on everything under the sun, or as he put it himself: 'Suggestive, Descriptive and Critical Dissertations on the most prominent topics, British and foreign, that form the social history of the past eight years.' Addressed by Dickens in one of his many aliases - the Uncommercial Traveller - these included: beer, criminal law, the workhouse sick, Mormon emigration, police inefficiency, cut-price theatre, the abuse of sailors in the mercantile marine, tramps, the Calais nightmail, the comparison of London to Paris, mass-market catering, Chatham dockyard, the safe manufacture of white-lead, and so on.

Come to think of it, he would have had plenty of trenchant and amusing things to say about Jamie Oliver, Nigella Lawson and the Beckhams. Read a single page from any one of these sparkling entries and you can see at a glance why, in its heyday, All the Year Round enjoyed a circulation larger than that of the Times.

In the end, All The Year Round did not so much cease publication as lose its master's attention. The 'uncommercial traveller' became obsessed by the need to make money and to meet his devoted public. Dickens became caught up in his reading tours, first in Britain and then in America. He died soon after, worn out by his exertions. Edwin Drood was unfinished. These pages awaited the attentions of Professors Slater and Drew.

I hope some literary prize panel celebrates the triumphant conclusion of their work with an appropriate palm. Next to Peter Ackroyd's biography, there is no surer insight into Dickens's extraordinary world. As well as giving the casual reader a scintillating picture of the Victorian milieus in which Dickens was happiest and most at home, this volume, which parallels the composition of Our Mutual Friend and The Mystery of Edwin Drood, is powerfully suggestive of the debt that his novels owed to the life of their author - tireless, high-spirited, voluble and irrepressibly contrarian.

But though Dickens liked a scrap as much as anyone, he also displayed a generosity and largeness of spirit towards his fellow writers that is exceptional. One of the gems of this book is Dickens's In Memoriam: W.M Thackeray, an old rival with whom he was reconciled less than a fortnight before Thackeray's death. 'Humorous... irresistibly extravagant... charming with children.' He might have been describing himself.

fields.headline: An angel at our table
fields.standfirst: Cook, columnist and the Third Most Beautiful Woman in the World, Nigella Lawson has reinvented our notion of domestic bliss. Harriet Lane meets the hostess with the mostest
fields.trailText: Cook, columnist and the Third Most Beautiful Woman in the World, Nigella Lawson has reinvented our notion of domestic bliss. Harriet Lane meets the hostess with the mostest.
fields.body:
Social affairs columnist. Literary commentator. Make-up guru. Food writer. And now TV cook. If you looked up 'multi-tasking' in the dictionary, the words 'Nigella Lawson' would probably appear alongside. But Lawson thinks this is rot. 'In real life, you can be interested in reading a book and in cooking and in lipstick and in politics - the one doesn't take away from the other.' There is no doubt, though, that it is her cooking that has made her a star; and not simply because her pea and garlic soup (much admired by Nigel Slater, who calls her 'the queen of the frozen pea') sent shares in Birds' Eye rocketing. Just as her recent TV series Nigella Bites drew to a close, a survey named her, with admirable precision, the Third Most Beautiful Woman in the World - pipped to the post by one of the Corrs and Catherine Zeta Jones.

Lawson's house in west London is full of people and cooking smells. We have left her husband John Diamond, her tame home economist Hettie Potter and a sizeable group from Vogue (photographer, photographer's assistant, and several people whose job it is to pour olive oil at the appropriate moment) downstairs in the kitchen, monitoring the pizza and cookies for her next food column. Lawson, in a steel-coloured velvet skirt and scarlet cashmere twinset from Anya Hindmarch, with the Maltesers logo embroidered across the bosom in glittery stitches, laughs a hollow laugh when the survey is mentioned.

'Yes, but as John said, "Did they give them multiple choice? Did they give them a list they could chose from?" It's so absurdly flattering that it's alarming. I could do without that, without thinking: "Oh Christ, do I really have to put make-up on whenever I go out?" and, "Oh my God, what about my eye bags?" When we went on holiday, the woman who owned the villa we rented said, "But I was told you were beautiful! It must be the worry." So, of course, it's flattering, but I'm neurotic enough to see the negative in anything positive. It's a great Jewish gift.'

In her cookbooks, though, Lawson sees the positive in the negative. On page 18 of her most recent book, How to be a Domestic Goddess, there is one extraordinary paragraph accompanying one particular cake. 'One warning: don't do what I did for the picture,' writes Lawson, 'which was to colour the lime-curd filling green. I don't know what got into me but I got out my colour paste and my probe and proved in one characteristically rash act that food is better left to its own devices. I decided we could just about live with the menacing green: things do go wrong in cooking and, generally, you can live with them.'

She is right on two fronts. One: the cake does look fairly unappetising - the sort of thing Morticia Addams might have whipped up. And two: yes, we can live with it. Its presence alongside more triumphant confections in this luscious cookbook is entirely reassuring. It offers the cheering knowledge that cookery writers have off days, too ('Well, I try and be honest'), and that kitchen disasters, in any case, tend to taste better than they look. Like the 50s housewives in their heart-shaped pinnies, standing smilingly by their stoves on the endpapers, it trumpets Lawson's ironic intentions.

Not all critics saw it like that on publication, which meant that a cookbook - a book about baking! - was suddenly reinvented as controversial political tract, and found itself bouncing around the the leader columns of the national press. Lawson, who emphasises that she finds cooking therapeutic and does it for her own pleasure rather than in an attempt to please others, was surprised when commentators accused her of betraying the sisterhood, 'because in the introduction I say that I have no desire to confine anyone to the kitchen quarters. And when I talk about "the familial warmth of the kitchen we fondly imagine used to exist", I think I make it clear that I don't believe it ever did. At this moment, the pizza interrupts: it is carried into the room with ceremonial reverence, and placed on a coffee table, where it prepares for its close-up. 'Do you think it could do with a bit of a blowtorch, to make the cheese look wetter, or not?' asks Lawson. Everyone thinks not and, as the shutter clicks, Lawson sits back down, absently rubbing her finger over the ghostly presence of a crayon mark (she and Diamond have two children, Cosima and Bruno) that has appeared on the sofa. The pizza is for Vogue's February issue: Christmas came to Lawson's kitchen months ago. Despite this, she is toying with the idea of cooking for 30 people on 25 December.

'There are two Christmas traditions I've inherited from my mother,' she says. 'One is the feeling that Christmas isn't complete if you haven't got a ham as well as a turkey. It means that the leftovers are much better. And in a curious way, despite the fact that we're talking about Christmas and ham, it's a very Jewish thing to want to provide a huge spread. I always cook for eight, but make enough to feed 30, so this year, I thought I might as well have enough people to eat it. The other thing is putting ground almonds in the brandy butter, which makes it slightly marzipanish.'

She has clear festive memories of her father Nigel (who went on to become the Conservative Chancellor) energetically blending brandy butter 'because it was before machinery'. Her mother, Vanessa, was the heiress to the Lyons Corner House fortune, and an extravagant, instinctive cook who raised her children in the kitchen. It wasn't until Lawson was 14, some time before her parents divorced, that she discovered that most people cooked from recipes. 'Her cooking wasn't really fancy, but I suppose it was considered fancy then because, unlike most food, it was quite Mediterranean.'

Lawson, 40, studied modern languages at Oxford, has lived in Florence, and has similar influences. Her alternative Christmas cake is a British spin on an Italian classic. 'The Certosino I came across through Anna del Conte. She's an Italian who came over here at 18, fell in love with an Englishman, and has been here ever since. While Lawson was a child, Christmas was always spent in London, and a little tense, 'mainly because my mother would overwork and overshop and always burst into tears at some point in the proceedings. And also because my parents made us open our presents after lunch, so of course all you wanted to do was get through lunch and get to the presents. But I always liked the taste of it.' This predilection is genetic. Her great-great-grandmother was such a fan of Christmas dinner that she ate it twice a year: once on 25 December, and once on Midsummer's Day.

In Heartburn, Nora Ephron's novel about a cookery writer whose home life suddenly and frighteningly unravels, the heroine explains, 'What I love about cooking is that after a hard day, there is something comforting about the fact that if you melt butter and add flour and then hot stock, it will get thick! These words must have an extra significance for Lawson, whose mother and sister Thomasina both died of cancer, and whose husband, also a journalist, was diagnosed with throat cancer three years ago. 'But on the other hand, it's about allowing yourself to feel part of the chaos in a safe way, because cooking isn't a precise art. There's a science that dictates what happens to certain ingredients at certain temperatures, but nevertheless you can't have absolute control over the outcome. You have enough control to be interested, but you're allowing yourself to dabble in the chaos, dip your foot into it without feeling there's a risk of drowning in it.'

Just as she cleaves to her mother's Christmas traditions, she is keen to instill her own in Cosima and Bruno. 'You do want your children, when they're older, to remember the things that gave shape to Christmas every year. I want to think of them making the Christmas tree decorations. I first made these by adapting a normal biscuit recipe, and then later I thought it would be nicer to make them more gingerbready, more peppery, not least because this would mean that the children would be less likely to eat them off the tree. They don't have to look perfect, and they're very very easy.'

Lawson considers herself neither a cook nor an expert. She comes at recipes, she says, from the point of view of a very greedy eater. 'If it's something I don't want to carry on eating once I'm full, then I don't want the recipe. I'm quite ruthless. I have to feel that I want to cook the thing again, and more than once. I need to feel that I have to stop myself from cooking it all the time.' Christmas crème brûlée

I don't need to tell you how beautiful this is: you can see. It's extravagant, certainly, but it's meant to be. And it feels like a treat, breaking through that gilt-tortoiseshell crust to the voluptuous depths of egg-nog-scented cream. The tip of freezing the bowl before pouring in the smooth cream-custard I culled from Simon Hopkinson. Serves 8.

600ml double cream
1 tsp orange-flower water
good grating fresh nutmeg
8 large egg yolks
3 tbsp caster sugar
6 tbsp demerara sugar
3-4 sheets edible gold leaf, optional
pie dish approximately 20cm in diameter
chef's blowtorch

Put the pie dish in the freezer for 20 minutes and half-fill the sink with cold water. Put the cream, orange-flower water and a brave grating of fresh nutmeg into a saucepan, and bring to boiling point, but do not let boil. Beat the egg yolks and caster sugar together in a bowl, and pour the flavoured cream over, still beating. Rinse and dry the pan and pour the custard mix back in. Cook over a medium heat until the custard thickens: about 10 minutes. You do want this to be good, voluptuous crème, so don't err on the side of runny caution. Remember you've got your sinkful of cold water to plunge the pan into should it really look as if it's about to split.

When the cream's thick enough, grate over a little more nutmeg and pour into the chilled pie dish. Leave to cool, then put in the fridge till truly cold. Sprinkle with demerara sugar, spoonful by spoonful, and burn with a blowtorch till you have a blistered carapace. Dab edible gold leaf on to the crust, using a pastry brush or your fingertips.

Certosino

75g seedless raisins
30ml Marsala
350g plain flour
2 tsp bicarbonate of soda
150g clear honey
150g caster sugar
40g unsalted butter
3 tbsp water
1 tbsp anise or fennel seeds
1 tsp ground cinnamon
375g Cox's apples (2 medium), roughly grated
200g blanched almonds, coarsely chopped
50g pine nuts
75g bitter chocolate, chopped
75g walnuts, chopped
25cm springform cake tin, buttered and lined

Suggestions for decorating:

4 tbsp apricot jam, to glaze
pecan halves
natural coloured glacé cherries
blanched whole almonds
marrons glacés
glacé fruits

Soak the raisins in the Marsala for 20 minutes and, while they're steeping, preheat the oven to 180C/gas mark 4. Measure the flour and bicarb out into a large bowl. Heat the honey, sugar, butter and water in a saucepan until the sugar dissolves. Add the anise or fennel seeds and cinnamon, pour this mixture over the bowl of flour and bicarb, and stir to combine. Mix in the other ingredients, not forgetting the soaked raisins and their liquid, then spoon into the tin and cook for 45 minutes to 1 hour. When the cake has cooled, heat the apricot jam in a small pan and paint most but not all of it over the top of the cake to glaze and give a sticky surface to which the fruits and so forth will adhere. Decorate with glacé fruits and nuts of your choice, leaving no gaps of cake visible on top. Brush with remaining glaze so all looks shiny.

Christmas biscuits

300g plain flour
pinch of salt
1 tsp baking powder
1 tsp mixed ground spice
1-2 tsp freshly ground pepper
100g unsalted butter
100g dark muscovado sugar
2 large eggs beaten with 4 tbsp runny honey
set of Christmas cutters
2 baking sheets, lined or non-stick

For the icing and trimmings:

300g icing sugar, sieved
3 tbsp boiling water
silver balls or sprinkles, florists' ribbon

Combine the flour, salt, baking powder, mixed spice and pepper in the processor. With the motor on, add the butter and sugar, then, the eggs and honey, though don't use all of this if the pastry has come together before it's used up. Form two discs and put one, covered in clingfilm, into the fridge. Preheat the oven to 170oC/gas mark 3. Dust a surface with flour, roll out the disc, also floured, to about 5mm, and cut out your decorations. Set aside the residue from this first disc, well covered, while you get on with rolling out the second. When you've got both sets of leftover dough, roll out and cut again until all the dough is used up. Now cut out a hole just below the top of every biscuit (for the ribbon). Put on the baking sheets and cook for 20 minutes: it's hard to see when they're cooked, but you can feel; if the underside is no longer doughy, they're ready. Transfer them to cool on a wire rack. Make up ordinary glacé icing by mixing approximately 3 tbsp of boiling water with the icing sugar and stir till you've got a glossy glaze. Ice the cold decorations and scatter sprinkles and sparkles as you like.
