webTitle: Observer review: Venice & the East by Deborah Howard

fields.headline: All aboard the Orient express
fields.standfirst: You thought Venice was a Western city? Think again. Deborah Howard relocates the city of the Doges in Venice & the East
fields.trailText: You thought Venice was a Western city? Think again. Deborah Howard relocates the city of the Doges in Venice & the East
fields.body:
Venice & the East
Deborah Howard
Yale £45, pp290
Buy it at BOL

We all feel the East in Venice, and feel is the operative word. For most of us, it is a sensation, no more, a pervasive hint of Islam in the shapes and shadows of the place, in its brilliant colours, its markets, its crooked back-alleys and the sensuous way it moves. For us, as for generations before us, it is just part of its hallucinatory spell. As Charles Dickens suggestively wrote long ago: 'Opium could not build such a city.'

In this dazzlingly brilliant work of scholarship, Deborah Howard analyses the magical effect, as it developed between the twelfth and sixteenth centuries, and lingers today: 'Demythologising the enchantment,' she calls it.

As a distinguished architectural historian and a Cambridge don, Howard's approach is fastidiously objective. She draws upon a vast range of references, her own knowledge is immense and this sumptuous volume is provided not only with 271 apposite pictures, but with full scholarly paraphernalia. Venice and the East is not an easy book to read, but no serious lover of the city could possibly fail to enjoy and treasure it.

Trade and transportation were at the bottom of Venice's oriental ambience. This was a city of trade, with a trading empire, and the search for commerce took its merchants to most parts of the Muslim world - there were Venetian working colonies in Cairo, Damascus, Acre, Aleppo, Baghdad and even, so Howard assures us, in fifteenth-century Amman, then hardly more than a trading post on the fringe of the desert. Such businessmen, and the sailors who conveyed them, brought back to Venice a vast body of knowledge about Islamic society, not least about architecture in the Islamic world.

As a result, the styles of the East were gradually, and often symbolically, absorbed. The Pharaohs at Alexandria appeared in twelfth-century mosaics of the Basilica as a reminder that it was from Alexandria that the Venetians had acquired the relics of St Mark, guarantees of their city's sanctity.

When in the thirteenth century Venetian architects raised the great domes of the Basilica above the original shallow Byzantine domes, they not only followed Islamic aesthetics, but Islamic techniques too. And who would have guessed that the Doge's Palace, as rebuilt in the 1340s, bore so frank a resemblance, startlingly illustrated here, to the great ceremonial hall erected in Cairo a few years before by the Mamluk Sultan al-Nasir Mohammed?

Yet her own beautifully creative photographs ornament this book, and often and again she reads, too, like an artist straining to be free. And, of course, the miraculous mythos of Venice cannot really be explained by scholars, because it is the indefinable inspiration (as even we agnostics must concede) of art's living, universal God.

webTitle: Observer review: Conquistadors by Michael Wood

fields.headline: Don't get your Incas in a twist
fields.standfirst: The pen is mightier than the screen in Michael Wood's book of the series, Conquistadors
fields.trailText: The pen is mightier than the screen in Michael Wood's book of the series, Conquistadors
fields.body:
Conquistadors
Michael Wood
BBC Books £18.99, pp288
Buy it at BOL

It was confindently predicted that video would kill the TV book. Why bother wading through the text when you simply had to hit 'play' on your remote control and someone would do the reading at you. The flaw in this argument was that people only bought videos to give away as presents and, as a gift, a video lacks some immediacy. You open it, you say thanks, you put it to one side, and, in time, you bin it. Thus it was that the TV book survived.

A good thing, too, for Michael Wood's Conquistadors is even better than his fine television series. It is sufficiently gripping that you soon forget all you were taught at school about how to read history books - 'Fact, fact, fact; on the one hand this, on the other that; it must, of course, not be forgotten; oh, yippee, a double-page illustration... that's the 100 Years War knocked on the head' - and start to enjoy it rather than concentrating on how to precis viciously the contents on to a Post-It note.

Wood's book is divided into four parts: Cortés and Montezuma, Pizarro's conquest of the Incas, Orellana's journey to El Dorado and da Vaca travelling across America to the Pacific. Perhaps most fascinating is the contrast between Cortés and Montezuma who were the respective honchos on 'the first time in history that two civilisations, which had no previous idea of each other, had met'. Cortés 'gambled all and won, but found in victory a strange hollowness'. Montezuma, 'who had been "on the mat", as the Aztecs would say, since 1503', was a believer in fate. When the wise men tell him the signs are bleak, he replies: 'My heart burns as if it is washed in chillies.' Setting a precedent, the gambler showed a greater commitment to the cause than the fatalist, although the fatalist came up with the better lines.

Equally good are the passages devoted to Pizarro conquering the Incas. At the end of August 1527, Pizarro was reduced to drawing a line in the sand on an island off Ecuador and saying: 'Comrades and friends, on that side lies the part which represents death, hardship, hunger, nakedness and abandonment; this side here represents comfort. Here you return to Panama - to be poor! There you may go on to Peru - to be rich.' Only 13 crossed the line with Pizarro. Within a decade, they had conquered Peru.

The book is at its best when interweaving original source material with Wood's travels. It is less good when he is afflicted by backpackery. On page 173, we find Wood 'much as the conquistadors must have done [taking] breakfast of flat bread and olives while Andean kites wheeled overhead'. Within 10 pages, 'we were lifted out by helicopter over mist-shrouded peaks'. Helicopter? How very Incan. This quibble aside, the book is a triumph and far better than the video.

webTitle: Observer review: The Constant Gardener by John Le Carré

fields.headline: The redemption of an unheroic hero
fields.standfirst: John Le Carré reaches beyond the thriller in The Constant Gardener
fields.trailText: John Le Carré reaches beyond the thriller in The Constant Gardener
fields.body:
The Constant Gardener
John Le Carré
Headline £16.99, pp456
Buy it at BOL

John Le Carré's novels may go on the shelves next to Tom Clancy (and sell as many copies) but if his popularity is due to a belief that he adheres to the Boy Scout code of fiction, then his public are reading him for the wrong reasons. His books have been formed by the nature of the Cold War; they are one of the most thorough and historically useful guides to the mentality of those who ran it that we have.

But for this author, the 'spy novel' - if there is such a thing - is a metaphor for examining the extremes of the human soul. What interests him is how far the 'reasonable man' will go if he is pushed. George Smiley may be a fictional construct as loved and universally recognised as Sherlock Holmes but he wins us over because of his humanity, not because of his ability to shoot round corners or deduce things from stray hairs on a carpet.

Since he killed off Smiley, Le Carré's fiction has been an attempt to generalise and diffuse his marvellous creation through various voices and faces, to accomplish, in other words, the traditional task of the novelist. His new novel gives us, unambiguously, the impression that its creator has suffered all the wrongs of man. It may use the form of the thriller but its moral and artistic concerns go well beyond the task of entertainment.

The Constant Gardener starts in the British Embassy in Nairobi, as Sandy Woodrow, the head of chancery, takes a rather nasty phone call. Tessa Quayle, the First Secretary's wife, has been brutally murdered up country. Her companion, Dr Arnold Bluhm, an African as politically committed as she is to the cause of his long-suffering fellow countrymen, has disappeared. Did he murder her? If he didn't, who did? Were they having an affair? And (this is Sandy speaking now) if they were, how in God's name are we going to put the tin lid on the shit hitting the fan?

One of the many pleasures of this book is Le Carré's way with the clichés favoured by the upper-class British establishment. On the novel's opening page, we are told that Sandy takes the shocking news 'like a bullet, jaw rigid, chest out, smack through his divided English heart' and the language is, as so often in Le Carré, intended to deceive. For although Sandy may seem to be the book's hero, he turns out to be acting under impulses that are the very opposite of English decency. Similarly, Justin Quayle, Tessa's husband is, on first acquaintance, brought to our attention as more hooray than hero, a child to Woodrow's man. He is shown holding a brandy glass 'as if it were a prize' and, at her funeral, seems to be standing close enough to her grave to allow it to symbolise the end of his, as well as her, career.

It is only as Justin's quest for his wife's murderers turns into a crusade that this masterly storyteller begins to show his hand. As Quayle flies round the world, on the tail of a sinister pharmaceutical company which has found friends among his English Establishment masters, this second XI Englishman acquires heroic status.

But if redemption through suffering sounds a bit creepily Christian, be not alarmed. Le Carré never lets up on the jeopardy in which he places his central character and the real issues he is confronting - from corruption in Kenya to the self-deception with which embassy wives console themselves - are never out of his sights. This is a work of fierce political intelligence, tackling the key question of the failure of the West to deal with all those things that the collapse of communism should have made easier to confront - Third World poverty, corporate greed and political cynicism.

The Constant Gardener 's conclusion may be sombre, but the book breathes life, anger and excitement until the casual, near brutal realism of its last sentence.

 Nigel Williams will be talking to John Le Carré on The Secret Centre, BBC2, on Boxing Day

webTitle: Observer review: Crying by Tom Lutz

fields.headline: They don't cry at funerals in Bali...
fields.standfirst: ...but over here, we'll shed bucketloads of tears at Leo's death in Titanic. Tom Lutz explores the history of weeping in Crying
fields.trailText: ...but over here, we'll shed bucketloads of tears at Leo's death in Titanic. Tom Lutz explores the history of weeping in Crying
fields.body:
Crying: The Natural and Cultural History of Tears
Tom Lutz
Norton £11.95, pp352
Buy it at BOL

Weeping is merely a physiological function, but like many such functions, it has taken on a bewilderingly varied set of cultural meanings. The conventions surrounding weeping vary from culture to culture, and from age to age. Sometimes a culture starts to regard ostentatious weeping with approval and admiration; at other times, the same culture can change its mind, and weeping becomes something to be done in the dark, in solitude, and regarded with shame.

In some places and at some times, it has been a formal demonstration of feeling rather than a spontaneous expression of it, like the rending of hair or the ululation of Middle Eastern funerals; at other times and places, such as our own, it is only regarded as proper when it is unplanned and sincere. Sometimes it is a feminine pursuit or, as Hobbes said, the prerogative of the powerless members of society, women and babies; at others, generals and politicians weep openly and are applauded for it.

What the function of tears is, no one really knows. The sort of tears which derive from emotion have a different chemical make-up to those which lubricate the eyeball, or are called forth by a reflex response to an onion or a poke in the eye. It has generally been supposed that crying offers some sort of safety valve for the emotions, and a person who never cries is merely storing up psychic trouble for himself, but the truth is that we don't really understand it.

People who don't cry, such as the hero of Camus's L'étranger, may be regarded as suspicious or even criminal; those who cry too readily are just as open to ridicule. It's a sort of unfair last resort in personal relations; there is no arguing with a girl in tears. Personally, I've always thought that the sort of people who cry easily at the cinema are exactly the sort of people who wouldn't make much of an effort to comfort a bereaved friend, or help in times of disaster. The harmless, meaningless shedding of tears at Titanic can reassure the stony-hearted that they, too, are sensitive and caring, and it is interesting that people are almost always eager to tell of the occasions when they cried.

Now that, in the wake of Princess Diana's funeral, we have become so very lachrymose a nation, and so convinced of the inevitable sincerity of tears, it is curious to read of conventions which governed weeping in the past. Probably most societies, at most times, have employed professional weepers at funerals, and never saw anything wrong or odd in it. If weeping at the funerals of adults is a more or less universal practice - only in Bali does it fairly definitely not happen - then other occasions come and go as moments to cry.

Plenty of cultures regard it as actively improper to cry at the death of a child. And, in a way, although we no longer regard it as shameful, we probably don't think of it as a particularly elevated activity, in the way that the eighteenth century did. Jackie Kennedy was praised for not shedding tears at the President's funeral; the occasion was too solemn and awful for that. And though there are some who, three years ago, were constantly urging the royal family to blub in public, the attitude which thinks that the Queen should not make a display of emotion at a state occasion prevailed, and remains the predominant opinion. Some thoughts, as Wordsworth said, lie too deep for tears.

Whether we are entering on an age, like the fourteenth century or the late-eighteenth century, where girls will wash their father's feet with their tears, remains to be seen. As yet, it is as much a target for ridicule as anything else. Paul Gascoigne became an absurd, Stan Laurel-like figure with his public weeping. No one trusts a politician when he cries: George Bush was a famous blubber, and Bob Dole lost all credibility when he was seen crying at Nixon's funeral. A novelist should think hard before he makes a character cry, and it is a daring film-maker who asks an actress to turn on the tears. As the theatrical adage has it, if you cry and they cry, that's OK; if you don't and they do, that's better; if you do and they don't, that's a disaster. And that is certainly as true for ordinary human relations as it is for anything else.

Tom Lutz has written an engaging and entertaining book which can't really be regarded as a history of crying, but rather as a series of curious snippets. It's a bit parochial, so that you are expected to know who Barbara Walters is, but need to be told that London is in England. His examples tend to be taken from American politicians - most readers will find it odd that he doesn't mention the Princess of Wales's funeral, which was such an international public demonstration of a shift in weeping habits.

All the same, it is a pleasant jog through a deeply interesting subject - how fascinating to know that American men, incredibly, now weep an average of four times a month. And he agreeably keeps clear of psychobabbling injunctions to weep, and in the end sees the insignificance of weeping. As Heine very truly said: 'Whatever tears one sheds, in the end, one always blows one's nose.'

fields.headline: Betty's memoirs spark £650,000 bidding war
fields.trailText: Betty Boothroyd is used to being at the centre of things. For eight years, she presided over the House of Commons as its first woman Speaker. But the past few days have surprised even her.
fields.body:
Betty Boothroyd is used to being at the centre of things. For eight years, she presided over the House of Commons as its first woman Speaker. But the past few days have surprised even her.

Only two months after leaving her post, publishers have offered more than half a million pounds for her memoirs in a bidding war that already puts her on a footing with some of the most successful political diarists of recent times - Alan Clark, Margaret Thatcher, Chris Patten and Edward Heath.

The figure involved reached £650,000 as this weekend approached and a deal is expected next week.

Boothroyd's literary agent Lisanne Radice, of Gregory and Radice, said she had been 'surprised and rather shaken' by the level of interest.

Two publishers are going head-to-head for the final round, but Radice said they are not Bloomsbury and Hodder and Stoughton which had both been interested.

'We have only a synopsis so far,' said Radice yesterday. 'I don't know exactly what these people are hoping for.'

The one-volume account is to cover Boothroyd's long political career as well as her brief spell as a dancer with the Tiller Girls. It will not be finished in time for the general election.

Radice said the memoir promised to buck the recent trend for political biographies to sell badly. 'These things entirely depend on the person,' she said. 'She is an exceptional person and one who will appeal right across the field.

'She is well known in the US and is very forthcoming, much more interesting to the general public than most members of the Cabinet.'

Boothroyd, who has been made a life peer, admitted in a television documentary screened four days ago that she had been proposed to three times, but had decided not to marry. She is rumoured to have led a colourful life, although friends insist she plans her book to be proper in tone.

Publishing political biography is risky, however, and the market has recently been saturated. Some, such as John Major's, do well (selling 15,000 copies in its first three weeks), while others, such as Norman Lamont's, make little impact, (selling only 619 in the same period).

'It is hard to see how this book can possibly make that kind of money for its publisher,' said a leading commissioning editor working in the political market.

'There just isn't the interest out there,' he added. 'And the timing is wrong. She will have been out of office for some time and the election will overshadow all political stories for most of next year.'

In 1995 the journalist Paul Routledge published a biography of Boothroyd, but she refused to co-operate.

The new memoirs will be written with the help of Michael Jones, a journalist friend of Boothroyd's for two decades.

webTitle: Focus: Is there a liberal elite?

fields.headline: Is there a liberal elite?
fields.standfirst: 'These people are everywhere that matters' the Right complains, as William Hague vows to defeat them.  Ben Summerskill  reports  on New Labour's network of movers and shakers
fields.trailText: 'These people are everywhere that matters' the Right complains, as William Hague vows to defeat them. Ben Summerskill reports on New Labour's network of movers and shakers
fields.body:
Readers of political tea leaves should have seen it coming. Two weeks ago the Daily Mail announced that liberalism had 'destroyed the values that once made this country safe to live in'. Last Friday William Hague - that most assiduous student of Daily Mail sensibilities - proclaimed in almost perfect harmony that the next Tory government would 'take on and defeat a liberal elite'.

Cue stupefaction from Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee, pin-up of the liberal Left and the only person named by Hague as a member of this dangerous posse. 'Liberal elite? Moi?' was the plaintive tone of the piece penned by Toynbee for Friday's Guardian. Toynbee insisted: 'It is quite difficult to be an elite of just one.'

As Hague prepares to revive his theme in a new pamphlet for the think-tank Politeia this week, is Toynbee really so isolated from the world that influences New Labour? Perhaps she could ask her admirer Gavyn Davies. He has just been appointed deputy chairman of the BBC. The partner of Sue Nye, assistant to Gordon Brown, Davies will no doubt get on roaringly well when he arrives at Broadcasting House next year.

He is already acquainted with the BBC's political editor Andrew Marr, a distinguished liberal. Marr, a former columnist on this paper, is husband of New Statesman political editor Jackie Ashley, the daughter of Labour grandee Jack. Davies might also run into Newsnight presenter Jeremy Paxman, the man who once applied to edit the New Statesman with a covering letter pledging: 'I consider myself a socialist. I believe in disarmament. I favour abolition of the House of Lords.' And, of course, Greg Dyke - appointed BBC director-general by New Labour - is a veteran donor to Labour Party coffers. A sympathetic psychiatrist might understand why the Tories get paranoid.

'These people are everywhere that matters,' complains Peter Hitchens, one of the right-wing columnists whom Toynbee, for her part, insists litter the British press. 'It's like a quiet version of anglicanism. Benevolent, mild, not given to wild enthusiasm.'

And the views they bring with them are deeply disquieting to souls like Hitchens. Almost all of them quietly espouse the values of multiculturalism, Europeanism, sexual liberalism and equality. No wonder traditionalists shudder.

'There are hordes of hangers-on to this government,' says Spectator editor Boris Johnson. 'We're surrounded by hundreds of great liberal Titans. Very few of us are foamingly right-wing nowadays so admission to this group is not difficult.'

The Guardian and The Observer are hotbeds of this pervasive liberalism, according to its trackers. A former special adviser to a Cabinet Minister admits: 'If [ Guardian editor] Alan [Rusbridger] calls, you take the call. You might not listen, but he has access, as do many of his colleagues.'

The monster feared by Hague lurks in the rest of the media too. Alan Yentob, one of the BBC's most powerful commissioners, is on the list. As are TV producers Waheed Alli, the Big Breakfast founder ennobled by New Labour, and his work partner Charlie Parsons. Just like Yentob, Alli is not white-skinned, causing as much disquiet to his Tory opponents in the House of Lords as the fact that he is openly gay. A senior Tory peer described Alli the other day as 'queer as the ace of spades', a splendid conjunction of the prejudices the liberal elite likes to challenge.

The constellation of think-tankers includes the well-connected Matthew Taylor, head of the Institute for Public Policy Research, Rabbi Julia Neuberger at the Kings Fund, and Will Hutton, head of the Industrial Society and an Observer columnist. As they network earnestly - policy lunches are as popular as drinks parties - they draw in single-issue campaigners such as Sheila McKechnie at the Consumers' Association, Stonewall director Angela Mason, and Commission for Racial Equality chief Susie Parsons. All meet Ministers regularly.

'These people are bien pensants, but they're not in touch,' claims Nigel Waterson, the Tory frontbencher who first denounced the 'elite' last summer. 'We now spend so much of our time discussing things that these metropolitan types are concerned with. They don't understand the true concerns of people around the country.'

Waterson might also be miffed at how many of his former colleagues now mix with the liberals. Chris Patten turns up at parties. Had you visited Daily Express editor Rosie Boycott's Notting Hill home the other evening you would have seen, chatting to the Independent's Yasmin Alibhai-Brown, John Stevens, ex-Tory MEP and pin-up of his former party's Europhile rump.

As disconcerting to the Tories as their own turncoats are the horde of businessmen - and some women - who front worthy government initiatives. Lord (Dennis) Stevenson is chairman of Pearson. He is helping to select people's peers. Derek Higgs, former £600,000-a-year boss of Prudential, is 'on side'. Even Kate Barker, chief economist at the CBI, is described by a Labour figurehead as 'influential and sympathetic'.

At Boycott's home you will also meet Philip Gould, the government's most influential focus groupie, and his publisher wife Gail Rebuck. The multi-millionaire head of Random House, she wields a contact book which networks the worlds of publishing and the arts. And it goes without saying that almost everyone in it is on side.

Helena Kennedy, Howard Davis, Bernard Crick, Anna Coote, Maggie Rae, Richard and Ruth Rogers, Julia Cleverdon, Jonathan Porritt, Adair Turner, Jon Snow, Michael Grade, Sue Slipman. The catalogue of sympathisers plugged into the grid is huge.

For many, rewards have already come; Andreas Whittam Smith is in charge of the British Board of Film Classification, Gerry Robinson heads the Arts Council. Who's up for a 30-strong list of working Labour peers in the new parliament is the talk of New Labour salons this winter.

But why should they be embarrassed? 'Twas ever thus,' says one of the best-known of the elite. 'The fact we have the government we have at present means that inevitably there is a network of people who know one another and mix socially and professionally and pass on their hunches and prejudices and instincts. It's access, and access is power.'

'We try and have influence with Ministers,' admits Polly Toynbee diffidently. 'But we gnash our teeth that they don't actually listen.'

Peter Hitchens retorts: 'Polly has nothing to worry about. Important people heed what she says. If I turned up at one of these events I'd be treated as if my knuckles were brushing the ground.'

Are you among the liberal elite?

Answer this simple questionnaire to place yourself in the pecking order:

1 Does columnist Polly Toynbee live in...

a. London WC1

b. Combe Florey

c. Surbiton?

2 Philip Gould and Gail Rebuck's £1 million home is situated conveniently close to...

a. Millbank Tower

b. The British Library

c. Camden (state) School for Girls

3 The River Café reservations number is ...

a. In your personal organiser

b. In your head

c. No need to book. Ruthie always finds you a table

4 Which close friend of Cherie's was John Birt's executive assistant at the BBC?

a. Valerie Davis

b. Maggie Rae

c. Katy Kay

5 At home, (Lord) Roy Jenkins prefers his fruit...

a. Straight from the vine

b. Puréed

c. Peeled by Dame Jennifer

6 Your copy of Al Gore's Earth in the Balance was given to you by ...

a. Jonathon Porritt

b. Gordon Brown

c. Al Gore

7 During the winter months Alastair and his policy pals go ice-skating where?

a. Somerset House

b. The Sobell Centre, Islington

c. The Rockefeller Centre

8 Waheed's last invitation to you was...

a. To lunch at the Lords

b. To dinner with Charlie

c. To a house party with masked ball

9 Will Hutton's mobile phone number begins...

a. 0778

b. 0931

c. 0896

10 Have you ever had...

a. coffee

b. lunch

c. an affair

...with Matthew Taylor, director of the IPPR?

Check the answers to test your mettle

Answers

1. a 2 points; minus 1 for b - Combe Florey is home to Telegraph columnist Auberon Waugh

2. c 2 points

3. a 1 point b 2 points c 3 points

4. c 2 points

5. c 4 points

6. a 1 point b 2 points c 3 points

7. b 3 points

8. a 1 point b 2 points c 3 points

9. a 2 points

10. a 1 point, b 2 points; minus 2 for c. Politics is more important than pleasure, thank you

How did you score?

More than 14: You are one of the liberal elite and probably already on the board of a major public body. Expect to hear from the honours secretary shortly

7-13: You are on the fringes of power. Anticipate a quango appointment within the next Parliament

6 or less: Your help delivering leaflets will always be much appreciated

webTitle: Dome boss gets £100,000 bonus as attendance falls

fields.headline: Dome boss gets £100,000 bonus as attendance falls
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The chief executive of the Millennium Dome is in line to receive a £100,000 bonus, despite the number of visitors to the attraction slumping to the lowest levels since the beginning of the year.
fields.body:
The chief executive of the Millennium Dome is in line to receive a £100,000 bonus, despite the number of visitors to the attraction slumping to the lowest levels since the beginning of the year.

Pierre-Yves Gerbeau will receive the money from the board of the New Millennium Experience Company (NMEC) on top of his £100,000 salary.

The controversial deal comes as the Prime Minister plans his first visit to the Dome since the shambolic New Year's Eve celebrations.

Senior Downing Street sources said Tony Blair was keen to visit the attraction this week to avoid the embarrassment of not going to the Dome at all during the year.

'We are trying to fit it into his diary,' the source said. 'He will say again that he admits that the Dome has not been the success that everyone hoped, but that for the people who have gone it has been an enjoyable experience.'

The controversial 'double salary' bonus was agreed with Gerbeau when he was appointed to run the struggling attraction from Euro Disney. Critics of the Dome expressed surprise that Gerbeau, known as P-Y, was to receive such a large amount. He will receive the bonus after hitting agreed attendance targets, although those were well below the 12 million visitors it was originally said would visit the attraction.

Since Gerbeau has been in charge there have been rows over the number of discounted tickets that have been sold to schoolchildren, price-cutting in the shops and the low number of visitors.

Earlier this month NMEC announced that just under 400,000 people went to the attraction in November, compared with more than 650,000 in October. Only one month, January, has seen lower figures.

Gerbeau, who begins a round of farewell interviews with an appearance on the BBC's Breakfast with Frost this morning, is planning a low-key goodbye party at the Dome next week before hundreds of staff are laid off.

Some will be kept on to help with decommissioning the attractions inside the Dome, which will then be auctioned off at the end of February. NMEC officials hope that the auction will raise between £2 million and £5m. It cost more than £240m to build the attractions in the first place.

webTitle: 'They were smart and they wore suits. They hurt me'

fields.headline: 'They were smart and they wore suits. They hurt me'
fields.standfirst:
Amelia Hill reveals the horrific plight of young girls from around the world who are shipped to Britain to work as child prostitutes. Too terrified to break free from their captors, they are locked into a world of sexual cruelty, exploitation and drugs - something the police and social services are only now waking up to.

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Amelia Hill reveals the horrific plight of young girls from around the world who are shipped to Britain to work as child prostitutes. Too terrified to break free from their captors, they are locked into a world of sexual cruelty, exploitation and drugs - something the police and social services are only now waking up to.
fields.body:
Fayemi was slumped in the back of the car. She had injected herself with a shot of heroin shortly before we met last week and was just finishing smoking a rock of crack-cocaine to get a fresh high. She had not eaten for two days, but she did not care.

Fayemi is 14. She has already seen and done things that no one should ever have to experience. She has wide, dark eyes and childishly translucent skin. But the life she has been forced to lead has aged her, causing wrinkles round her eyes more often found in a much older woman.

Six months ago, Fayemi's father sold her to two men who visited their village in Nigeria. She saw the men speak to her father and hand him money, but she had no idea what it was about until she was bundled into a car.

When they reached Lagos airport, Fayemi was handed to a woman who already had two other girls trailing behind her. The woman gave the three girls sweets and fizzy drinks - and they were waved through immigration. Fayemi slept throughthe flight: 'I was tired,' she says in halting English. 'My eyes were closed all the time.'

At Gatwick, the group was met by two men. Dazed and drained, Fayemi didn't resist when one of them took her away. She had never been out of her village and in this strange and terrifying new world, she had no choice but to stick close to the only adult who seemed to care what happened to her.

The man took her to a flat in London. There were five other girls. The oldest was about 18; the youngest, Maria, was just six. 'She came from Nigeria like me,' Fayemi said. 'But the others came from far away. I could not understand their words.'

Men came to the flat every day. 'From early, early and then late also. They were smart. They wore suits. They hurt me.' Sometimes Fayemi was taken to their offices and sometimes they came to the flat. She was never left alone and any money she was given by the men who came to have sex with her was immediately taken away.

She hated her new life. She protested and the men who ran the brothel gave her some heroin and showed her how to inject it. It was her first introduction to drugs. 'It made it hurt more little,' she said, twisting her matted hair tightly between delicate fingers.

Two weeks ago, Fayemi climbed out of the window of the flat and ran away. She now spends between 10pm to 6am every day walking the streets of East London, dressed in the long fake fur coat and pink trousers given to her when she reached England.

She wants the cars to stop because she needs the money but every time someone slows down, she is terrified. 'The men said they would kill me if I left. It true.' She started to cry. Tomorrow, she said, she would go further away; a girl she met suggested Nottingham or perhaps Croydon. She's not sure where they are. Someone else suggested somewhere called 'Scomland'.

The trafficking of children into Britain for the purposes of sexual slavery was virtually unheard of four years ago. Many organisations refuse to accept that it is happening: 'There's no evidence at all that foreign girls are being bought into this country and set to work as prostitutes,' said Jane Ayres, director of the Praed Street Project in Charing Cross, a highly respected, government-funded body. But an Observer investigation has uncovered incontrovertible evidence that foreign girls as young as 11 are being trafficked to work as prostitutes in flats around London.

These girls are not only victims of sexual exploitation, but are here illegally and under the age of consent. Every caution is taken by their pimps to escape detection: the children's services are not advertised, they never work outdoors and, although they sometimes visit punters in their homes or offices, they are accompanied by their jailers from the moment they leave the flat to the minute they return.

The Observer has found a small number of children who have escaped their masters working on the streets of South and East London. All are too terrified of authority and of adults to ask for help, believing that whatever terrible treatment they have suffered, the Government and police will do little to help them.

These girls eke out lives of terrible danger: unless they can persuade another brothel to take them in - a highly unlikely option, given their illegal age and status in the country - they must walk the streets in a city whose language they cannot speak and whose mores are alien to them.

'There are three girls on the block here who are obviously underage and barely speak English,' said Gemma, who has been working as a prostitute since her mother stood her on a street corner at the age of 11. Within months, her brother had bought two false passports and two tickets to England. 'I wore different hair and different clothes,' she said, twisting in her seat and shredding the cigarette packet in front of her. Her attention was starting to fail: it had been a couple of hours since she smoked her last rock of crack-cocaine and her friend hasn't returned yet with the fresh supply she was sent to buy.

Chanel's brother set up her in a flat in London with other four girls. 'No English girls,' she said. 'There was a Romanian girl with a baby. She was young like me but the men came to look at the baby without any clothes. I don't think they touched it; they just watched.'

The only time she managed to save a few pounds, her brother beat her so badly she was bruised from her lower thigh to her shoulder. He didn't hit her face, though; that came courtesy of a recent customer.

Six months ago, she ran away. After drifting around the city in terror, she turned up in Brixton. Her days now start at 11pm with a visit to the crack house on the corner of Brixton Hill and end at around 6am, after the morning rush of businessmen has ended.

Her brother, furious to be deprived of his easy income, tracked his sister down and set fire to her flat at a time when she should have been asleep inside. The heat of the fire was so intense that the windows exploded but Chanel had gone out earlier.

The fire destroyed her few possessions. And now she is homeless. In the past week she has slept outside in the bitter cold or in the house of punters, one of whom raped her while she was sleeping.

'My mother doesn't know where I am. I haven't seen her for two years,' she said. 'It's Christmas soon and I want to go home but I am in too much trouble.' Detective Inspector Paul Holmes, of Scotland Yard's clubs and vice unit, the only pro-active organisation in the country targeting prostitution, has admitted he is horrified by the result of The Observer 's investigation. 'The problem of girls being trafficked for sexual purposes is a major one but this is worse than anything we have encountered so far,' he said.

'This is the first intelligence we have had that we have a problem in relation to young girls rather than girls in their late teens, and we can't even prove that those girls, who are mostly Albanian girls hidden in Soho flats, are underage because they're almost impossible to find and have false ID,' he added.

The issue is so new that experts admit it is impossible to know what started the trend. They suggest the strength of sterling, the widening global gap between rich and poor, and point out the fact that even though our ports and airports have tightened up their immigration controls, Eurostar offers an easy route in. Others point to the fact that while under the current law, traffickers risk nothing more than a fine or, at worst, less than two years' imprisonment, drug traffickers risk at least 10 years. Set this against the enormous profit traffickers of women and children are already making - an estimated $7 billion in 1998 - and it seems more pertinent to ask why didn't this happen earlier?

Nicola Mullenger, a worker for Mainliners, a drug outreach project funded by Lambeth, South wark and Lewisham councils, compares the trend to the entry of Coca-cola into Eastern Europe after the wall came down in 1989. 'It's completely unexploited territory here,' she said. 'Britain is a gift to them.'

Professor David Barrett, the country's leading expert on child prostitution, believes numbers of child victims of trafficking have been increasing at the rate of 15 per cent each year for the last three years. He predicts an explosive rise unless action is taken.

'There are probably around 1,600 women trafficked into Britain each year and so to maintain that we're just a staging post when children are concerned is bordering on the foolishly naive. Race and youth both have price premiums in this country just as in any other. You have to imagine the lives some of these girls have been leading: they've lived in gut-wrenching poverty in war-torn countries with not the slightest hope of escape,' Barrett said.

'Once their self-esteem has been completely destroyed and they have dulled their response to the abuse of prostitution, life in a rich, western world can offer them some advantages over the family that betrayed them and to whom they can never return now anyway.'

Doodle, one of the many dealers in Brixton who sell drugs to the local girls - who will visit him up to 20 times a night, spending their money as they earn it - said: 'I've seen a massive rise in the number of young, foreign girls coming to my flat in the last 18 months. It's a new and fascinating world to them: £10 is £1,000 to them - they think they're in heaven.'

''When I was 11, I was walking down the street outside my house in Nottingham when these men passed and said things to me that I didn't understand. I filmed them having sex with me and then threatened to tell. I asked them for more than £3,000 each. It's a shame it didn't work - I hate punters: they're all bastards.'

webTitle: Drivers who kill face jail for 10 years

fields.headline: Drivers who kill face jail for 10 years
fields.standfirst: Police given tough powers to seize cars
fields.trailText: Police given tough powers to seize cars
fields.body:
Britain's most dangerous drivers are facing a major clampdown, including prison sentences of up to 10 years and the impounding of their cars, as the Government attempts to defuse public anger at lenient sentences for motorists who break the law.

In a raft of measures to be announced this week, the Government will say it wants to see more people disqualified for speeding and drinking and driving, harsher sentences for drivers who kill people in car crashes, a special, separate punishment system for people who drive faster than 100mph and community service orders for motorists who habitually break the law.

Among the most controversial proposals being considered by the Home Office and the Department of Transport are new police powers to impound cars for 'short, sharp shock' punishment. The 'temporary forfeiture' rules would be used to stop people who continue to drive when banned.

'Disqualification will not just mean losing your licence,' a highly placed government source said. 'It will mean losing your car as well.'

Research has shown that as many as 800,000 people are driving in Britain without a licence or insurance and that nearly all serious accidents are caused by a hard core of 'flyers' - motorists, often young men, who break the driving laws most often.

In another radical step, people who have killed or injured pedestrians or passengers because of dangerous driving will be forced to work in hospitals under a new community punishment order.

'People will work in a casualty department for a month, for example,' said a source who has been consulted on the report to be published by the Home Office on Tuesday. 'That way they could see something of the damage they cause by their actions.'

The Government will urge courts to use the full range of powers against dangerous drivers. Although motorists can be sentenced to up to 10 years in prison for causing death by dangerous driving, one official said there was no record of a judge handing down such a sentence.

A 'two-strikes' rule will also be proposed, banning drivers for anything up to 10 years if they are involved in a second drink-driving or serious speeding offence. Lifetime bans will be considered for drivers who break the law three times.

Many more motorists will also be forced to go through re-education lessons and to re-take their test after a second offence.

'This is not anti-motorist, it is anti-dangerous motorist,' said a senior government source. 'We want to hit the dangerous motorist, and hit them hard.'

The Government's action comes as part of its road safety strategy, which has set targets for reducing road deaths by 40 per cent for adults and 50 per cent for children.

'The Home Office has to be aware that it is the multiple-offenders who are the problem,' said John Dawson, head of campaigns for the AA.

'Nearly 3,500 people were killed on Britain's roads last year and 40,000 people were injured. The public will support any action against those who cause death by their recklessness.'

The present 12-points system for banning drivers who break the law will also be looked at. A 20-point system is being considered so that courts can differentiate more clearly between minor and serious motoring crimes.

Charles Clarke, the Home Office Minister who will launch the report, has privately told colleagues that he has 'great sympathy' for families who are furious about short sentences handed down to motorists whose dangerous driving has led to deaths.

Last Christmas there was a furious reaction when Bruce Taylor, a van driver from Elgin in the north-east of Scotland, was given 300 hours of community serviceinstead of a prison sentence. He had killed a teenager after failing to slow down at a 'give way' sign.

webTitle: Leader:   Racism that shames the Opposition

fields.headline: Hague's folly
fields.standfirst:
Racism that shames the Opposition

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Racism that shames the Opposition
fields.body:
William Hague last week claimed that a liberal élite had indiscriminately branded Britain's police as racist. In making his carefully planned attack, the leader of the Opposition plumbed new depths. Not only were the statistics used to prove his case embarrassingly wrong; everything was wrong.

It betrays a politician at his wits' end for ideas and vividly demonstrates the current intellectual and moral bankruptcy of the Right. Mr Hague claims that the Macpherson Report's condemnation of institutional racism inside London's Metropolitan Police is used as blanket condemnation of every police officer in Britain. No such blanket condemnation is made. But we have to confront brute reality; the Lawrence inquiry exposed institutional racism, and Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir John Stevens and his colleagues have been right to respond by trying to root it out.

If Mr Hague is against this, he should say so. Equally, the Tory leader must recognise that all contemporary Western legal systems have sought to move away from vigilante justice in which the sole concern is to assuage the understandably high emotions of the victims of crime. The criminal justice system is meant instead to represent an objective standard of sentencing and to balance deterrence with rehabilitation and atonement. This view is not the preserve of a liberal élite: it is the tried and tested approach of all mature societies towards justice.

The causes of crime are not that we permit insufficient vigilantism and wrongly accuse the police of racism. They lie, as they always have, in a complex relationship between individual proclivities to criminality and acute personal and social distress. The response requires a combination of smart policing, a fair justice system and measures to redress the economic and social well-springs from which crime flows. Mr Hague invites us in this - as in his approach to Europe, tax and minority groups - to be negative, defensive and fearful. If this is the best the Tory leader can offer, he and his party will deserve their drubbing at the next election.

webTitle: Paparazzi lie in wait for the fresher prince

fields.headline: Paparazzi lie in wait for the fresher prince
fields.standfirst:
Town defies media invasion and pledges to defend William as 'just another student', reports Stuart Millar

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Town defies media invasion and pledges to defend William as 'just another student', reports Stuart Millar
fields.body:
It could be a scene from a low-rated disaster movie: the population of a historic and genteel small town go about their Christmas shopping, blissfully unaware of the mayhem advancing in their direction. Occasionally, there are little rumblings of the trouble ahead, nervous whispers hinting at an inevitable fate, before those who voice their concern are dismissed with a complacent smile.

Welcome to St Andrews, the ancient university burgh set to be the epicentre of the biggest tabloid frenzy since the death of Diana: the transformation of her eldest son from awkward schoolboy to bona fide public figure. In other words, fair game.

Ten months before Prince William arrives to begin his four-year art history degree, the first signs are emerging of the extent to which St Andrews will be subjected to the relentless, unforgiving glare of global press attention. Locals report that the two biggest tabloids, the Sun and the Mirror, have already bought houses in the Fife town, opening manoeuvres in what is certain to be a ruthless game to secure the ultimate William stories.

The stakes were raised again last week with the wall-to-wall publication of pictures of the prince enjoying his gap year on an Operation Raleigh project in Chile. Cleaning toilets in his Marigolds, play-wrestling with local kids, mucking in with his fellow volunteers: every picture was part of the royal family's carefully honed campaign to rescue its out-of-date image by selling William as just an ordinary, modern, fun-loving 18-year-old.

The plan of St James's Palace is to protect the prince from the worst ravages of paparazzi attention by releasing just enough footage of him to satisfy the royal-watching public's voracious appetite. Before the Patagonian coverage, there were the Union Jack waistcoat shots from Eton to mark his 18th birthday, and before that, pictures of him aged 17, looking nervous with his father and brother at Highgrove before his driving test.

But the strategy carries dangers: with each new photo or interview, the palace risks losing control of William coverage. In the aftermath of Diana's death, the press agreed that the two young princes should be left alone to complete their schooling.

Now, as he is deliberately shaped into a sought-after public figure, the tall, dashing, youthful saviour of the monarchy, the media may feel justified in taking the gloves off. And the venue for that showdown will be among the spires and huddled lanes of St Andrews. Last week, however, there was little evidence that this realisation has dawned on the town. Under a winter sun that did nothing to ease the chill off the North Sea, locals were more bored than concerned by the royal arrival.

'We're sick of hearing about him,' complained one man. 'He'll either fit in or he won't. Whichever way, we'll not be bothering him if he doesn't bother us.' His wife was more sympathetic. 'I'm sure everybody will respect his privacy. It'll be strange at first but I'm sure it'll all calm down quickly enough.'

From the university's hierarchy to first-year students, from councillors to local pensioners, St Andrews, both town and gown, is happily convinced that William will be 'just another student'.

The only clue to the contrary is the understandable reluctance of estate agents to discuss the clients behind the upsurge in demand for property that has coincided with the announcement of the prince's university choice. 'I don't think we would have anything to say on that at all. Sorry,' said the polite woman from Murray Donald and Caithness before putting down the phone.

The tone is being set by the university itself. Professor Colin Vincent, the vice-chancellor, told the General Council it was 'important for the whole university, students, academic staff, domestic and other workers alike, to recognise that we must protect this member of our community and never seek to exploit his, or indeed any other, student's presence in our midst'.

The university's official response to media inquiries is well-meaning. 'As with all successful applicants, the university will look forward to welcoming him to our community next year,' a spokeswoman told The Observer. 'We have every confidence that St Andrews will offer Prince William the opportunity to continue his education in a unique, nourishing and challenging environment.'

And the inevitable influx of journalists and photographers baying for access to the prince? 'The university aims to continue dealing with press interest in the same way it has up until now, co-operating with all reasonable requests as and when they arise.' Jane Ann Liston, one of the town's three Liberal Democrat councillors, also dismissed any suggestion that St Andrews would be swamped by the William media tidal wave.

'We are used to being in the spotlight with the golf, so I think most of the locals couldn't care a rat about William or the media. As far as I'm concerned he is just another student and he should be given the chance to be exactly that. He has said he wants to just be called William and he is entitled to his privacy, so I - and most of the other people in the town feel the same - will take great pleasure in getting in the way of the paparazzi if we find they are getting irritating.'

Even the student association, former hotbed of right-wing political manoeuvring and bad behaviour, is content to regurgitate the official line that William will slip effortlessly into university life without so much as a ripple. Simone Thomson, the association's vice-president communications, in a familiar refrain, said: 'Our position will always be the same: he is just another student here.'

Those with a better understanding of what William represents to the press sound a more cautious note. 'These are interesting times, because the press still has to be careful,' said Max Clifford, the tabloid PR guru. 'It's still not open season on William and editors are looking on it with caution. They can't do anything that will annoy the Press Complaints Commission, so they will have to tread carefully at first to find a balance, yet they are mad keen to get him, particularly with girlfriends or at parties.

'He has huge potential for the tabloids. His mother was the biggest star of the tabloid world.' Locals like Cllr Liston believe William may attract worse irritants than the world's media. 'I think an even bigger difficulty could be an influx of rich young girls, mainly Americans, who want to snare him and become queen,' she said. 'St Andrews already has enough yas of its own, and they all have very loud, annoying voices.'

webTitle: US microchip to make mobile phones safer

fields.headline: US microchip to make mobile phones safer
fields.standfirst: Special report: mobile phone fears
fields.trailText: Worries about radiation from mobile phones may be over thanks to a new device developed by American scientists and the US military due to go on sale in Britain within months.
fields.body:
Worries about radiation from mobile phones may be over thanks to a new device developed by American scientists and the US military due to go on sale in Britain within months.

The BioChip, a tiny microchip that fits into the battery of the mobile phone, makes safe the signals created during a phone call that experts say can damage the cells of the brain. Mobile phones emit an electrical impulse whose strong, regular rhythm has been proved to cause serious stress in cell walls. The BioChip produces another impulse which disrupts the rhythm, stopping stress in the cells. 'The chip emits a weak electromagnetic impulse which mimicks the natural impulse that the cell is used to,' said the chip's manufacturer, Dr Thomas Magnussen. 'The impulse is engineered so that it prevents the cells from picking up the regular rhythm coming from the phone signal.'

More than half of British adults use mobile phones, and for years there have been fears over their safety. The Department of Health recently asked that phones sold in the run-up to Christmas should carry pamphlets asking adults to use them for no more than 20 minutes, and that children should use them only in an emergency.

The BioChip is the first device to offer a safer mobile phone since it was suggested this year that hands-free sets might concentrate the radiation on the user and worsen any possible health risks.

'The effects on cells of electromagnetic radiation from mobile phones are quite disturbing and well defined,' said Magnussen. 'The body's cells go into a state of shock. It's the same effect as if toxic chemicals were introduced to the cell.'

The chip, powered by the phone battery, emits a weaker impulse when the phone is transmitting signals. A hundred thousand are already on sale in California, and will be on sale in the UK from next March. The chip raises the cost of a battery by around a third. 'The BioChip is the result of 14 years of research begun by the US Army,' said Magnussen. 'They were concerned about the effects of radio telephones in their soldiers' helmets.'

Magnussen, who runs the EMX Corporation in San José, California, cites research by four universities - three American and one Danish - all of which support the idea that phone signals put cells into a state of shock. The technique the BioChip uses has been endorsed over 10 years by five universities - in Colorado, West Ontario, Columbia, Washington State and the Catholic University in Washington DC. Professor Ted Leitovitz of the Catholic University invented the chip after he was given $4 million by the US military to research the problem over four years.

British sales of the BioChip will provide a reliable gauge as to how safe the public feel about mobile phones. The Federation of Electronics Industry, which represents the interests of phone manufacturers, last week denied there were any clear effects of phone radiation on the human body, citing a recent report by the World Health Organisation.

webTitle: Why the Tube is an issue for us all

fields.headline: Why the Tube is an issue for us all
fields.standfirst: If London's transport team pulls off a good compromise with Labour, we could enter a grand new age of public sector investment
fields.trailText: The worm is turning. For too long a combination of stoicism, deference, phlegm and impotence has made the British put up with second- and third-rate public services. But these past few months you can sense the change in the air. The fury at the implosion of the rail system has begun to translate into a wider insistence that this cannot be allowed to continue. Whether it's waiting for hours in a hospital A&E department or being unable to predict our travel time, we want better.
fields.body:
The worm is turning. For too long a combination of stoicism, deference, phlegm and impotence has made the British put up with second- and third-rate public services. But these past few months you can sense the change in the air. The fury at the implosion of the rail system has begun to translate into a wider insistence that this cannot be allowed to continue. Whether it's waiting for hours in a hospital A&E department or being unable to predict our travel time, we want better.

Which is why the particular skirmish between Ken Livingstone and John Prescott over the partial privatisation of the London Underground (the public-private partnership or PPP) is emerging as a national political issue. The creation of a London mayor was meant to produce a political vehicle to fight for London's interests; so it is proving. Indeed, it is going one better. We are watching the best argued and most politically serious economic and financial challenge to Treasury-made rules governing public investment mounted in the last generation. You don't have to live in London to care that Livingstone pulls off at least a good compromise and, who knows, maybe even a victory over the proposed PPP for the Tube. This is the breach that could benefit every citizen in Britain.

Last week produced two milestones. Bob Kiley, the tough 60-something New York businessmen who masterminded the turn-round of the New York and Boston undergrounds and who has been hired by Livingstone as London's Commissioner for Transport, launched his own £10 billion plan to rehabilitate the Tube's infrastructure. Essentially, he wants to scrap the PPP and modernise the Underground using the same model he developed in the United States. His team at Transport for London (TfL) would be in the driving seat to direct what would otherwise be a hopelessly uncoordinated investment programme, and he would top up the promise of a long-term Government grant and the Tube's own revenues to finance the investment with two simple new ideas.

He would borrow money directly from the London stock market by earmarking a flow of revenue to repay the cash. And he would cut deals with private contractors to modernise the Underground; they would put up 10 per cent of the total cost which they would get back only by meeting performance targets. It is simple, practical and unideological - and we know from the experience of New York and Boston that it works.

Milestone two was a report from the National Audit Office, the Government financial watchdog, over whether the PPP will prove to be value for money. The NAO recognises that London Underground has been as thorough as it can be in its approach, but says that the structure of the PPP makes the exercise close to impossible.

Here I should declare an interest; the Industrial Society conducted a review of the PPP for Ken Livingstone, and found that the proposed system for assessing whether it offered value for money was seriously biased against the public sector. In addition, many of the hoped-for efficiency gains were highly speculative. We hoped the NAO would build on our recommendations in its own analysis. It has. The result is that if the Government is to go ahead, it has to be very confident of its expectations for PPP over the next 30 years. Given the NAO's doubts and Bob Kiley's scathing criticism, this has now become close to impossible - something Prescott and Blair both acknowledge.

The search is on for a compromise, with Prescott now telling Kiley and Livingstone that he will not award any PPP contracts for the time being, giving them eight vital weeks until the end of February to prove their case. But success demands the Treasury gives up two sacred principles. The first is that no public body can be trusted to borrow and invest money on its own account because, by definition, anything done by the public sector is useless. And, second, that the private sector is inevitably more efficient that the public sector.

In the past I would have said there wasn't a hope in hell. The Treasury always wins, and the country ends up with second-rate infrastructure or such a hopelessly convoluted scheme for involving the private sector that the alternative is also second-rate. But now the rules are different. London has an independent power base in the Mayor. The public is angry. And Kiley represents something new.

Livingstone has dared to do what no left-of-centre British government ever has before; he is paying market rates (£250,000 a year) to a public official with a proven track record and offering market incentives to secure efficiency gains in the public sector. We don't have to privatise to get better managerial skills; we simply have to adopt similar incentives, but with the advantage that ownership stays in the public sector to serve the public interest.

A partial compromise could be the Government offering a long-term grant and Livingstone accepting he must offer PPP-type efficiency gains - but that covers only some of the bones of contention. Where the gap between the two sides seems unbridgeable is over Kiley's insistence that he, rather than private contractors, has to have final control, which means giving him the right to borrow.

The Treasury may hope private companies accept more risk; in practice they don't, says Kiley. The situation is 'heads the private sector wins, tails the public sector loses'. If the Underground was automatically profit making, it might be wholly or partially privatisable; but it is not. We have to learn the lessons from rail privatisation.

And with the NAO offering its support to Kiley's criticism, the Treasury and Prescott are on weak ground. The only way out is to unscramble the PPP and give managerial control back to Kiley - but then TfL would have to borrow, which today's legal framework only allows it to do with government agreement. And that need for central government agreement makes the financial markets leery about lending to local government bodies since three recent legal cases have revealed to them that where any minor problem is not agreed centrally, then they will have problems in getting their money back. If Kiley is to rebuild London's Underground as he did in New York, those rules must change.

That is why this is a national rather than a London issue. The US Congress changed the law for New York, with implications for the rest of the US; the same could happen here. A robust framework would be needed to ensure that where public bodies like TfL borrow and act on their own they do so efficiently and accountably - but this is a debate that has never been had before.

Livingstone is forcing upon Britain an argument about the financing of public infrastructure that has till now been held only on Treasury terms with results that are a national disgrace. Nobody can predict how the argument will end or what the result will be; but thank goodness the issues are in the open. We may start to get better - and not before time.

fields.headline: Heir today, gone tomorrow
fields.standfirst:
Republicans may have an unlikely ally in their pursuit of a remodelled monarchy - Prince William

Special report: future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Republicans may have an unlikely ally in their pursuit of a remodelled monarchy - Prince William
fields.body:
Call me a foot-dragger, but I am not certain the moment is right for an all-out push to abolish the monarchy. What with tracking down the last PlayStation 2 on the planet, amassing Bob the Builder stocking-fillers and meeting Christmas postal deadlines (circa last October, due to rail crisis), it seems possible that the nation's mind is not fully concentrated on the iniquities of the Act of Settlement 1701.

The Guardian joined the royal debate with a call to amend or scrub the Act, which stipulates that only Protestant heirs of Princess Sophia may take the British throne. Thereafter, the royal family should, in time, admit that the game is up and that a modern country needs a republic, as The Observer has been urging now for some time. How soon the House of Windsor might be ushered out of Balmoral and into a retirement bungalow with the ermine in the loft and Dunroyallin on the gate is a matter for conjecture.

Never, say those delighted by last week's supposed counter-offensive to republican forces. Study the reporting of Prince William's gap year in Chile and marvel at the veneration accorded to the royals. Express newspapers excelled in their coverage, notching up 17 pages on the Willometer over two days, and others were not far behind in epic accounts of the prince's porridge-making exploits and laudable humility (noblesse o' bleach?) in scrubbing lavatories. The community William visited did not rate as a blackspot of humanity.

On infant mortality figures, Chile fares better than Bahrain and not much worse than Belgium. Of course, you might not send a privileged 18-year-old to Burundi or Mali, but neither might you expect his sacrifices (no bed to sleep in, no forelock-tuggers) wholly to eclipse last week's Unicef report noting that 11 million children die each year from preventable diseases, 170 million are malnourished and 100 million never see a classroom, let alone one equipped with an heir to the throne scrawling wombats on the blackboard.

Clare Short's White Paper on globalisation and the poor didn't get much of a look in either. Nor did the Joseph Rowntree Foundation's report on slow progress in alleviating poverty and social exclusion at home. Saving the dispossessed was the sole province of William, whose exploits were deemed to have the useful, knock-on effect of also rescuing the monarchy. As Melanie McDonagh noted reverentially in the Daily Mail: 'Truly, Prince William is the best chance the Royal Family has for its survival.' So how did this exercise in salvation come about? The trinity of the press, St James's Palace and the Press Complaints Commission has never been particularly holy.

Earlier this year, the Prince of Wales complained to the PCC after the News of the World published pictures of his son at school. Another picture, purporting to show William 'jungle-training in Belize', turned out to have been shot on Salisbury Plain. The official birthday portfolio of the prince in Union Jack waistcoat and Eton tails resulted in a row over copyright and the resignation of a palace fixer.

It also taught editors that William does not necessarily sell papers. The Eton pictures, published in a splurge almost as munificent as the gap year travelogue, wiped 200,000 copies off the sales of five tabloids. But by then the prince was 18 and bigger issues were at stake. Palace officials believed that British newspapers were likely to stalk William to Chile. What else to do but despatch a film crew and a Press Association team to slake media interest, particularly at a time when the royals crave publicity and an image-building campaign is afoot to portray Charles as a socially-aware prince who can be both pointy-head (tackling GM issues) and populist (a walk-on part in Coronation Street).

How tempting to extend the mood of glasnost to his son, and how easy to go over the top. If there had been only a few pictures, no backlash would have followed. Despite the lure of a publicity blitz which gave William hardly fewer ITV viewers (5.1 million against 5.2) than the Prime Minister's 'real issues' broadcast, I would guess that shrewder influences at the palace had a frisson of worry. The weight of coverage looked as excessive as the corset-popping effusions offered by the BBC's Jenny Bond and others. In addition, the universal assumption that William was his mother reincarnate sounded trite and creepy.

Note the caring touch. Marvel at the telegenic manner. And ignore the fact that Diana was a disturbed, damaged attention-seeker whose hospice visiting was poised uneasily between compassion and manipulation. How disingenuous, or even cruel, of the press to seek to steer William down the same route of flawed sanctity, and how unwise of the palace not to see that the eulogies would swiftly degenerate into griping about the absurd focus on a pampered teenager.

I actually feel sorry for William, who looks a nice enough boy. How is he supposed to react if advisers tell him that that lavatory-scouring will keep the hounds of hell at bay? How, at 18, can he gauge the inevitable result? Deep in the Express's unctuous reporting was a mordant footnote. 'The media will not always be able meekly to accept reports and pictures approved, Kremlin-style, by the Palace. It will expect reasonable access to report on our future king.' In other words, the gloves are off.

Adult members of the royal family are public figures, supported by the public purse. They should expect reasonable scrutiny. Even so, this warning is ominous news for the Windsors. Royalty is rather like chutney - best-preserved under hermetic seal and prone to moulder once the lid is lifted. Publicity has damaged the monarchy, if not yet gravely. One in four people wants an elected head of state, rising to one in three among Labour voters and the William age-group. Monarchists and the undecided will not, for now, be swayed by the small print. The elaborate knitting of constitutional anomalies, however due for unpicking, is not the cue for tricoteuses to gather.

The growing unease that does exist coalesces instead around the issues of living in an arcane, recidivist, Eurosceptic country, puffed up on ceremony and the crumbled imperial dreams symbolised by monarchy. Businesses may rot, Vauxhall may founder, but all will yet be well as long as we hang on to our grandiose ideas of nationhood and our own currency with the Queen's head on it. However dimly, the modernisers in the royal family are aware of this disquiet.

Once the mystique of royalty hinged on the assumption that we wanted to be just like them. Now they want, up to a very limited point, to be just like us. Hence the projection of ordinary William, an emblem of social conscience and modern manners and the potential saviour of the British monarchy. But recent history suggests that the stuffier the royal presence, the less trouble ensues. And besides, the saccharine idyll is already dented. The media will not want to play the game of sycophantic image-building for much longer, and neither may a prince with a taste for freedom and all his growing-up to do.

What happens then is anybody's guess. While it is possible that national fury over Crown prerogative may yet connive at the extinction of the monarchy, it is probable that the fissile reaction between the anti-republican press and a royal family it professes to adore will provide better fuel for the tumbrels.

webTitle: Corrupt police split reward cash with fake informants

fields.headline: Corrupt police split reward cash with fake informants
fields.standfirst:
Drug addict detective fabricated tip-offs, sabotaged court cases and planted evidence

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Drug addict detective fabricated tip-offs, sabotaged court cases and planted evidence
fields.body:
Corrupt detectives across Britain are pocketing tens of thousands of pounds by sharing reward money with a network of 'fake' informants, The Observer can reveal.

The scam involves the recruitment of petty crooks who appear before senior officers and confirm that they provided the original tip-off which led to a subsequent seizure or arrest. They then got their reward, which can range from several hundred to several thousand pounds. The money is later split with the detective concerned.

The practice came to light during the Old Bailey trial of former Detective Constable Austin Warnes, who pleaded guilty last week to charges of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice.

Warnes had played a key role in a plot to assist Simon James in winning custody of his young son. James had hired private detective Jonathan Rees from the Law and Commercial agency in south London to plant a significant quantity of cocaine in a car belonging to his estranged wife, Kim, a former model. The plan was to get her sent to prison, leaving the child in the father's sole care.

Warnes, a long-time cocaine addict who moonlighted for Law and Commercial, had agreed to assist the plot by passing false information to local police that Kim James was involved in high-level cocaine dealing. The plan failed because anti-corruption detectives had been monitoring Rees's agency, following concerns that he had been making illegal payments to a number of serving police officers in return for confidential information. Bugging devices alerted them to the James plot.

Following his arrest last September, Warnes had originally claimed that the tip-off about Kim James came from his registered informant, who was later revealed to be reformed gangster turned bestselling author Dave Courtney. At the Old Bailey trial, Courtney revealed that, far from being an informant, he had been involved in a '100 per cent corrupt' relationship with Warnes for 15 years which involved recruiting fake informants, obtaining information from the police computer and sabotaging numerous court cases.

An investigation by The Observer has revealed that Warnes's unscrupulous practices went far deeper than those admitted during the trial. Officers in other police forces, including Essex and Greater Manchester, have been investigated for allegedly sharing rewards with informants.

Warnes fed his own drug habit by regularly stealing drugs during raids. Warnes also assisted Courtney and dozens of other professional criminals in the south London area to avoid capture and evade charges by providing them with information about police investigations. In order to cover himself and not face questioning about why he was accessing police files, Warnes would say one of his informants had knowledge relevant to the case.

'The information he provided was invaluable,' says Mick, a one-time armed robber and one of those who benefited from Warnes' corruption. 'He would be able to tell you what statements the police had obtained, who they had interviewed, which properties were under surveillance, which phones were being tapped - the lot. Worth its weight in gold. You would pay between £5,000 and £10,000 a time, but it was well worth it.'

Documents obtained by The Observer show that, in one case, Warnes intervened after an attempted kidnapping. One of the suspects, an associate of Courtney, had gone on the run. Warnes telephoned the officer in charge and said he had an informant that might be able to help in the case but would require all the information. The officer in charge of the kidnap later noted: 'The impression gleaned from the information requested and questions asked was not one of an officer keen to assist but more of an officer bent on obtaining information for his own purposes.'

Warnes would regularly brag about fitting people up and applying pressure to ensnare people. He would carry out surveillance before making arrests to ensure they were carried out in the most compromising position possible. If a villain had a mistress, he would be arrested at her address rather than at home in order to increase the level of hassle if he pleaded not guilty. If he had a small child, the raid would take place late on Friday evening and fake drugs would be planted in his wife's possessions.

This would lead to the wife being held in custody and the child being taken into care over the weekend. 'By the end of the weekend, it would all be looking so grim he'd have to plead guilty. He said he collected fag ends - you can get DNA from traces of saliva - to plant at crime scenes to implicate people he didn't like.'

The Old Bailey heard that Warnes had bragged about his ability to help with matters concerning the 'IRA, driving offences, drugs, anything,' witness Brendan McGirr said. The court also heard from club owner Lee Smith, who admitted paying Warnes £500 per week in order to be warned if his venue was to be raided.

Rees and Simon James were convicted of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice. Both men were sentenced to six years. Warnes was sentenced to four years. James Cook, who had been filmed planting the drugs in the car, and Courtney were both acquitted of all charges.

Courtney, a one-time friend of the Kray twins, has made 10 court appearances in the past 15 years and has now received 10 not guilty verdicts in a row. 'I have always had faith in the British Justice system,' he said outside the court.

'That not guilty verdict was both for the charge I faced and the accusation that I was a grass. I have never been an informer.'
