webTitle: UDA threat to out top Army mole

fields.headline: UDA threat to out top Army mole
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The British government is resisting demands for a public inquiry into the military's undercover intelligence-gathering Force Research Unit, fearing that loyalists could reveal the identity of 'Steak Knife' - the Army's most important agent inside the IRA.
fields.body:
The British government is resisting demands for a public inquiry into the military's undercover intelligence-gathering Force Research Unit, fearing that loyalists could reveal the identity of 'Steak Knife' - the Army's most important agent inside the IRA.

Suspects in the murder of Belfast solicitor Pat Finucane have threatened to disclose 'Steak Knife's' identity if they are forced to give evidence to an inquiry into the killing.

The Observer has learned that members of the UDA's unit in Belfast's Highfield believe they know who 'Steak Knife' is and are prepared to name him if they are made scapegoats for the FRU's involvement in loyalist killings during the Eighties and Nineties.

The SDLP's call for inquiries into the Finucane murder, along with similar investigations into the deaths of Rosemary Nelson and Robert Hamill, are key elements of the party's pre-conditions for taking their seats on the Central Policing Board.

But it is understood the Government is concerned that a public probe into the FRU and RUC Special Branch's relationship with the UDA in north and west Belfast will lead to the outing of key informants.

Officially, the Government says it is reluctant to grant the SDLP demand because all three cases are the subject of criminal investigations. However, an inquiry into the 1989 murder of Finucane would reveal the extent of the FRU's wider relationship with the UDA in the Greater Shankill area and their role in passing on army intelligence files of republican suspects to loyalist killers.

This would inevitably lead to the events surrounding the killing two years earlier of Francisco Notarantonio, a Catholic pensioner shot dead in his Ballymurphy home by UDA assassins. FRU undercover soldiers asked their agent working inside the UDA, Brian Nelson, to dissuade his loyalist comrades from killing an IRA man whom they had been targeting for several months. Nelson was the UDA's so-called intelligence officer, whose job it was to glean information on republican activists.

Instead, the FRU passed on the details of Notarantonio, who was murdered instead of the original target. The FRU wanted to keep their agent, working in the highest echelons of the IRA's Belfast Brigade, alive and were prepared to sacrifice ordinary nationalists.

A senior loyalist commander told The Observer that the UDA in Highfield had been spying on 'Steak Knife' for several weeks, using a flat to watch their target at his home across the peaceline. 'The feeling among the UDA is that if their men are sent down for killings that took place before the Good Friday Agreement, if the Government is willing to sacrifice them, then they will tell all about their relationship with the FRU. And that includes the whole "Steak Knife" episode,' he said.

The SDLP's spokesman on policing, Alex Attwood, said there was a need for the events connected to the Finucane murder and the role of the FRU to be brought into the public domain.

'The very fact that such activities went on requires that we have these public inquiries. Events like the murder of Finucane, Rosemary Nelson and Hamill, will cast a shadow over the future unless we can throw light on these matters now.'

But the Democratic Unionist Party claimed the SDLP was 'electioneering' rather than seeking justice in its demands for further Bloody Sunday-style inquiries.

Gregory Campbell, the DUP's security spokesman, said: 'This is more about being more radical and green than Sinn Fein in the run-up to the general election. Every time I hear nationalists asking for more and more inquiries into this incident I remember John Hume's words about us all "drawing a line under the past". It seems that the SDLP have quietly dropped Hume's line in pursuit of one-sided justice.'

webTitle: Have you heard the one about Dubya?

fields.headline: Have you heard the one about Dubya?
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: He is now officially President-elect, but that means George 'Dubya' Bush is also number one target for comedians across America, from New York to Los Angeles .
fields.body:
He is now officially President-elect, but that means George 'Dubya' Bush is also number one target for comedians across America, from New York to Los Angeles .

Here are two of the best:

Scene: bar at a surgeons' convention in Paris

The Israeli doctor raises his glass and says: 'Here's to Israeli medicine! It's so advanced, we can take a kidney out of one person, put it in another, and have him looking for work in six weeks.'

The German doctor splutters in his beer. 'That's nothing! In Germany, we can take a lung out of one person, put it in another and have him looking for work in four weeks.'

The Russian doctor downs his vodka. 'Ha! We Russians can take half a heart from one person, put it in another and have them both looking for work in two weeks.'

The American doctor finishes his whisky, slams his empty glass on the table and hisses: 'Gentlemen, we Americans are gonna take an asshole out of Texas, put him in the White House, and half the goddam country will be looking for work the very next day.'

Moral dilemma:

You are in the Midwest, and there is a huge flood in progress. Many homes have been lost, water supplies compromised and infrastructure destroyed. Let's say that you're a photographer out getting pictures for a news agency, travelling alone, looking for particularly poignant scenes.

You come across George W Bush, who has been swept away by the floodwaters. He is barely hanging on to a tree branch and is about to go under.

You can either put down your camera and save him, or take a Pulitzer Prize-winning photograph of him as he loses his grip on the branch.

So, here's the question and think carefully before you answer it: Which lens would you use?

fields.headline: Horror on oil islands revealed
fields.standfirst:
Indonesian military blamed for rape, torture and killings in remote province fighting for its independence

Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Indonesian military blamed for rape, torture and killings in remote province fighting for its independence
fields.body:
He is now deaf and has problems speaking. Muhibbudin, 23, was arrested by the Indonesian military and held for 20 days on suspicion of being a member of the group that is fighting for the independence of Indonesian's northernmost province of Aceh.

He claims he was repeatedly kicked in the head, burnt on the legs and hardly fed. A harrowing photograph of this scarred and skeletal figure suggests he is not exaggerating. Muhibbudin was then taken to a hospital where he claims a military doctor removed his kidney to give to a member of the Indonesian military.

He was kept in hospital for two months where he alleges that he was repeatedly beaten and kicked. This is when he stopped hearing.

Muhibbudin's story is among more than 50 statements taken by Lesley McCulloch, a British researcher for the Centre of Defence Studies, who was in Aceh last month investigating the activities of the Indonesian military.

Many of the victims tell of torture, disappearance of male family members and rape of women, providing further evidence of human rights violations by Indonesian-government backed militia as the country's security forces crack down on separatists fighting for independence, known as the Free Aceh Movement (GAM).

One local rights group has said 841 people had been killed this year in Aceh - an oil-rich archipelago - more than double the total for 1999. At least 5,500 people have died during the past decade in fighting between government and rebel forces.

McCulloch conducted her interviews in Banda Aceh, the capital of the province, in fear of raids from the Indonesian elite military police, Brimob.

She said: 'I spoke to more than 50 people who had come from all over Aceh. Hundreds of people were queueing up. It was really traumatic. I heard so many awful stories from people who were very afraid to speak to me. Western governments are simply not aware of the scale of the human rights violations carried out by the Indonesian military.'

The stories come only days after four international human rights workers were executed by a group linked to the Indonesian military.

Another human rights worker escaped to tell his story of a three-hour ordeal after he and the others were abducted by a group of 15 men.

They were beaten with rifle butts, driven around to two military command posts, tied up and shot at point-blank range in the head. One of their captors filmed the executions with a video camera.

Those killed worked for the Danish human rights group, the International Rehabilitation Council for Torture victims.

The human rights worker who escaped, Nazruddin Abdul Gani, 22, said they were killed because they were treating torture victims in a stronghold area of the Free Aceh Movement.

The surviving witness named Ampon Thayeb, who has worked with the Indonesian military for more than a decade, as the perpetrator of the executions.

He said that Ampon ordered two of the workers, Idris and Ernita, out of the vehicle in which they were all being held. Nazruddin then watched as the two were shot. He and two others were ordered out of the same van and marched to a building in their underwear. Nazruddin managed to untie his hands and escape into the forest. The killers gunned down his companions. The bodies of his colleagues were later found at the site by the Indonesian Red Cross.

Joe Saunders, of Human Rights Watch, based in New York, said: 'This is one of the rare cases in Aceh in which a victim has come forward and publicly identified the perpetrator. The Indonesian government can have no excuses for failing to arrest and prosecute Ampon Thayeb and his army backers.'

Indonesian police deny the accusations, saying the aid workers were killed by separatists of the Free Aceh Movement, and the Indonesian government said: 'If they are confident with their allegations, they have to provide evidence... but so far many of the claims have proven to be untrue.'

Human rights groups, including Amnesty International, have called for the arrest and prosecution of those responsible for the killings which follow the murder of three workers for the UN's human rights agency UNHCR in the same area in September.

Human Rights Watch said: 'The Indonesia government is allowing its security forces to target humanitarian workers in Aceh, just as it allowed militias to target such workers in West Timor.'

Meanwhile, Indonesia has sent more than 2,000 troops to Aceh ahead of a visit by President Abdurrahman Wahid.

A military spokesman said the soldiers would be on standby to provide security during Wahid's visit in the light of worsening security conditions and assassination threats against the president.

But he said the troops would focus on rebuilding homes and public facilities destroyed by floods and landslides.

Wahid is scheduled to visit Aceh on Tuesday, when he will declare a form of Islamic, or Sharia, law and hand over a $10 million aid package to the province.

Last Thursday, the Free Aceh Movement warned that it had intelligence of what it called a hardline military plot to kill the president during his trip.

webTitle: Robot sub to find secrets of Antarctic krill

fields.headline: Robot sub to find secrets of Antarctic krill
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Andrew Brierley will spend a lonely Christmas this year - on a boat in the Antarctic with a robot submarine, several million tiny shrimps and little else for company.
fields.body:
Andrew Brierley will spend a lonely Christmas this year - on a boat in the Antarctic with a robot submarine, several million tiny shrimps and little else for company.

His festive sacrifice should pay dividends, however, for the biologist has embarked on a mission aimed at determining the fate of sea life in the Southern hemisphere.

'What happens under the ice is of fantastic importance to the oceans' food chain - and as the world heats up, it is becoming clear there could be profound and damaging consequences,' Dr Brierley told The Observer before he left for the Falklands last week.

The purpose of Brierley's mission is simple: to use Britain's £5 million revolutionary robot submarine, Autosub - the most advanced underwater probe ever built - to study krill, the hub of the southern ocean's food chain.

Krill are small, shrimp-like creatures that graze the underside of sea ice. 'They are crucial to all wildlife in the southern oceans,' said Brierley, of the British Antarctic Survey. 'Krill eat a form of algae called phytoplankton, and in turn are eaten by everything else - fish, seals, polar bears. If krill die out, so would all these creatures.'

Researchers have recently discovered that krill thrive in climatic extremes. When winters are severe and sea ice is thickest, then the crustaceans do well. In warm, iceless periods, they decline.

'We are not sure why this happens,' Brierley said. 'Either the sea ice provides a good surface for phytoplankton to grow on, and so provides krill with lots of food, or it stops predators like penguins and seals from getting at them.

'It is crucial that we find out exactly what is going on, however - for if global warming continues, and sea-ice shrinks as we expect, then the world's krill could die out, taking out all creatures that feed on them.'

Unfortunately the everyday life of the krill has been a closed book for scientists. The vibrations of their icebreakers and their stomping on ice floes tend to drive off shoals long before they can get near them. However, such ignorance should disappear with the use of Autosub, the world's first 'intelligent' submarine.

Autosub is a torpedo with a brain that can dive to depths of four miles and stay underwater for days while moving at a stately 2mph. Instruments are stored in its nose, while 5,000 alkaline-manganese batteries, enough to provide a kilowatt of power for 100 hours, are kept in its carbon-fibre central hull.

Fins automatically direct the craft downwards, counteracting its built-in buoyancy. 'That means that, if the sub stops for any reason, it automatically rises to the surface,' said Glyn Griffiths, head of the ocean technology division at Southampton Oceanography Centre.

'Another crucial point is that Autosub runs extremely quietly. We used it to study herring earlier this year and found it could pass right beside shoals without disturbing them. That is helpful when you are investigating marine life.'

Thus Autosub - on its first mission to the polar regions - will be able to investigate krill from close quarters. Brierley, on his surface craft, will be able to monitor how they feed, and how they are eaten by predators - including himself.

'I'll probably have a couple of them as a starter for my Christmas lunch. They're quite tasty. You just put a couple on a plate and microwave them for 20 seconds. It would be a shame to waste them, after all.'

webTitle: Girls of six sold into sex slavery

fields.headline: Girls of six sold into sex slavery
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Children as young as six are being smuggled into Britain to work as slaves in a disturbing new growth area of the sex industry.
fields.body:
Children as young as six are being smuggled into Britain to work as slaves in a disturbing new growth area of the sex industry.

An Observer investigation has discovered that the children from developing countries are being sold by their families and smuggled into the UK on planes and ferries.

Bewildered and unable to speak English, we found girls who had been kept prisoners in brothels and forced to have sex with businessmen.

Clients pay up to £500 for every half-hour they spend with a child, some of whom have not reached puberty. Although rumours have been circulating for some time about the trend, police have been unable to find evidence because the children are constantly supervised.

But The Observer interviewed a number of trafficked children on the streets of London who have escaped their 'owners'. Many are homeless and addicted to drugs. All are terrified and refuse to trust any adults.

'The problem of girls being trafficked for sexual purposes is a major one, but this is worse than anything we have encountered,' said Detective Inspector Paul Holmes, head of Scotland Yard's drugs and vice unit. 'This is the first concrete intelligence that we have a problem in relation to young children rather than mid-teen girls.'

The children that escape are at more risk on the streets than other young prostitutes because they often cannot understand what punters are asking for, may agree to something dangerous and are less attuned to warning signs.

Gemma, 15, a prostitute in Brixton, south London, who has worked on the streets since she was 11, said: 'I can see violent men a mile off because I understand the signs. These girls don't understand anything and can't speak enough English to ask.' Traffickers of people risk a simple fine or less than two years in jail, compared with the 10-year minimum sentence for those convicted of drug trafficking.

webTitle: Special relationship? It's always been an illusion

fields.headline: Special relationship? It's always been an illusion
fields.standfirst:
Geoffrey Wheatcroft questions the idea that America is our unfailing natural ally. Blair should note the US tendency to pursue its own interests

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Tony Blair used the quaint words yet again. He was the first national leader to call the next President of the United States and congratulate him last week, telling George W. Bush he was 'sure the special relationship between the two countries would endure'.
fields.body:
Tony Blair used the quaint words yet again. He was the first national leader to call the next President of the United States and congratulate him last week, telling George W. Bush he was 'sure the special relationship between the two countries would endure'.

What has certainly endured for many years is the underlying illusion of British policy encapsulated in that phrase. It has been said that this special relationship was special mainly in that only one side knew it existed. The very phrase with a truly strange belief, that the Americans are our natural and eternal allies. One thing to be said for the new Bush presidency is that neither 'relationship' nor illusion is likely to survive the next four years.

It is true that we have close and enduring links with the Americans. Ranting anti-American Europhiles are as silly about this as ranting pro-American Europhobes in their own way. On Friday, Philip Lader, the soon-to-depart American Ambassador, spoke about the economic and security ties between the two countries, but more to the point than security is a common history, culture, legal tradition and language.

But that still does not mean that the Americans are always on our side - or have any reason to be. Only the other week, Baroness Thatcher was spouting again her platitudes about the Americans as our truest and oldest friends, who had always stood beside us, unlike the wicked Europeans. Despite her fondness for historical pageantry, she has never had much of grasp of historical reality, as this outburst once again showed.

One of her better appointments to the House of Lords was the historian Robert Skidelsky. Her eyes might be opened if she read the newly published final vol ume of his excellent life of Keynes. As Skidelsky shows, supposedly altruistic Lend-Lease was actually the means by which, while providing a certain amount of military aid for the beleaguered British (whose defeat by Hitler would have been disastrous for the United States), the Americans waged a ruthless economic war which all but destroyed us as an exporting country.

It is almost stranger that the idea of the 'special relationship' should have survived Suez in 1956. Whatever the rights and wrongs of that escapade, the Eden government embarked on it confident that the Americans would support us, or at least not oppose us. In the event, the Eisenhower administration did just that, pulling the financial rug from under the British and reminding us bluntly who was boss.

To this day, Washington singlemindedly pursues its own interests, a tradition which will only modulate under the new Bush adminstration with a new American mood of isolationism, or at least withdrawal. No doubt Bush's foreign policy, if one can call it that, will be a cocktail of special interests well shaken with ignorance and prejudice. So was Clinton's often enough, but he had at least a veneer of cosmpolitanism to which Bush does not pretend.

There could not be a more vivid contrast than that between a departing President who spent two formative years at Oxford and an incoming President who has visited Europe only once.

And yet, while we may blanch at the Americans' self-absorption and parochialism, they have some valid grievances of their own. Although Patrick Buchanan may not have won many votes, he expressed what many Americans inchoately feel, and he could yet have an indirect influence on Bush. It is not only American backwoodsmen who increasingly echo Buchanan.

Why should 270 million Americans, with a domestic product of $7,800 billion, be expected to defend 375 million citizens of the European Union, with a combined economic product of $8,600bn? Why should the United States spend almost half as much again of its GDP on defence as we do (not to say twice as much as the Germans)? Why were four-fifths of Nato missions in the Balkans last year flown by the Americans?

This is a painfully important subject for our own Government to address, going far deeper than any footling Europhile-Europhobe debate about a rapid reaction force. And the implications of a Bush presidency are by no means necessarily a bad thing for us, if we can face up to them. For half a century, America has picked up the bill for Europe's defence, ironically thereby subsidising the European welfare state. That free lunch will soon be over.

Has Blair thought that through as he simpers to Bush about the special relationship? Whenever we hear the Prime Minister use that phrase, we might smile forgivingly. But whenever he talks about his enthusiasm for Nato and the European defence intitiative, for sending British troops to Kosovo and to Sierra Leone, we ought to ask a question which is only thrown into harsh highlight by the American election: how does Blair think he is going to pay for it?

webTitle: Paisley rapper fights hatred with humour

fields.headline: Paisley rapper fights hatred with humour
fields.standfirst:
Yo bro! Move over Eminem. Big Daddy Ian Paisley is takin' over the 'hood.

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Yo bro! Move over Eminem. Big Daddy Ian Paisley is takin' over the 'hood.
fields.body:
All the homeboys of Northern Ireland want for Christmas, it seems, is 'The Paisley Rap'.

An Ian Paisley CD - which includes lyrics such as 'I'm the main man in the DUP, there's no Shinner fit to mess with me' and 'For a fire and brimstone bible tutorial/get your ass down the Martyrs Memorial/for when I'm in the pulpit there's no compromise/ and no bullshit' - has sold thousands of copies in the Province in the run-up to the festive season.

Accompanied by funky bass, drumbeat and sample tracks of that ultimate Orange anthem - the Sash - the rap is allegedly a homage to the Democratic Unionist leader, but is in fact the work of east Belfast-born comic John McBlain.

McBlain, who slips back and forth across Belfast's peacelines as quickly as he changes from Paisley into Gerry Adams, is about to be launched on television this weekend.

The 38-year-old impressionist whose repertoire also includes impersonating boxers Barry McGuigan and Chris Eubank as well as Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness now wants to break into mainstream British comedy.

The comedian along with London based writer Dermot Harrigan are putting the finishing touches to a new video featuring McBlain as Tony Blair, William Hague and the Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson for the British market before the general election.

In the darkest days of the Troubles the comedian would spend half the evening entertaining IRA supporters in republican social clubs before crossing into loyalist areas to impersonate the same politicians for hard-line Protestant audiences.

'I remember working on nights when there were massacres and bombs in Belfast. I would go into clubs where some of the killers and their supporters socialised and would have to entertain them by sending up their own leaders and politicians. But I always seemed to get away with it and I never, ever tailored my act for each side. I never had one set for the Prods and another for the Catholics,' he said.

McBlain's new slot on Ulster Television's Kelly programme, one of Ireland's most popular weekend talk shows, marks an 18-year journey from one man stand-up to national television.

'I used to get into lots of trouble at school for impersonating the teachers, for mimicking their voices, that's where it started. One teacher called me aside and said I had a talent. So I began recording tapes at home and selling them to my friends,' McBlain said.

The result was a series of tapes in the early 1990s known as 'Spittin' Politics' one of which included a notorious episode involving famous Northern Ireland politicians travelling to Spain where they get drunk and discuss anal sex on the beach.

The controversial comedian's worst scrape occurred a year ago when, dressed as Gerry Adams, he made a joke about IRA hunger striker Bobby Sands in a north Belfast republican club.

'One guy who was a bit drunk came up to me and threatened to have me run out of Ardoyne. But that's the only real hassle I've had. Since the ceasefires, people are more ready to laugh at their own side and not just the opposition.'

McBlain, a Protestant who grew up in the loyalist Newtonards Road area, said he is treated with as much courtesy by republican audiences as unionist ones.

One of McBlain earliest and most loyal fans is the Belfast singer and composer Van Morrison.

'I first met Van over years ago on a BBC show when I was doing my Paisley impersonations. Van stopped me on the stairs and said he was a big fan,' McBlain recalled.

Since then, McBlain has been on five UK tours with Van Morrison, including a warm-up act at Wembley Arena two years ago.

Among his other fans is John de Chastelain, the Canadian general tasked with overseeing the destruction of terrorist arms in Ireland.

During a recent function, which took place on the day the IRA announced it had opened a second arms dump to international observers, McBlain dressed up as Adams and marched over to de Chastelain offering him cash to stop inspecting the IRA arsenals.

But McBlain has yet to penetrate the national comedy scene in the UK.

webTitle: Focus: A mother's anguish - and  a President's profits

fields.headline: A mother's anguish - and  a President's profits
fields.standfirst:
The violent death of a boy in a private hospital shocked the US. Ed Vulliamy reveals that George W. Bush was an investor in the firm at the heart of the affair and shows how some of Bush's biggest backers stand to gain from his health reforms

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The violent death of a boy in a private hospital shocked the US. Ed Vulliamy reveals that George W. Bush was an investor in the firm at the heart of the affair and shows how some of Bush's biggest backers stand to gain from his health reforms
fields.body:
At 10.30pm the phone rang at Jean Allen's home beside a lake on the outskirts of Greensboro, North Carolina. The call was from the Charter private hospital into which her son Tristan, 16, had been admitted six days earlier.

'Tristan got upset and stopped breathing,' said a woman's voice. 'You'd better come to the hospital.'

Allen had seen her son, whom she had adopted at 10 months, only that morning, in February 1998. His doctors agreed he could be discharged next day because his treatment for bipolar disorder, or manic depression, seemed to be working.

Tristan never came home. When Allen and her husband Richard arrived at the hospital that evening, she told The Observer last week, 'the police were there; the psychiatrist looked at me and said: "He died". Just that.'

'I found out from the police they'd put a towel around his mouth' - a process called 'restraint', involving five staff. 'The coroner's verdict was "death by asphyxiation". I was with him all his life, but not at that last moment. That's when my nightmare began.'

Tristan's violent death was revealed to the American public last year by the CBS 60 Minutes programme. Within a month Charter Behavioral Health Systems fell apart in shame. The programme prompted a criminal investigation, yet to conclude.

But only now can it be revealed that this squalid story is linked to the height of American power. Among investors in the company which bought, owned and leased the hospitals, pocketing a profit of $114,000, was the man who last week became the US President-elect, George W. Bush.

And the businessman at the apex of the corporate pyramid of which Charter was the underpinning was the man who made Bush rich, a market wizard called Richard Rainwater.

There is no reason why - or suggestion that - Bush, Rainwater or any senior executives involved knew what was going on inside the hospitals. But the companies that owned the hospitals - Crescent Real Estate and a spin-off called Crescent Operating, set up specially to manage them - lie at the centre of a network defining Bush's career.

Crescent was founded and chaired by Rainwater, who with others catapulted Bush into politics and became entwined with his rise, both as donors to his campaigns and beneficiaries from his policies. The failure of deregulation is at the heart of the Charter Behavioral story. And last week health care reforms were endorsed as a priority by Bush and his deputy, Dick Cheney. Their aim is to cut public costs and amplify the role of the private sector.

Rainwater and Bush became linked over the purchase of the Texas Rangers baseball team in 1989. Rainwater had resisted the baseball authorities' approaches to buy the flagging team, but changed his mind after meeting Bush, whose father was then President. With a tight-knit handful of investors Rainwater and Bush bought the Rangers.

Bush's investment was $600,000, enhanced by special provisions and the building of a new stadium at taxpayers' expense. When he sold his stock in 1998, Bush walked away with $14.9 million. Rainwater, in turn, became a friend of President Bush's family - staying at Camp David and flying in Air Force One - and King Midas to the President's son.

Rainwater had always been lured by the fortunes to be made in health care. His first venture had been Columbia hospitals in 1987, later Columbia/HCA after buying the rival Health Corporation of America. The company became America's largest chain of 'for-profit' hospitals.

But two employees in Florida, acting under 'whistleblower' legislation, said they had filed false claims for government funds under the Medicare and Medicaid systems. In 1997 the authorities raided a hospital in El Paso, Texas, Bush's turf.

Last May, Columbia agreed to pay $745m as a partial settlement. The company, said a spokesman, denies wrongdoing, although two of its mid-ranking executives were convicted last year of conspiring to defraud government health insurance programmes.

The year before Bush became Governor of Texas in November 1994, 60 per cent of his personal income of $610,772 came from businesses he invested in with Rainwater, who was among his biggest campaign donors, giving $100,000. That year, Rainwater set up Crescent Real Estate, which became his chief interest. Eight members of the Rangers ownership team invested, including Bush with 4,000 shares.

Rainwater was chairman; his deputy was John Goff, another partner in the Rangers purchase and contributor to Bush's campaign with his wife Janet; they gave $200,000. Goff and Janet re-appear with two donations apiece worth $200,000 to the presidential war chest. Indeed, the register of donors to Bush in the early part of 1999 reads like a Rolodex directory of Crescent executives.

After he was elected governor, Bush put most of his investments into a blind trust - the Lone Star Trust - in the interests of political propriety.

In January 1997, Rainwater's Crescent entered the psychiatric hospital business. Rainwater splashed out $400m to buy 95 psychiatric hospitals from Magellan, the country's largest behavioural health company and owner of the Charter Medical Corporation - America's largest provider of behavioural care. Rainwater already had a 12 per cent stake in Magellan. The deal was a joint venture: Magellan would lease the franchise to Charter, Crescent would lease the properties.

A re-christened Charter Behavioral Health Systems would treat the patients and Goff was assigned to be its executive chairman.

'The [psychiatric hospital] industry has had its share of black eyes,' Goff acknowledged, 'but we see momentum coming back.' Rainwater set up a new spin-off company, Crescent Operating, to manage the hospitals because of federal law banning real estate companies operating services of this kind. This company stayed in the family: Goff headed it, and documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission show that shareholders in the Crescent parent, such as Bush, would reap automatic dividends from the spin-off company.

Despite the blind Lone Star Trust, Bush's relationship with Rainwater, which had dogged the governor's campaign, continued to do so. There were coincidences between Bush's policies and Rainwater's commercial interests. The most eye-catching was Bush's proposal to privatise Texas's mental health hospitals, from which Magellan and Columbia were likely beneficiaries. Magellan was awarded one of two hospitals transferred from the state sector in a pilot scheme, but the plan was scrapped.

A Bill allowing cities to levy taxes for sports stadiums resulted in a payment of $10m to Crescent by the Dallas Mavericks basketball team - as revealed by the Houston Chronicle in 1998. The state of Texas sold three office blocks belonging to the teachers' retirement fund to Crescent - the sale of one block alone costing the pension system $44m. The trust fund for the Texas university and public schools system invested $20m in Crescent during Bush's first term as governor. And a school property tax reform of 1997 saved Rainwater $2.5m in taxes.

Confronted with these coincidences by the Houston Chronicle and New York Times, both Bush and Rainwater denied operating a system of favours.

Later, Charter fell foul of regulatory authorities in Bush's own state, where it had eight hospitals. In 1995 Bush's own administration ordered it to pay $1.5m in settlement of alleged fraud of Medicare payments.

By September 1997 the empire had grown by acquisition and Charter came under pressure to cut costs and fill beds. A government report found that at a Charter hospital - Brookside in Nashua, New Hampshire - patients had been subjected to sexual abuse, records falsified and blood was not cleaned from a ward floor. The hospital was later closed.

Dr Hisham Hafez, who worked there for 10 years, told The Observer in an interview last week that Charter's regime had become 'so rotten, the system was not a system. They were squeezing the hospital for profit. The atmosphere was toxic; the goal was not to do good work, the goal was to cut costs, to maintain a budget at all costs.

'The hospital was being run,' said Hafez, 'by a bunch of very brutal and not very smart people, with doctors cut out of the loop. If you're trusted and expected to take care of people's kids, you cannot run things that way. You can make a living by doing things ethically and professionally; you cannot make a living out of being corrupt - that is Mafia. It's not even a way to do good business. When it collapsed, it was like the old Soviet Union - once it begins to fall, everything falls apart with incredible speed.'

There had been other warning signs. In spring 1997 Antonio de Guzman, psychiatrist at Charter's hospital at Pembroke, Massachusetts, was charged with sexually abusing three young patients, and later convicted for what the judge called 'disgusting and repugnant' crimes. That summer, the Department of Health published a report on its investigation into malpractice at Pembroke and in the autumn, police were called to quell a riot on the teenagers' ward. On 1 December James Galligan, a 59-year-old patient, died during a 'restraint'.

On that same day came the bombshell. Alerted by the report of Tristan Sovern's death in North Carolina, CBS correspondent Ed Bradley and his team recruited a trained social worker from Philadelphia, Terrance Johnson, to infiltrate Charter Greensboro with a micro-camera in his spectacles.

The programme found Tristan to be the third patient to have died within four months in Charter's hospitals. Medical practice does permit such restraints for patients whose behaviour is often difficult to manage. But Johnson's camera recorded a child with a broken wrist shrieking with pain when tethered by his wrists in a 'restraint' exercise similar to that which led to Tristan's death.

A girl just admitted is seen being led screaming into a lift; 'Get off me! Let me talk to my Mom!' she yells. 'She had no idea what was happening to her,' explains Johnson. Staff brag to Johnson about their lack of training and the cavalier falsification of records.

Krystle Leech was taken for outpatient counselling after writing a note that mentioned suicide. But she was removed to a seclusion room, and her parents told she would have to stay.

When they protested, Benny and Sherry Leech say they were were told that if they left with their daughter 'they would call the police', recalled Benny Leech, 'they would come to our house and handcuff her... and she could be sent anywhere in the state... I didn't truthfully know what they could and could not legally do'.

Bradley gathered a panel of expert regulators to comment on Johnson's findings. While government officials are appalled, Dr Dennis O'Leary, president of the independent Joint Commission that regulates private hospitals - and whose fiefdom would be expanded by a Bush administration - pleads: 'Our information pathways need to be improved.'

Within two days of transmission of the CBS programme, the US government regulatory machine, that Bush now heads but derides, moved in. President Clinton ordered a review of Charter's hospitals, and units were closed in New Hampshire, Virginia, Alaska, California and Georgia.

Charter went into free fall: the company sold 53 of its remaining hospitals; the Justice Department joined the regulatory authorities and opened a nationwide criminal investigation still in progress, alleging 'fraud and abuse...and false claims', to quote Magellan's own filing with the government. Magellan said it was co-operating with the investigations; no findings have been made. In February this year, Charter filed for bankruptcy. Crescent Operating took over what was left of the hollow empire.

But how much did Bush know about his investment with Crescent? The Observer has opened one eye of the blind trust to question how much Bush knew about where his money was invested. Crescent's filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission shows that on 4 April 1997 - three months after Crescent bought into Charter - the Lone Star Trust owned 4,220 shares in Crescent; the documents are available to anyone taking trouble to examine them.

A further document at the commission, dated December 1998, shows that the previous 29 January, one year after the Charter purchase, Lone Star Trust sold its shares in Crescent at a profit of $114,000.

A reason for the sale was given: Bush was concerned about a conflict of interests involving Crescent's investments in the casino business, to which he was politically opposed. Crescent's gambling ambitions had dogged Bush during his election to the governorship in 1994 and returned to haunt him as Rainwater announced his intention to buy Station Casinos of Las Vegas.

There is another twist to the Crescent stock sale: Bush's trust sold this 'blind' stock when shares were at their peak value of $40 each - for a total of $168,800. Shortly after the sale, Crescent's stock plunged to $21 per share.

Later in 1998, the Lone Star Trust was liquidated as Bush prepared his bid for the presidency. In November of that year, John Goff resigned from Charter Behavioral's board.

Rainwater's office told The Observer 'he really doesn't talk' about his relationship with Bush. A Crescent spokeswoman said it did not 'call the shots' in Charter's hospitals. It did not run them but owned the facilities they leased.

She said Goff was now chief executive of Crescent and Crescent Operating. She said they had believed Charter was a very good investment. But the market 'had changed' and it was 'a bad time' for the industry.

Joan and Richard Allen, meanwhile, mourn their dead son. 'I've been through despair and rage,' said Mrs Allen. 'I don't care any more about people like Rainwater; if I did I'd go insane.'

With money from a legal settlement with Charter, she established a foundation, Tristan's Quest, which helps special-needs children. 'It's what I live for,' she added.

fields.headline: Minister faces 'sleaze' inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Foreign Office Minister Keith Vaz faces new political controversy following an investigation by a parliamentary watchdog into the activities of a company owned by his wife and mother.
fields.body:
Foreign Office Minister Keith Vaz faces new political controversy following an investigation by a parliamentary watchdog into the activities of a company owned by his wife and mother.

The Observer can reveal that Elizabeth Filkin, the Commissioner for Parliamentary Standards, has been quizzing the Minister for Europe over the activities of a firm called Mapesbury Communications. The decision to question Vaz has come as part of Filkin's 10-month investigation.

Filkin has wanted to know what the Minister's relationship is with Mapesbury, in particular whether he has ever received any benefits from the firm which he should have declared in the register of Members' interests.

Mapesbury was created by Vaz in 1994, when he was a backbench Labour MP, to publish a calendar for the Asian community paid for by adverts taken out by local businesses. In the past two years Mapesbury's combined turnover has totalled more than £120,000 and it has nearly £20,000 worth of assets.

According to Companies House, the directors of Mapesbury are Merlyn Vaz, the Minister's mother, and Maria Fernandes, the Minister's wife. Mapesbury's registered office is at his mother's house in Leicester and it is described as a publishing and public relations firm.

Vaz has never declared any involvement with the company in the Register of Members' Interests. Although he set up the firm up, the Minister maintains that since 1996 Mapesbury has been solely used by his wife.

Vaz says that prior to this he registered all the details of Mapesbury with the former parliamentary commissioner Sir Gordon Downey, who advised him that as long as he received no benefits from Mapesbury he did not have to declare his involvement.

Whitehall sources say Filkin is checking the Minister's answers. Her investigation into the Minister - which involves several complaints about his conduct - will be finished in the New Year and her report passed to the Standards and Privileges committee. If her inquiry leaves questions unanswered, the committee has powers to demand documents from the company.

All allegations of wrongdoing have been denied by Vaz, who believes he is the target of political enemies in his constituency. He is confident he will be cleared when the commissioner completes her investigation .

Whitehall sources have admitted that Downing Street is uneasy about Filkin's inquiry and is nervous that whatever the outcome, the Tories will seek to make political capital out of it. It is understood there has been pressure on Filkin to delay her report until after the election.

Geoffrey Bindman, Vaz's lawyer, said: 'Keith Vaz has never been a shareholder of Mapesbury, nor a director and has never received any benefits from it. There has been no suggestion from Filkin that he has been guilty in acting wrongly in relation to Mapesbury. The Minister receives advice from a former parliamentary commissioner which he has followed to the letter.'

Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, has been criticised at Westminster for the way she goes about investigating MPs. Her rigorous inquiries into MPs' activities and business interests have caused growing bitterness among politicians who feel their reputations have been wrongly tarnished.

webTitle: The man who is really running the USA

fields.headline: The man who is really running the USA
fields.standfirst:
As George W. Bush chills out in Texas, his deputy Dick Cheney has emerged as the key power-broker who looks set to be the driving force behind the new administration. Peter Preston reports on the 'real' President

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: It is a bizarre way to make a new government. The theoretical President-elect sits in Texas, chilling out and taking a few photo-opportunities - while, far away in Washington, the real President-elect tries to fill 7,000 jobs in 37 days, an almost biblical miracle worker.
fields.body:
It is a bizarre way to make a new government. The theoretical President-elect sits in Texas, chilling out and taking a few photo-opportunities - while, far away in Washington, the real President-elect tries to fill 7,000 jobs in 37 days, an almost biblical miracle worker.

Lo! he got off his bed (after a fourth heart attack) and began to work like a demon. There can be no clearer demonstration where the power will lie these next four White House years: with the supposed first reserve a heart beat from the presidency, Dick Cheney. He will be a Vice-President unique in American history. He will call the shots of detail and decision.

In legend, Cheney's titular role is the most despised job in D.C. Ask Dan Quayle or the shade of Spiro Agnew. Who wants to be responsible for boring travel to boring places the President is too busy to go to? Bill Clinton got Ireland, Al Gore got Africa. But now the pitcher of warm spit runneth over.

When Washington insiders joke about this running mate, they mean he is the mate old President Bush summoned back to the colours to run things for his callow son. They also find something deeply evocative about the few Bush-Cheney joint appearances through the weeks since election day. Bush Jnr sticking rigidly to a simple script and making jokes about his dog: Cheney leaping in whenever a press question threatens to get complicated.

A scene from memory lane. Remember how, a quarter of a century ago, Gerald Ford (in a presidential TV debate with Jimmy Carter) informed a giggling world that Poland was not part of the Soviet bloc? Who, in that debacle, had the job of drafting a 'statement of clarification' for the President - then fuming impotently as, after reading it, Ford said he still thought of Warsaw as kind of free?

Cheney, Ford's Chief of Staff at 34, is one of America's master minders. Even if George W. was a towering intellect, he would still find the move from the governor's mansion to the White House a bemusing time of trial. Carter, Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton all wallowed haplessly through their first year on Pennsylvania Avenue. Cheney is there, at the very least, to steer the notoriously bungaloid-brained Bush through; but it is clear that his influence, in fact, will be greater still.

George is not the smart Bush brother - that is Jeb, Governor of Florida - nor is he particu larly experienced in running things. The governorship, in Texan terms, is only the state's fifth most powerful job. Cheney, by contrast, oozes experience. Oval Office insider, six-term congressman, Defence Secretary, big oil businessman, one of Daddy Bush's oldest, most trusted friends.

At first sight, George W.'s surprise decision to put him on the presidential ticket last July seemed mere reassurance, recruiting a seasoned pro to a fledgling squad. Now, after a nightmare of an election, it looks both more prescient and more high-risk than that.

Experience matters - but, less comfortably, does the vice-presidential bruiser with the right-wing agenda? Cheney, short, owlish, overweight, brought no discernible charisma to the campaign trail. He is an efficient but one-paced speaker. He does not enjoy stump life or the endless days of glad-handing. His own half-stab at a presidential run against Clinton in 1996 collapsed of its own accord. He did not have the ambition for the fight. He prefers the backstairs route.

Some voters, moreover, choked on the obscene (by British standards) packages of stock options, pay-offs and compensations that the oil company he ran for five years, Halliburton, showered on its departing chief executive - not just the $20 million cash in hand, but the further $10m or more he continues to hold.

Now, however, comes political pay-back. Cheney knows how to construct a White House staff and an administration. Been there and done that, in extremis, for the hapless Ford. Cheney has the contacts and chums. It was he, at Defence, who whisked Colin Powell from a mid-league military rating to become Chief of the General Staffs. Put together the emerging stalwarts of a George W. administration - Powell again, at State, Condoleezza Rice, Andy Card - and they are all names from the Cheney contact book of Republican administrations past, all veterans of Washington beltway life. Old brooms mopping up.

But fate - and the Supreme Court - has also handed Cheney another, more testing role. He could, if he had stayed in Congress, have been majority leader. His contacts on the Hill are still good - and if there is one thing friends and foes both say about him, it is that he can be a calm, low-key conciliator. An odd dichotomy. On his record, Cheney is the arch-conservative, with a House voting record - on guns, abortion and all the right-wing gut issues - to make liberals quail. As a congressman, Cheney even voted once to keep Nelson Mandela in prison because he was a 'terrorist'. He was one of the six most rabid Republicans in the House.

But close up, edging from one problem to another, he can be pragmatic and humanly unpredictable. (His stentorian views on gay rights in the military or elsewhere, for instance, did not extend to his gay press spokesman at the Pentagon and do not now extend to his openly lesbian daughter, Mary).

The personal gap between principle and practice opens every time he confronts actual dilemmas and has to produce actual solutions. Now, apart from the faithful Card, there is no one else around with the grasp or the clout to solve the conundrum of this tenuously legitimate presidency - to put it in place and make it run.

Powell will be out of the domestic loop at the State Department. George W., sitting in Austin by the phone, may want to play the homely bipartisan, but he lacks either the contacts or the grasp of detail to be more than a meeter-and-greeter at this stage. Cheney has to do what he is manifestly there for: to run the show.

Difficulties? There are plenty of them. Even Bush - who puts himself down in public with a becoming excess of modesty - may find it difficult to live long with the perception that he is a smiling puppet. He is, somewhat testily, already casting himself as a great 'delegator'.

The tell-tale alarm in the days after the heart attack could soon turn to dignity affronted if Cheney's profile comes to overshadow the Oval Office. Yet he cannot be pushed aside: he was elected just as much as his boss. More, the office of Vice-President is not designed for taking basic responsibilities, so traditional lines of responsibility are bound to get tangled. Cabinet stars, such as Powell, who had his run-ins with a militarily amateurish Cheney during the Gulf War, could quickly grow restive. Scope for muddle and strife: considerable.

Predictably, too, Cheney may find any honeymoon with the media short-lived. Too many journalists remember it was he (learning from Britain's Falklands crisis) who shut the media out of the Panama invasion and then erected a hi-tech wall of silence around the Gulf. Those tactics, and that attitude, will not help him now. Nor will the continuing anger over his Halliburton share options, which makes him an instant fat cat in any controversy with a poverty angle, such as social security or health care reform - not to mention the curse of Big Oil.

This extraordinary Vice-President, another drunk driver in his youth, another student nomad who steadied himself when he married a local Wyoming girl (who became a notably strident conservative), will need more than all of his personal skills. He will need huge luck.

That luck has not been running his way since 7 November. The heart attack was a fourth grim warning - one watching doctors worry about openly. (His wife, with macabre timing, has just re-released a novel that features a 59-year-old Vice-President who dies of a heart attack - Cheyney is 59). And the final shambles in the Supreme Court has made the task of hand-crafting an administration for Junior not just hectic but politically complex. Harassed embryo government seeks tame Democrats in unity drive.

More ominously still, for all the swill of sudden sweetness, the fury from Florida - including the storming of the canvassing board offices in Dade County by a threatening gang of Republican demonstrators - has profoundly soured the atmosphere in Washington. Who sent that mob? The shark-toothed House majority whip, Tom DeLay. How do you heal anything with a butcher leading your troops?

There is an uncomfortable irony here. The Bushes, father and son, chose Cheney as candidate number two in July, when George W. was far ahead in the polls. They did not need his grey presence on the campaign trail because they assumed victory; they wanted him to do just what he is doing - to put a coherent administration in place.

What they did not foresee, however, is that it would have to be an administration that reached out to the other half of a divided country - not a coalition of the Right that Cheney and DeLay both represent. Even to begin to make it function, Cheney will have to swallow his beliefs, abandon his ideological chums, and turn himself into a different breed of politician. The stress the doctors fret over is psychological as well as physical. But at least he knows what is at stake.

'The quality of the transition has a direct bearing on the quality of the administration that follows it.' There is, self-evidently, no other quality tester in sight. Now, as the keys pass, one Vice-President is left to work 18 hours a day, unpicking the locks - and gridlocks - another Vice-President leaves behind.

webTitle: We won it, and now we're going to do what we want

fields.headline: We won it, and now we're going to do what we want
fields.standfirst:
The President-elect talked of compromise last week, but for Republican hardliners it's now payback time, writes Ed Vulliamy

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The questions linger across America's scorched political terrain: who won the election? Bush or Gore, the Democrats or Republicans?
fields.body:
The questions linger across America's scorched political terrain: who won the election? Bush or Gore, the Democrats or Republicans?

Most important, which will predominate - the peace promised by the President-elect in his speech last week, or the reality of bitterness that has riven the country with his election?

Bush's victory speaks for itself: he will have won by a single vote of tomorrow's Electoral College, thanks to a single vote in a divided Supreme Court and 534 out of six million votes cast in Florida with a re-count abandoned by decree only hours from completion.

Not a mandate, say the Democrats, for a sweeping programme of reforms to health care and social security, tax cuts for the wealthiest few and international isolationism after eight years of the Clinton presidency.

And yet, for the first time since 1954, the Republicans can, on paper, do what they want. 'This is something I've been worked toward for 22 years,' said the party's Chief Whip and emergent powerhouse Tom DeLay. 'I mean, we got it. We have the House, we have the Senate, we have the White House, which means we have the agenda.'

DeLay is one of the hard line right-wingers who believe that Bush owes his election to them, one of many in the party, in business and on the Hill, who have waited a long time for this moment, who owe no debt to compromise whatever Bush may have said last Wednesday night, and who plan to prevent any, at all costs.

'The agenda' is indeed a conservative one (the 'compassionate' bit was left behind in the North Carolina primary), and Bush's deputy Dick Cheney has been crystal clear that the new administration will stick to it faithfully whatever olive branches Bush may have proffered last week.

Even the much-vaunted overture to Louisiana Democrat Senator John Breaux was one to a staunch Bush supporter and, more important, one of the family as far as the big oil industry is concerned.

But not all Republicans are convinced that this is the moment for an all out ideological assault on the Bill Clinton legacy.

'It's clearly better to be in than out,' said Mike Murphy a party consultant who worked with John McCain. 'But there's plenty of difficulty.'

Even the House speaker Dennis Hassert counselled that the proposed tax cut of $1.3 trillion (43 per cent of which goes to the top 3 per cent of earners) would be best moderated for presentation to Capitol Hill, especially with the first signs of an economic downturn which may haunt the Bush administration.

Even Republican Senator Charles Grassley of Iowa, who will chair the new Finance Committee next month, thought it unlikely Congress would pass a tax cut of the magnitude proposed by Bush: 'If there continues to be a downturn in the economy,' he said. 'It might make sense to do something not that big, but across the board.'

Grassley's view, however, will not wash with those who believe they put Bush in office and who expect their due and remuneration, be it financial or political.

Away from the limelight last week a group of Republicans was formed on Capitol Hill and within the party apparatus with the specific aim of raising funds to keep up the pressure on Bush to adhere to the right-wing agenda.

This caucus, which may yet consolidate into a formal group, includes the leaders of the party in Congress who also staged the take over of Capitol Hill in 1994 - DeLay, House leader Dick Armey and Trent Lott in the Senate.

Meanwhile, on the other side, anyone who saw Al Gore party the night away with Tom Petty and Jon Bon Jovi last Wednesday would think he had won the election.

And as far as the Democrats, half the nation and a formidable array of 280 prominent historians whose signatures underscored a round robin last week are concerned, he did.

He won the popular vote and most Americans (especially the Bush campaign and Supreme Court judges) know that had the recount continued in Florida he would also have won that pivotal state and with it tomorrow's Electoral College.

Various outstanding lawsuits may yet prove this to be the case and such a result was calculated in a recent study by the Miami Herald . The paper assembled a team of academics and, using scientific methods of polling and demography, worked out that if Florida's 185,000 'under votes' had been counted, even by the most cautious forecasts Gore would have won by 23,000.

There is a constituency within the Democrat Party, which believes Gore should and could have won a landslide and is ready to discard him in favour of a new candidate, possibly Hillary Clinton or Dick Gephardt in 2004.

'It's going to be a little difficult for the Vice-President to stay up there in 2004,' said representative Adam Smith. 'A fresh face might serve well, given what a tough battle we've been through.' But for the moment at least, Gore cuts something of a heroic figure and becomes the first European-style Leader of the Opposition in recent American history, a role for which the system does not provide and which Gore will need to carve for himself.

House minority Whip David Bonior says that Gore 'helped himself immeasurably in the way he fought the last month-and-a-half' over what Democrats regard as 'a basic issue of justice'.

Democrat officials are already talking about a Gore/Hillary ticket in 2004; badges have been produced in Washington saying 'Re-elect Gore in 2004' - emphasis on the re -elect.

Albeit stunned by the Supreme Court's brazen foray into politics, Democrats in Washington last week were not altogether downcast. 'The party is in pretty good shape,' say Nick Baldick, who ran the ground operation in Florida. 'We picked up Senate seats, we're competitive in the House and our base is strong.' In contrast to the condition of their party after the defeats of Walter Mondale and Mike Dukakis, the Democrats are unified by seizing righteous indignation and well placed for a challenge at the 2002 congressional elections.

Even Republican consultant Larry McCarthy concedes that 'except for Gore, they had a pretty good election. The most telling numbers are that Gore and Ralph Nader won a left-of-centre majority. The underlying movements of the electorate are not good for us.'

If there is a pall of illegitimacy hanging over the Bush presidency it is because of the remarkable ruling of the Supreme Court to halt the Florida recount. The decision was without precedent and left the political and judicial worlds in pandemonium.

In his dissent from that ruling, the court's elder statesman John Paul Stevens said: 'Although we may never know with complete certainty the identity of the winner of this year's presidential election, the identity of the loser is clear - it is the nation's confidence in the judge as an impartial guardian of the rule of law.'

It was the message of the entire election epic, after which the loser is certainly more clearly etched than the winner. The ruling has detonated bitter rancour across an America now divided all the way up to the highest authority in the land.

And whatever heart the Democrats might take for their future, a senior White House aide reminded: 'Meanwhile we have Bush.'
Bush isn't the only winner and Gore is not the only loser. Here are a few other people, places - and animals - whose status has changed

WINNERS

George W. Bush's dog, Spotty, who now has the run of the most famous lawn in America.

Bill Gates. Microsoft was facing potentially ruinous federal action. Its founder, however, is a major Republican donor.

Oil prospectors. Bush plans to throw open the Alaskan wildlife reserves to the nature-loving petrochemical industry.

Middle initials. How different it all could have been had Gore used his (it's A., incidentally, for Arnold.)

David Letterman (above right), Jay Leno and late-night comedy TV, which emerged as a surprisingly trustworthy source of political news.

Republican actress and Bush friend Bo Derek (right), and other luminous modern global stars such as campaign theme song singer Billy Ray Cyrus.

Bill Clinton, whose legacy will be left undimmed by a Gore administration which might actually have achieved something.

Line-dancing. Pick-up trucks. Cowboy hats. Insane hawkish generals. Horsemen of Apocalypse

Fyodor Dostoevsky. As read to the nation by former librarian and incoming First Lady Laura Bush.

LOSERS

Buddy, Clinton's brown labrador. Poor Buddy has lost the run of the Rose Garden and will now be sequestered in a small yard in Chappaqua surrounded by an electric fence.

Celeb Democrat activists, who lose their access to the Lincoln Bedroom - Barbra Streisand, Fleetwood Mac, Ben Affleck, Uma Thurman, Naomi Wolf, Robert Redford.

The Supreme Court, which turned out to merit the same status as a kangaroo court held by feuding drunks in a burning Port-au-Prince whorehouse.

Jeb Bush, who now not only will never make it to the White House but can't even take credit for helping his brother

Ralph Nader, who will always be resented for lifting Democrat votes.

Fyodor Dostoevsky. As read to the nation by former librarian and incoming First Lady Laura Bush.
fields.bodyText: The questions linger across America's scorched political terrain: who won the election? Bush or Gore, the Democrats or Republicans? Most important, which will predominate - the peace promised by the President-elect in his speech last week, or the reality of bitterness that has riven the country with his election? Bush's victory speaks for itself: he will have won by a single vote of tomorrow's Electoral College, thanks to a single vote in a divided Supreme Court and 534 out of six million votes cast in Florida with a re-count abandoned by decree only hours from completion. Not a mandate, say the Democrats, for a sweeping programme of reforms to health care and social security, tax cuts for the wealthiest few and international isolationism after eight years of the Clinton presidency. And yet, for the first time since 1954, the Republicans can, on paper, do what they want. 'This is something I've been worked toward for 22 years,' said the party's Chief Whip and emergent powerhouse Tom DeLay. 'I mean, we got it. We have the House, we have the Senate, we have the White House, which means we have the agenda.' DeLay is one of the hard line right-wingers who believe that Bush owes his election to them, one of many in the party, in business and on the Hill, who have waited a long time for this moment, who owe no debt to compromise whatever Bush may have said last Wednesday night, and who plan to prevent any, at all costs. 'The agenda' is indeed a conservative one (the 'compassionate' bit was left behind in the North Carolina primary), and Bush's deputy Dick Cheney has been crystal clear that the new administration will stick to it faithfully whatever olive branches Bush may have proffered last week. Even the much-vaunted overture to Louisiana Democrat Senator John Breaux was one to a staunch Bush supporter and, more important, one of the family as far as the big oil industry is concerned. But not all Republicans are convinced that this is the moment for an all out ideological assault on the Bill Clinton legacy. 'It's clearly better to be in than out,' said Mike Murphy a party consultant who worked with John McCain. 'But there's plenty of difficulty.' Even the House speaker Dennis Hassert counselled that the proposed tax cut of $1.3 trillion (43 per cent of which goes to the top 3 per cent of earners) would be best moderated for presentation to Capitol Hill, especially with the first signs of an economic downturn which may haunt the Bush administration. Even Republican Senator Charles Grassley of Iowa, who will chair the new Finance Committee next month, thought it unlikely Congress would pass a tax cut of the magnitude proposed by Bush: 'If there continues to be a downturn in the economy,' he said. 'It might make sense to do something not that big, but across the board.' Grassley's view, however, will not wash with those who believe they put Bush in office and who expect their due and remuneration, be it financial or political. Away from the limelight last week a group of Republicans was formed on Capitol Hill and within the party apparatus with the specific aim of raising funds to keep up the pressure on Bush to adhere to the right-wing agenda. This caucus, which may yet consolidate into a formal group, includes the leaders of the party in Congress who also staged the take over of Capitol Hill in 1994 - DeLay, House leader Dick Armey and Trent Lott in the Senate. Meanwhile, on the other side, anyone who saw Al Gore party the night away with Tom Petty and Jon Bon Jovi last Wednesday would think he had won the election. And as far as the Democrats, half the nation and a formidable array of 280 prominent historians whose signatures underscored a round robin last week are concerned, he did. He won the popular vote and most Americans (especially the Bush campaign and Supreme Court judges) know that had the recount continued in Florida he would also have won that pivotal state and with it tomorrow's Electoral College. Various outstanding lawsuits may yet prove this to be the case and such a result was calculated in a recent study by the Miami Herald . The paper assembled a team of academics and, using scientific methods of polling and demography, worked out that if Florida's 185,000 'under votes' had been counted, even by the most cautious forecasts Gore would have won by 23,000. There is a constituency within the Democrat Party, which believes Gore should and could have won a landslide and is ready to discard him in favour of a new candidate, possibly Hillary Clinton or Dick Gephardt in 2004. 'It's going to be a little difficult for the Vice-President to stay up there in 2004,' said representative Adam Smith. 'A fresh face might serve well, given what a tough battle we've been through.' But for the moment at least, Gore cuts something of a heroic figure and becomes the first European-style Leader of the Opposition in recent American history, a role for which the system does not provide and which Gore will need to carve for himself. House minority Whip David Bonior says that Gore 'helped himself immeasurably in the way he fought the last month-and-a-half' over what Democrats regard as 'a basic issue of justice'. Democrat officials are already talking about a Gore/Hillary ticket in 2004; badges have been produced in Washington saying 'Re-elect Gore in 2004' - emphasis on the re -elect. Albeit stunned by the Supreme Court's brazen foray into politics, Democrats in Washington last week were not altogether downcast. 'The party is in pretty good shape,' say Nick Baldick, who ran the ground operation in Florida. 'We picked up Senate seats, we're competitive in the House and our base is strong.' In contrast to the condition of their party after the defeats of Walter Mondale and Mike Dukakis, the Democrats are unified by seizing righteous indignation and well placed for a challenge at the 2002 congressional elections. Even Republican consultant Larry McCarthy concedes that 'except for Gore, they had a pretty good election. The most telling numbers are that Gore and Ralph Nader won a left-of-centre majority. The underlying movements of the electorate are not good for us.' If there is a pall of illegitimacy hanging over the Bush presidency it is because of the remarkable ruling of the Supreme Court to halt the Florida recount. The decision was without precedent and left the political and judicial worlds in pandemonium. In his dissent from that ruling, the court's elder statesman John Paul Stevens said: 'Although we may never know with complete certainty the identity of the winner of this year's presidential election, the identity of the loser is clear - it is the nation's confidence in the judge as an impartial guardian of the rule of law.' It was the message of the entire election epic, after which the loser is certainly more clearly etched than the winner. The ruling has detonated bitter rancour across an America now divided all the way up to the highest authority in the land. And whatever heart the Democrats might take for their future, a senior White House aide reminded: 'Meanwhile we have Bush.' Bush isn't the only winner and Gore is not the only loser. Here are a few other people, places - and animals - whose status has changed WINNERS George W. Bush's dog, Spotty, who now has the run of the most famous lawn in America. Bill Gates. Microsoft was facing potentially ruinous federal action. Its founder, however, is a major Republican donor. Oil prospectors. Bush plans to throw open the Alaskan wildlife reserves to the nature-loving petrochemical industry. Middle initials. How different it all could have been had Gore used his (it's A., incidentally, for Arnold.) David Letterman (above right), Jay Leno and late-night comedy TV, which emerged as a surprisingly trustworthy source of political news. Republican actress and Bush friend Bo Derek (right), and other luminous modern global stars such as campaign theme song singer Billy Ray Cyrus. Bill Clinton, whose legacy will be left undimmed by a Gore administration which might actually have achieved something. Line-dancing. Pick-up trucks. Cowboy hats. Insane hawkish generals. Horsemen of Apocalypse Fyodor Dostoevsky. As read to the nation by former librarian and incoming First Lady Laura Bush. LOSERS Buddy, Clinton's brown labrador. Poor Buddy has lost the run of the Rose Garden and will now be sequestered in a small yard in Chappaqua surrounded by an electric fence. Celeb Democrat activists, who lose their access to the Lincoln Bedroom - Barbra Streisand, Fleetwood Mac, Ben Affleck, Uma Thurman, Naomi Wolf, Robert Redford. The Supreme Court, which turned out to merit the same status as a kangaroo court held by feuding drunks in a burning Port-au-Prince whorehouse. Jeb Bush, who now not only will never make it to the White House but can't even take credit for helping his brother Ralph Nader, who will always be resented for lifting Democrat votes. Fyodor Dostoevsky. As read to the nation by former librarian and incoming First Lady Laura Bush.

fields.headline: @large
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: One night only
fields.body:
One night only

At this festive time of year, @large feels the need to back up its contrived pub spiel with hard facts and invent as many potential conversation starters as possible. The Office for National Statistics' website is a goldmine of fantastic facts to inject into mundane chats with your cousin from Letchworth.

Imagine our horror, therefore, when attempting to reach the said website, at coming across a free service 'dedicated to those individuals who wish only to fulfil the physical side of a relationship'. ONS, you see, also stands for 'one night stand', so best stick to www.nationalstatistics.gov.uk from now on.

@ a boy

Our effort to formalise a text message language for the sake of global peace has got off to a stunning start. Reader Donald MacKay came up with the superb name of 'L@-in' for our attempts to codify grammatical rules for this burgeoning form of communication.

Mackay says: 'The progenitor of modern languages begets a child for the networked generation.' We are inclined to agree.

Before we get into the details of the present subjunctive, we want to hear views on the new language's base. Do we invent rules that will be applicable across languages or that work just around English?

Please send suggestions to at.large@observer.co.uk

Clean breast

Eidos, the embattled British games designer, has succumbed to the obvious and admitted to augmenting the size of Lara Croft's breasts in the latest Tomb Raider game. The pneumatic Ms Croft's figure is more 'defined and smoothed' according to the Eidos website. The company, which sponsors Manchester City Football Club, denied that it was getting obsessed with a bunch of big girl's blouses.

webTitle: Fraud probe as bill for EC office rises

fields.headline: Fraud probe as bill for EC office rises
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: The Fraud Squad has been called in by Neil Kinnock to investigate why the already high cost of renovating the European Commission's headquarters seems to be ballooning out of control.
fields.body:
The Fraud Squad has been called in by Neil Kinnock to investigate why the already high cost of renovating the European Commission's headquarters seems to be ballooning out of control.

In a new threat to the credibility of the commission, which resigned en masse last year, a damning report into the project has been handed to the EU's fraud unit.

The commission is already committed to spending around £270 million on renovating its sprawling, star-shaped office block in central Brussels, which it occupied before the building was found to be riddled with asbestos.

But the Belgian government has admitted it now expects the bill for the hulking Berlaymont building to rise by at least another £33m. That, observers agree, is probably a conservative estimate.

A report from British consultants Ernst & Young has sown panic in the commission. Officials are reluctant to discuss the matter in any detail, citing legal reasons and the need to carry out sensitive negotiations with the Belgian authorities, which are largely responsible for managing the project. The report says work is unlikely to be finished before 2003, even though 3,000 EU officials were due to start working there last June. That would make it almost three years late.

The report predicts 'significant' cost over-runs unless drastic action is taken, and suggests some contractors working on the project may be guilty of fraud.

It is known that Kinnock, the commission vice-president responsible for administrative reform, has serious concerns about a large bill presented by one contractor. An investigation is under way.

A full independent audit is to be carried out to confirm the seriousness of the situation and the EC is reviewing the entire project.

It has informed the Belgian government of its worries, and Kinnock is likely to meet senior Belgian Ministers in the new year to try to get the project back on track.

However, the commission is desperate to distance itself from the problem, preferring to blame the cost over-runs and delays on the government, which owns the building and leases it to the EC.

'They are the ones handling it, but we're following it. We don't wish to enter the Berlaymont at any price or under any conditions,' one official told The Observer .

The fact remains that the commission is paying out at least £270m of what is effectively EU taxpayers' money to finance the renovation, leaving it open to accusations of financial mismanagement and lack of oversight.

In its strangely low-key announcement of the fraud investigation earlier this month the commission seemed to recognise what is at stake. It said: 'These actions demonstrate the commission's wish to protect the EU's financial interests. It wants to be certain that renovation is completed at the right price.'

The building, in the EU quarter of Brussels, will house the EU commissioners and their staff.
