webTitle: I have seen the future - and it's 300 years old

fields.headline: I have seen the future - and it's 300 years old
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The thing about great ideas is that they are usually blindingly obvious - afterwards. A little more than two years ago, a New Zealand-based philosophy professor named Denis Dutton had the idea of creating an intelligent sieve for the web. He assembled a small team (one suspects they were his graduate students) who trawled the web every day for intellectually demanding and interesting content and publishing pointers to what they found. The result was Arts and Letters Daily (www.cybereditions.com/aldaily/) an indispensable guide which has long been the default home page for every browser I use.
fields.body:
The thing about great ideas is that they are usually blindingly obvious - afterwards. A little more than two years ago, a New Zealand-based philosophy professor named Denis Dutton had the idea of creating an intelligent sieve for the web. He assembled a small team (one suspects they were his graduate students) who trawled the web every day for intellectually demanding and interesting content and publishing pointers to what they found. The result was Arts and Letters Daily (www.cybereditions.com/aldaily/) an indispensable guide which has long been the default home page for every browser I use.

In a world increasingly dominated by overdesigned flash-clutter and graphics-intensive pages, Dutton's guide has a quaint, old-fashioned simplicity. It's basically just a long, scrolling page of text, topped by an antique masthead complete with Latin inscription and engraving of comely maiden. New entries come at the top and eventually ageing entries fall off the bottom (but are given a dignified resting-place in an archive). There is very little advertising, and what there is is restrained and tasteful.

The whole thing is modelled, Dutton says, on eighteenth century broadsheets - publications that tried to pack the maximum amount of news and comment onto the minimum amount of paper, regardless of the strain this might impose on readers' eyesight.

Arts and Letters Daily works for several reasons. One is that it triumphantly confirms its founder's original hypothesis - that there is a cornucopia of wonderful writing out there on the web and all that was needed was a mechanism for finding it and bringing it to the attention of people who are too busy to do the kind of intensive browsing serious web-reading requires. But its success is mainly due to the way it met the needs of the large group of internet users who are turned off by the frenetic 'hot picks' and 'cool links' of the brain-dead surfing community.

Dutton's target audience is what Alabama Governor George Wallace used to call 'pointy- headed intellectuals' - subscribers to the New York Review of Books, readers of newspapers such as The Observer and online magazines such as Salon.

They are people who will follow any link that points to the writing of Frank Kermode, Robert Hughes, Bill Joy or Daniel Dennett. People like you and me, in fact.

Twelve months ago, Dutton sold Arts and Letters Daily to the owners of Lingua Franca, but seems to have retained editorial control over it. The change of ownership has given him the space to return to what one suspects was his original subver sive notion - Cybereditions, an online book publisher focusing on high-quality non-fiction and scholarly writing rendered uneconomic by the philistinic book-keeping of the print publishing business.

Cybereditions makes out-of-print books available in new editions as downloadable e-books, and as paperbacks produced by print-on-demand technology. And the economies of online delivery mean that Dutton can offer substantial royalties - up to 40 per cent - to authors.

In a world where thousands of worthwhile books become unavailable every year after their print runs are exhausted, Cybereditions is a truly great idea. It recognises that books need never again go 'out of print', even if the global market for them is only a few thousand copies.

It also offers the prospect of changing the whole concept of an 'edition'. 'An electronic book can be continually revised,' Dutton told a Salon interviewer recently, 'more like a computer program than a printed book. You can have an initial edition, then make some corrections - that's edition 1.01. Some more and you have edition 1.02 right up to a really new edition, and that's version 2.0.'

Blindingly obvious - now.

webTitle: Railtrack to be stripped of key powers

fields.headline: Railtrack to be stripped of key powers
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack is to be stripped of its spending powers on all new projects in a de facto takeover of all but its most menial duties by the Government and the Strategic Rail Authority.
fields.body:
Railtrack is to be stripped of its spending powers on all new projects in a de facto takeover of all but its most menial duties by the Government and the Strategic Rail Authority.

In a clear indictment of rail privatisation, the state will effectively take control of all future investments in the stricken rail network.

Railtrack will merely be in charge of day-to-day maintenance and operations, which will also have to improve under stricter monitoring of safety and efficiency.

'Railtrack has no choice. It is being sidelined,' said a source close to discussions on the company's future.

The Government has finally lost patience with the company's woeful performance in improving the track, signals and stations handed over to it from British Rail in 1999. It has since made record profits and handed out shareholder dividends and staff bonuses.

The prolonged crisis on the network in the wake of the Hatfield crash in October, caused by a broken rail that Railtrack should have had fixed, has sealed its fate.

As passengers face travel misery over Christmas, with no sign of the service returning to normal until the spring, the Government has acted to strip Railtrack completely of its strategic role.

It will stop short of renationalisation and will not take a stake in the company.

But from next spring Railtrack will have no say over how the proposed £60 billion of public and private sector investment earmarked by the Government for rail over the next 10 years is spent.

Railtrack will be expected to implement the 'national rail recovery plan' for repairing cracked tracks and getting services back to normal. And it will still be in charge of the existing network and its most important project, the £5.8bn modernisation of the West Coast Main Line.

But in future all new projects to modernise and expand the railway infrastructure will be undertaken by the state-sanctioned Strategic Rail Authority, in conjunction with rail regulator Tom Winsor and Ministers.

The SRA will decide what modernisation and expansion projects are important and will let contracts to private sector partners, which are expected to invest around half of the £60bn.

The finished infrastructure will be delivered into Railtrack's balance sheet, and it will oversee the operation and maintenance.

Later this week the SRA is expected to announce that East Coast operator GNER has fought off challenger Virgin to win a renewal of its franchise.

fields.headline: Upping the revolution
fields.standfirst:
Microsoft may well be predicting problems for the personal computer but, as Simon Moores explains, the PC has a whole new future - in The Grid

More net news
fields.trailText: Late last summer, the popularity of a music-sharing phenomenon called Napster sent cold shivers down the collective spines of music publishers everywhere. If you had read the story of Napster's battle with 'Big Music', you may have thought it had more to do with the future of publishing and the protection of intellectual property, than with the next step in the evolution of the internet.
fields.body:
Late last summer, the popularity of a music-sharing phenomenon called Napster sent cold shivers down the collective spines of music publishers everywhere. If you had read the story of Napster's battle with 'Big Music', you may have thought it had more to do with the future of publishing and the protection of intellectual property, than with the next step in the evolution of the internet.

A 'civilisation-altering' event for the digital-media industry but still a primitive example of an emerging technology, Napster's shadow extends far beyond questions of copyright and the pirating of popular music. A new Pandora's box has been opened, a paradigm shift in technology, which suggests that a globally distributed framework of personal computers, now called the Grid, can compete with or even replace the powerful network of centralised servers that we recognise as the world wide web.

Grid computing, more usually described as 'peer to peer' (P2P) or distributed computing, may change the way in which we interact with the growing mountain of information that surrounds us. It will influence the way software is designed, and its touch is already being felt through the arrival of products such as Sony's PlayStation 2 and the vision behind Microsoft's 'Dot Net' strategy.

Indeed this vision may pull the PC back from the brink of redundancy. On Thursday Microsoft issued its first prof its warning in 10 years. Analysts inferred an irreversible decline in the PC software market and Microsoft shares lost a third of their value.

But P2P offers the technology to use the spare capacity of home computers.

In fundamental terms, the Grid represents a devolution of the internet's own form of central government, a redistribution of power among millions of connected devices, creating what is effectively a global supercomputer from the network itself.

In a flash of genius, the scientific research institute Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence (Seti) enlisted the help of 2 million PC users to analyse daily radio spectrum searches, having found the cost of using supercomputers prohibitively expensive. Interested PC owners downloaded Seti's analysis software from the internet and installed it as a screen saver. When the user wasn't working on the PC, the Seti@home program accepted a proportion of the organisation's workload from the internet and processed the data, passing results back to Seti's main system in California. In practice, Seti created a huge supercomputer by using its volunteers' idle processor time.

Napster, which claims 25 million users, has a similar service, Aimster, which uses AOL to access a network of 120 million people. The files they share are most commonly compressed (MP3) music, exchanged on a 'person to person' basis rather than through access to a central internet server; although the existence of a centralised directory on a Napster server was the excuse the music industry needed to take Napster to court. Like Seti@home, this is a P2P network.

With millions of people using the internet every day, and the wider availability of high-bandwidth connections, many types of device can conceivably work together as a single distributed system. The whole becomes greater than the sum of its parts, much like bees in a hive, capable of contributing all or part of their resources to a much greater purpose.

This prompted Intel chief technology officer Pat Gelsinger to comment: 'Peer-to-peer computing could be as important to the internet's future as the web browser was to its past.' Indeed, the company, according to a report in Red Herring magazine, claims to have saved $500m 'by leveraging the power of its own worldwide network of personal computers'.

Intel views the PC-centric nature of the Grid as an opportunity for the company to maintain its dominance. Other server manufacturers, whose businesses are based on very large and powerful servers, may not be so happy at the idea of a network of millions of PCs replacing larger computers.

The appeal of P2P networking is that as the Grid expands, the number of connections between users grows exponentially, creating a vast and almost brain-like shared network.

But P2P, which really involves two young technologies, the sharing of digital content and the sharing of computers, has still to reach the point where it can leap from being an untidy commercial threat to old-econ omy interests to a sound economic proposition for a networked society.

As an investment prospect, P2P offers two emergent market opportunities: resource allocation, where companies may rent network bandwidth or processor time on the public's PCs, and shared media, digital audio and multimedia distribution. But the challenges are great, the returns uncertain and overall investment in the sector remains modest - reportedly below $100m. Grid computing requires that special software and intelligent agents be installed on participating devices, allowing it to act as both client and server, and making it capable of initiating and responding to search requests that can swiftly ripple through all other shared devices linked to it.

Internet search engines can be notoriously ambivalent when it comes to refined data searches: in most cases, the information retrieved is not real-time and only as good as the last data cache on the web search engine. Activity from start-up companies is now being focused on creating software that can work in and manage transactions on the scale of a P2P network of thousands, if not millions, of PCs. This relies on these PCs being connected to the Grid, sharing their local processors and their 'public' files and directories. As an example, each PC in one school could be connected to the PCs in every school in the country, creating an enormously powerful educational supercomputer in the process. In this way, any information on the network becomes a real-time shared resource.

Before the Grid can make even a modest assault on the infrastructure of the Internet, two distinct problems have to be overcome: privacy and bandwidth. With cybercrime now a rampant problem, the internet's more centralised model does at least offer some protection from a direct assault on a PC. However, unless security can be guaranteed, people will be reluctant to adopt an 'open-house' approach to the future of personal computing.

With the internet becoming the delivery mechanism for every conceivable form of digital media and entertainment content, bandwidth is constantly playing catch-up with demand. Grid computing over a P2P network of tens of thousands, if not millions of computing devices, all passing data between themselves will demand huge amounts of reliable bandwidth.

Just as we were becoming comfortable with one view of technology and the evolution of the internet, another, larger wave of more radical change may be about to wash over society. The Grid's commercial potential still remains unclear and a host of issues need resolving.

A universal micro-payment system is also required, so that should a large research company wish to hire the number-crunching power of 10,000 volunteer PCs overnight, a route for the owner to receive a tiny transactional amount in return becomes available.

As the network becomes the computer, the principles of the Grid, as expressed by one analyst, Alan Zeichick, may point to a radically different future: 'Millions of participants, no central servers, no search engines, no registration, no index, no database, no identification - and nobody for the lawyers or governments to sue or negotiate with.'

webTitle: Heather Connon: Not totally barking to bet on the dogs

fields.headline: Not totally barking to bet on the dogs
fields.trailText: 'Value' shares, which generally have a higher yield than growth stocks, have come sharply back into favour as the gloss has worn off the technology sector.
fields.body:
Four months ago, we suggested that investors take a bit of a gamble on the dogs of the Footsie. We advised buying shares in the 10 companies in the FTSE 100 index with the highest yield (dividends as a percentage of the share price) at that time.

This has paid off handsomely. Some of the shares have done spectacularly: Abbey National and Alliance & Leicester have risen by 56 and 40 per cent respectively. Others have done badly: United Utilities and Powergen have both fallen by more than 2 per cent. But overall the average gain has been 19 per cent - not bad for four months, and comfortably ahead of the FTSE 100, which has barely moved over the same period.

Of course, the past four months have hardly been typical. 'Value' shares, which generally have a higher yield than growth stocks, have come sharply back into favour as the gloss has worn off the technology sector. Abbey has attracted a bid, which has also pushed up the price of Alliance & Leicester.

But there is never a typical time in the stock market: the City is constantly seizing on new themes and ideas. The FTSE 100 is always likely to see some bid activity. And the evidence suggests it was not a one-off. The gamble was prompted by research from Tony Jackson, equity strategist at Charterhouse. He calculated that anyone buying the 10 highest-yielding stocks at the beginning of 1998 or 1999 and selling them at the end of the year would have done well. In 1998, for example, the portfolio would have grown by 50 per cent, while the FTSE 100 grew by 15 per cent.

The theory originated in the US, with the dogs of the Dow which, until very recently, had consistently done well. Since 1995, the Dow's dogs stayed in the doghouse as technology stocks, which often have no yield at all, captured investors' imagination.

So will it hold true in 2001? Should investors have a punt on the dogs of the FTSE 100? The 10 highest yielding companies in the index at the moment are Bass, British American Tobacco, Lattice Group (spun off from BG), Powergen, Scottish Power, United Utilities, Invensys, Marks & Spencer, Royal & Sun Alliance and Scottish & Southern Energy. (ICI, which yields 6.2 per cent based on its historic dividend, has already said the dividend will halve in 2001.)

It is not a portfolio many investors would choose. Five of the 10 are utilities, and the City is not sure Invensys and M&S will recover from their recent poor performance. BAT is facing a tide of litigation in the US.

But the dogs of the Footsie is not based on rational analysis. It is a gamble - a bet that some will do well enough to make up for the others. The statistics suggest it is worth having a punt - but only if you have the stomach for risk. As the health warning says, past performance is not necessarily a guide to the future.

fields.headline: White ally scorned by Mugabe
fields.standfirst:
Nicholas van Hoogstraten backed land seizures to save his own estates. He failed, reports Andrew Meldrum

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Clouds of tear gas blanketed central Harare yesterday as police tried to disperse crowds of angry shoppers protesting against the accidental killing of a woman.
fields.body:
Clouds of tear gas blanketed central Harare yesterday as police tried to disperse crowds of angry shoppers protesting against the accidental killing of a woman.

The seething unrest and fury in the Zimbabwean capital over heavy-handed policing is matched by destructive havoc in rural areas, where nine people have died in an anthrax outbreak as a result of the massive disruptions caused by President Robert Mugabe's land seizures.

The widespread dissatisfaction is a response to an extraordinary congress of the ruling Zanu-PF party last week, which reaffirmed its support for Mugabe.

'We have rioting and tear gas in the streets today, and that is an indication of what is to come as a result of this congress,' said Zimbabwean political scientist John Makumbe yesterday. 'Mugabe offered fear and intimidation as his policies. His speech was pure venom, encouraging hatred and racism, and a call for violence.'

The President's single-minded pursuit of seizures of white-owned land will speed up the disintegration of the national economy and hasten the demise of his party, said Makumbe.

Not even Mugabe's most sycophantic white supporter, the British property tycoon Nicholas van Hoogstraten, has escaped the anti-white fury. One of Zimbabwe's largest landowners, van Hoogstraten thought he would be feted as a guest of honour at the convention. Ever eager for publicity, he negotiated with the BBC to send a crew to film him arm-in-arm with Mugabe, waving to the cheering crowds.

Instead he skulked away from Harare last week with his dreams of acclaim in tatters and his property empire overrun by thousands of Mugabe's violent war veterans. He was not even a delegate to the congress, let alone a guest of honour, according to party officials.

Mugabe launched his most bitter attack yet on white landowners, calling them 'white devils'. He specifically denounced British and other foreigners among them, vowing to take all they own.

'Our party must continue to strike fear in the heart of the white man. They must tremble,' Mugabe told an 8,000-strong audience last Thursday. 'They think because they are white they have a divine right to our resources. Not here. The white man is not indigenous to Africa. Africa is for Africans.'

The last person he wanted to be seen with was van Hoogstraten, one of Britain's wealthiest men, whose land in Zimbabwe is worth £32m following his purchase of the Lonrho holdings here. Van Hoogstraten, who is building himself a mansion in Sussex, apparently reckoned that by publicly praising Mugabe his vast estates would be untouched while the farms of other whites were seized. As further insurance, he donated tens of thousands of pounds to Zanu-PF.

'I'm in bed with his party,' he boasted a few months ago. 'Comrade Mugabe has kept the country peaceful and relatively wealthy for 20 years. I entirely agree with what Mugabe has said and done.'

He denounced farmers who protested against the land seizures as 'white trash'.

That was before 'Comrade Mugabe' seized three of van Hoogstraten's prime properties and sent supporters on to his fourth, and largest, estate. Van Hoogstraten then found that his much-vaunted connections came to nothing. Far from basking in the limelight at the Zanu-PF congress, he was bitterly surveying his losses in Zimbabwe last week. After his outspoken remarks on Zimbabwe, van Hoog-straten found he had few friends in Zimbabwe to turn to for support or consolation.

'We steer clear of him,' said an official of the Commercial Farmers Union (CFU). 'He made it clear he didn't care what happened to other farmers, so why should we care what happens to his properties? He's not very pleasant.'

The largest of van Hoogstraten's farms, Central Estates, encompasses 326,000 acres in the Mvuma area of Midlands province. It has not been designated for seizure, but suffered severe damage as it was invaded by an estimated 5,000 of Mugabe's supporters. They have put up homes, ploughed new fields and thoroughly disrupted the work of the vast ranch, say neighbouring farmers. Central Estate has also seen bitter fighting between peasants, who resettled themselves there, and war veterans, who claim they control the land.

Another of van Hoog-straten's properties, Eastdale Estate, has been taken over by about 140 families in the past few weeks. Three other large farms have been officially designated for seizure. Van Hoogstraten bought the Zimbabwean farms from Lonrho. It appears he tried to mimic the legendary Lonrho chief 'Tiny' Rowland by trying to befriend Mugabe.

In a bid to regain control of his properties, van Hoog-straten offered Mugabe's government 12,000 acres for re-settlement in return for removal of squatters on the rest of his land. Cephas Msipa, governor of the Midlands province, confirmed that 'Nick' had made an offer, but so far the government has made no decision.

More than 2,000 farms have been listed for seizure and a further 1,700 are already overrun by illegal squatters. Many of the occupiers are armed and have assaulted and threatened the white owners. Police have taken no action despite Supreme Court orders for them to enforce the law. Mugabe has told the police to ignore the court rulings.

Last week Henry Elsworth, 70, a prominent farmer whom Mugabe had directly threatened, was ambushed and shot dead on his farm in the Redcliff area of Midlands province. Elsworth, who was on crutches, died trying to protect his 20-year-old son from the attackers' gunfire. The son, Ian, survived with nine bullet wounds and identified his attackers as war veterans.

'The entire farming community is in mourning over that killing,' said Robert Vaughn-Evans. 'It was a very sinister, premeditated murder. It was a chilling message to all other farmers.'

War veterans' leader Chenjerai 'Hitler' Hunzvi pressed home their message at the opening of the congress. 'We are now fighting for our land and whosoever is killed, it's tough luck,' said Hunzvi. 'In fact it is now going to be very hard for commercial farmers.

'They may not even reap or harvest the crops they have planted. We have finished negotiating with them. What is now left is confrontation.'

That confrontation - historic and of tragic proportions - now looms, so it is hardly surprising that van Hoogstraten's self-serving friendship with Mugabe has collapsed.

webTitle: Phil Hogan: Power to the party

fields.headline: Power to the party
fields.trailText: I've been in the dark all day as a result of the electricity people deciding to rewire Hertfordshire as a Christmas surprise.
fields.body:
I've been so in the dark all day as a result of the electricity people deciding to rewire Hertfordshire as a Christmas surprise that I hardly know what time it is until I am suddenly confronted by four children rushing in from school with urgent Nintendo-based requirements and a wife wondering aloud why it has not occurred to me to ring Eastern Energy and inquire in a cross voice what the chances are of having our life returned to the early 21st century in the near future if it's not too much trouble. I'm right on the case, I say. I quickly dial the number by the glow from her cheeks.

Ah yes, says the young man at the other end, they're out working on it now. No doubt they are, I say, but when will they finish working on it? He couldn't say at present - perhaps if I ring back in an hour when he's had the chance to leg it and leave me in the capable hands of a recorded message?

I've got a better idea. Why doesn't he call the engineers on the other phone and then just tell me?

There follows a short silence while he dreams up some preposterously feeble reason why this would not be possible.

Ah! he says, just remembering, they're not allowed to have their phones switched on. It's too, er hazardous.

I resist the urge to issue a resounding stage laugh as demanded by the conventions of the same Venezuelan soap opera from which this excuse was dredged, but sharply draw his attention instead to the triple irony of his office being described in the Yellow Pages as an 'emergency information helpline' before slamming the phone down with some satisfaction, though admittedly not the kind of satisfaction that accrues from having done anything remotely constructive.

'What's the news?' shouts my wife.

'Don't worry, everything's under control,' I coo, which is the best I can do under the circumstances - the circumstances being that, actually, I'm supposed to be going to a Christmas party with my friend Neil. 'They say that if we ring back in about an hour'

'Is this party absolutely critical?' she says suddenly reading my mind.

'Of course,' I say. 'Frank Skinner might be there.'

So off I tramp down to the station, having my first shower of the day courtesy of the torrential rain, and two hours later I am in a pub in South Kensington with Neil discussing his latest expensive haircut (not quite tapered enough, he says), his dodgy football knee (sign of ageing), his unusual decision to bring spare shoes (not fully explained) and his alarm at the number of people who keep telling him he looks like Simon Callow.

We go to the party, which is a bright, glittery affair, with blue drinks and sausages on sticks and a long white bar and an ice-sculpted drinks dispenser that allows you to get vodka down your front without even using a glass. Plus, there's a decent spattering of well known people to pester from the world of comedy and I am soon trying out my considerable slurring talents on David Baddiel, who responds to all the salient points of my argument without once looking over my shoulder to see if there's anyone less bulging-eyed and swaying that he might understandably need to speak to very urgently.

Spurred by my success, Neil goes sprinting over to fulfil a longstanding personal ambition to ask Harry Hill how he would have his hair if he had any to start with. He returns only partly in triumph, having met someone on the way back who thinks he looks like Simon Callow. Still we have a fine time and at some point I ring my wife to explain why it might be better if I didn't come home tonight, after which everything goes dark again until Neil's wife Delyth comes down at five in the morning to point out that there's no need to lie half naked snoring like a buffalo draped over their sofa in the freezing cold when there's a perfectly good spare room upstairs.

I wake some days later to a nice cup of tea, a toothbrush still in the box and, amazingly, some unused Calvin Kleins in my size. There's even a pair of crutches that Delyth brought back as a souvenir from a skiing holiday. Excellent. I wonder if they've got any hot water

I resist the urge to issue a resounding stage laugh as demanded by the conventions of the same Venezuelan soap opera from which this excuse was dredged, but sharply draw his attention instead to the triple irony of his office being described in the Yellow Pages as an 'emergency information helpline' before slamming the phone down with some satisfaction, though admittedly not the kind of satisfaction that accrues from having done anything remotely constructive. 'What's the news?' shouts my wife. 'Don't worry, everything's under control,' I coo, which is the best I can do under the circumstances - the circumstances being that, actually, I'm supposed to be going to a Christmas party with my friend Neil. 'They say that if we ring back in about an hour' 'Is this party absolutely critical?' she says suddenly reading my mind. 'Of course,' I say. 'Frank Skinner might be there.' So off I tramp down to the station, having my first shower of the day courtesy of the torrential rain, and two hours later I am in a pub in South Kensington with Neil discussing his latest expensive haircut (not quite tapered enough, he says), his dodgy football knee (sign of ageing), his unusual decision to bring spare shoes (not fully explained) and his alarm at the number of people who keep telling him he looks like Simon Callow. We go to the party, which is a bright, glittery affair, with blue drinks and sausages on sticks and a long white bar and an ice-sculpted drinks dispenser that allows you to get vodka down your front without even using a glass. Plus, there's a decent spattering of well known people to pester from the world of comedy and I am soon trying out my considerable slurring talents on David Baddiel, who responds to all the salient points of my argument without once looking over my shoulder to see if there's anyone less bulging-eyed and swaying that he might understandably need to speak to very urgently. Spurred by my success, Neil goes sprinting over to fulfil a longstanding personal ambition to ask Harry Hill how he would have his hair if he had any to start with. He returns only partly in triumph, having met someone on the way back who thinks he looks like Simon Callow. Still we have a fine time and at some point I ring my wife to explain why it might be better if I didn't come home tonight, after which everything goes dark again until Neil's wife Delyth comes down at five in the morning to point out that there's no need to lie half naked snoring like a buffalo draped over their sofa in the freezing cold when there's a perfectly good spare room upstairs. I wake some days later to a nice cup of tea, a toothbrush still in the box and, amazingly, some unused Calvin Kleins in my size. There's even a pair of crutches that Delyth brought back as a souvenir from a skiing holiday. Excellent. I wonder if they've got any hot water

fields.headline: Race relations
fields.trailText: I was in a mixed-race relationship once, at least I think I was. We were so young, and together so briefly, I'm not sure whether it would qualify as a relationship.
fields.body:
I was in a mixed-race relationship once, at least I think I was. We were so young, and together so briefly, I'm not sure whether it would qualify as a relationship, but then people never seem to refer to 'mixed-race flings' or 'mixed-race one-night stands'. Once you're with a 'person of colour', it seems that the experience automatically becomes as cultural-political as much as it is emotional-sexual - it isn't 'allowed' to be transitory or meaningless, even when it is.

This despite the fact that my Jamaican-Irish boyfriend was so light-skinned that it was only next to freakishly pale me that he looked black at all. On the street, he could have passed for Italian. Next to me, he was Malcolm X. Sometimes, just for fun, we would lie in bed, holding hands, with our arms aloft, and pretend to be a racial-harmony poster, or a scene out of Hair .

It would probably make a better story if I could claim that we split because of prejudice and outside pressure - that I was vilified, spat at in the street, and should actually be given some kind of special 'nice white person' award for standing by my man as long as I did. Truth is, we simply stopped ringing each other, and drifted apart, just like every other mismatched couple since time began. Indeed, were it not for the fact of his colour, I rather doubt that I would remember him quite so vividly. Which probably makes me guilty of exoticism - the gushy, air-kissing, lefty-liberal face of racism.

Exoticism is a posh word for racism lite - the kind of sickening, over-compensatory 'honky' BS Black Grape lampooned so brilliantly in the single 'Reverend Black Grape', with its call out to 'all you nice black people!' Racism proper is a different matter. While Britain is undoubtedly one of the more tolerant societies, something has to explain why black men still can't drive anything more salubrious than a three-wheeled pizza van without being harassed by the police. Or why, recently, a house-hunting white couple knocked on my door, rather too pointedly enquiring about the 'mix' of the street, and whether some of the neighbours were prone to playing 'loud music'. 'Only me,' I said sweetly, and shut the door with a bang. Don't get me wrong. It's not that I'm prejudiced against stupid white people - I just wouldn't want to live next door to one.

Boris Becker and his wife Barbara doubtless know all there is to know about racism, both of the 'lite' and 'proper' varieties. They split recently after seven years together, but the fact that Boris was white, Barbara was black and they were both German put undue strain on their marriage from the start. Sometimes you wonder at the real usefulness of celebrity multiracial couples. With, say, David Bowie and Iman, the things they have in common - fame, beauty, wealth - seem far more evident than any racial difference. The Beckers seemed different, simply because they were German. It is said that throughout their relationship, sacks of hate mail and death threats from neo-Nazi extremists arrived daily for them and their small children. And while they dealt with this, they were also dealing with their status as Europe's most celebrated multiracial sports-based glamour couple. They had become, if you like, the exoticist's Posh and Becks.

As the saga unfolded, Becker seemed to blossom from being a rather unattractive, robotic tennis player to being a man of substance. Often he would proclaim simply that he was madly in love, though this was generally overlooked in favour of his pronouncements on his fears for the safety of his family: 'I have a black wife, and black children, and I'm not just talking about it - I live this problem every day.' Meanwhile, Barbara Becker was rarely asked for her opinion. It is meant as no discredit to the Beckers that this seems to be the general way with multiracial couples, famous and non-famous. However tight, loving and equal a couple might be, to society at large it is ordinarily the white rather than black half who is perceived to be making 'the stand'.

Since the split, it is rumoured that Becker has a new love, and that this woman is also black. Which information makes a mockery of how the reports on the separation have honed in on the difficulties the Beckers faced as a mixed-race couple in modern Germany. While it can't help to have death threats pouring through your letterbox every day of your married life, it seems spurious, even slightly racist, to suggest that after seven years together, and with a black girlfriend waiting in the wings, Boris Becker split with his wife because of racial prejudice. It almost suggests that, as multiracial icons, the Beckers are simply not 'allowed' to fall out of love like 'normal' couples - there has to be some deeper sociopolitical meaning behind it. Moreover, that, for all the enlightened world's exoticist cooing and air kissing, couples such as the Beckers are never fully accepted as 'normal' after all.

 barbara.ellen@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Can I claim over 'unfair' sacking?
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: I want to claim constructive dismissal - but since I was with my last employer for less than a year, there could be a problem. In a disciplinary hearing, the company accused me of being a bad teamworker, but produced no evidence. Eventually, I found documents in my personnel file which had not been shown to me because they 'involved third parties'. Is there anything I can do?
fields.body:
I want to claim constructive dismissal - but since I was with my last employer for less than a year, there could be a problem. In a disciplinary hearing, the company accused me of being a bad teamworker, but produced no evidence. Eventually, I found documents in my personnel file which had not been shown to me because they 'involved third parties'. Is there anything I can do?

Since you were employed for less than a year, you do not have the right to claim for constructive dismissal. You could theoretically claim for breach of contract, alleging that you had a right to proper disciplinary procedures, and, if these are referred to in your contract, your case would be stronger. However, if you were allowed to work out your notice, it would not be worth your while bringing a case because the courts say that the compensation owed is your notice pay.

Some workers argue that they've run up costs of £20-£30 on bus fares and photocopying in an effort to get another job. These can be attached to a breach of contract settlement, but it is unlikely that they would be given alone. And the heartache of a case would far outweigh that sum.

Legal advice from the Acton Law Shop .

fields.headline: Putting your holiday on ice
fields.standfirst:
It's not just nurses and fire crews who give up the day that was once sacred, says Alexander Garret. Pubs, mobile phone firms and even a bank now require staff on Christmas Day

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: As you tuck into your Christmas dinner, having raised a glass of bubbly and listened to the Queen's speech, spare a thought for the hundreds of thousands of people who will still be toiling away.
fields.body:
As you tuck into your Christmas dinner, having raised a glass of bubbly and listened to the Queen's speech, spare a thought for the hundreds of thousands of people who will still be toiling away.

Nobody knows quite how many people work on Christmas Day, but all the signs are that the number is growing, and that what was once the most special day of the year is in danger of becoming just a quiet day in the office.

There have always been some who had to sacrifice pulling the crackers for clocking on: nurses and other hospital workers, police, fire-crews, and those maintaining other essential services such as water, gas and electricity.

But other groups are increasingly being added to their numbers: helpline operators, computer support staff, security guards, catering workers, even shop assistants. Closing simply isn't an option for many businesses, because non-stop all-hours year-round service is what the customers have been promised.

Some hackles have already been raised by the moves to turn 25 December into just another day. Last January, the late Cardinal Hume, who led the Catholic church in England and Wales, urged a revolt: 'It is quite wrong that people should have to work over Christmas simply because the financial arrangements of the world require it. We should say "no, we aren't going to do it".'

The shopworkers' union Usdaw has now launched its own 'Protect Christmas Day' campaign. The union's political officer, Ruth Stoney, says that while once it was only small corner shops and off-licences that opened on 25 December, there has been an increasing trend by national retailers and convenience stores to join in.

Sainsbury's is one culprit, although the supermarket chain insists it is opening only two 'local' stores on petrol forecourts this year. Others named by Stoney include Budgens and Woolworths, which is opening a store in North Wales. 'The danger is that once a few big ones open, the others will follow because they feel they need to compete,' she says.

She points out that shopworkers work under enormous stress in the weeks up to Christmas, and then start all over again with sales beginning on Boxing Day.

Even convenience stores can employ up to 30 people, and it can be difficult for staff to refuse if they are asked to come in, she points out. Pubs which may once have opened just to give customers a quick drink are now laying on full-scale Christmas catering.

The Rushcutters, in Thorpe St. Andrew on the edge of Norwich, has been heavily promoting Christmas lunch at £45 a head. The pub - one of hundreds that will be serving up turkey and sprouts on the day - is part of the Chef & Brewer group, owned by Scottish & Newcastle Breweries.

The brewer says around 42,000 managers and staff at its pubs and restaurants will be working at Christmas. 'Wherever possible, we endeavour to accommodate the personal needs of our staff, but we find that many of them enjoy covering the Christmas shifts: the atmosphere in the pubs is festive and fun,' a spokesman said. Their reward is double pay; but that may be scant consolation for those who would rather have spent the the day enjoying their own Christmas lunch than preparing or serving somebody else's.

Those working in catering may regard working unsociable hours as normal, but the sanctity of Christmas is also being eroded in newer industries, where service is regarded as paramount. At First Direct, the 24-hour online bank, 33 people will staff the lines at its call centre during Christmas Day. Company spokeswoman Sarah Ring stresses that all have volunteered, and says that most calls will be from customers ringing to wish the staff a happy Christmas. 'In between answering calls, the reps play board games, eat chocolate and generally have a fun and festive day together.'

At Vodafone - which ran ads two years ago discouraging customers from calling on Christmas Day - there are likely to be more than 500 people staffing helplines and other services this year. With the company likely to have sold around a million phones in the run-up to Christmas, many of which may be opened for the first time on Christmas Day, Vodafone considers it essential to have somebody available to help those who have problems.

Spokeswoman Libby Pritchard says: 'It is a key time for us. Imagine the disappointment of not being able to use your new phone straight away, because there is nobody there to help.' She points out that for many people, a mobile phone is increasingly regarded as a lifeline.

Nowhere does the burden of Christmas Day working fall more heavily than in the National Health Service: hospitals do their best to send non-urgent cases home, but they have to stay open come what may. This means hundreds of thousands of nurses, doctors and other staff having to spend Christmas away from their families.

Josie Irwin, senior employment relations adviser at the Royal College of Nursing, says the country's 315,000 NHS nurses can expect to be paid 60 per cent extra, plus a paid day off in lieu if they have to work on 25 December. For a staff nurse on £17,000, the extra money is around £40.

It is impossible to say yet how many will be called in. 'A lot of trusts will already have said that, with 20,000 unfilled vacancies nationwide, we're sorry but we can't give you time off,' Irwin explains. 'They will all have staffing plans, but if there is a flu virus, thousands more will be called in to deal with the emergency.'

webTitle: How to be popular with your colleagues

fields.headline: How to be popular with your colleagues
fields.trailText: 1 Make sure you say hello, smile and know the names of everyone in your department or whose help you will need. You cannot have a wonderful relationship with someone unless you know their name.
fields.body:
1 Make sure you say hello, smile and know the names of everyone in your department or whose help you will need. You cannot have a wonderful relationship with someone unless you know their name.

2 Be cheerful. 'Nobody likes a whinger,' says Nina, a businesswoman with workplace friendships going back three decades. 'You want someone who can come into a room and make you laugh.'

3 Do favours - 'small ones, not huge ones - because that spooks people out', says Dr Sandi Mann, author of Psychology goes to Work. If you cover up for Fred's lateness or Sonia's blunder, they are likely to feel grateful to you. While an ambitious person will take advantage of a colleague's weakness - by highlighting their errors to bosses, for instance - a more decent type will act as a protector.

4 Do your own job well. Even if you are goodness itself, people will resent you if they have to sort out your mess, finish off your photocopying and regularly cover for you when you are off sick. Being reliable and consistent will not make you beloved overnight, but you will develop a reputation for decency and reliability over the years.

5 Recognise that a bit of self-deprecation goes a long way, especially if it is funny. The former Conservative Chancellor Kenneth Clarke, one of the most popular politicians of recent years, was famous for his undapper appearance, particularly his brown suede shoes. 'It does no harm at all to have an image,' says political lobbyist Peter. 'When Bill always comes in a woolly hat, it gives an impression to colleagues of familiarity and stability.'

6 Remember that you are never too old to have role models. Look at your most popular colleagues and try to work out what makes them widely liked. You don't constantly have to be giving money to the poor. Popularity can go with toughness, for instance, if that person still treats others with respect, asks their opinions and gives them straight answers.

7 Accentuate your shared interests, advises Sandi Mann. 'We tend to like people who are similar to ourselves,' she says. Ambitious people - who want to cultivate popularity to get promotion - often go this route. Many of them probably may hate golf and opera, but understand that they need to fake enthusiasms about these things if they want to get on in the bank. But Mann warns: 'Impression and emotion management is a very stressful area.'

webTitle: Over 50 - but not over the hill

fields.headline: Over 50 - but not over the hill
fields.standfirst:
Companies should do more to keep experienced older staff, says Richard Scase

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It is well known that Britain has an ageing population. Like most other countries in Europe, it will experience an increase in life expectancy over the next decade, creating an older, dependent population. This will have a huge direct as well as indirect impact on the economy, a demographic time bomb that will affect both labour and consumer markets.
fields.body:
It is well known that Britain has an ageing population. Like most other countries in Europe, it will experience an increase in life expectancy over the next decade, creating an older, dependent population. This will have a huge direct as well as indirect impact on the economy, a demographic time bomb that will affect both labour and consumer markets.

As part of this trend, the fiftysomething age group is expanding. Baby boomers have reached maturity. From 20 per cent of the population today, they will grow to 25 per cent over the next few years. Yet fewer of them are in full-time employment. The proportion for men has fallen from 93 per cent in the Seventies to 75 per cent today, while for women it has remained constant at about 60 per cent.

Consider that this is happening in an economy where skills shortages are growing. The number of young people entering the labour market is declining sharply, partly the result of falling birth rates in the Seventies and Eighties. A key issue, then, is whether the economy can continue to accept such a low participation rate among 50-year-olds, which on the face of it suggests a huge underutilisation of talent and skills.

The first question to ask is: are the disappearing fifties being pushed out of employment or pulled out by the attractions of life after work?

The answer seems to be both. Corporate restructuring continues to be a major 'push' factor. The application of information and communica tion technologies has allowed companies to automate their management processes, rendering obsolete the more rigid hierarchical structures of traditional bureaucracies. This does not mean the end of hierarchical controls - on the contrary. Information technologies allow even stricter monitoring of performance (even if we work from home). But it does not require tiers of managers. Middle managers in their fifties are usually first to be earmarked to go.

It is the same with corporate mergers and acquisitions, where the driving motive, particularly in financial services and manufacturing, is cost-cutting through reducing head count. So 50-year-olds are normally first to be offered redundancy.

Companies' justification for pushing out their older employees is that these people are in a better position to cope with unemployment. They are seen to have fewer family responsibilities and lower financial demands because mortgages and loans have been repaid.

What this assumption fails to recognise, however, is that this is a 'sandwiched' generation. A growing number of its members have greater and more complex financial burdens because of increasing life expectancy and the more turbulent nature of their personal life histories. The former obliges more 50- year-olds to be responsible for ageing parents. But the gender revolution means many women are no longer prepared to look after elderly relatives in 'granny flats'. Paid-for residential care is seen as a better option. At the same time, an increase in divorce means that a growing number of 50-year-old men are having to support children from their first marriage who are now at university plus those from a current relationship who may be still at school. As a result, they may have far greater financial burdens than younger colleagues.

But corporate 'push' also operates in a more informal sense. Ageism is rife in British industry - probably more so than in the US, Germany, Japan or Scandinavia. Some of this is built into corporate human resource policies. But it is also evident in more subtle ways. As companies restructure operational processes around teams and project management, the new cultures often reflect the interests of younger employees. Feeling marginalised in these peer groups, older colleagues feel themselves under pressure to quit - a not uncommon experience in high-tech and media industries.

But there are also 'pull' factors that encourage some 50-year-olds to quit their jobs. These are largely middle-class professionals who can afford to take voluntary early retirement - in strong contrast to those with insecure, low-paid and manual jobs who have to slog it out until they can draw their state pensions.

More privileged managers and professionals, benefiting from lump-sum payments and income from company pension schemes, are the time- and cash-rich spenders that marketers refer to. It remains to be seen whether these pension schemes will be as affordable for companies in the next 10 years as they have been in the past.

But while the good times last, the early-retired baby boomers seem to be having the time of their lives. As the hippie generation of 30 years ago, many never really wanted to have full-time jobs anyway. Needing income in a cold climate, they took up careers in the expanding public and private-sector professions of the late Sixties and Seventies. They do not see themselves as 'early retired' but rather as moving into 'life after work' - an opportunity to do all the things which intensive employment and family pressures have prevented them from doing over the previous 20 years.

These people have now established a lifestyle role model that government policy will find it difficult to shift. Despite demographic and economic trends that require people to continue working well into their sixties, a culture of early retirement has set in. Performance-related reward systems and project-management principles are re- inforcing this intensity of work, creating stress and a work-life imbalance. Early retirement for affluent 50-year-olds offers the ideal escape route.

Scandinavian countries have far higher employment-participation rates among people in their fifties and sixties. Is this because they have far more effective family-friendly employment policies for all sectors of their working populations? Making employment more enjoyable and less stressful would reduce the attractions of early retirement among professionals and the other fiftysomething experts whose skills are in demand.

To reduce mid-life executive burnout ought to be part of companies' social responsibility. It is only through their actions, backed up by effective, family-friendly legislation for all employees of whatever age, that the problem of talented 50-year-olds choosing to exit the labour market will be resolved.

Richard Scase is a professor at Kent University and co-author (with Jonathan Scales) of Fit and Fifty, commissioned by the Economic and Social Research Council for an all-party group of MPs.
fields.bodyText: It is well known that Britain has an ageing population. Like most other countries in Europe, it will experience an increase in life expectancy over the next decade, creating an older, dependent population. This will have a huge direct as well as indirect impact on the economy, a demographic time bomb that will affect both labour and consumer markets. As part of this trend, the fiftysomething age group is expanding. Baby boomers have reached maturity. From 20 per cent of the population today, they will grow to 25 per cent over the next few years. Yet fewer of them are in full-time employment. The proportion for men has fallen from 93 per cent in the Seventies to 75 per cent today, while for women it has remained constant at about 60 per cent. Consider that this is happening in an economy where skills shortages are growing. The number of young people entering the labour market is declining sharply, partly the result of falling birth rates in the Seventies and Eighties. A key issue, then, is whether the economy can continue to accept such a low participation rate among 50-year-olds, which on the face of it suggests a huge underutilisation of talent and skills.
